docs.text: Korean English 한 시간 후 in 1 hour / 1 hour later 두 시간 전 2 hours ago 몇 시간 후에 in a few hours 세 시간쯤 about 3 hours

docs.title: Minutes
docs.text:
Korean English 오 분 후 in 5 minutes 십 분 전 10 minutes ago 이십 분쯤 about 20 minutes 삼십 분 안에 within 30 minutes

Examples: - 십 분 후에 출발해요 (We leave in 10 minutes) - 한 시간 전에 도착했어요 (I arrived 1 hour ago) - 삼십 분 걸려요 (It takes 30 minutes) - 오 분만 기다리세요 (Wait just 5 minutes)

docs.title: Daily Schedule
docs.text:
• 아침 일곱 시에 일어나요 (I wake up at 7 in the morning)
  • 오전 아홉 시에 일해요 (I work at 9 AM)
  • 점심은 낮 열두 시 반에 먹어요 (I eat lunch at 12:30 PM)
  • 저녁 여섯 시에 퇴근해요 (I leave work at 6 PM)
  • 밤 열한 시에 자요 (I go to bed at 11 PM)

docs.title: Appointments and Meetings
docs.text:
• 내일 오후 두 시에 만나요 (Let's meet tomorrow at 2 PM)
  • 회의가 오전 열 시에 있어요 (The meeting is at 10 AM)
  • 비행기가 오후 세 시 사십 분에 출발해요 (The plane departs at 3:40 PM)
  • 영화가 여섯 시 오십 분에 시작해요 (The movie starts at 6:50)

docs.title: Duration and Waiting
docs.text:
• 버스가 십 분 후에 와요 (The bus comes in 10 minutes)
  • 한 시간 동안 기다렸어요 (I waited for 1 hour)
  • 삼십 분쯤 걸려요 (It takes about 30 minutes)
  • 오 분만 더 기다리세요 (Wait just 5 more minutes)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Write these times in Korean:

  1. 3:15
  2. 7:30 (using 반)
  3. 11:45
  4. 1:00 PM (include 오후)
  5. 9:10 AM (include 오전)
  6. 12:00 (noon - use special word)
  7. 6:55
  8. 10:05
  9. 4:20
  10. 8:30 PM (include 오후)
Show Answers 1. 세 시 십오 분 2. 일곱 시 반 3. 열한 시 사십오 분 4. 오후 한 시 5. 오전 아홉 시 십 분 6. 정오 7. 여섯 시 오십오 분 8. 열 시 오 분 9. 네 시 이십 분 10. 오후 여덟 시 반

docs.title: Additional Practice: Answer in Korean
docs.text:
Answer these questions in complete sentences:

  1. 지금 몇 시예요? (It's 2:30)
  2. 몇 시에 만나요? (Let's meet at 5 PM)
  3. 학교가 몇 시에 시작해요? (School starts at 9 AM)
  4. 몇 시에 자요? (I go to bed at 11 PM)
  5. 버스가 언제 와요? (The bus comes in 10 minutes)
  6. 얼마나 걸려요? (It takes 30 minutes)
  7. 영화가 몇 시에 끝나요? (The movie ends at 8:45)
  8. 점심을 몇 시에 먹어요? (I eat lunch at 12:30)
  9. 몇 시간 동안 공부했어요? (I studied for 3 hours)
  10. 지금 몇 시예요? (It's 7:15 AM - include 오전)
Show Answers 1. 지금 두 시 반이에요 2. 오후 다섯 시에 만나요 3. 학교가 오전 아홉 시에 시작해요 4. 밤 열한 시에 자요 5. 버스가 십 분 후에 와요 6. 삼십 분 걸려요 7. 영화가 여덟 시 사십오 분에 끝나요 8. 점심을 열두 시 반에 먹어요 9. 세 시간 동안 공부했어요 10. 지금 오전 일곱 시 십오 분이에요

docs.title: Basic Expressions
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Category Key Expressions Greetings 안녕하세요, 안녕히 가세요/계세요 Thanks 감사합니다, 고맙습니다 Apologies 죄송합니다, 미안합니다 Self-Introduction 저는...입니다 Questions 뭐, 어디, 언제, 왜, 어떻게, 누구 Common Phrases 괜찮아요, 잠시만요, 모르겠어요

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Basic expressions are the foundation of everyday Korean communication. This section covers essential phrases you'll use constantly in daily interactions, from greeting people to asking questions and introducing yourself.

docs.title: Greetings
docs.text: Learn how to greet people appropriately in different contexts, say goodbye properly, and express thanks and apologies at various formality levels.

docs.title: Self-Introduction
docs.text: Master the essential patterns for introducing yourself, including stating your name, age, occupation, and nationality in natural Korean.

docs.title: Asking Questions
docs.text: Understand the fundamental question words and patterns that allow you to gather information and participate in conversations effectively.

docs.title: Common Daily Phrases
docs.text: Build your repertoire of frequently-used expressions that help you navigate everyday situations, from asking for help to expressing understanding or confusion.

docs.title: Learning Strategy
docs.text:
1. Start with Greetings: These are used most frequently and help establish rapport
  2. Practice Self-Introduction: Being able to introduce yourself opens doors to conversations
  3. Master Question Patterns: Questions keep conversations flowing and help you learn more
  4. Build Common Phrases: These practical expressions solve real communication problems

docs.title: Context Matters
docs.text:
Korean expressions often have multiple forms depending on:

  • Formality level: Formal vs. informal situations
  • Relationship: Speaking to elders, peers, or younger people
  • Setting: Professional, social, or family contexts

Pay attention to when each form is appropriate as you progress through this section.

docs.title: Practice Tips
docs.text:
• Practice expressions in complete sentences, not isolation
  • Pay attention to natural intonation patterns
  • Learn the appropriate contexts for each expression
  • Start with formal forms when in doubt
  • Practice with different subjects and objects to build flexibility

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text: Work through each subsection in order, or jump to the area most relevant to your immediate needs. Each page includes practical exercises to reinforce your learning.

docs.title: Asking Questions
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Question Word Korean Usage What 뭐/무엇 Things, actions Where 어디 Locations When 언제 Time Why 왜 Reasons How 어떻게 Methods, manner Who 누구 People How much/many 얼마 Price, amount Which 어느 Choices

docs.title: Yes/No Questions
docs.text:
In Korean, yes/no questions are formed simply by adding a question mark and rising intonation. The sentence structure remains the same.

Statement: 학생입니다. (I'm a student.) Question: 학생입니까? (Are you a student?)

Formal endings: - -습니까/-ㅂ니까? (most formal) - -아요/-어요? (polite) - -니? -야? (informal)

Examples: - 한국 사람입니까? (Are you Korean? - formal) - 학생이에요? (Are you a student? - polite) - 밥 먹었어? (Did you eat? - casual)

docs.title: 뭐
docs.text:
Casual form of "what," most commonly used in conversation.

Basic patterns: - 이게 뭐예요? (What's this?) - 뭐 해요? (What are you doing?) - 뭐 먹고 싶어요? (What do you want to eat?)

docs.title: 무엇
docs.text:
Formal form of "what," used in writing and formal speech.

Examples: - 무엇을 찾으세요? (What are you looking for?) - 무엇이 필요합니까? (What do you need?)

docs.title: Common "What" Questions
docs.text:
Korean English 이름이 뭐예요? What's your name? 이게 뭐예요? What's this? 뭐 하세요? What do you do? 뭐 먹을래요? What do you want to eat? 취미가 뭐예요? What's your hobby? 무슨 일이에요? What's the matter?

Note: 무슨 + noun = "what kind of..." - 무슨 음식? (What kind of food?) - 무슨 영화? (What kind of movie?)

docs.title: Where: 어디
docs.text: Used to ask about locations and places.

docs.title: Basic Patterns
docs.text:
• 어디예요? (Where is it?)
  • 어디 가요? (Where are you going?)
  • 어디에 있어요? (Where is it located?)
  • 어디에서 왔어요? (Where are you from?)

docs.title: Common "Where" Questions
docs.text:
Korean English 화장실이 어디예요? Where's the bathroom? 어디 살아요? Where do you live? 어디 아파요? Where does it hurt? 어디에서 만날까요? Where shall we meet? 집이 어디예요? Where's your home?

Particle notes: - 어디 (basic location) - 어디에 (location with 에) - 어디에서 (location/origin with 에서) - 어디로 (direction with 로)

docs.title: When: 언제
docs.text: Used to ask about time.

docs.title: Basic Patterns
docs.text:
• 언제예요? (When is it?)
  • 언제 가요? (When are you going?)
  • 언제 만날까요? (When shall we meet?)
  • 언제 왔어요? (When did you come?)

docs.title: Common "When" Questions
docs.text: Korean English 생일이 언제예요? When's your birthday? 언제 시작해요? When does it start? 언제 끝나요? When does it end? 언제 다시 올 거예요? When will you come again? 언제부터 한국어를 배웠어요? Since when have you been learning Korean?

docs.title: Why: 왜
docs.text: Used to ask for reasons and causes.

docs.title: Basic Patterns
docs.text:
• 왜요? (Why?)
  • 왜 그래요? (Why is that? / What's wrong?)
  • 왜 안 와요? (Why aren't you coming?)
  • 왜 그렇게 생각해요? (Why do you think so?)

docs.title: Common "Why" Questions
docs.text: Korean English 왜 늦었어요? Why are you late? 왜 안 먹어요? Why aren't you eating? 왜 전화 안 했어요? Why didn't you call? 왜 슬퍼요? Why are you sad? 왜 한국어를 배워요? Why are you learning Korean?

docs.title: How: 어떻게
docs.text: Used to ask about methods, manner, and condition.

docs.title: Basic Patterns
docs.text:
• 어떻게 가요? (How do you go?)
  • 어떻게 해요? (How do you do it?)
  • 어떻게 지내요? (How are you? / How have you been?)

docs.title: Common "How" Questions
docs.text: Korean English 어떻게 왔어요? How did you get here? 이름을 어떻게 써요? How do you write your name? 어떻게 알았어요? How did you know? 한국말을 어떻게 배웠어요? How did you learn Korean? 어떻게 생각해요? What do you think? (How do you think?)

docs.title: 어떻다 (How is it?)
docs.text:
Used to ask about condition or quality:

  • 날씨가 어때요? (How's the weather?)
  • 맛이 어때요? (How's the taste?)
  • 영화가 어땠어요? (How was the movie?)

docs.title: Who: 누구
docs.text: Used to ask about people.

docs.title: Basic Patterns
docs.text:
• 누구예요? (Who is it?)
  • 누구랑 가요? (Who are you going with?)
  • 누가 했어요? (Who did it?)

Note: 누구 becomes 누가 when used as subject.

docs.title: Common "Who" Questions
docs.text: Korean English 이 사람이 누구예요? Who is this person? 누구를 기다려요? Who are you waiting for? 누가 만들었어요? Who made it? 누구 거예요? Whose is it? 누구한테 물어봤어요? Who did you ask?

docs.title: How Much/Many: 얼마
docs.text: Used to ask about price and quantity.

docs.title: Price
docs.text:
• 얼마예요? (How much is it?)
  • 이게 얼마예요? (How much is this?)
  • 모두 얼마예요? (How much in total?)

docs.title: Time Duration
docs.text:
• 얼마나 걸려요? (How long does it take?)
  • 얼마나 기다렸어요? (How long did you wait?)
  • 얼마나 자주 가요? (How often do you go?)

docs.title: Quantity
docs.text: For counting specific items, use: - 몇 + counter (How many...?) - 몇 개예요? (How many pieces?) - 몇 명이에요? (How many people?) - 몇 시예요? (What time is it?)

docs.title: Which: 어느
docs.text: Used to choose between options.

docs.title: Basic Patterns
docs.text:
• 어느 거예요? (Which one?)
  • 어느 게 좋아요? (Which is good?)
  • 어느 나라 사람이에요? (Which country are you from?)

Examples: - 어느 색이 예뻐요? (Which color is pretty?) - 어느 쪽으로 갈까요? (Which way shall we go?) - 어느 것을 고를 거예요? (Which one will you choose?)

docs.title: Combining Question Words
docs.text:
You can combine question words for more specific questions:

  • 언제 어디에서 만날까요? (When and where shall we meet?)
  • 누가 왜 그랬어요? (Who did it and why?)
  • 뭐 어떻게 할 거예요? (What and how will you do it?)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Ask "What's this?" in polite form.

  2. How do you ask "Where's the bathroom?" formally?

  3. Ask "When does the movie start?" in polite form.

  4. How do you say "Why are you late?" politely?

  5. Ask "How do you get to the station?" formally.

  6. How do you ask "Who is that person?" in polite form?

  7. Ask "How much is this?" casually.

  8. Ask "Which one do you like?" in polite form.

  9. Translate: "Where and when shall we meet?"

  10. Create a question: Ask someone what they did yesterday and why (polite form).

Show Answers 1. 이게 뭐예요? 2. 화장실이 어디입니까? or 화장실이 어디예요? 3. 영화가 언제 시작해요? 4. 왜 늦었어요? 5. 역에 어떻게 가십니까? or 역에 어떻게 가요? 6. 저 사람이 누구예요? 7. 이거 얼마야? or 이거 얼마예요? 8. 어느 게 좋아요? 9. 어디에서 언제 만날까요? 10. Example answer: 어제 뭐 했어요? 왜 그랬어요? (What did you do yesterday? Why did you do that?) Or: 어제 뭐 했어요? 왜요? (What did you do yesterday? Why?)

docs.title: Common Daily Phrases
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Korean Meaning Context 잠시만요 Just a moment Asking to wait 괜찮아요 It's okay / I'm fine Reassurance 모르겠어요 I don't know Uncertainty 다시 말해 주세요 Please say again Repetition 천천히 말해 주세요 Please speak slowly Comprehension 알겠어요 I understand / I got it Confirmation 도와주세요 Please help me Requesting help 괜찮습니다 It's alright Declining/accepting

docs.title: 잠시만요 / 잠깐만요
docs.text:
"Just a moment" - Used when asking someone to wait briefly.

Usage: - Answering the phone - Needing time to think - Making someone wait

Examples: - A: 주문 받겠습니다. (I'll take your order.) - B: 잠시만요. 메뉴 좀 더 볼게요. (Just a moment. Let me look at the menu more.)

Variations: - 잠깐만요 (more casual) - 잠시만 기다려 주세요 (Please wait a moment - more formal)

docs.title: 괜찮아요 / 괜찮습니다
docs.text:
Multi-purpose phrase meaning "It's okay," "I'm fine," or "It's alright."

Usage scenarios:

1. Declining an offer: - A: 물 좀 드릴까요? (Shall I give you some water?) - B: 괜찮아요. (I'm okay, thanks.)

2. Reassuring someone: - A: 죄송합니다. (I'm sorry.) - B: 괜찮아요. (It's okay.)

3. Saying you're fine: - A: 어디 아파요? (Are you hurt?) - B: 괜찮아요. (I'm fine.)

4. Asking if something is okay: - 이거 괜찮아요? (Is this okay?) - 내일 괜찮으세요? (Are you free/okay tomorrow?)

docs.title: 알겠어요 / 알았어요
docs.text:
Understanding and acknowledgment.

알겠어요 = "I understand" / "I got it" (future-oriented) 알았어요 = "I understood" / "Okay, got it" (past-oriented)

Examples: - A: 내일 10시에 오세요. (Please come at 10 tomorrow.) - B: 알겠습니다. (Understood.)

  • A: 이거 하지 마세요. (Don't do this.)
  • B: 알았어요. (Got it.)

Informal: 알겠어 / 알았어

docs.title: 모르겠어요
docs.text:
"I don't know" / "I'm not sure"

Structure: 모르다 (to not know) + -겠어요

Examples: - 잘 모르겠어요. (I'm not sure.) - 어떻게 하는지 모르겠어요. (I don't know how to do it.) - 답을 모르겠어요. (I don't know the answer.)

Variations: - 몰라요 (more direct: I don't know) - 모릅니다 (formal) - 몰라 (casual)

docs.title: 어떻게 하죠?
docs.text:
"What should I do?" / "How do I do this?"

Examples: - 길을 잃었어요. 어떻게 하죠? (I'm lost. What should I do?) - 비밀번호를 모르겠어요. 어떻게 하죠? (I don't know the password. What should I do?)

docs.title: 무슨 뜻이에요?
docs.text:
"What does it mean?"

Examples: - 이게 무슨 뜻이에요? (What does this mean?) - 그 말이 무슨 뜻이에요? (What does that word mean?)

docs.title: 다시 말해 주세요
docs.text:
"Please say it again" - When you didn't hear or understand.

Examples: - 죄송한데, 다시 말해 주세요. (Sorry, but please say it again.) - 못 들었어요. 다시 말해 주세요. (I didn't hear. Please say it again.)

Variations: - 한 번 더 말해 주세요 (Please say it one more time)

docs.title: 천천히 말해 주세요
docs.text:
"Please speak slowly"

Examples: - 천천히 말해 주세요. 한국어를 잘 못해요. (Please speak slowly. I'm not good at Korean.)

docs.title: 이해가 안 돼요
docs.text:
"I don't understand"

Examples: - 설명을 들었는데 이해가 안 돼요. (I heard the explanation but I don't understand.) - 한국어로 하면 이해가 안 돼요. (I don't understand if you do it in Korean.)

Alternative: - 이해 못 했어요 (I didn't understand)

docs.title: 도와주세요
docs.text:
"Please help me"

Structure: 돕다 (to help) + -아/어 주세요 (please do for me)

Examples: - 도와주세요! (Help me!) - 좀 도와주실 수 있어요? (Could you help me a bit?) - 짐 좀 들어 주세요. (Please help me carry the luggage.)

docs.title: 부탁 좀 들어 주세요
docs.text:
"Please do me a favor"

Examples: - 부탁 좀 들어 주세요. (Please do me a favor.) - 부탁이 하나 있는데요. (I have a favor to ask.)

docs.title: 가르쳐 주세요
docs.text:
"Please teach me" / "Please show me"

Examples: - 어떻게 하는지 가르쳐 주세요. (Please teach me how to do it.) - 한국어를 가르쳐 주세요. (Please teach me Korean.)

docs.title: 어렵다 / 어려워요
docs.text:
"It's difficult" / "It's hard"

Examples: - 한국어가 어려워요. (Korean is difficult.) - 이 문제가 너무 어려워요. (This problem is too hard.)

docs.title: 힘들어요
docs.text:
"It's tough" / "I'm having a hard time"

Examples: - 요즘 일이 너무 힘들어요. (Work is really tough these days.) - 공부가 힘들어요. (Studying is tough.)

docs.title: 안 돼요
docs.text:
"It won't work" / "It's not allowed" / "Don't do that"

Usage scenarios:

1. Not allowed: - 여기는 사진 촬영이 안 돼요. (Photography is not allowed here.)

2. Won't work: - 이 방법은 안 돼요. (This method won't work.)

3. Prohibition: - 안 돼요! 그거 하지 마세요! (No! Don't do that!)

docs.title: 그렇습니다 / 그래요
docs.text:
"That's right" / "Yes, it is"

Examples: - A: 한국 사람이에요? (Are you Korean?) - B: 네, 그렇습니다. (Yes, that's right.)

docs.title: 아니에요
docs.text:
"No, it's not" / "No"

Examples: - A: 학생이에요? (Are you a student?) - B: 아니에요. 회사원이에요. (No, I'm an office worker.)

docs.title: 맞아요 / 틀려요
docs.text:
"That's correct" / "That's wrong"

Examples: - 맞아요. 그게 정답이에요. (That's correct. That's the right answer.) - 틀려요. 다시 해 보세요. (That's wrong. Try again.)

docs.title: 확실해요 / 확실하지 않아요
docs.text:
"I'm sure" / "I'm not sure"

Examples: - 확실해요. 그 사람이에요. (I'm sure. It's that person.) - 확실하지 않아요. (I'm not sure.)

docs.title: 아마도 / 아마
docs.text:
"Maybe" / "Perhaps"

Examples: - 아마 내일 비가 올 거예요. (It will probably rain tomorrow.) - 아마도 늦을 것 같아요. (Maybe I'll be late.)

docs.title: 실례합니다
docs.text:
"Excuse me" - When interrupting or passing by.

Examples: - 실례합니다. 길을 물어보고 싶은데요. (Excuse me. I'd like to ask for directions.)

docs.title: 여기요 / 저기요
docs.text:
"Excuse me" - Getting someone's attention (servers, staff).

Examples: - 저기요! 주문할게요. (Excuse me! I'd like to order.) - 여기요! 물 좀 주세요. (Excuse me! Please give me some water.)

docs.title: 그냥
docs.text:
"Just" / "No reason" / "Nothing special"

Examples: - A: 뭐 해요? (What are you doing?) - B: 그냥 쉬어요. (Just resting.)

  • A: 왜요? (Why?)
  • B: 그냥요. (No reason.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How do you ask someone to wait a moment politely?

  2. Your friend apologizes for being late. How do you tell them it's okay?

  3. You don't understand what someone said. Ask them to say it again.

  4. How do you tell someone you don't know the answer?

  5. Ask someone to speak more slowly because you're learning Korean.

  6. You need help carrying something. How do you ask?

  7. Someone asks if you understand. Confirm that you do (polite form).

  8. How do you say "It's difficult" in Korean?

  9. You want to get a server's attention. What do you say?

  10. Someone explains something but you still don't understand the meaning. What do you ask?

Show Answers 1. 잠시만요 or 잠깐만요 2. 괜찮아요 3. 다시 말해 주세요 4. 모르겠어요 or 몰라요 5. 천천히 말해 주세요. 한국어를 배우고 있어요. 6. 도와주세요 or 좀 도와주실 수 있어요? 7. 알겠어요 or 알겠습니다 8. 어려워요 or 어렵습니다 9. 저기요 or 여기요 10. 무슨 뜻이에요? (What does it mean?)

docs.title: Greetings
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Korean Meaning Context 안녕하세요 Hello Formal, most common 안녕 Hi/Bye Informal, friends 안녕히 가세요 Goodbye To person leaving 안녕히 계세요 Goodbye To person staying 감사합니다 Thank you Formal 고맙습니다 Thank you Polite but warmer 고마워요 Thanks Casual polite 고마워 Thanks Informal 죄송합니다 I'm sorry Formal apology 미안합니다 I'm sorry Polite apology 미안해요 Sorry Casual polite

docs.title: 안녕하세요
docs.text:
The most versatile greeting in Korean, used throughout the day in formal and semi-formal situations.

Usage: - Meeting someone for the first time - Greeting colleagues, shopkeepers, service staff - Any situation where you want to be polite

Example: - 안녕하세요. 저는 김민수입니다. (Hello. I'm Kim Minsu.) - 안녕하세요? 잘 지냈어요? (Hello? Have you been well?)

docs.title: 안녕
docs.text:
Informal greeting used among close friends and to younger people.

Usage: - With friends your age or younger - Casual settings among peers - Can mean both "hello" and "bye"

Example: - 안녕! 오랜만이야. (Hi! Long time no see.) - 그럼 안녕. (Then, bye.)

docs.title: 안녕히 가세요
docs.text:
Used when the other person is leaving and you are staying.

Literal meaning: "Go peacefully"

Example: - A: 저는 이만 가볼게요. (I'll get going now.) - B: 네, 안녕히 가세요. (Yes, goodbye.)

docs.title: 안녕히 계세요
docs.text:
Used when you are leaving and the other person is staying.

Literal meaning: "Stay peacefully"

Example: - A: 안녕히 계세요. 내일 봬요. (Goodbye. See you tomorrow.) - B: 네, 조심히 가세요. (Yes, go safely.)

docs.title: Memory Tip
docs.text:
• 가세요 (go) = person is GOING away
  • 계세요 (stay) = person is STAYING

docs.title: Formal: 감사합니다
docs.text:
The most formal and common way to say thank you.

Usage: - Business situations - Speaking to strangers - Showing sincere gratitude

Example: - 도와주셔서 감사합니다. (Thank you for helping me.) - 정말 감사합니다. (Thank you so much.)

docs.title: Polite: 고맙습니다 / 고마워요
docs.text:
Warmer and slightly less formal than 감사합니다.

Example: - 선물 고맙습니다. (Thank you for the gift.) - 말해 줘서 고마워요. (Thanks for telling me.)

docs.title: Informal: 고마워
docs.text:
Used with close friends and younger people.

Example: - 고마워! 네 덕분이야. (Thanks! It's thanks to you.)

docs.title: Formal: 죄송합니다
docs.text:
The most formal apology, literally meaning "I am guilty/at fault."

Usage: - Serious mistakes - Business contexts - Speaking to superiors or strangers

Example: - 늦어서 죄송합니다. (I'm sorry for being late.) - 정말 죄송합니다. (I'm truly sorry.)

docs.title: Polite: 미안합니다 / 미안해요
docs.text:
Less formal but still polite apology.

Example: - 깜빡했어요. 미안합니다. (I forgot. I'm sorry.) - 늦어서 미안해요. (Sorry for being late.)

docs.title: Informal: 미안해
docs.text:
Used with friends and close acquaintances.

Example: - 미안해. 다시는 안 그럴게. (Sorry. I won't do it again.)

docs.title: 실례합니다
docs.text:
"Excuse me" - used when interrupting or passing by someone.

Example: - 실례합니다. 길 좀 물어볼게요. (Excuse me. I'd like to ask for directions.)

docs.title: 수고하세요
docs.text:
"Keep up the good work" - said to people who are working.

Example: - 수고하세요! (Good work! / Keep it up!)

Note: Don't say this to superiors or customers.

docs.title: 잘 먹겠습니다
docs.text:
"I will eat well" - said before eating.

Example: - (Before starting a meal) 잘 먹겠습니다!

docs.title: 잘 먹었습니다
docs.text:
"I ate well" - said after finishing a meal.

Example: - (After finishing) 잘 먹었습니다. 감사합니다.

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How do you greet someone formally in the afternoon?

  2. You're leaving a shop. What do you say to the shopkeeper who is staying?

  3. Someone holds the door open for you. How do you thank them formally?

  4. You accidentally bump into someone on the street. What do you say?

  5. You're at a friend's house for dinner. What do you say before eating?

  6. How do you say "goodbye" to a friend casually?

  7. Your boss thanks you for your work. How do you respond?

  8. You forgot to send an important email to your supervisor. How do you apologize?

  9. Someone says 안녕히 가세요 to you. Are you staying or leaving?

  10. What's the difference between 감사합니다 and 고마워?

Show Answers 1. 안녕하세요 2. 안녕히 계세요 3. 감사합니다 4. 죄송합니다 or 실례합니다 5. 잘 먹겠습니다 6. 안녕 or 잘 가 7. 감사합니다 or 고맙습니다 8. 죄송합니다 9. Leaving (가세요 = go, so they're telling you to "go peacefully") 10. 감사합니다 is more formal and used in professional/formal situations; 고마워 is warmer and used in casual/personal contexts

docs.title: Self-Introduction
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern Korean Example I am... 저는...입니다 저는 학생입니다 My name is... 제 이름은...입니다 제 이름은 민수입니다 I'm X years old ...살입니다 스물다섯 살입니다 My job is... 제 직업은...입니다 제 직업은 선생님입니다 I'm from... ...에서 왔습니다 미국에서 왔습니다 Nice to meet you 만나서 반갑습니다 -

docs.title: 저는...입니다
docs.text:
The fundamental pattern for introducing yourself.

Structure: 저는 + [noun] + 입니다

  • 저 = I (humble form)
  • 는 = topic particle
  • 입니다 = to be (formal)

Examples: - 저는 학생입니다. (I am a student.) - 저는 의사입니다. (I am a doctor.) - 저는 한국 사람입니다. (I am Korean.)

docs.title: Informal Variations
docs.text:
• Polite informal: 저는...이에요/예요

  • 저는 학생이에요. (I'm a student.)

  • Casual: 나는/난...이야/야

  • 나는 학생이야. (I'm a student.)

docs.title: Formal: 제 이름은...입니다
docs.text:
제 = my (저의 contracted)

Examples: - 제 이름은 김민수입니다. (My name is Kim Minsu.) - 제 이름은 사라입니다. (My name is Sarah.)

docs.title: Alternative Patterns
docs.text:
저는 [이름](이)라고 합니다

More natural in speech, means "I am called..."

Examples: - 저는 민수라고 합니다. (I'm called Minsu.) - 저는 존이라고 합니다. (I'm called John.)

Note: Use 이라고 after consonants, 라고 after vowels.

docs.title: Asking Someone's Name
docs.text:
• 이름이 뭐예요? (What's your name? - casual polite)
  • 성함이 어떻게 되세요? (What's your name? - honorific)

docs.title: 저는...살입니다
docs.text:
살 = years old (counter)

Examples: - 저는 스물다섯 살입니다. (I'm 25 years old.) - 저는 서른 살입니다. (I'm 30 years old.)

docs.title: Age in Korean
docs.text:
Use native Korean numbers for age:

  • 스무 살 (20)
  • 스물한 살 (21)
  • 스물다섯 살 (25)
  • 서른 살 (30)
  • 마흔 살 (40)

docs.title: Asking Someone's Age
docs.text:
• 몇 살이에요? (How old are you? - casual)
  • 연세가 어떻게 되세요? (How old are you? - honorific)

Note: Age questions can be sensitive; consider context.

docs.title: 저는...입니다 / 제 직업은...입니다
docs.text:
Common Occupations:

Korean Meaning 학생 student 선생님 teacher 의사 doctor 간호사 nurse 회사원 office worker 공무원 civil servant 엔지니어 engineer 요리사 chef 경찰관 police officer 변호사 lawyer 디자이너 designer 프로그래머 programmer

Examples: - 저는 선생님입니다. (I'm a teacher.) - 제 직업은 의사입니다. (My occupation is doctor.) - 저는 회사원이에요. (I'm an office worker.)

docs.title: Asking About Occupation
docs.text:
• 직업이 뭐예요? (What's your job?)
  • 무슨 일 하세요? (What work do you do?)

docs.title: ...에서 왔습니다
docs.text:
Structure: [country/city] + 에서 + 왔습니다 (came from)

Common Countries:

Korean Country 한국 Korea 미국 USA 영국 UK 중국 China 일본 Japan 캐나다 Canada 호주 Australia 프랑스 France 독일 Germany 스페인 Spain

Examples: - 저는 미국에서 왔습니다. (I'm from America.) - 저는 서울에서 왔어요. (I'm from Seoul.)

docs.title: Stating Nationality
docs.text:
Structure: [country] + 사람 + 입니다

Examples: - 저는 미국 사람입니다. (I'm American.) - 저는 한국 사람이에요. (I'm Korean.) - 저는 영국 사람입니다. (I'm British.)

docs.title: Asking About Origin
docs.text:
• 어디에서 왔어요? (Where are you from?)
  • 어느 나라 사람이에요? (What country are you from?)

docs.title: 만나서 반갑습니다
docs.text:
"Nice to meet you" - said when meeting someone for the first time.

Variations by formality: - Formal: 만나서 반갑습니다 - Polite: 만나서 반가워요 - Casual: 만나서 반가워

Example dialogue: - A: 저는 김민수입니다. 만나서 반갑습니다. - B: 저는 이지은입니다. 저도 반갑습니다.

docs.title: 잘 부탁합니다
docs.text:
"Please treat me well" - often said after introductions, especially in work contexts.

Example: - 앞으로 잘 부탁합니다. (Please treat me well going forward.)

docs.title: Formal (Business/First Meeting)
docs.text:
안녕하세요. 저는 김민수입니다. 저는 서울에서 왔습니다. 저는 회사원이고 삼십 살입니다. 만나서 반갑습니다. 잘 부탁합니다.

(Hello. I'm Kim Minsu. I'm from Seoul. I'm an office worker and I'm 30 years old. Nice to meet you. Please treat me well.)

docs.title: Casual Polite (Social Setting)
docs.text:
안녕하세요. 저는 사라라고 해요. 미국에서 왔어요. 저는 영어 선생님이에요. 스물여덟 살이에요. 만나서 반가워요.

(Hi. I'm called Sarah. I'm from America. I'm an English teacher. I'm 28 years old. Nice to meet you.)

docs.title: Informal (Friends)
docs.text:
안녕! 나는 준이야. 부산에서 왔어. 대학생이고 스물두 살이야. 만나서 반가워!

(Hi! I'm Jun. I'm from Busan. I'm a university student and I'm 22. Nice to meet you!)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Introduce yourself with your name using the formal pattern.

  2. How do you say "I'm a student" formally?

  3. Tell someone you're 27 years old in polite form.

  4. State that you're from Canada formally.

  5. Say "I'm an engineer" using the 라고 합니다 pattern.

  6. How do you ask someone "What's your occupation?" politely?

  7. State your nationality if you're American (formal).

  8. Combine: "My name is John and I'm a doctor."

  9. How do you say "Nice to meet you" in casual polite form?

  10. Write a complete self-introduction (4-5 sentences) in formal style including: name, age, occupation, and where you're from.

Show Answers 1. 저는 [your name]입니다 or 제 이름은 [your name]입니다 2. 저는 학생입니다 3. 저는 스물일곱 살이에요 4. 저는 캐나다에서 왔습니다 5. 저는 엔지니어라고 합니다 6. 직업이 뭐예요? or 무슨 일 하세요? 7. 저는 미국 사람입니다 8. 제 이름은 존이고 의사입니다 or 저는 존이라고 하고 의사입니다 9. 만나서 반가워요 10. Example answer: 안녕하세요. 저는 김수진입니다. 저는 서울에서 왔습니다. 저는 선생님이고 서른두 살입니다. 만나서 반갑습니다. (Hello. I'm Kim Sujin. I'm from Seoul. I'm a teacher and I'm 32 years old. Nice to meet you.)

docs.title: Basic Vocabulary
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Category Key Words Examples Family 가족 아버지, 어머니, 형, 누나 Food 음식 밥, 김치, 불고기, 비빔밥 Places 장소 집, 학교, 회사, 병원 Verbs 동사 가다, 먹다, 자다, 공부하다 Adjectives 형용사 크다, 작다, 좋다, 나쁘다

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Building a strong vocabulary foundation is essential for Korean language proficiency. This section covers the most common and useful words you'll encounter in daily life, organized by category for easier learning and retention.

docs.title: Family Terms
docs.text: Learn both formal and informal terms for family members, understanding the nuanced system that changes based on speaker's gender and formality level.

docs.title: Food and Dining
docs.text: Master vocabulary for common Korean foods, restaurant situations, and describing tastes and preferences.

docs.title: Common Places
docs.text: Build your vocabulary for everyday locations from homes and schools to shops and public facilities.

docs.title: Essential Verbs
docs.text: Learn the 50 most frequently used verbs in Korean with practical example sentences showing real usage patterns.

docs.title: Essential Adjectives
docs.text: Master descriptive words for people, objects, and situations that form the foundation of daily communication.

docs.title: 1. Context Over Isolation
docs.text:
Always learn words in context, not as isolated vocabulary items. A word learned in a sentence is remembered better and used more accurately.

Don't: 먹다 = to eat Do: 밥을 먹어요 = I eat rice/meal

docs.title: 2. Group by Theme
docs.text:
Learn related words together to build semantic networks in your brain. This section groups vocabulary thematically for this reason.

Example: When learning 아버지 (father), also learn 어머니 (mother), 부모님 (parents), etc.

docs.title: 3. Active Usage
docs.text: Don't just read vocabulary - actively use it: - Write example sentences - Say words out loud - Practice with exercises - Use in conversation

docs.title: 4. Spaced Repetition
docs.text: Review vocabulary at increasing intervals: - Day 1: Learn new words - Day 2: Review - Day 4: Review - Day 7: Review - Day 14: Review - Day 30: Review

docs.title: 5. Learn Word Families
docs.text:
Korean uses word building extensively. Learn related forms together:

Example: - 공부 (study - noun) - 공부하다 (to study) - 공부방 (study room) - 공부시간 (study time)

docs.title: 6. Notice Patterns
docs.text: Korean vocabulary often follows patterns: - Sino-Korean numbers in dates, money, addresses - Native Korean numbers for age, items - Counters for different object types

docs.title: 7. Use Multiple Senses
docs.text:
• Visual: Write words, use flashcards
  • Auditory: Listen to pronunciation, repeat aloud
  • Kinesthetic: Write by hand, type, use gestures
  • Contextual: Use words in sentences and conversations

docs.title: Formal vs. Informal Vocabulary
docs.text:
Korean has distinct formal and informal vocabulary, especially for:

Family terms: - Formal: 아버지 (father) - Informal: 아빠 (dad)

Daily objects: - Formal: 식사 (meal) - Informal: 밥 (meal/rice)

Tip: Learn both forms but start with formal terms when uncertain. It's better to be overly polite than accidentally rude.

docs.title: Common Noun Suffixes
docs.text:
• -자: person who does (의사 = doctor, 기자 = reporter)
  • -실: room (교실 = classroom, 화장실 = bathroom)
  • -점: shop (빵점 = bakery, 서점 = bookstore)
  • -관: building (도서관 = library, 영화관 = cinema)

docs.title: Verb + Noun Combinations
docs.text:
• 하다 verbs: 공부하다 (to study), 운동하다 (to exercise)
  • 되다 verbs: 선생님이 되다 (to become a teacher)
  • 주다 verbs: 가르쳐 주다 (to teach for someone)

docs.title: How to Use This Section
docs.text:
1. Start with Categories Most Relevant to You
  2. If you love food, begin with food vocabulary

  3. If you're living in Korea, prioritize places vocabulary

  4. Complete the Exercises

  5. Each page has 8-10 practice exercises
  6. Check answers only after attempting all questions

  7. Retry incorrect answers

  8. Create Your Own Sentences

  9. Use the vocabulary in your own example sentences

  10. This personalizes learning and improves retention

  11. Track Your Progress

  12. Keep a vocabulary notebook
  13. Note which words you struggle with

  14. Review difficult words more frequently

  15. Practice Production, Not Just Recognition

  16. Don't just recognize words when you see them
  17. Practice producing them in speech and writing
  18. This is how you move from passive to active vocabulary

docs.title: Beginner Level (This Section)
docs.text:
• Family: 15-20 essential family terms
  • Food: 30-40 common foods and restaurant phrases
  • Places: 20-25 everyday locations
  • Verbs: 50 most common verbs
  • Adjectives: 50 most common adjectives

Total target: ~200-250 high-frequency words

docs.title: Integration with Grammar
docs.text:
Vocabulary and grammar work together. As you learn words: - Notice particle usage (이/가, 을/를, 에, 에서) - Pay attention to verb endings - Observe sentence patterns - See how adjectives modify nouns

The grammar sections complement vocabulary learning by showing you how to use these words correctly in sentences.

docs.title: Remember
docs.text:
Quality over quantity: It's better to know 100 words well (can use in sentences correctly) than to recognize 500 words but can't use them.

Frequency matters: Focus on high-frequency words first. The 1000 most common words account for ~80% of everyday conversation.

Use it or lose it: Vocabulary not used regularly fades. Regular practice and real-world usage are essential for retention.

docs.title: 50 Essential Adjectives
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Category Key Adjectives Size 크다, 작다, 길다, 짧다 Quality 좋다, 나쁘다, 새것, 낡다 Appearance 예쁘다, 못생기다, 깨끗하다 Temperature 덥다, 춥다, 뜨겁다, 차갑다 Emotion 행복하다, 슬프다, 화나다 Difficulty 쉽다, 어렵다, 간단하다

docs.title: Size and Dimension
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 크다 to be big 커요 집이 커요 (The house is big) 작다 to be small 작아요 방이 작아요 (The room is small) 길다 to be long 길어요 머리가 길어요 (Hair is long) 짧다 to be short 짧아요 치마가 짧아요 (The skirt is short) 넓다 to be wide/spacious 넓어요 거실이 넓어요 (The living room is spacious) 좁다 to be narrow 좁아요 길이 좁아요 (The road is narrow) 높다 to be high/tall 높아요 산이 높아요 (The mountain is high) 낮다 to be low 낮아요 목소리가 낮아요 (The voice is low) 두껍다 to be thick 두꺼워요 책이 두꺼워요 (The book is thick) 얇다 to be thin 얇아요 종이가 얇아요 (The paper is thin)

Usage Examples: - 이 가방이 너무 커요. (This bag is too big.) - 손이 작아요. (My hands are small.) - 이 바지가 너무 길어요. (These pants are too long.) - 아파트가 넓고 좋아요. (The apartment is spacious and nice.)

docs.title: Quality and Condition
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 좋다 to be good 좋아요 날씨가 좋아요 (The weather is good) 나쁘다 to be bad 나빠요 기분이 나빠요 (I feel bad) 새롭다 to be new 새로워요 옷이 새로워요 (The clothes are new) 낡다 to be old/worn 낡아요 신발이 낡았어요 (The shoes are old) 깨끗하다 to be clean 깨끗해요 방이 깨끗해요 (The room is clean) 더럽다 to be dirty 더러워요 차가 더러워요 (The car is dirty) 바쁘다 to be busy 바빠요 요즘 바빠요 (I'm busy these days) 한가하다 to be free/leisurely 한가해요 오늘은 한가해요 (I'm free today) 편하다 to be comfortable 편해요 의자가 편해요 (The chair is comfortable) 불편하다 to be uncomfortable 불편해요 신발이 불편해요 (The shoes are uncomfortable)

Usage Examples: - 한국어가 좋아요. (Korean is good/I like Korean.) - 새 휴대폰을 샀어요. (I bought a new phone.) - 방을 깨끗하게 청소했어요. (I cleaned the room cleanly.) - 주말에는 한가해요. (I'm free on weekends.)

docs.title: Appearance and Beauty
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 예쁘다 to be pretty 예뻐요 꽃이 예뻐요 (The flowers are pretty) 아름답다 to be beautiful 아름다워요 경치가 아름다워요 (The scenery is beautiful) 못생기다 to be ugly 못생겼어요 - 귀엽다 to be cute 귀여워요 강아지가 귀여워요 (The puppy is cute) 멋있다 to be cool/stylish 멋있어요 옷이 멋있어요 (The clothes are cool) 잘생기다 to be handsome 잘생겼어요 배우가 잘생겼어요 (The actor is handsome)

Usage Examples: - 정말 예쁜 드레스예요. (It's a really pretty dress.) - 아기가 너무 귀여워요. (The baby is so cute.) - 멋있는 차네요. (That's a cool car.)

docs.title: Temperature
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 덥다 to be hot (weather) 더워요 여름은 더워요 (Summer is hot) 춥다 to be cold (weather) 추워요 겨울은 추워요 (Winter is cold) 뜨겁다 to be hot (object) 뜨거워요 커피가 뜨거워요 (The coffee is hot) 차갑다 to be cold (object) 차가워요 물이 차가워요 (The water is cold) 시원하다 to be cool/refreshing 시원해요 바람이 시원해요 (The wind is cool) 따뜻하다 to be warm 따뜻해요 방이 따뜻해요 (The room is warm)

Usage Examples: - 오늘 날씨가 너무 더워요. (Today's weather is too hot.) - 밖이 추워요. 코트를 입으세요. (It's cold outside. Wear a coat.) - 뜨거운 물 조심하세요. (Be careful of hot water.) - 따뜻한 차 한 잔 주세요. (Please give me a cup of warm tea.)

docs.title: Emotions and Feelings
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 행복하다 to be happy 행복해요 가족과 함께 있으면 행복해요 (I'm happy when with family) 슬프다 to be sad 슬퍼요 영화가 슬퍼요 (The movie is sad) 기쁘다 to be glad 기뻐요 만나서 기뻐요 (I'm glad to meet you) 화나다 to be angry 화나요 왜 화났어요? (Why are you angry?) 무섭다 to be scary 무서워요 귀신이 무서워요 (Ghosts are scary) 외롭다 to be lonely 외로워요 혼자 있으면 외로워요 (I'm lonely when alone) 걱정되다 to be worried 걱정돼요 시험이 걱정돼요 (I'm worried about the exam) 부끄럽다 to be shy/embarrassed 부끄러워요 얼굴이 부끄러워요 (I'm embarrassed)

Usage Examples: - 정말 행복한 하루였어요. (It was a really happy day.) - 친구가 떠나서 슬퍼요. (I'm sad because my friend is leaving.) - 무서운 영화를 봤어요. (I watched a scary movie.)

docs.title: Difficulty and Ease
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 쉽다 to be easy 쉬워요 문제가 쉬워요 (The problem is easy) 어렵다 to be difficult 어려워요 한국어가 어려워요 (Korean is difficult) 간단하다 to be simple 간단해요 설명이 간단해요 (The explanation is simple) 복잡하다 to be complicated 복잡해요 길이 복잡해요 (The road is complicated)

Usage Examples: - 이 문제는 너무 쉬워요. (This problem is too easy.) - 발음이 어려워요. (Pronunciation is difficult.) - 간단한 질문이 있어요. (I have a simple question.)

docs.title: Speed and Pace
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 빠르다 to be fast 빨라요 차가 빨라요 (The car is fast) 느리다 to be slow 느려요 거북이가 느려요 (The turtle is slow) 급하다 to be urgent 급해요 일이 급해요 (The work is urgent)

Usage Examples: - 시간이 빨라요. (Time goes fast.) - 천천히 말해 주세요. 너무 빨라요. (Please speak slowly. It's too fast.) - 급한 일이 있어요. (I have urgent business.)

docs.title: Distance and Proximity
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 가깝다 to be near 가까워요 학교가 가까워요 (School is near) 멀다 to be far 멀어요 집이 멀어요 (Home is far)

Usage Examples: - 여기에서 역이 가까워요. (The station is near from here.) - 회사가 멀어서 힘들어요. (It's hard because the company is far.)

docs.title: Weight and Heaviness
docs.text: Korean Meaning Present Form Example 무겁다 to be heavy 무거워요 가방이 무거워요 (The bag is heavy) 가볍다 to be light 가벼워요 옷이 가벼워요 (The clothes are light)

docs.title: Quantity and Degree
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Present Form Example 많다 to be many/much 많아요 사람이 많아요 (There are many people) 적다 to be few/little 적어요 시간이 적어요 (There is little time)

Usage Examples: - 친구가 많아요. (I have many friends.) - 돈이 적어요. (I have little money.)

docs.title: Adjectives as Predicates
docs.text: Korean adjectives function as verbs and don't need a copula: - 날씨가 좋다. (The weather is good.) - NOT 좋이다 - 꽃이 예쁘다. (The flower is pretty.)

docs.title: Adjectives Modifying Nouns
docs.text: When modifying nouns, adjectives take different forms: - Present: -(으)ㄴ - 큰 집 (big house) - 작은 방 (small room) - 예쁜 꽃 (pretty flower) - 좋은 사람 (good person)

docs.title: Irregular Adjectives
docs.text: Common irregular patterns: - ㅂ irregular: 춥다 → 추워요, 덥다 → 더워요 - ㄷ irregular: 듣다 → 들어요 - ㅎ irregular: 빨갛다 → 빨개요 - ㅡ irregular: 크다 → 커요, 쓰다 → 써요

docs.title: Negative Form
docs.text:
To make negative: - 안 + adjective: 안 좋아요 (not good) - Adjective + 지 않다: 좋지 않아요 (not good)

Examples: - 안 예뻐요. (It's not pretty.) - 어렵지 않아요. (It's not difficult.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How do you say "The weather is good today" in Korean?

  2. Translate: "My room is small but clean."

  3. How do you say "Korean is difficult but interesting"?

  4. Say "This coffee is too hot" in Korean.

  5. How do you describe someone as "pretty" in Korean?

  6. Translate: "I'm happy when I'm with friends."

  7. How do you say "The problem is easy" in Korean?

  8. Say "The station is near but the company is far" in Korean.

  9. How do you say "I'm busy these days" in Korean?

  10. Translate: "Summer is hot and winter is cold."

Show Answers 1. 오늘 날씨가 좋아요 2. 제 방은 작지만 깨끗해요 or 우리 방은 작은데 깨끗해요 3. 한국어는 어렵지만 재미있어요 or 한국어는 어려운데 재미있어요 4. 이 커피가 너무 뜨거워요 5. 예뻐요 (as predicate) or 예쁜 사람 (modifying noun) 6. 친구들과 함께 있으면 행복해요 7. 문제가 쉬워요 8. 역은 가까운데 회사는 멀어요 or 역은 가깝지만 회사는 멀어요 9. 요즘 바빠요 10. 여름은 덥고 겨울은 추워요

docs.title: Family Terms
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Relationship Formal Informal Father 아버지 아빠 Mother 어머니 엄마 Older brother (male speaker) 형 형 Older brother (female speaker) 오빠 오빠 Older sister (male speaker) 누나 누나 Older sister (female speaker) 언니 언니 Younger sibling 남동생 (brother) / 여동생 (sister) 동생

docs.title: Parents
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Usage 아버지 Father Formal, when talking about your father to others 아빠 Dad Informal, when addressing your father 어머니 Mother Formal, when talking about your mother to others 엄마 Mom Informal, when addressing your mother 부모님 Parents Respectful way to refer to parents (님 = honorific)

Examples: - 우리 아버지는 의사입니다. (My father is a doctor.) - 아빠, 이거 봐요! (Dad, look at this!) - 어머니께서 요리하고 계세요. (Mother is cooking.) - 부모님이 오셨어요. (My parents came.)

docs.title: Grandparents
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Usage 할아버지 Grandfather Paternal or maternal 할머니 Grandmother Paternal or maternal 외할아버지 Maternal grandfather Specifically mother's father 외할머니 Maternal grandmother Specifically mother's mother

Examples: - 할아버지는 올해 80세입니다. (Grandfather is 80 years old this year.) - 외할머니 집에 갔어요. (I went to maternal grandmother's house.)

docs.title: Older Siblings (Gender and Speaker Matter!)
docs.text: Korean sibling terms change based on: 1. The gender of the speaker 2. The gender of the sibling

docs.title: From Male Speaker's Perspective
docs.text: Korean Meaning Notes 형 Older brother Used by males 누나 Older sister Used by males

docs.title: From Female Speaker's Perspective
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 오빠 Older brother Used by females 언니 Older sister Used by females

Important: These terms are also used for close friends and romantic partners who are older, not just biological siblings.

Examples: - (Male speaking) 우리 형은 회사원이에요. (My older brother is an office worker.) - (Male speaking) 누나, 이거 도와주세요. (Older sister, please help me with this.) - (Female speaking) 오빠가 선물을 줬어요. (Older brother gave me a gift.) - (Female speaking) 언니랑 쇼핑 갔어요. (I went shopping with older sister.)

docs.title: Younger Siblings
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 남동생 Younger brother Any speaker 여동생 Younger sister Any speaker 동생 Younger sibling Gender-neutral term

Examples: - 남동생이 학생이에요. (My younger brother is a student.) - 여동생은 고등학생입니다. (My younger sister is a high school student.) - 동생이 두 명 있어요. (I have two younger siblings.)

docs.title: Aunts and Uncles
docs.text: The Korean system for aunts and uncles is specific about which side of the family and marriage status:

docs.title: Father's Side
docs.text: Korean Meaning 큰아버지 Father's older brother 작은아버지 Father's younger brother 고모 Father's sister 고모부 Father's sister's husband

docs.title: Mother's Side
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 외삼촌 Mother's brother 이모 Mother's sister 이모부 Mother's sister's husband

Examples: - 고모가 미국에 살아요. (My paternal aunt lives in America.) - 이모부는 선생님이에요. (My maternal aunt's husband is a teacher.)

docs.title: Cousins
docs.text: Korean Meaning Notes 사촌 Cousin General term 사촌 형 Older male cousin Male speaker 사촌 오빠 Older male cousin Female speaker 사촌 누나 Older female cousin Male speaker 사촌 언니 Older female cousin Female speaker 사촌 동생 Younger cousin Any speaker

docs.title: Spouse
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Usage 남편 Husband Formal 아내 Wife Formal 부인 Wife Very formal, respectful 와이프 Wife Casual (from English "wife")

Examples: - 제 남편은 엔지니어입니다. (My husband is an engineer.) - 아내가 의사예요. (My wife is a doctor.)

docs.title: In-Laws
docs.text: Korean Meaning 시어머니 Husband's mother 시아버지 Husband's father 장인어른 Wife's father 장모님 Wife's mother 시누이 Husband's sister 시동생 Husband's younger brother 처남 Wife's younger brother 처형 Wife's older sister

docs.title: Children
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 아들 Son 딸 Daughter 자녀 Children (formal) 아이 Child/children (informal) 애기 / 아기 Baby

Examples: - 아들이 둘 있어요. (I have two sons.) - 딸이 대학생이에요. (My daughter is a university student.) - 아이가 몇 명이에요? (How many children do you have?)

docs.title: Honorific Usage
docs.text:
When talking about someone else's family members, use honorific forms:

Your family Others' family 아버지 아버님 어머니 어머님 할아버지 할아버님 할머니 할머님 아들 아드님 딸 따님

Examples: - 어머님은 어디 계세요? (Where is your mother?) - 따님이 정말 예쁘네요. (Your daughter is really pretty.)

docs.title: Addressing vs. Referring
docs.text:
When addressing (calling) family members: - Use informal terms: 아빠, 엄마, 형, 언니, etc. - Often just use the relationship term as their name

When referring to (talking about) your family to others: - Use formal terms: 아버지, 어머니, 남동생, etc. - Shows respect in social contexts

Example: - To your father: "아빠, 밥 먹어요?" (Dad, shall we eat?) - About your father: "우리 아버지는 의사입니다." (My father is a doctor.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How does a male say "my older brother" in Korean?

  2. How does a female say "my older brother" in Korean?

  3. What's the formal way to say "parents"?

  4. You're a female talking about your older sister. What term do you use?

  5. What's the difference between 할아버지 and 외할아버지?

  6. How do you say "my younger sister"?

  7. You're male and talking to your older sister. How do you address her?

  8. What's the honorific way to refer to someone else's mother?

  9. How do you say "my mother is a teacher" using the formal term for mother?

  10. Translate: "I have an older brother and a younger sister" (as a female speaker).

Show Answers 1. 형 2. 오빠 3. 부모님 4. 언니 5. 할아버지 is grandfather (general), 외할아버지 specifically means maternal grandfather (mother's father) 6. 여동생 7. 누나 8. 어머님 9. 우리 어머니는 선생님입니다 or 저희 어머니는 선생님이십니다 (more honorific) 10. 오빠 한 명하고 여동생 한 명 있어요 Or: 오빠랑 여동생이 있어요

docs.title: Food and Dining
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Category Examples Staples 밥 (rice), 국 (soup), 김치 (kimchi) Main Dishes 불고기, 비빔밥, 김치찌개, 삼겹살 Drinks 물, 커피, 차, 주스, 맥주, 소주 Tastes 맛있다, 달다, 짜다, 맵다, 시다 Restaurant 주문하다, 계산하다, 메뉴, 포장

docs.title: Staple Foods
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 밥 Rice / Meal Also means "meal" in general 국 Soup Clear soup 찌개 Stew Thicker than 국 김치 Kimchi Fermented vegetables 빵 Bread From English "bread" 면 Noodles General term 밥 Cooked rice Staple food

Examples: - 밥 먹었어요? (Did you eat? - common greeting) - 국이 뜨거워요. (The soup is hot.) - 김치가 매워요. (The kimchi is spicy.)

docs.title: Popular Main Dishes
docs.text:
Korean Description 비빔밥 Mixed rice with vegetables and sauce 불고기 Marinated grilled beef 갈비 Grilled ribs (usually beef or pork) 삼겹살 Pork belly (grilled) 김치찌개 Kimchi stew 된장찌개 Soybean paste stew 냉면 Cold noodles 잡채 Stir-fried glass noodles 떡볶이 Spicy rice cakes 김밥 Seaweed rice rolls 치킨 Fried chicken (Korean style) 라면 Instant ramen noodles

Examples: - 불고기를 먹고 싶어요. (I want to eat bulgogi.) - 떡볶이가 너무 매워요. (Tteokbokki is too spicy.) - 삼겹살 2인분 주세요. (Two servings of pork belly, please.)

docs.title: Side Dishes
docs.text: Korean Meaning 반찬 Side dishes (general term) 김치 Kimchi (most common side) 깍두기 Cubed radish kimchi 무 Pickled radish 콩나물 Bean sprouts 시금치 Spinach

docs.title: Proteins
docs.text: Korean Meaning 고기 Meat (general) 소고기 Beef 돼지고기 Pork 닭고기 Chicken 생선 Fish 계란 Egg 두부 Tofu 해산물 Seafood

docs.title: Vegetables
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 야채 Vegetables 당근 Carrot 양파 Onion 마늘 Garlic 배추 Napa cabbage 오이 Cucumber 토마토 Tomato 감자 Potato 고추 Pepper (chili)

Examples: - 고기를 안 먹어요. (I don't eat meat.) - 생선을 좋아해요. (I like fish.) - 야채가 많이 들어가요. (It has a lot of vegetables.)

docs.title: Common Beverages
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 물 Water 커피 Coffee 차 Tea 녹차 Green tea 주스 Juice 우유 Milk 탄산음료 Carbonated drink / Soda 맥주 Beer 소주 Soju (Korean liquor) 막걸리 Rice wine 와인 Wine

Examples: - 물 좀 주세요. (Please give me some water.) - 커피 한 잔 주세요. (One cup of coffee, please.) - 맥주 마실래요? (Do you want to drink beer?)

docs.title: Basic Taste Adjectives
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Example 맛있다 Delicious 맛있어요 맛없다 Not delicious 맛없어요 달다 Sweet 달아요 짜다 Salty 짜요 맵다 Spicy 매워요 시다 Sour 셔요 쓰다 Bitter 써요 싱겁다 Bland 싱거워요

Examples: - 이 음식은 맛있어요. (This food is delicious.) - 너무 매워요. (It's too spicy.) - 좀 짜요. (It's a bit salty.) - 안 매워요? (Isn't it spicy?)

docs.title: Temperature and Texture
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 뜨겁다 Hot (temperature) 차갑다 Cold 따뜻하다 Warm 시원하다 Cool, refreshing 부드럽다 Soft, tender 바삭하다 Crispy 질기다 Chewy, tough

Examples: - 국이 뜨거워요. (The soup is hot.) - 시원한 물 주세요. (Please give me cold/refreshing water.) - 고기가 부드러워요. (The meat is tender.)

docs.title: Ordering
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 주문하다 To order 메뉴 Menu 주문할게요 I'll order 이거 주세요 Please give me this ...개 주세요 Please give me X items ...인분 Serving for X people

Examples: - 메뉴판 좀 주세요. (Please give me the menu.) - 주문할게요. (I'll order now.) - 비빔밥 2인분 주세요. (Two servings of bibimbap, please.) - 이거 하나 주세요. (One of this, please.)

docs.title: During the Meal
docs.text: Korean Meaning 잘 먹겠습니다 I will eat well (before eating) 잘 먹었습니다 I ate well (after eating) 맛있게 드세요 Enjoy your meal (polite) 물 좀 주세요 Please give me water 더 주세요 Please give me more 반찬 더 주세요 More side dishes, please

docs.title: Paying
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 계산하다 To pay / calculate bill 계산해 주세요 Check, please 얼마예요? How much is it? 카드 돼요? Do you take cards? 현금 Cash 영수증 Receipt 포장 Takeout / to-go

Examples: - 계산해 주세요. (Check, please.) - 카드로 할게요. (I'll pay by card.) - 포장해 주세요. (Please pack it to go.)

docs.title: Meal Times
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 아침 Morning / Breakfast 점심 Lunch 저녁 Evening / Dinner 간식 Snack 야식 Late-night snack

Examples: - 아침 먹었어요? (Did you eat breakfast?) - 점심 뭐 먹을래요? (What do you want to eat for lunch?) - 저녁에 만날까요? (Shall we meet in the evening?)

docs.title: Expressing Preferences
docs.text:
• 좋아해요 (I like it)
  • 싫어해요 (I dislike it)
  • 못 먹어요 (I can't eat it)
  • 안 먹어요 (I don't eat it)
  • 배불러요 (I'm full)
  • 배고파요 (I'm hungry)
  • 목말라요 (I'm thirsty)

Examples: - 매운 음식을 좋아해요. (I like spicy food.) - 고기를 못 먹어요. (I can't eat meat.) - 배불러요. 더 못 먹어요. (I'm full. I can't eat more.)

docs.title: Dietary Restrictions
docs.text:
• 채식주의자 (vegetarian)
  • 비건 (vegan)
  • 알레르기 (allergy)
  • 고기 안 먹어요 (I don't eat meat)
  • 해산물 알레르기가 있어요 (I have a seafood allergy)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How do you say "This food is delicious" in Korean?

  2. Order two servings of pork belly at a restaurant.

  3. How do you ask for the check?

  4. What do you say before eating?

  5. Translate: "The soup is too spicy."

  6. How do you say "I like kimchi" in Korean?

  7. Ask for cold water at a restaurant.

  8. How do you say "I'm full" in Korean?

  9. Order one coffee and ask if they take cards.

  10. Tell the server you don't eat meat and ask what they recommend.

Show Answers 1. 이 음식은 맛있어요 2. 삼겹살 2인분 주세요 3. 계산해 주세요 4. 잘 먹겠습니다 5. 국이 너무 매워요 6. 김치를 좋아해요 7. 차가운 물 주세요 or 시원한 물 주세요 8. 배불러요 9. 커피 한 잔 주세요. 카드 돼요? 10. 고기를 안 먹어요. 뭐 추천해 주세요? Or: 저는 고기를 못 먹는데요, 뭐가 좋아요?

docs.title: Common Places
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Category Examples Home/Living 집, 방, 아파트, 화장실 Education 학교, 대학교, 도서관, 교실 Work 회사, 사무실, 은행, 우체국 Healthcare 병원, 약국, 치과 Shopping 마트, 백화점, 시장, 편의점 Transportation 역, 공항, 버스 정류장, 주차장 Leisure 공원, 카페, 식당, 영화관

docs.title: General Housing
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 집 Home / House General term 아파트 Apartment Most common in Korea 빌라 Villa Small apartment building 방 Room Also 방 (room) 거실 Living room - 부엌 Kitchen Also 주방 화장실 Bathroom / Toilet - 침실 Bedroom - 현관 Entrance / Entryway -

Examples: - 집에 가요. (I'm going home.) - 아파트에 살아요. (I live in an apartment.) - 방이 세 개 있어요. (There are three rooms.) - 화장실이 어디예요? (Where's the bathroom?)

docs.title: Locations in Context
docs.text: 에 vs. 에서: - 에: Static location (being at) - 집에 있어요. (I'm at home.) - 에서: Action location (doing at) - 집에서 공부해요. (I study at home.)

docs.title: Schools
docs.text: Korean Meaning 학교 School 유치원 Kindergarten 초등학교 Elementary school 중학교 Middle school 고등학교 High school 대학교 University 학원 Private academy / Cram school

docs.title: School Locations
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 교실 Classroom 도서관 Library 강당 Auditorium 운동장 Playground / Sports field 식당 Cafeteria / Restaurant 강의실 Lecture hall

Examples: - 대학교에 다녀요. (I attend university.) - 도서관에서 공부해요. (I study at the library.) - 학원에 가요. (I'm going to the academy.)

docs.title: Work Locations
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 회사 Company 사무실 Office 공장 Factory 가게 Shop / Store 점 Store (suffix)

Examples: - 회사에 가요. (I'm going to work/company.) - 사무실에 있어요. (I'm in the office.)

docs.title: Service Facilities
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 은행 Bank 우체국 Post office 경찰서 Police station 소방서 Fire station 대사관 Embassy

Examples: - 은행에 가야 해요. (I have to go to the bank.) - 우체국이 어디예요? (Where's the post office?)

docs.title: Healthcare
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 병원 Hospital / Clinic General medical facility 약국 Pharmacy - 치과 Dentist - 한의원 Oriental medicine clinic Traditional Korean medicine 응급실 Emergency room -

Examples: - 병원에 가야 해요. (I need to go to the hospital.) - 약국에서 약을 사요. (I buy medicine at the pharmacy.) - 치과 예약이 있어요. (I have a dentist appointment.)

docs.title: Retail Locations
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 마트 Mart / Supermarket From "mart" 슈퍼 Supermarket Small convenience store 편의점 Convenience store 24/7 stores 백화점 Department store High-end 시장 Market Traditional market 쇼핑몰 Shopping mall -

Examples: - 마트에서 장을 봐요. (I do grocery shopping at the mart.) - 편의점에 갔어요. (I went to the convenience store.) - 시장이 더 싸요. (The market is cheaper.)

docs.title: Specific Shops
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 빵집 Bakery 서점 Bookstore 꽃집 Flower shop 미용실 Hair salon 세탁소 Laundromat / Dry cleaner 옷가게 Clothing store

Examples: - 빵집에서 빵을 샀어요. (I bought bread at the bakery.) - 서점에 가고 싶어요. (I want to go to the bookstore.)

docs.title: Stations and Terminals
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Notes 역 Station Train/subway station 지하철역 Subway station - 기차역 Train station - 버스 정류장 Bus stop - 공항 Airport - 터미널 Terminal Bus terminal 주차장 Parking lot -

Examples: - 역에서 만나요. (Let's meet at the station.) - 공항에 어떻게 가요? (How do you get to the airport?) - 버스 정류장이 어디예요? (Where's the bus stop?)

docs.title: Transportation Locations
docs.text: Korean Meaning 택시 정류장 Taxi stand 지하철 입구 Subway entrance 출구 Exit 입구 Entrance

docs.title: Dining and Cafes
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 식당 Restaurant 음식점 Restaurant (formal) 카페 Cafe 찻집 Tea house 술집 Bar / Pub 노래방 Karaoke room

Examples: - 식당에서 밥 먹어요. (I eat at a restaurant.) - 카페에서 커피 마셔요. (I drink coffee at a cafe.) - 노래방에 갈래요? (Do you want to go to karaoke?)

docs.title: Entertainment Venues
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 영화관 Movie theater / Cinema 극장 Theater 공연장 Performance hall 박물관 Museum 미술관 Art museum 놀이공원 Amusement park 동물원 Zoo

Examples: - 영화관에서 영화를 봐요. (I watch movies at the cinema.) - 박물관에 가고 싶어요. (I want to go to the museum.)

docs.title: Outdoor Spaces
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 공원 Park 산 Mountain 바다 Sea / Ocean 해변 Beach 강 River 호수 Lake

Examples: - 주말에 공원에 가요. (I go to the park on weekends.) - 산에 올라가요. (I climb mountains.) - 바다에서 수영해요. (I swim in the sea.)

docs.title: Sports and Fitness
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 체육관 Gym 헬스장 Fitness center 수영장 Swimming pool 운동장 Sports field 테니스장 Tennis court

Examples: - 헬스장에 다녀요. (I go to the gym.) - 수영장에서 운동해요. (I exercise at the pool.)

docs.title: Religious Places
docs.text: Korean Meaning 교회 Church 성당 Catholic church 절 Buddhist temple 사찰 Temple 성당 Cathedral

docs.title: Public Facilities
docs.text:
Korean Meaning 시청 City hall 구청 District office 관공서 Government office 주민센터 Community center 출입국관리사무소 Immigration office

Examples: - 구청에 가야 해요. (I have to go to the district office.) - 주민센터에서 등록해요. (I register at the community center.)

docs.title: Common Patterns
docs.text:
가다 (to go): - [place] + 에 가다 - 학교에 가요. (I go to school.)

오다 (to come): - [place] + 에서 오다 - 집에서 왔어요. (I came from home.)

있다 (to be at): - [place] + 에 있다 - 도서관에 있어요. (I'm at the library.)

하다 (to do): - [place] + 에서 하다 - 공원에서 운동해요. (I exercise at the park.)

docs.title: Direction Particles
docs.text:
• 에: to, at (destination/location)
  • 에서: from, at (origin/action location)
  • 로: toward, by way of (direction)
  • 까지: until, to (endpoint)

Examples: - 학교에 가요. (I go to school.) - 학교에서 와요. (I come from school.) - 학교로 가요. (I go toward school.) - 학교까지 걸어가요. (I walk to/until school.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How do you say "Where's the bathroom?" in Korean?

  2. Translate: "I go to the library every day."

  3. How do you say "I'm at home" in Korean?

  4. Ask where the nearest convenience store is.

  5. How do you say "Let's meet at the subway station"?

  6. Translate: "I study at a cafe."

  7. How do you say "I need to go to the hospital"?

  8. Ask how to get to the airport.

  9. Say "I'm going to the market to shop."

  10. Translate: "The bank is next to the post office."

Show Answers 1. 화장실이 어디예요? 2. 매일 도서관에 가요 or 저는 매일 도서관에 가요 3. 집에 있어요 4. 가까운 편의점이 어디예요? or 제일 가까운 편의점이 어디예요? 5. 지하철역에서 만나요 or 지하철역에서 만날까요? 6. 카페에서 공부해요 7. 병원에 가야 해요 8. 공항에 어떻게 가요? 9. 시장에 장보러 가요 or 마트에 쇼핑하러 가요 10. 은행이 우체국 옆에 있어요

docs.title: 50 Essential Verbs
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Category Key Verbs Daily Actions 가다, 오다, 먹다, 자다, 일어나다 Communication 말하다, 듣다, 보다, 읽다, 쓰다 Activities 하다, 공부하다, 일하다, 운동하다 States 있다, 없다, 알다, 모르다 Likes/Wants 좋아하다, 싫어하다, 원하다

docs.title: Movement Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 가다 to go 가요 학교에 가요 (I go to school) 오다 to come 와요 친구가 와요 (My friend comes) 걷다 to walk 걸어요 공원에서 걸어요 (I walk in the park) 뛰다 to run 뛰어요 빨리 뛰어요 (I run fast) 타다 to ride 타요 버스를 타요 (I ride the bus) 나가다 to go out 나가요 밖에 나가요 (I go outside) 들어가다 to go in 들어가요 방에 들어가요 (I go into the room) 들어오다 to come in 들어와요 들어와요! (Come in!) 서다 to stand 서요 거기 서요 (Stand there) 앉다 to sit 앉아요 의자에 앉아요 (I sit on the chair) 눕다 to lie down 누워요 침대에 누워요 (I lie on the bed)

Usage Examples: - 내일 학교에 가요. (I go to school tomorrow.) - 친구가 집에 왔어요. (My friend came to my house.) - 매일 30분 걸어요. (I walk 30 minutes every day.) - 버스를 타고 회사에 가요. (I take the bus and go to work.)

docs.title: Daily Life Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 먹다 to eat 먹어요 밥을 먹어요 (I eat rice/meal) 마시다 to drink 마셔요 물을 마셔요 (I drink water) 자다 to sleep 자요 밤에 자요 (I sleep at night) 일어나다 to wake up 일어나요 아침에 일어나요 (I wake up in the morning) 씻다 to wash 씻어요 손을 씻어요 (I wash my hands) 샤워하다 to shower 샤워해요 매일 샤워해요 (I shower every day) 입다 to wear 입어요 옷을 입어요 (I wear clothes) 벗다 to take off 벗어요 신발을 벗어요 (I take off shoes) 신다 to wear (shoes) 신어요 신발을 신어요 (I put on shoes) 쓰다 to wear (hat) 써요 모자를 써요 (I wear a hat)

Usage Examples: - 아침 먹었어요? (Did you eat breakfast?) - 커피를 마시고 싶어요. (I want to drink coffee.) - 어제 일찍 잤어요. (I slept early yesterday.) - 보통 7시에 일어나요. (I usually wake up at 7.)

docs.title: Communication Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 말하다 to speak 말해요 한국어를 말해요 (I speak Korean) 이야기하다 to talk 이야기해요 친구랑 이야기해요 (I talk with friends) 듣다 to listen/hear 들어요 음악을 들어요 (I listen to music) 보다 to see/watch 봐요 영화를 봐요 (I watch movies) 읽다 to read 읽어요 책을 읽어요 (I read books) 쓰다 to write 써요 편지를 써요 (I write letters) 묻다 to ask 물어요 질문을 물어요 (I ask questions) 대답하다 to answer 대답해요 질문에 대답해요 (I answer questions) 전화하다 to call 전화해요 친구한테 전화해요 (I call my friend) 문자하다 to text 문자해요 문자해요 (I text)

Usage Examples: - 천천히 말해 주세요. (Please speak slowly.) - 뭐라고 했어요? 못 들었어요. (What did you say? I didn't hear.) - 무슨 책을 읽어요? (What book are you reading?) - 매일 일기를 써요. (I write a diary every day.)

docs.title: Activity Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 하다 to do 해요 숙제를 해요 (I do homework) 공부하다 to study 공부해요 한국어를 공부해요 (I study Korean) 일하다 to work 일해요 회사에서 일해요 (I work at a company) 운동하다 to exercise 운동해요 매일 운동해요 (I exercise daily) 요리하다 to cook 요리해요 저녁을 요리해요 (I cook dinner) 청소하다 to clean 청소해요 방을 청소해요 (I clean the room) 빨래하다 to do laundry 빨래해요 주말에 빨래해요 (I do laundry on weekends) 쇼핑하다 to shop 쇼핑해요 백화점에서 쇼핑해요 (I shop at the department store) 여행하다 to travel 여행해요 여름에 여행해요 (I travel in summer) 놀다 to play/hang out 놀아요 친구랑 놀아요 (I hang out with friends)

Usage Examples: - 뭐 해요? (What are you doing?) - 도서관에서 공부해요. (I study at the library.) - 주말에 뭐 했어요? (What did you do on the weekend?) - 운동 좋아해요? (Do you like exercising?)

docs.title: Existence and Knowledge Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 있다 to exist/have 있어요 시간이 있어요 (I have time) 없다 to not exist/not have 없어요 돈이 없어요 (I don't have money) 살다 to live 살아요 서울에 살아요 (I live in Seoul) 알다 to know 알아요 그 사람을 알아요 (I know that person) 모르다 to not know 몰라요 잘 몰라요 (I don't know well) 배우다 to learn 배워요 한국어를 배워요 (I learn Korean) 가르치다 to teach 가르쳐요 영어를 가르쳐요 (I teach English)

Usage Examples: - 형제가 있어요? (Do you have siblings?) - 지금 시간 없어요. (I don't have time now.) - 어디에 살아요? (Where do you live?) - 한국어를 알아요? (Do you know Korean?)

docs.title: Emotion and Preference Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 좋아하다 to like 좋아해요 음악을 좋아해요 (I like music) 싫어하다 to dislike 싫어해요 매운 음식을 싫어해요 (I dislike spicy food) 사랑하다 to love 사랑해요 가족을 사랑해요 (I love my family) 원하다 to want 원해요 휴식을 원해요 (I want rest) 바라다 to hope/wish 바라요 건강하기를 바라요 (I hope you're healthy)

Usage Examples: - 무엇을 좋아해요? (What do you like?) - 김치를 싫어해요. (I dislike kimchi.) - 뭐 먹고 싶어요? (What do you want to eat?)

docs.title: Transaction Verbs
docs.text:
Korean Meaning Polite Form Example 사다 to buy 사요 옷을 사요 (I buy clothes) 팔다 to sell 팔아요 물건을 팔아요 (I sell things) 주다 to give 줘요 선물을 줘요 (I give a gift) 받다 to receive 받아요 편지를 받아요 (I receive a letter) 만들다 to make 만들어요 케이크를 만들어요 (I make a cake)

Usage Examples: - 어디에서 샀어요? (Where did you buy it?) - 생일 선물을 줬어요. (I gave a birthday present.) - 누구한테 받았어요? (Who did you receive it from?)

docs.title: 하다 Verbs
docs.text: Many Korean verbs are formed by adding 하다 to a noun: - 공부 (study) + 하다 = 공부하다 (to study) - 운동 (exercise) + 하다 = 운동하다 (to exercise) - 요리 (cooking) + 하다 = 요리하다 (to cook)

docs.title: Irregular Verbs
docs.text: Some common verbs are irregular: - 듣다 (to listen) → 들어요 - 묻다 (to ask) → 물어요 - 걷다 (to walk) → 걸어요 - 눕다 (to lie down) → 누워요

docs.title: Object Particles
docs.text: Most verbs take objects with particles: - 을/를: Object particle - 밥을 먹어요 (eat rice) - 영화를 봐요 (watch a movie)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. How do you say "I go to school" in Korean?

  2. Translate: "I eat breakfast every morning."

  3. How do you say "I don't know" in casual polite form?

  4. Say "I study Korean at home" in Korean.

  5. How do you ask "What are you doing?" in Korean?

  6. Translate: "I listen to music every day."

  7. How do you say "I have an older sister" in Korean?

  8. Say "I want to watch a movie" in Korean.

  9. How do you say "I bought clothes yesterday"?

  10. Translate: "I live in Seoul and work at a company."

Show Answers 1. 학교에 가요 or 저는 학교에 가요 2. 매일 아침 아침을 먹어요 or 매일 아침에 밥을 먹어요 3. 몰라요 or 모르겠어요 4. 집에서 한국어를 공부해요 5. 뭐 해요? 6. 매일 음악을 들어요 7. 언니가 있어요 (female speaker) or 누나가 있어요 (male speaker) 8. 영화를 보고 싶어요 9. 어제 옷을 샀어요 10. 서울에 살고 회사에서 일해요

docs.title: Elementary Level (초급)
docs.text: Welcome to the Elementary level of Korean learning. At this stage, you'll expand your communication abilities by learning how to connect ideas, express conditions, and use various verb forms that are essential for everyday conversation.

docs.title: Sentence Connectors (01-connectors)
docs.text:
Master the art of linking sentences and clauses to create more natural, flowing Korean:

  • And connector (-고): Connect sequential and simultaneous actions
  • Because/Reason (-서 vs -니까): Express cause and reason with nuanced differences
  • But/Contrast (-지만 vs -는데): Show contrast and set context appropriately
  • If/Conditional (-면): Express conditions and hypothetical situations
  • When/Time (-을 때, -자마자, -고 나서): Describe timing relationships

docs.title: Verb Forms (02-verb-forms)
docs.text:
Express desires, abilities, and experiences:

  • Want to (-고 싶다): Express personal desires and observe others' wants
  • Can/Cannot (-ㄹ 수 있다/없다): Discuss ability and possibility with precision
  • Try to (-아/어 보다): Talk about experiences and attempts

docs.title: Learning Approach
docs.text:
At the Elementary level, focus on:

  1. Nuanced differences: Many Korean grammar patterns seem similar but carry different nuances. Pay attention to the subtle distinctions.
  2. Natural flow: These patterns help you move beyond choppy, simple sentences to more natural speech.
  3. Context awareness: Korean grammar is highly context-dependent. Learn when each pattern is most appropriate.
  4. Practice combinations: Try combining multiple patterns as you become comfortable with each one.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting this level, you should be comfortable with:

  • Hangul reading and writing
  • Basic sentence structure (subject-object-verb)
  • Present, past, and future tenses
  • Basic particles (이/가, 은/는, 을/를)
  • Informal polite speech level (요 form)

docs.title: Navigation
docs.text:
Start with connectors to build your sentence-linking abilities, then move to verb forms to express more complex ideas. Each section includes detailed explanations, comparisons, examples, and practice exercises.

Ready to begin? Start with Sentence Connectors!

docs.title: Sentence Connectors (연결어미)
docs.text: Sentence connectors are grammatical endings that link clauses together, allowing you to express complex ideas in a single flowing sentence. They are essential for natural Korean speech and writing.

docs.title: Why Connectors Matter
docs.text:
In Korean, stringing together multiple simple sentences sounds choppy and unnatural:

Choppy: 저는 집에 갔어요. 저는 밥을 먹었어요. Natural: 저는 집에 가서 밥을 먹었어요.

Connectors create the flow that native speakers use constantly in everyday conversation.

docs.title: Sequential and Simultaneous Actions
docs.text:
• -고: Links actions in sequence or happening at the same time
  • Learn about: And Connector

docs.title: Cause and Reason
docs.text:
• -서: Natural consequence, objective reason
  • -니까: Subjective reason, stronger connection to the result
  • Learn about: Because Connector

docs.title: Contrast and Background
docs.text:
• -지만: Direct contrast, "but/however"
  • -는데: Sets context, softer contrast, introduces background information
  • Learn about: But Connector

docs.title: Conditions
docs.text:
• -면: General conditional "if"
  • -다면: Hypothetical "if it were"
  • -(으)려면: "If you intend to/in order to"
  • Learn about: If Connector

docs.title: Timing
docs.text:
• -을 때: "When" (at the time of)
  • -자마자: "As soon as"
  • -고 나서: "After doing"
  • Learn about: When Connector

docs.title: Common Patterns
docs.text:
Most connectors attach to verb stems and follow predictable patterns:

  1. Verb stem + connector ending
  2. Some require different forms based on tense
  3. Consonant vs vowel endings may differ

docs.title: Learning Strategy
docs.text:
1. Start with -고 and -서 as they're the most frequently used
  2. Master the nuanced differences between similar connectors (-서 vs -니까, -지만 vs -는데)
  3. Practice each connector in multiple contexts
  4. Listen for these patterns in Korean media to understand natural usage

docs.title: Important Notes
docs.text:
• The first clause with a connector typically does NOT take tense markers (past/future)
  • The tense is usually shown only in the final verb of the sentence
  • Some connectors can be used in both formal and informal situations, while others are more restricted

Ready to start? Begin with the And Connector (-고)!

docs.title: And Connector: -고
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern: Verb stem + 고 Meaning: "and" (sequential or simultaneous actions) Formation: Works with all verbs regardless of final consonant Example: 가다 → 가고, 먹다 → 먹고, 읽다 → 읽고

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text:
The -고 connector is one of the most versatile and commonly used connectors in Korean. It links two actions or states that are related, showing either:

  1. Sequential actions: First action, then second action
  2. Simultaneous actions: Both actions happening at the same time
  3. Simple listing: Two or more facts/states without strong time relationship

docs.title: Formation Rules
docs.text:
-고 is one of the simplest connectors:

  1. Take the verb stem (remove 다)
  2. Add 고
  3. No changes based on vowels or consonants

Examples: - 가다 (to go) → 가고 - 먹다 (to eat) → 먹고 - 읽다 (to read) → 읽고 - 마시다 (to drink) → 마시고 - 듣다 (to listen) → 듣고

docs.title: 1. Sequential Actions (이어진 동작)
docs.text:
Actions that happen one after another:

  • 학교에 가고 친구를 만났어요. I went to school and met a friend.

  • 손을 씻고 밥을 먹어요. I wash my hands and eat.

docs.title: 2. Simultaneous Actions (동시 동작)
docs.text:
Actions happening at the same time:

  • 음악을 듣고 공부해요. I study while listening to music.

  • 커피를 마시고 이야기해요. Let's talk while drinking coffee.

docs.title: 3. Simple Listing (나열)
docs.text:
Listing characteristics or facts:

  • 그 사람은 키가 크고 잘생겼어요. That person is tall and handsome.

  • 이 방은 넓고 깨끗해요. This room is spacious and clean.

docs.title: Tense and -고
docs.text:
The -고 clause does NOT take tense markers. Tense is shown only in the final verb:

  • ❌ 집에 갔고 밥을 먹었어요.
  • ✓ 집에 가고 밥을 먹었어요. I went home and ate.

docs.title: Multiple -고 in One Sentence
docs.text:
You can chain multiple -고 connectors:

  • 아침에 일어나고 샤워하고 옷을 입고 학교에 가요. I wake up in the morning, shower, get dressed, and go to school.

docs.title: -고 with 있다/계시다
docs.text:
-고 있다 forms the present progressive (currently doing):

  • 지금 밥을 먹고 있어요. I am eating now. (Note: This is a different pattern, not a simple connector)

docs.title: -고 vs -아서/어서
docs.text:
Both can connect actions, but with differences:

Feature -고 -아서/어서 Relationship Loose connection Cause-effect Order Can sometimes swap Cannot swap order Imperative Can be used Cannot be used

Examples: - 밥을 먹고 갔어요. (I ate and went - sequential) - 밥을 먹어서 갔어요. (I ate, so I went - implies eating was the reason for being able to go)

docs.title: Sequential Actions
docs.text:
1. 영화를 보고 저녁을 먹었어요. I watched a movie and had dinner.

  2. 숙제를 하고 친구한테 전화했어요. I did homework and called a friend.

  3. 편의점에 가고 우유를 샀어요. I went to the convenience store and bought milk.

docs.title: Simultaneous Actions
docs.text:
1. 텔레비전을 보고 밥을 먹어요. I eat while watching TV.

  2. 노래를 부르고 춤을 춰요. I sing and dance (at the same time).

docs.title: Listing
docs.text:
1. 이 가방은 예쁘고 싸요. This bag is pretty and cheap.

  2. 오늘 날씨가 춥고 바람이 많이 불어요. Today the weather is cold and it's very windy.

  3. 저는 학생이고 동생도 학생이에요. I am a student and my younger sibling is also a student.

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Connect: 저는 한국어를 공부하다 + 친구는 일본어를 공부하다 (use -고)

  2. Fill in the blank: 아침에 일어나___ 커피를 마셔요.

  3. Make one sentence: 도서관에 갔어요. 책을 읽었어요.

  4. Connect: 이 음식은 맛있다 + 이 음식은 건강해요

  5. Translate: I exercised and took a shower. (운동하다, 샤워하다)

  6. Fix the error: 어제 영화를 봤고 재미있었어요.

  7. Connect three actions: 일어나다 + 씻다 + 학교에 가다

  8. Fill in: 그 사람은 친절하___ 똑똑해요.

  9. Create a sentence using -고 with simultaneous actions (음악을 듣다, 걷다)

  10. Translate: This coffee is hot and delicious. (뜨겁다, 맛있다)

Show Answers 1. 저는 한국어를 공부하고 친구는 일본어를 공부해요. *I study Korean and my friend studies Japanese.* 2. 아침에 일어나**고** 커피를 마셔요. *I wake up in the morning and drink coffee.* 3. 도서관에 가고 책을 읽었어요. *I went to the library and read a book.* (Note: Past tense only on the final verb) 4. 이 음식은 맛있고 건강해요. *This food is delicious and healthy.* 5. 운동하고 샤워했어요. *I exercised and took a shower.* 6. **Corrected**: 어제 영화를 보고 재미있었어요. *Yesterday I watched a movie and it was fun.* (Explanation: Don't use past tense marker on -고 clause) 7. 아침에 일어나고 씻고 학교에 가요. *I wake up in the morning, wash up, and go to school.* 8. 그 사람은 친절하**고** 똑똑해요. *That person is kind and smart.* 9. 음악을 듣고 걸어요. / 음악을 들으면서 걸어요. *I walk while listening to music.* (Note: -으면서 is more precise for simultaneous actions) 10. 이 커피는 뜨겁고 맛있어요. *This coffee is hot and delicious.*

docs.title: Because Connector: -서 vs -니까
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern 1: Verb stem + 아서/어서/여서 Pattern 2: Verb stem + (으)니까 Meaning: "because, so, since" Key Difference: -서 = natural consequence, objective | -니까 = subjective reason, justification

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Both -서 and -니까 express cause and reason, but they have important nuanced differences in usage, formality, and the relationship between clauses.

docs.title: -아서/어서/여서
docs.text:
Follow vowel harmony rules:

  1. Stem ends in 아 or 오 → 아서
  2. 가다 → 가서

  3. 좋다 → 좋아서

  4. Stem ends in other vowels → 어서

  5. 먹다 → 먹어서

  6. 읽다 → 읽어서

  7. 하다 verbs → 여서 (often contracts to 해서)

  8. 공부하다 → 공부하여서 → 공부해서

docs.title: -(으)니까
docs.text:
Based on final consonant:

  1. Stem ends in vowel or ㄹ → 니까
  2. 가다 → 가니까

  3. 만들다 → 만드니까 (ㄹ drops)

  4. Stem ends in consonant → 으니까

  5. 먹다 → 먹으니까
  6. 읽다 → 읽으니까

docs.title: 1. Subjectivity Level
docs.text:
-서: Objective, natural consequence - States facts and obvious connections - The result follows naturally from the cause

-니까: Subjective reasoning, justification - Speaker's interpretation or reasoning - Often used when explaining or justifying

Examples: - 비가 와서 길이 젖었어요. It rained, so the street is wet. (natural consequence)

  • 비가 오니까 우산을 가져가세요. Since it's raining, take an umbrella. (speaker's suggestion based on rain)

docs.title: 2. Commands and Suggestions
docs.text:
-서: CANNOT be used with commands, suggestions, or requests in the second clause

-니까: CAN be used with commands, suggestions, or requests

  • ❌ 추워서 창문을 닫으세요.

  • ✓ 추우니까 창문을 닫으세요. It's cold, so please close the window.

  • ❌ 늦어서 빨리 가세요.

  • ✓ 늦으니까 빨리 가세요. We're late, so please go quickly.

docs.title: 3. Speaker's New Realization
docs.text:
-니까: Can express a new realization or discovery -서: Does not carry this meaning

  • 집에 가니까 아무도 없었어요. When I went home, (I found/realized) no one was there.

docs.title: 4. Formality and Strength
docs.text: -니까: Stronger, more direct, can sound formal or assertive -서: Softer, more natural in casual conversation

docs.title: 5. Question Form
docs.text:
-니까: Can be used in questions (asking for the listener's reason) -서: Cannot be used in questions

  • 왜 학교에 안 가니까? Why aren't you going to school?

docs.title: Objective Cause and Effect
docs.text:
1. 배가 고파서 밥을 먹었어요. I was hungry, so I ate.

  2. 너무 피곤해서 일찍 잤어요. I was very tired, so I slept early.

  3. 시간이 없어서 택시를 타야 해요. I don't have time, so I have to take a taxi.

docs.title: Natural Consequences
docs.text:
1. 열심히 공부해서 시험을 잘 봤어요. I studied hard, so I did well on the exam.

  2. 어제 많이 걸어서 다리가 아파요. I walked a lot yesterday, so my legs hurt.

docs.title: With Commands/Suggestions
docs.text:
1. 위험하니까 조심하세요. It's dangerous, so please be careful.

  2. 맛있으니까 많이 드세요. It's delicious, so please eat a lot.

docs.title: Justifications/Explanations
docs.text:
1. 제가 한국 사람이니까 한국어를 잘해요. Since I'm Korean, I speak Korean well.

  2. 여기가 우리 집이니까 편하게 있으세요. Since this is our house, please be comfortable.

docs.title: New Realizations
docs.text: 1. 가방을 열어 보니까 지갑이 없었어요. When I opened my bag, (I found) my wallet wasn't there.

docs.title: Comparison Chart
docs.text: Feature -아서/어서 -(으)니까 Objectivity Objective, factual Subjective, interpretive With commands ✗ Cannot use ✓ Can use With suggestions ✗ Cannot use ✓ Can use In questions ✗ Cannot use ✓ Can use Formality Neutral, softer Can be formal/assertive Realization ✗ No ✓ Yes Natural consequence ✓ Yes ✓ Yes

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Fill in the blank (choose -서 or -니까): 날씨가 좋___ 산책하러 갔어요.

  2. Which is correct for a command?: a) 위험해서 하지 마세요. b) 위험하니까 하지 마세요.

  3. Connect with -서: 어제 바빴다 + 친구를 못 만났어요.

  4. Connect with -니까: 비가 오다 + 우산을 가져가세요.

  5. Explain why this is wrong: 시간이 없어서 빨리 가세요.

  6. Translate using -서: I didn't have money, so I couldn't buy it. (돈이 없다, 사다)

  7. Translate using -니까: It's late, so please go home. (늦다, 집에 가다)

  8. Which should you use?: 문을 열다 + (I realized) 고양이가 있었어요.

  9. Create a sentence with -서 expressing natural consequence (비가 오다, 길이 미끄럽다)

  10. Create a sentence with -니까 giving a suggestion (피곤하다, 쉬다)

Show Answers 1. 날씨가 좋**아서** 산책하러 갔어요. *The weather was nice, so I went for a walk.* (Explanation: Natural consequence, no command/suggestion) 2. **b) 위험하니까 하지 마세요.** *It's dangerous, so please don't do it.* (Explanation: Commands require -니까) 3. 어제 바빠서 친구를 못 만났어요. *I was busy yesterday, so I couldn't meet my friend.* 4. 비가 오니까 우산을 가져가세요. *It's raining, so please take an umbrella.* (Explanation: Suggestion requires -니까) 5. **Error explanation**: Commands and suggestions cannot use -서. It should be: 시간이 없으니까 빨리 가세요. 6. 돈이 없어서 살 수 없었어요. / 돈이 없어서 못 샀어요. *I didn't have money, so I couldn't buy it.* 7. 늦으니까 집에 가세요. *It's late, so please go home.* 8. **-니까** should be used: 문을 여니까 고양이가 있었어요. *When I opened the door, (I found) there was a cat.* (Explanation: Expressing new realization) 9. 비가 와서 길이 미끄러워요. *It's raining, so the road is slippery.* 10. 피곤하니까 좀 쉬세요. *You're tired, so please rest.* (Alternative: 피곤하니까 쉬는 게 좋아요. *Since you're tired, it's better to rest.*)

docs.title: But Connector: -지만 vs -는데
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern 1: Verb stem + 지만 = "but, however" (direct contrast) Pattern 2: Verb stem + 는데/은데/ㄴ데 = "but, and, while" (context setting, softer contrast) Key Difference: -지만 = sharp contrast | -는데 = background info, softer contrast, multi-purpose

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Both -지만 and -는데 can express contrast, but -는데 is far more versatile and carries different nuances depending on context. Understanding when to use each is crucial for natural Korean speech.

docs.title: -지만
docs.text:
Simple formation for all verbs:

  1. All verbs/adjectives: Stem + 지만
  2. 가다 → 가지만
  3. 먹다 → 먹지만
  4. 좋다 → 좋지만
  5. 학생이다 → 학생이지만

docs.title: -는데/은데/ㄴ데
docs.text:
Complex formation based on verb type and tense:

Present Tense:

  1. Action verbs (vowel/ㄹ ending) → 는데
  2. 가다 → 가는데

  3. 만들다 → 만드는데

  4. Action verbs (consonant ending) → 는데

  5. 먹다 → 먹는데

  6. 읽다 → 읽는데

  7. Descriptive verbs/adjectives (vowel ending) → ㄴ데

  8. 크다 → 큰데

  9. 비싸다 → 비싼데

  10. Descriptive verbs/adjectives (consonant ending) → 은데

  11. 작다 → 작은데

  12. 좋다 → 좋은데

  13. Nouns → 인데

  14. 학생 → 학생인데

Past Tense: All types → 았는데/었는데/였는데 - 갔는데, 먹었는데, 공부했는데

docs.title: 1. Contrast Strength
docs.text:
-지만: Direct, clear-cut contrast (A but B) - Strong opposition between clauses - Similar to English "but" or "however"

-는데: Softer contrast, often providing background - Less confrontational - More flexible in meaning

Examples: - 비싸지만 샀어요. It was expensive, but I bought it. (clear opposition)

  • 비싼데 샀어요. It's expensive, but/and I bought it. (softer, could imply surprise or just providing info)

docs.title: 2. Multiple Functions of -는데
docs.text: Unlike -지만 (which only shows contrast), -는데 has several functions:

docs.title: A. Background Information
docs.text:
Setting the scene for the main clause:

  • 저는 학생인데, 무엇을 도와드릴까요? I'm a student, (so) what can I help you with?

docs.title: B. Softer Contrast
docs.text:
Less confrontational than -지만:

  • 한국 음식을 좋아하는데 매운 음식은 못 먹어요. I like Korean food, but I can't eat spicy food.

docs.title: C. Asking Questions Politely
docs.text:
-는데 can soften questions, making them less direct:

  • 지금 시간 있으신데 같이 갈까요? You have time now, so shall we go together?

docs.title: D. Expressing Surprise or Unexpectedness
docs.text:
When the second clause is surprising:

  • 어제 공부를 안 했는데 시험을 잘 봤어요. I didn't study yesterday, but (surprisingly) I did well on the exam.

docs.title: E. Trailing Off (Unfinished Sentences)
docs.text:
-는데 can end a sentence, leaving the implication unsaid:

  • 배가 고픈데... I'm hungry (and... [implying: let's eat, what should we do?])

  • 미안한데... I'm sorry but... [implying: I have a request or problem]

docs.title: 3. Formality
docs.text: -지만: Neutral formality, widely used -는데: Slightly more casual, very common in spoken Korean

docs.title: 4. Sentence Ending
docs.text: -지만: Rarely ends sentences (needs a second clause) -는데: Can end sentences (especially in conversation)

docs.title: Using -지만 (Direct Contrast)
docs.text:
1. 한국어는 어렵지만 재미있어요. Korean is difficult, but it's fun.

  2. 피곤하지만 숙제를 해야 해요. I'm tired, but I have to do homework.

  3. 이 음식은 맛없지만 건강에 좋아요. This food doesn't taste good, but it's healthy.

  4. 돈이 없지만 행복해요. I don't have money, but I'm happy.

docs.title: Background Information
docs.text:
1. 내일 시험이 있는데 같이 공부할래요? I have an exam tomorrow, (so) do you want to study together?

  2. 저는 서울에 사는데, 고향은 부산이에요. I live in Seoul, (but/and) my hometown is Busan.

docs.title: Softer Contrast
docs.text:
1. 가고 싶은데 시간이 없어요. I want to go, but I don't have time.

  2. 맛있는데 너무 비싸요. It's delicious, but it's too expensive.

docs.title: Surprise/Unexpectedness
docs.text:
1. 날씨가 추운데 반팔을 입었어요. The weather is cold, but (surprisingly) I wore short sleeves.

  2. 한국에 온 지 한 달밖에 안 됐는데 한국어를 잘하네요. You've only been in Korea for a month, but (surprisingly) you speak Korean well.

docs.title: Trailing Off
docs.text:
1. 저기요, 실례지만... (실례인데...) Excuse me, I'm sorry but...

  2. 좀 피곤한데... (쉬고 싶다는 뉘앙스) I'm a bit tired... (implying: I want to rest)

docs.title: Comparison Chart
docs.text: Feature -지만 -는데 Contrast type Direct, strong Soft, flexible Background info ✗ No ✓ Yes Can end sentence ✗ Rare ✓ Common Formality Neutral Slightly casual Question use Limited ✓ Polite questions Functions Contrast only Multiple uses Formation Simple Complex (tense/type dependent)

docs.title: When to Choose Which
docs.text:
Use -지만 when: - You want clear, unambiguous contrast - A truly contradicts B - Writing formal documents

Use -는데 when: - Providing background information - Making polite requests or questions - Expressing surprise - Speaking conversationally - Wanting a softer, less confrontational tone

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Fill in the blank (choose -지만 or -는데): 이 가방은 작___ 많이 들어가요.

  2. Which is more natural for background info?: a) 저는 학생이지만 도와드릴게요. b) 저는 학생인데 도와드릴게요.

  3. Connect with -지만: 비가 오다 + 우산이 없어요.
