1. Complete with the most appropriate particle: 저는 어머니 ______ 시장에 갔어요. (I went to the market with my mother.) [neutral/polite]

  2. Complete: 사과 ______ 배를 샀습니다. (I bought apples and pears.) [formal writing]

  3. Which is most casual: (a) 친구와 (b) 친구하고 (c) 친구랑?

  4. Complete: 오빠 ______ 게임했어. (I played games with my older brother.) [casual]

  5. Fix the formality: In a business email, "고객님하고 미팅" should be changed to...?

  6. Translate (neutral): I studied with my friend.

  7. Complete: 한국어 ______ 영어를 공부해요. (I study Korean and English.) [neutral]

  8. Which 받침 rule applies to 랑? (a) 랑 for no 받침 (b) 랑 for 받침

  9. Create a sentence using 하고 to list three things you need to buy.

  10. Rewrite this sentence in casual form: 저는 친구와 저녁을 먹었어요.

Show Answers 1. 하고 (neutral/polite, appropriate for everyday conversation about family) Note: 랑 would also be acceptable if speaking very casually 2. 와 or 과 - 사과와 배를 샀습니다. (formal, no 받침) Note: If you wanted to use both, it would be different fruits, but the question asks for one particle 3. (c) 친구랑 is most casual 4. 랑 or 이랑 - 오빠랑 게임했어. (casual, no 받침 on 오빠) 5. 고객님과 미팅 or 고객님과의 미팅 (Use formal 과 instead of neutral 하고 in business contexts) 6. 저는 친구하고 공부했어요. Alternative: 친구하고 같이 공부했어요. (with 같이 "together") 7. 하고 8. (a) is partially correct - the rule is: - 랑 for nouns without 받침 - 이랑 for nouns with 받침 9. Example answers: - 빵하고 우유하고 계란을 사야 해요. (I need to buy bread, milk, and eggs.) - 사과하고 바나나하고 포도를 살 거예요. (I'm going to buy apples, bananas, and grapes.) - 노트하고 펜하고 책을 사야 돼요. (I need to buy a notebook, pen, and book.) 10. 나는 친구랑 저녁 먹었어. Alternative: 저는 친구랑 저녁을 먹었어요. (slightly less casual) Changes made: - 저는 → 나는 or keep 저는 (depending on casualness level) - 와 → 랑 (casual particle) - 먹었어요 → 먹었어 (casual ending)

docs.title: Korean Speech Levels Overview
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Korean has 7 traditional speech levels, simplified to 4 practical levels in modern usage: - 격식체 (Formal Polite): 합쇼체 - 합니다/습니다 (public speeches, formal situations) - 비격식체 (Informal Polite): 해요체 - 해요/아요/어요 (most common, everyday polite) - 비격식체 (Informal Casual): 해체 - 해/아/어 (반말, friends, family, younger people) - 격식체 (Formal Casual): 하게체 - 하게 (rare, elderly to younger adults)

docs.title: Understanding Speech Levels
docs.text: Speech levels (높임말/반말) are one of the most distinctive features of Korean. They reflect social relationships, age, status, and context. Using the appropriate level is crucial for natural, respectful communication.

docs.title: The Traditional Seven Levels
docs.text:
Historically, Korean has seven speech levels, but modern usage focuses on three main levels:

  1. 합쇼체 (Formal Polite) - -습니다/ㅂ니다
  2. 해요체 (Informal Polite) - -아요/어요/해요
  3. 해체 (Informal Casual/반말) - -아/어/해

Less common levels: 4. 하게체 - Used by elderly to younger adults 5. 하오체 - Archaic formal 6. 하게체 - Archaic 7. 해라체 - Commands, writing

docs.title: Modern Practical Levels
docs.text: For learners, focus on these three:

docs.title: 1. 합쇼체 (Formal Polite)
docs.text:
Endings: -습니다/ㅂ니다 (statement), -습니까/ㅂ니까 (question)

When to use: - News broadcasts - Public announcements - Business presentations - Meeting someone very senior - Military/police contexts - Formal speeches

Formality: Very high Distance: Creates respectful distance

docs.title: 2. 해요체 (Informal Polite)
docs.text:
Endings: -아요/어요/해요

When to use: - Daily conversations with strangers - Service interactions (stores, restaurants) - Talking to colleagues - Speaking to someone older you don't know well - Most versatile and common level

Formality: Medium-high (polite but friendly) Distance: Respectful but approachable

docs.title: 3. 해체 (Informal Casual/반말)
docs.text:
Endings: -아/어/해, -다

When to use: - Close friends of similar age - Speaking to younger people/children - Family members (varies by family) - Between couples - After mutual agreement to use 반말

Formality: Low (casual, friendly) Distance: Close, intimate

docs.title: Hierarchy of Formality
docs.text:
Most Formal
    ↑
합쇼체 (-습니다/ㅂ니다)
    |
해요체 (-아요/어요/해요) ← Default for most situations
    |
해체 (-아/어/해) 반말
    ↓
Least Formal

docs.title: Key Factors in Choosing Speech Levels
docs.text:
1. Age (나이) - Older person: Use polite forms (해요체 or 합쇼체) - Same age/younger: Can use 반말 after establishing rapport - Korean age vs international age matters

2. Social Status (지위) - Boss, teacher, senior: Use polite forms - Colleague of same rank: Usually 해요체 - Junior/subordinate: 해요체 or 반말 depending on relationship

3. Relationship (관계) - Strangers: Always 해요체 or higher - Acquaintances: 해요체 - Close friends: 반말 - Family: Varies (often 반말 to younger, 해요체 to elders)

4. Context (상황) - Formal settings: 합쇼체 - Casual settings: 해요체 or 반말 - Professional settings: 해요체 or 합쇼체

docs.title: Mixing Speech Levels (존댓말/반말)
docs.text:
Don't mix within the same conversation partner: - ❌ 뭐 해요? 나 배고파. (Mixing polite and casual) - ✓ 뭐 해? 나 배고파. (All casual) - ✓ 뭐 해요? 저 배고파요. (All polite)

Can adjust over time: - Start formal when meeting someone new - Gradually shift to casual as relationship develops - Usually the older person suggests: "반말 하자" (Let's speak casually)

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Using 반말 too soon
  2. Wait for clear signals or mutual agreement

  3. Better to be too polite than too casual

  4. Wrong level in professional settings

  5. Even with close colleague, maintain 해요체 in meetings

  6. Context matters more than personal relationship

  7. Inconsistent levels

  8. Pick a level and stick with it

  9. Switching mid-conversation is awkward

  10. Using 합쇼체 in daily conversation

  11. Sounds overly formal and stiff
  12. 해요체 is appropriate for most situations

docs.title: Regional and Generational Differences
docs.text:
Seoul/Standard: - Clear distinction between levels - More likely to maintain formality longer

Other regions: - May use 반말 more quickly - Different dialect forms affect speech levels

Younger generation: - May use 해요체 even with parents - More flexible about 반말 among friends

Older generation: - Stricter about hierarchy - May use traditional forms like 하게체

docs.title: Practical Usage Tips
docs.text:
When in doubt: 1. Use 해요체 (safest default) 2. Mirror the other person's level 3. Ask if unsure: "반말 해도 돼요?" (Is it okay to speak casually?)

Adjusting levels: - Formal to casual: Natural progression - Casual to formal: Awkward, avoid going backwards

In writing: - Formal documents: 합쇼체 - Emails to colleagues: 해요체 - Text messages to friends: 반말 - Social media: Depends on audience

docs.title: Learning Path
docs.text:
For detailed information on each speech level:

  1. Polite Informal (해요체) - Start here, most useful
  2. Casual (해체/반말) - For friends and family
  3. Formal Polite (합쇼체) - For formal situations

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Which speech level should you use when meeting someone older for the first time?

  2. What does 반말 mean?

  3. Which is the most commonly used speech level in daily life?

  4. Complete: In a business presentation, you should use ______ level.

  5. True or False: You can immediately use 반말 with someone your age.

  6. What should you say to ask if it's okay to speak casually?

  7. Which ending belongs to 해요체: (a) -습니다 (b) -아요 (c) -아

  8. Can you mix 해요체 and 반말 in the same conversation with one person?

  9. If someone older suggests "반말 하자," what does this mean?

  10. Which level is more formal: 합쇼체 or 해요체?

Show Answers 1. 해요체 (Informal Polite) is the safest choice. If the situation is very formal, 합쇼체 may be appropriate. 2. 반말 means "casual/informal speech" or "low speech level" - the informal casual speech level used with friends, family, and younger people. 3. 해요체 (Informal Polite / -아요/어요/해요) is the most commonly used in daily life. 4. 합쇼체 (Formal Polite) 5. False. You should start with 해요체 and only switch to 반말 after establishing rapport or mutual agreement. Age alone doesn't automatically mean you can use 반말. 6. 반말 해도 돼요? (Is it okay to speak casually?) Alternative: 반말 할까요? (Shall we speak casually?) Mutual suggestion: 반말 하자. (Let's speak casually.) 7. (b) -아요 (also -어요, -해요) 8. No, you should not mix speech levels with the same conversation partner. Pick one level and maintain consistency. 9. It means "Let's speak casually/informally" - the older person is suggesting both parties drop formalities and use 반말. This is a friendly gesture that indicates comfort and closeness. 10. 합쇼체 is more formal than 해요체. Hierarchy: 합쇼체 (most formal) > 해요체 (polite) > 해체/반말 (casual)

docs.title: Casual Speech (반말 / 해체)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

  • 반말 (해체): -아/어/해 endings (no 요)
  • Informal, casual speech used with close relationships
  • Use with: close friends (same age), younger people, children, family (depending on family culture)
  • NOT for: strangers, elders, superiors, formal situations
  • Requires mutual agreement or clear social permission
  • Conjugates same as 해요체 but drops the 요

docs.title: What is 반말?
docs.text:
반말 (literally "half speech") refers to informal, casual speech. It's called 해체 in formal linguistic terms. This level removes the politeness marker -요 and uses casual endings.

Key characteristic: No -요 ending, creates intimacy and casualness

Relationship indicator: Using 반말 signals: - Close friendship - Family bonds - Higher social position speaking to lower - Adult speaking to child - Comfortable, intimate relationship

docs.title: Formation Rules
docs.text:
반말 follows the same vowel harmony as 해요체, but removes -요:

1. ㅏ/ㅗ stems → -아 

가다 → 가 (go)
오다 → 와 (come)
보다 → 봐 (see)
자다 → 자 (sleep)

2. Other vowels → -어 

먹다 → 먹어 (eat)
서다 → 서 (stand)
읽다 → 읽어 (read)

3. 하다 verbs → 해 

공부하다 → 공부해 (study)
일하다 → 일해 (work)
좋아하다 → 좋아해 (like)

4. Descriptive verbs (adjectives): Can use plain -다 form in casual statements 

크다 → 크다 / 커 (is big)
예쁘다 → 예쁘다 / 예뻐 (is pretty)
좋다 → 좋다 / 좋아 (is good)

docs.title: Conjugation Patterns
docs.text:
Present tense statements: - 가 (go/goes) - 먹어 (eat/eats) - 해 (do/does)

Present tense questions: - Verb stem + -니? / -냐? (more casual) - 가니? / 가? (Are you going?) - 먹니? / 먹어? (Are you eating?)

Past tense: - Add -았/었/했 (same as 해요체 but no 요) - 갔어 (went) - 먹었어 (ate) - 했어 (did)

Future tense: - Verb stem + -(으)ㄹ 거야 - 갈 거야 (will go) - 먹을 거야 (will eat)

Commands (해라체): - Verb stem + -아/어/해 - 가! (Go!) - 먹어! (Eat!) - Same form as statements but with commanding tone

docs.title: Question Endings in 반말
docs.text:
Several ways to form questions in 반말:

1. Rising intonation: - 가? (Going?) - 먹어? (Eating?)

2. -니? / -니 (softer): - 가니? (Are you going?) - 뭐 하니? (What are you doing?)

3. -냐? (more direct, often masculine): - 가냐? (Are you going?) - 뭐 하냐? (What are you doing?)

4. -어? (casual, common): - 어디 가? (Where are you going?) - 좋아? (Is it good?)

docs.title: When to Use 반말
docs.text:
Appropriate contexts: - Close friends of same age - Speaking to younger siblings - Adults to children - Within couples - Among close peers who agreed to use 반말 - Between teammates in sports/clubs (among peers)

Permission needed: - Usually the older person suggests: "반말 하자" (Let's speak casually) - Between same-age people: "우리 반말 할까?" (Should we speak casually?) - Once established, maintain consistency

NOT appropriate: - Strangers, regardless of age - Elders, even if comfortable - Workplace superiors - Service workers - Formal situations - First meetings

docs.title: 반말 vs 해요체
docs.text:
Feature 반말 해요체 Ending -아/어/해 -아요/어요/해요 Formality Casual Polite Distance Close Respectful distance Use Friends, family Most situations Example 뭐 해? 뭐 해요?

Switching from 해요체 to 반말: 

Initial meeting: 어디 가세요? (Where are you going?) - very polite
After rapport: 어디 가요? (Where are you going?) - polite
Close friends: 어디 가? (Where are you going?) - casual

docs.title: Common 반말 Expressions
docs.text:
Greetings: - 안녕! (Hi! / Bye!) - 잘 가! (Bye! - to person leaving) - 잘 있어! (Bye! - to person staying) - 오랜만이야! (Long time no see!)

Questions: - 뭐 해? (What are you doing?) - 어디 가? (Where are you going?) - 왜? (Why?) - 진짜? (Really?) - 뭐 먹을래? (What do you want to eat?)

Statements: - 나 배고파. (I'm hungry.) - 좋아. (Good. / I like it.) - 몰라. (I don't know.) - 알았어. (I got it. / Okay.) - 나 갈게. (I'll go.)

Responses: - 응 / 어 (Yeah) - 아니 (No) - 그래 (Okay / Yes / That's right) - 알았어 (Got it)

docs.title: Pronouns in 반말
docs.text:
First person: - 나 (I) - casual - 내 (my) - casual

(Compare: 저/제 in polite speech)

Second person: - 너 (you) - casual - 네 / 니 (your) - casual

(Compare: No direct "you" in polite speech, use name + 씨)

Examples: - 나 내일 학교 가. (I'm going to school tomorrow.) - 너 뭐 해? (What are you doing?) - 이거 내 거야. (This is mine.)

docs.title: Tone and Context
docs.text:
Tone matters: - Same words can sound friendly or rude depending on tone - 가! can be "Go!" (friendly) or "Get out!" (rude) - Context and relationship determine interpretation

Situations where 반말 might sound rude: - Using with someone older (even if close) - Using too soon in a relationship - Using in professional settings - Using with strangers - Wrong context (formal situation)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Between close friends: 

A: 야, 오늘 뭐 해?
B: 집에서 쉬려고. 너는?
A: 나 영화 보러 갈 건데, 같이 갈래?
B: 좋아! 몇 시에?
A: 3시에 보자.
B: 알았어. 어디서 만날래?
A: 극장 앞에서 만나자.

A: Hey, what are you doing today?
B: I'm planning to rest at home. How about you?
A: I'm going to watch a movie, want to come?
B: Sounds good! What time?
A: Let's meet at 3.
B: Got it. Where should we meet?
A: Let's meet in front of the theater.

Older person to younger (parent to child): 

엄마: 숙제 다 했니?
아들: 아직 안 했어.
엄마: 빨리 해. 저녁 먹기 전에 끝내야지.
아들: 알았어, 엄마.

Mom: Did you finish your homework?
Son: Not yet.
Mom: Hurry up and do it. You need to finish before dinner.
Son: Okay, Mom.

Between couple: 

A: 배고프지?
B: 응, 뭐 먹을래?
A: 치킨 먹자!
B: 좋아! 주문할게.
A: 나 콜라도 마시고 싶어.
B: 알았어. 같이 시킬게.

A: You're hungry, right?
B: Yeah, what do you want to eat?
A: Let's eat chicken!
B: Sounds good! I'll order.
A: I also want to drink cola.
B: Got it. I'll order it together.

Teammates (same age): 

A: 오늘 연습 어땠어?
B: 힘들었어. 넌?
A: 나도. 내일도 해야 돼?
B: 응, 내일도 있어.
A: 알았어. 같이 가자.

A: How was practice today?
B: It was tough. How about you?
A: Me too. Do we have to do it tomorrow too?
B: Yeah, we have it tomorrow too.
A: Got it. Let's go together.

docs.title: Cultural Notes
docs.text:
1. Establishing 반말: - Usually needs explicit agreement - Common phrase: "우리 이제 반말 하자" (Let's speak casually now) - Older person typically initiates

2. Age hierarchy: - Even one year difference can affect 반말 use - Korean age vs international age matters - Same-age friends: 친구 (can use 반말)

3. Gender dynamics: - Historically, men used 반말 more freely - Modern usage more equal between genders - Still some gender differences in question endings

4. Family variations: - Some families use 해요체 with parents - Others use 반말 with everyone - Varies by family culture and region

5. Workplace culture: - Usually maintain 해요체 at work - Might use 반말 outside work if close - Depends on company culture

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Using 반말 too early: ❌ Meeting someone: 안녕! 뭐 해? ✓ Meeting someone: 안녕하세요! 뭐 하세요?

2. Mixing 반말 and 해요체: ❌ 너 어디 가요? ✓ 너 어디 가? (all casual) ✓ 어디 가요? (all polite)

3. Using 반말 with elders: ❌ To older person: 뭐 해? ✓ To older person: 뭐 하세요?

4. Wrong pronouns: ❌ In polite speech: 너 뭐 해요? ✓ In polite speech: 뭐 해요? (omit pronoun or use name)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Convert to 반말: 뭐 해요?

  2. Convert to 반말: 어디 갔어요?

  3. What does "반말 하자" mean?

  4. Complete: 너 내일 학교에 ______? (Are you going to school tomorrow?) [가다, casual question]

  5. Is it appropriate to use 반말 with a stranger your age?

  6. Convert to 반말: 저는 배고파요.

  7. What's the casual form of 저 (I)?

  8. Complete: 영화 ______? (Did you watch the movie?) [보다, past, casual]

  9. Create a short dialogue between two close friends using 반말.

  10. Explain when it's appropriate to switch from 해요체 to 반말.

Show Answers 1. 뭐 해? 2. 어디 갔어? 3. "Let's speak casually/informally" - It's a suggestion to drop formalities and use 반말 with each other. 4. 가? or 가니? 5. No, it is not appropriate. Always start with 해요체 with strangers, regardless of age. Only use 반말 after establishing a relationship and getting mutual agreement. 6. 나 배고파. or 나는 배고파. 7. 나 (I) and 내 (my) Compare to polite: 저 (I) and 제 (my) 8. 봤어? 9. Example dialogue: A: 야, 주말에 뭐 했어? B: 아무것도 안 했어. 그냥 집에서 쉬었어. 너는? A: 나 친구들이랑 놀러 갔어. B: 어디 갔는데? A: 홍대에 갔어. 너도 다음에 같이 가자. B: 좋아! 언제 갈래? A: 다음 주말에 어때? B: 완벽해. 연락해! A: Hey, what did you do on the weekend? B: I didn't do anything. I just rested at home. How about you? A: I went out with friends. B: Where did you go? A: I went to Hongdae. You should come with us next time. B: Sounds good! When should we go? A: How about next weekend? B: Perfect. Contact me! 10. It's appropriate to switch from 해요체 to 반말 when: **Conditions:** - Both people are similar age (same age or close) - You've established some rapport and comfort - The older person suggests it first (usually with "반말 하자") - Or same-age friends mutually agree (우리 반말 할까?) - The relationship has developed to a comfortable level **Process:** - Start with 해요체 when you first meet - Build rapport over time (could be one meeting or several) - Wait for social cues or explicit permission - Once agreed, maintain 반말 consistently in casual contexts **Never switch if:** - The person is clearly older (more than a year or two) - You're in a professional/work relationship - The other person hasn't reciprocated or agreed - You're in a formal setting When in doubt, maintain 해요체. It's better to be too polite than too casual.

docs.title: Formal Polite Speech (합쇼체)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

  • 합쇼체: -습니다/ㅂ니다 (statements), -습니까/ㅂ니까 (questions)
  • Most formal speech level in modern Korean
  • Use with: public speeches, news, formal presentations, military, very formal business
  • Creates respectful distance and official tone
  • Less common in daily conversation (해요체 is preferred)
  • 받침 distinction: -습니다/습니까 (with 받침), -ㅂ니다/ㅂ니까 (no 받침)

docs.title: What is 합쇼체?
docs.text:
합쇼체 is the most formal polite speech level in contemporary Korean. It's characterized by the endings -습니다/ㅂ니다 for statements and -습니까/ㅂ니까 for questions.

Name origin: Named after 하다 → 합니다 (do/does formally)

Characteristics: - Very formal and respectful - Creates professional distance - Official and ceremonial tone - Used in structured, formal contexts - Less personal than 해요체

docs.title: Formation Rules
docs.text:
합쇼체 has a 받침 distinction:

Statements:

1. Verb stem with 받침 → -습니다 

먹다 → 먹습니다 (eat)
읽다 → 읽습니다 (read)
있다 → 있습니다 (exist/have)
듣다 → 듣습니다 (listen)

2. Verb stem without 받침 → -ㅂ니다 

가다 → 갑니다 (go)
오다 → 옵니다 (come)
보다 → 봅니다 (see)
자다 → 잡니다 (sleep)

3. 하다 verbs → 합니다 

공부하다 → 공부합니다 (study)
일하다 → 일합니다 (work)
사랑하다 → 사랑합니다 (love)

Questions:

1. With 받침 → -습니까 

먹다 → 먹습니까? (Do you eat?)
읽다 → 읽습니까? (Do you read?)
있다 → 있습니까? (Is there/Do you have?)

2. Without 받침 → -ㅂ니까 

가다 → 갑니까? (Do you go?)
오다 → 옵니까? (Do you come?)
보다 → 봅니까? (Do you see?)

3. 하다 verbs → 합니까 

공부하다 → 공부합니까? (Do you study?)
일하다 → 일합니까? (Do you work?)

docs.title: Tense Conjugations
docs.text:
Past tense statements: - Verb stem + -았/었/했 + -습니다

갔습니다 (went)
먹었습니다 (ate)
공부했습니다 (studied)
있었습니다 (was/had)

Past tense questions: - Verb stem + -았/었/했 + -습니까

갔습니까? (Did you go?)
먹었습니까? (Did you eat?)
공부했습니까? (Did you study?)

Future tense: - Verb stem + -(으)ㄹ 것입니다

갈 것입니다 (will go)
먹을 것입니다 (will eat)
공부할 것입니다 (will study)

docs.title: Descriptive Verbs (Adjectives)
docs.text:
Follow the same pattern:

Statements: 

크다 → 큽니다 (is big)
작다 → 작습니다 (is small)
좋다 → 좋습니다 (is good)
예쁘다 → 예쁩니다 (is pretty)

Questions: 

큽니까? (Is it big?)
작습니까? (Is it small?)
좋습니까? (Is it good?)

docs.title: Negation
docs.text:
With 안: 

안 갑니다 (not go)
안 먹습니다 (not eat)
안 좋습니다 (not good)

With -지 않다: 

가지 않습니다 (not go)
먹지 않습니다 (not eat)
좋지 않습니다 (not good)

docs.title: When to Use 합쇼체
docs.text:
Appropriate contexts: - News broadcasts (TV, radio) - Public speeches and presentations - Formal business presentations - Military communication - Police/official announcements - Meeting very senior executives - Ceremonial occasions - Academic conferences - Court proceedings - Official documents read aloud

Situations for 합쇼체: - You're on stage addressing an audience - Broadcasting to the public - Presenting to senior leadership - In hierarchical institutions (military, government) - Maximum formality is expected - Professional distance is required

docs.title: 합쇼체 vs 해요체
docs.text:
The choice between these two polite forms depends on context:

Feature 합쇼체 해요체 Formality Very high Medium-high Context Formal, public Daily, conversational Distance Maximum respect Friendly respect Usage Speeches, news Most conversations Example 갑니다 가요

Same sentence, different levels: 

합쇼체: 저는 학생입니다. (I am a student.) - formal
해요체: 저는 학생이에요. (I am a student.) - polite but casual

docs.title: Special Verb Forms
docs.text:
이다 (to be): 

Statement: -입니다
Question: -입니까?

저는 학생입니다. (I am a student.)
학생입니까? (Are you a student?)

있다/없다 (exist/not exist, have/not have): 

있습니다 / 없습니다
있습니까? / 없습니까?

시간이 있습니다. (I have time.)
돈이 없습니다. (I don't have money.)
질문이 있습니까? (Do you have questions?)

docs.title: Common Expressions in 합쇼체
docs.text:
Greetings and introductions: 

안녕하십니까? (Hello? - very formal)
만나서 반갑습니다. (Nice to meet you.)
감사합니다. (Thank you.)
죄송합니다. (I'm sorry.)
실례합니다. (Excuse me.)

Presentations: 

오늘 발표를 시작하겠습니다. (I will begin today's presentation.)
설명드리겠습니다. (I will explain.)
질문이 있으십니까? (Do you have questions?)
이상입니다. (That's all. / This concludes...)
감사합니다. (Thank you.)

News/Announcements: 

지금부터 뉴스를 시작합니다. (We now begin the news.)
오늘의 날씨입니다. (Here is today's weather.)
다음 소식입니다. (Here is the next news.)

docs.title: When NOT to Use 합쇼체
docs.text:
Avoid 합쇼체 in: - Daily conversations (sounds too stiff) - Casual social interactions - Speaking with friends or family - Informal business conversations - Restaurants, shops, casual services - Most workplace conversations (unless very formal meeting)

Why it sounds awkward: In everyday situations, 합쇼체 creates excessive distance and sounds robotic or overly formal, making interactions uncomfortable.

Example of awkwardness: 

At a cafe:
❌ 커피 한 잔 주시겠습니까? (Too formal)
✓ 커피 한 잔 주세요. (Natural)

To colleague:
❌ 오늘 회의가 있습니까? (Too formal)
✓ 오늘 회의가 있어요? (Natural)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
News broadcast: 

앵커: 안녕하십니까? 9시 뉴스입니다.
오늘 서울의 날씨는 맑습니다.
기온은 25도입니다.
내일은 비가 올 것입니다.
이상 날씨 뉴스였습니다.

Anchor: Hello? This is the 9 o'clock news.
Today's weather in Seoul is clear.
The temperature is 25 degrees.
Tomorrow it will rain.
This was the weather news.

Business presentation: 

발표자: 안녕하십니까? 저는 마케팅 부서의 김민수입니다.
오늘은 신제품에 대해 설명하겠습니다.
이 제품은 작년에 개발했습니다.
시장 반응이 매우 좋습니다.
질문이 있으십니까?
감사합니다.

Presenter: Hello? I am Kim Minsu from the marketing department.
Today I will explain about the new product.
We developed this product last year.
The market response is very good.
Do you have any questions?
Thank you.

Military context: 

상관: 오늘의 임무를 설명하겠습니다.
0800시에 출발합니다.
모두 준비하십시오.
질문이 있습니까?

Superior: I will explain today's mission.
We depart at 0800.
Everyone prepare.
Do you have questions?

Formal meeting: 

사장님: 올해 실적이 좋습니다.
모두 수고하셨습니다.
내년에도 열심히 일하십시오.
회의를 마치겠습니다.

CEO: This year's performance is good.
Everyone worked hard.
Please work hard next year too.
I will close the meeting.

docs.title: Cultural Notes
docs.text:
1. Formality creates distance: - 합쇼체 maintains professional boundaries - Shows maximum respect but less warmth - Appropriate for hierarchical situations

2. Context is everything: - Same person might use 합쇼체 on stage, 해요체 off stage - Switching levels based on situation is natural

3. Generational differences: - Older generation more comfortable with 합쇼체 - Younger generation prefers 해요체 even in semi-formal situations - Corporate culture varies by company

4. Regional variations: - Some regions/contexts use 합쇼체 more frequently - Seoul business culture often uses 해요체 - Traditional institutions prefer 합쇼체

5. Learning priority: - Master 해요체 first - Learn 합쇼체 for recognition (news, speeches) - Use 합쇼체 only in clearly formal contexts

docs.title: Mixing Formal Elements
docs.text:
Even in 해요체, you can add formal respect:

Honorific verbs in 해요체: 

계세요 (to exist/stay - honorific)
주무세요 (to sleep - honorific)
드세요 (to eat/drink - honorific)

This allows politeness without full 합쇼체 formality: 

할아버지께서 주무세요. (Grandfather is sleeping.) - polite 해요체
할아버지께서 주무십니다. (Grandfather is sleeping.) - formal 합쇼체

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Overusing in daily life: ❌ Daily: 점심 먹었습니까? ✓ Daily: 점심 먹었어요?

2. Wrong 받침 rules: ❌ 가습니다 (incorrect) ✓ 갑니다 (correct - no 받침)

3. Mixing with casual pronouns: ❌ 너 어디 갑니까? ✓ 어디 가십니까? (honorific)

4. Using when 해요체 is better: In most interpersonal conversations, 합쇼체 sounds awkward and creates unnecessary distance.

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Conjugate 먹다 to 합쇼체 statement form.

  2. Conjugate 가다 to 합쇼체 question form.

  3. What's the 합쇼체 form of 하다 (statement)?

  4. Convert to 합쇼체: 저는 학생이에요.

  5. Which is appropriate for a news broadcast: (a) 오늘 날씨가 좋아요 (b) 오늘 날씨가 좋습니다

  6. Conjugate 읽다 to 합쇼체 past tense: ______.

  7. Is 합쇼체 appropriate for casual conversation with colleagues?

  8. Convert to 합쇼체 question: 시간이 있어요?

  9. Create a formal announcement about a meeting using 합쇼체.

  10. Explain the difference in usage between 합쇼체 and 해요체.

Show Answers 1. 먹습니다 2. 갑니까? 3. 합니다 4. 저는 학생입니다. 5. (b) 오늘 날씨가 좋습니다 - 합쇼체 is standard for news broadcasts 6. 읽었습니다 7. No, 합쇼체 is too formal for casual workplace conversations. Use 해요체 instead. 합쇼체 might be used in very formal business presentations or meetings with top executives, but not in daily colleague interactions. 8. 시간이 있습니까? 9. Example announcements: 회의 공지: 내일 오전 10시에 중요한 회의가 있습니다. 모든 직원은 회의실에 모여 주시기 바랍니다. 회의 자료를 미리 준비하십시오. 질문이 있으시면 연락 주십시오. 감사합니다. Meeting announcement: There is an important meeting tomorrow at 10 AM. All employees please gather in the meeting room. Please prepare meeting materials in advance. If you have questions, please contact me. Thank you. Alternative: 안녕하십니까? 다음 주 월요일에 전체 회의를 진행하겠습니다. 시간은 오후 2시입니다. 장소는 본관 3층 대회의실입니다. 참석 부탁드립니다. 이상입니다. 10. Difference between 합쇼체 and 해요체: **합쇼체 (-습니다/ㅂ니다):** - Most formal polite level - Used in: news, public speeches, formal presentations, military, very formal business - Creates maximum respectful distance - Professional and official tone - Less personal, more ceremonial - Example: 저는 학생입니다. **해요체 (-아요/어요/해요):** - Informal polite level (but still respectful) - Used in: daily conversations, most social interactions, casual business - Polite but friendly and approachable - Most versatile for everyday use - More personal and conversational - Example: 저는 학생이에요. **When to use each:** - 합쇼체: Broadcasting to public, formal speeches, maximum formality required - 해요체: Everyday default for polite conversation (strangers, colleagues, acquaintances) **Key insight:** In modern Korean, 해요체 is used far more frequently. 합쇼체 is reserved for genuinely formal contexts. When in doubt for daily life, use 해요체.

docs.title: Polite Informal Speech (해요체)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

  • 해요체: -아요/어요/해요 endings
  • Most versatile and commonly used speech level
  • Polite but approachable, friendly but respectful
  • Use with: strangers, colleagues, acquaintances, elders you're comfortable with
  • Safe default for most situations when in doubt
  • Conjugates using vowel harmony rules

docs.title: What is 해요체?
docs.text:
해요체 (also called 존댓말 or 요 form) is the informal polite speech level. It's polite enough to show respect but casual enough for everyday conversation. This is the most practical speech level for learners to master first.

Name origin: Named after 하다 → 해요 (do/does politely)

docs.title: Formation Rules
docs.text:
해요체 follows vowel harmony rules:

1. ㅏ/ㅗ stems → -아요 

가다 → 가요 (go)
오다 → 와요 (come)
보다 → 봐요 (see)
자다 → 자요 (sleep)

2. Other vowels → -어요 

먹다 → 먹어요 (eat)
서다 → 서요 (stand)
읽다 → 읽어요 (read)

3. 하다 verbs → 해요 

공부하다 → 공부해요 (study)
일하다 → 일해요 (work)
요리하다 → 요리해요 (cook)

4. Irregular verbs maintain patterns 

듣다 → 들어요 (listen) [ㄷ irregular]
짓다 → 지어요 (build) [ㄷ irregular]

docs.title: Conjugation Patterns
docs.text:
Statements: - Verb/Adjective stem + -아요/어요/해요

Questions: - Same form + rising intonation - 가요? (Are you going?) - 먹어요? (Are you eating?)

Past tense: - Add -았/었/했 before -요 - 갔어요 (went) - 먹었어요 (ate) - 공부했어요 (studied)

Future tense: - Verb stem + -(으)ㄹ 거예요 - 갈 거예요 (will go) - 먹을 거예요 (will eat)

Negation: - 안 + Verb-아요/어요/해요 - 안 가요 (not going) - Verb stem + -지 않아요 - 가지 않아요 (not going)

docs.title: When to Use 해요체
docs.text:
Perfect for: - First meetings with adults - Daily conversations at shops, restaurants - Speaking with colleagues - Talking to acquaintances - Speaking to elders in casual settings - Service industry workers - Strangers on the street

Social contexts: - Most versatile level - Shows respect without being overly formal - Creates friendly but appropriate distance - Default choice when relationship is unclear

Age considerations: - Always safe with older people - Appropriate with same-age people you just met - Can be used even with close friends (depends on preference)

docs.title: 해요체 vs Other Levels
docs.text:
해요체 vs 합쇼체: - 해요체: 밥을 먹어요. (I eat rice.) - friendly, daily - 합쇼체: 밥을 먹습니다. (I eat rice.) - formal, speeches

해요체 vs 반말: - 해요체: 뭐 해요? (What are you doing?) - polite - 반말: 뭐 해? (What are you doing?) - casual, close

docs.title: Common Verbs in 해요체
docs.text:
Daily actions: 

가다 → 가요 (go)
오다 → 와요 (come)
먹다 → 먹어요 (eat)
마시다 → 마셔요 (drink)
자다 → 자요 (sleep)
일어나다 → 일어나요 (wake up)
보다 → 봐요 (see, watch)
듣다 → 들어요 (listen, hear)
말하다 → 말해요 (speak)
읽다 → 읽어요 (read)
쓰다 → 써요 (write)

Common adjectives: 

좋다 → 좋아요 (good)
나쁘다 → 나빠요 (bad)
크다 → 커요 (big)
작다 → 작아요 (small)
많다 → 많아요 (many)
적다 → 적어요 (few)
예쁘다 → 예뻐요 (pretty)
맛있다 → 맛있어요 (delicious)

docs.title: Politeness Strategies with 해요체
docs.text:
1. Add 좀 (please, a bit): - 좀 도와주세요. (Please help me a bit.) - 물 좀 주세요. (Please give me some water.)

2. Use -(으)세요 for respect: - 앉으세요. (Please sit down.) - 드세요. (Please eat/drink.)

3. Use 주세요 (please give/do): - 말씀해 주세요. (Please speak.) - 기다려 주세요. (Please wait.)

4. Humble forms for yourself: - 제가 할게요. (I'll do it.) - 잘 모르겠어요. (I don't really know.)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Basic conversations: - A: 어디 가요? (Where are you going?) - B: 학교에 가요. (I'm going to school.)

  • A: 뭐 먹을래요? (What do you want to eat?)

  • B: 김치찌개 먹을래요. (I want to eat kimchi stew.)

  • A: 주말에 뭐 했어요? (What did you do on the weekend?)

  • B: 친구 만나고 영화 봤어요. (I met a friend and watched a movie.)

At a restaurant: 

손님: 여기요! 주문할게요.
직원: 네, 말씀하세요.
손님: 불고기 정식 하나 주세요.
직원: 음료수는 뭐로 하시겠어요?
손님: 콜라 주세요.

Customer: Excuse me! I'll order.
Staff: Yes, go ahead.
Customer: Please give me one bulgogi set.
Staff: What would you like for a drink?
Customer: Please give me cola.

Meeting someone new: 

A: 안녕하세요? 저는 김민수예요. 만나서 반가워요.
B: 안녕하세요. 저는 이지은이에요. 반갑습니다.
A: 어디 사세요?
B: 서울에 살아요. 민수 씨는요?
A: 저도 서울에 살아요.

A: Hello? I'm Kim Minsu. Nice to meet you.
B: Hello. I'm Lee Jieun. Nice to meet you.
A: Where do you live?
B: I live in Seoul. How about you, Minsu?
A: I also live in Seoul.

At work (colleague conversation): 

A: 오늘 회의가 몇 시예요?
B: 3시에 있어요.
A: 자료 준비했어요?
B: 네, 다 준비했어요.

A: What time is the meeting today?
B: It's at 3.
A: Did you prepare the materials?
B: Yes, I prepared everything.

docs.title: Cultural Notes
docs.text:
1. 해요체 is the learner's best friend: - When in doubt, use 해요체 - You rarely go wrong with this level - Shows you're trying to be respectful

2. Can maintain 해요체 even with friends: - Some friends prefer to keep using 해요체 - Not everyone switches to 반말 - Especially common between opposite genders

3. Work environments: - 해요체 is standard among colleagues - May use 반말 outside work if close - Usually maintain 해요체 with seniors

4. Adding -요 makes it polite: - Even casual forms can add -요 for politeness - 좋아 → 좋아요 (good) - 뭐야 → 뭐예요 (what is it)

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Forgetting 요: ❌ 좋아. (Sounds like 반말) ✓ 좋아요. (Proper 해요체)

2. Wrong vowel harmony: ❌ 가어요 ✓ 가요

3. Using 합쇼체 in daily situations: ❌ 밥을 먹습니다. (Too formal for casual conversation) ✓ 밥을 먹어요. (Natural)

4. Dropping 요 with strangers: ❌ 어디 가? (Too casual for strangers) ✓ 어디 가요? (Polite and appropriate)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Conjugate 가다 to 해요체 present tense.

  2. Conjugate 먹다 to 해요체 past tense.

  3. What's the 해요체 form of 하다?

  4. Translate: Where are you going? (polite informal)

  5. Complete: 저는 커피를 ______. (I drink coffee.) [마시다]

  6. Is 해요체 appropriate for speaking to your boss?

  7. Conjugate 공부하다 to 해요체 future tense (will study).

  8. Complete: 영화를 ______. (I watched a movie.) [보다, past]

  9. Create a dialogue between two people meeting for the first time using 해요체.

  10. Explain when to use 해요체 vs 합쇼체.

Show Answers 1. 가요 2. 먹었어요 3. 해요 4. 어디 가요? More polite: 어디 가세요? 5. 마셔요 6. Yes, 해요체 is appropriate for speaking to your boss in most modern workplaces, though some very traditional or hierarchical companies might expect 합쇼체. 해요체 strikes a good balance of respect and approachability. 7. 공부할 거예요 8. 봤어요 9. Example dialogue: A: 안녕하세요? 저는 박수진이에요. B: 안녕하세요. 저는 최민호예요. 만나서 반가워요. A: 반가워요. 어디서 오셨어요? B: 부산에서 왔어요. 수진 씨는요? A: 저는 서울 사람이에요. B: 아, 그렇군요. 무슨 일 하세요? A: 회사원이에요. 민호 씨는요? B: 저는 학생이에요. A: Hello? I'm Park Sujin. B: Hello. I'm Choi Minho. Nice to meet you. A: Nice to meet you. Where are you from? B: I'm from Busan. How about you, Sujin? A: I'm from Seoul. B: Oh, I see. What do you do? A: I'm an office worker. How about you, Minho? B: I'm a student. 10. 해요체 vs 합쇼체: **Use 해요체 (-아요/어요) when:** - Daily conversations with most people - Speaking with colleagues, acquaintances - Casual but polite situations - Most service interactions - When you want to be friendly but respectful **Use 합쇼체 (-습니다/ㅂ니다) when:** - Formal presentations or speeches - News broadcasts - Very formal business situations - First time meeting someone very senior - Military or official contexts - When maximum formality is required In summary: 해요체 is your daily default; 합쇼체 is for formal/official situations. When in doubt, 해요체 is safer for everyday life.

docs.title: Intermediate Korean
docs.text: Welcome to the intermediate level! At this stage, you'll expand your ability to express complex ideas, report what others say, and use sophisticated grammatical structures.

docs.title: Complex Grammar Patterns
docs.text:
Master advanced sentence structures that allow you to:

  • Modify nouns with verb clauses (relative clauses)
  • Convert verbs into nouns (nominalization)
  • Express simultaneous actions and timing relationships
  • Indicate purpose and intention clearly
  • Describe results and changes
  • Express degrees and extent

docs.title: Reported Speech
docs.text:
Learn to convey what others have said, asked, or commanded:

  • Report statements in various tenses
  • Report questions (both yes/no and wh-questions)
  • Report commands and requests
  • Use shortened colloquial forms

docs.title: Learning Path
docs.text:
1. Complex Grammar - Build sophisticated sentence structures
  2. Reported Speech - Master indirect speech patterns
  3. Passive & Causative - Understand voice changes
  4. Honorifics - Navigate formal language properly
  5. Advanced Conjunctions - Connect complex ideas

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting this level, you should be comfortable with:

  • All basic grammar patterns
  • Past, present, and future tenses
  • Common verb forms and endings
  • Basic particles and connectors
  • Speech levels (informal and formal)

docs.title: Study Tips
docs.text:
Practice Regularly: These patterns require consistent exposure to internalize.

Listen Actively: Pay attention to how native speakers use these structures in dramas, podcasts, and conversations.

Write Examples: Create your own sentences using each pattern to reinforce learning.

Mix Patterns: Combine different grammar structures in single sentences for fluency.

docs.title: Ready to Begin?
docs.text: Start with Complex Grammar to build your foundation in sophisticated sentence construction!

docs.title: Complex Grammar Patterns
docs.text: This section covers sophisticated grammatical structures that allow you to express complex ideas naturally and fluently.

docs.title: 1. Noun Modification
docs.text:
Learn to create relative clauses by modifying nouns with verb phrases.

  • -는 for present tense actions
  • -(으)ㄴ for past tense or adjectives
  • -(으)ㄹ for future actions or intentions

Example: 어제 본 영화 (the movie I saw yesterday)

docs.title: 2. Nominalizing
docs.text:
Convert verbs and adjectives into nouns using two different methods.

  • -기: General nominalizer, subject/object of verbs
  • -ㅁ/음: More formal, abstract concepts

Example: 한국어를 배우기가 재미있어요 (Learning Korean is fun)

docs.title: 3. While/During
docs.text:
Express simultaneous actions and time relationships.

  • -면서: Doing two things at once
  • -는 동안: During a period of time
  • -다가: Switching from one action to another

Example: 음악을 들으면서 공부해요 (I study while listening to music)

docs.title: 4. Purpose
docs.text:
Indicate the purpose or goal of an action.

  • -(으)려고: In order to
  • -기 위해(서): For the purpose of
  • -(으)러 가다/오다: Go/come to do something

Example: 친구를 만나려고 카페에 갔어요 (I went to the cafe to meet a friend)

docs.title: 5. Result
docs.text:
Describe outcomes and changes in state.

  • -게 되다: Come to, end up (doing)
  • -아/어지다: Become (change of state)

Example: 한국어를 잘하게 됐어요 (I came to speak Korean well)

docs.title: 6. Degree/Extent
docs.text:
Express the degree or extent of an action or state.

  • -ㄹ 만큼: To the extent that, enough to
  • -ㄹ 정도로: To the degree that

Example: 울 만큼 슬펐어요 (I was sad enough to cry)

docs.title: Study Strategy
docs.text:
1. Master Each Pattern: Study one pattern at a time thoroughly
  2. Compare Similar Forms: Understand subtle differences between related patterns
  3. Create Your Examples: Practice by writing your own sentences
  4. Combine Patterns: Once comfortable, mix patterns in complex sentences

docs.title: Why These Matter
docs.text:
These patterns are essential for:

  • Natural, fluent Korean speech
  • Understanding native content (dramas, news, books)
  • Expressing complex thoughts and relationships
  • Moving beyond basic communication

Start with Noun Modification to learn how to create descriptive, information-rich sentences!

docs.title: Degree/Extent
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern Meaning Formation Example -(으)ㄹ 만큼 Enough to, to the extent Vowel/ㄹ: -ㄹ 만큼 울 만큼 (enough to cry) (degree that warrants) Consonant: -을 만큼 먹을 만큼 먹었어요 -(으)ㄹ 정도로 To the degree that Vowel/ㄹ: -ㄹ 정도로 죽을 정도로 (to the point of dying) (extreme degree) Consonant: -을 정도로 아플 정도로 -(으)ㄹ 정도 About/approximately Same as above 할 수 있을 정도 (about able to do) (level/extent)

Key Difference: 만큼 = sufficient amount; 정도로/정도 = degree/level (often extreme)

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: These patterns express the extent, degree, or level of an action or state, often comparing or indicating sufficiency.

docs.title: -(으)ㄹ 만큼 (Enough To, To the Extent That)
docs.text:
Formation: - After vowel or ㄹ: -ㄹ 만큼 (가다 → 갈 만큼) - After consonant: -을 만큼 (먹다 → 먹을 만큼)

Key Features:

  • Sufficient degree: Enough to warrant something
  • Comparison: As much as, to the extent of
  • Cause and effect: The degree leads to a result
  • Can be positive or negative

Common Patterns:

  • Verb + -(으)ㄴ/는 만큼: as much as (actual amount)
  • 할 수 있을 만큼: as much as one can
  • Adjective + -(으)ㄹ 만큼: enough to be

docs.title: -(으)ㄹ 정도로 (To the Degree That)
docs.text:
Formation: - After vowel or ㄹ: -ㄹ 정도로 (가다 → 갈 정도로) - After consonant: -을 정도로 (먹다 → 먹을 정도로)

Key Features:

  • Extreme degree: Often emphasizes unexpectedness
  • Hyperbolic expressions: Can be exaggerated
  • Strong emphasis: More dramatic than 만큼
  • Usually followed by result clause

docs.title: -(으)ㄹ 정도 (About, Approximately, Level)
docs.text:
Formation: Same as 정도로 but without 로

Key Features:

  • Approximate level: Around that degree
  • Less extreme: More neutral than 정도로
  • Can stand at end: 이해할 수 있을 정도예요
  • Estimation: About this much

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
For -(으)ㄹ 만큼:

  1. Take the verb/adjective stem
  2. Check if it ends in vowel/ㄹ or consonant
  3. Add -ㄹ 만큼 or -을 만큼
  4. Add result clause

For -(으)ㄹ 정도로/정도:

  1. Take the verb/adjective stem
  2. Check if it ends in vowel/ㄹ or consonant
  3. Add -ㄹ 정도로/정도 or -을 정도로/정도
  4. Add result clause or end sentence

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
-(으)ㄹ 만큼 (Sufficient Extent):

  • 울 만큼 슬펐어요 (I was sad enough to cry)
  • 죽을 만큼 배고파요 (I'm hungry enough to die)
  • 믿을 만한 사람이에요 (He's a person trustworthy enough)
  • 볼 만한 영화예요 (It's a movie worth watching)
  • 먹을 만큼 먹었어요 (I ate as much as I needed to)
  • 이해할 만해요 (It's understandable)
  • 살 만해요 (It's livable/worth living)

With Present Tense (-는 만큼):

  • 아는 만큼 보여요 (You see as much as you know)
  • 먹는 만큼 내요 (Pay as much as you eat)
  • 일하는 만큼 받아요 (Get paid as much as you work)
  • 노력하는 만큼 성공해요 (Succeed as much as you try)

-(으)ㄹ 정도로 (Extreme Degree):

  • 죽을 정도로 바빠요 (I'm busy to the point of dying)
  • 미칠 정도로 더워요 (It's hot to the point of going crazy)
  • 울 정도로 웃겼어요 (It was funny to the point of crying)
  • 넘어질 정도로 놀랐어요 (I was surprised to the point of falling over)
  • 잊어버릴 정도로 오래됐어요 (It's been long enough to forget)
  • 포기할 정도로 어려웠어요 (It was difficult to the point of giving up)

-(으)ㄹ 정도 (Approximate Level):

  • 이해할 수 있을 정도예요 (It's at a level I can understand)
  • 한국어를 읽을 정도는 돼요 (I'm at least at a level where I can read Korean)
  • 대화할 정도는 아니에요 (It's not at a conversation level)
  • 먹을 수 있을 정도로 익었어요 (It's cooked to an edible level)
  • 기억할 정도로 인상적이었어요 (It was impressive to the point of remembering)

Comparing 만큼 vs 정도로:

Similar meaning, different emphasis:

  • 울 만큼 슬펐어요 (Sad enough to cry - sufficient sadness)
  • 울 정도로 슬펐어요 (Sad to the point of crying - extreme emphasis)

With Past/Present Tense:

  • 죽을 만큼 힘들었어요 (It was hard enough to die)
  • 죽는 만큼 힘들었어요 (It was as hard as dying)
  • 기억할 만한 순간이었어요 (It was a moment worth remembering)

Complex Examples:

  • 잠을 못 잘 정도로 걱정했어요 (I worried to the point where I couldn't sleep)
  • 한국어를 가르칠 만큼 잘해요 (I'm good enough at Korean to teach it)
  • 눈물이 날 정도로 감동적이었어요 (It was touching to the point of tears)
  • 이해할 수 있을 만큼 설명했어요 (I explained enough to be understandable)
  • 믿을 수 없을 정도로 빨라요 (It's fast to an unbelievable degree)

docs.title: Special Patterns
docs.text:
만하다 (Worth doing, About):

  • 볼 만하다 (worth seeing)
  • 읽을 만하다 (worth reading)
  • 살 만하다 (worth living, livable)

As much as nouns:

  • 당신만큼 (as much as you)
  • 이것만큼 (as much as this)
  • 3시간 정도 (about 3 hours)
  • 10명 정도 (about 10 people)

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
❌ 죽을 만큼 바빠요 (Technically correct but 정도로 is more natural for extreme degree) ✅ 죽을 정도로 바빠요

❌ 먹을 정도 먹었어요 (Missing topic/particle) ✅ 먹을 만큼 먹었어요 (ate enough)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. (울다) ____ 슬픈 영화였어요. (enough to)

  2. (죽다) ____ 추워요. (extreme degree)

  3. (믿다) ____ 사람이에요. (worthy/reliable)

  4. (알다) ____ 보여요. (as much as you know)

  5. Translate: "It's hot to the point of going crazy."

  6. (먹다) ____ 먹었어요. (as much as needed)

  7. (넘어지다) ____ 놀랐어요. (to the point of)

  8. (이해하다) ____ 설명해 주세요. (to an understandable level)

  9. Translate: "It's a book worth reading."

  10. (잊어버리다) ____ 오래됐어요. (to the degree of forgetting)

Show Answers 1. 울 만큼 - **울 만큼** 슬픈 영화였어요. - It was a movie sad enough to cry 2. 죽을 정도로 - **죽을 정도로** 추워요. - It's cold to the point of dying (extreme cold) 3. 믿을 만한 - **믿을 만한** 사람이에요. - He's a trustworthy person (worthy of trust) 4. 아는 만큼 - **아는 만큼** 보여요. - You see as much as you know (common saying) 5. 미칠 정도로 더워요. - 미치다 (go crazy) + -ㄹ 정도로 for extreme emphasis 6. 먹을 만큼 - **먹을 만큼** 먹었어요. - I ate as much as I needed (sufficient amount) 7. 넘어질 정도로 - **넘어질 정도로** 놀랐어요. - I was surprised to the point of falling over 8. 이해할 수 있을 정도로 - **이해할 수 있을 정도로** 설명해 주세요. - Please explain it to an understandable level 9. 읽을 만한 책이에요. - 읽다 → 읽을 만하다 (worth reading) 10. 잊어버릴 정도로 - **잊어버릴 정도로** 오래됐어요. - It's been long to the degree of forgetting

docs.title: Nominalizing
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Form Usage Formation Example -기 General nominalizer Stem + 기 먹기 (eating) Subject/Object 먹기가 좋아요 After modifiers 빨리 먹기 -ㅁ/음 Formal/written Vowel: -ㅁ 먹음 (eating) Abstract concepts Consonant: -음 앎 (knowing) Subject marker 먹음을 좋아해요

Common Pattern: -기 + adjective describes the action itself - 쉽다 (easy to do), 어렵다 (hard to do), 좋아하다 (like to do)

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Nominalizing transforms verbs and adjectives into nouns, allowing them to function as subjects, objects, or topics in sentences. Korean has two main nominalizers with different uses and formality levels.

docs.title: -기 (Informal, Spoken)
docs.text:
Formation: Simply add -기 to the verb/adjective stem.

  • 먹다 → 먹기
  • 공부하다 → 공부하기
  • 쉽다 → 쉽기

When to Use -기:

  1. As subject/object with descriptive adjectives
  2. 한국어를 배우기가 재미있어요 (Learning Korean is fun)

  3. 수영하기를 좋아해요 (I like swimming)

  4. After adverbs and modifiers

  5. 빨리 먹기 (eating quickly)

  6. 열심히 공부하기 (studying hard)

  7. In certain fixed expressions

  8. 먹기 전에 (before eating)
  9. 보기 좋다 (good to see)

docs.title: -ㅁ/음 (Formal, Written)
docs.text:
Formation: - After vowel or ㄹ: Add -ㅁ (가다 → 감) - After consonant: Add -음 (먹다 → 먹음)

When to Use -ㅁ/음:

  1. With object particle 을/를
  2. 그의 거짓말함을 알았어요 (I knew about his lying)

  3. 일찍 일어남을 좋아해요 (I like waking up early)

  4. In formal or written contexts

  5. 금연 (no smoking) - from 금하다 + -ㅁ

  6. 앎 (knowledge) - from 알다

  7. Abstract concepts and principles

  8. 삶 (life) - from 살다
  9. 믿음 (belief) - from 믿다

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
For -기:

  1. Take the verb/adjective stem (remove -다)
  2. Add -기
  3. Use with subject/topic particles or in -기 expressions

For -ㅁ/음:

  1. Take the verb/adjective stem
  2. Check if stem ends in vowel/ㄹ or consonant
  3. Add -ㅁ (vowel/ㄹ) or -음 (consonant)
  4. Use with object particle 을/를 or as standalone noun

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
-기 as Subject:

  • 운동하기가 힘들어요 (Exercising is hard)
  • 한국 음식 만들기가 쉬워요 (Making Korean food is easy)
  • 일찍 자기가 건강에 좋아요 (Sleeping early is good for health)

-기 as Object:

  • 저는 노래하기를 좋아해요 (I like singing)
  • 영화 보기를 싫어해요 (I dislike watching movies)
  • 요리하기를 배우고 싶어요 (I want to learn cooking)

-기 with Adjectives:

  • 이 문제는 풀기 어려워요 (This problem is difficult to solve)
  • 김치는 먹기 매워요 (Kimchi is spicy to eat)
  • 이 책은 읽기 쉬워요 (This book is easy to read)

-기 Before:

  • 자기 전에 이를 닦아요 (I brush my teeth before sleeping)
  • 먹기 전에 손을 씻으세요 (Wash your hands before eating)
  • 떠나기 전에 전화하세요 (Call before leaving)

-ㅁ/음 with Object Particle:

  • 그의 옴을 기다려요 (I'm waiting for his coming)
  • 진실을 말함이 중요해요 (Speaking the truth is important)
  • 매일 운동함을 추천해요 (I recommend exercising daily)

-ㅁ/음 as Abstract Nouns:

  • 삶이 아름다워요 (Life is beautiful)
  • 앎은 힘이에요 (Knowledge is power)
  • 믿음이 필요해요 (Belief is necessary)

Comparison:

  • 읽기가 좋아요 (Reading is good) - casual
  • 읽음이 좋아요 (Reading is good) - formal
  • 수영하기 싫어요 (I don't like swimming) - natural with -기
  • 수영함을 싫어해요 (I dislike swimming) - more formal/written

docs.title: Common Expressions with -기
docs.text:
• -기 때문에 (because of doing)
  • -기 위해서 (in order to)
  • -기로 하다 (decide to do)
  • -기 시작하다 (start doing)
  • -기 쉽다/어렵다 (easy/hard to do)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. (공부하다) 한국어를 ____가 재미있어요.

  2. (운동하다) 매일 ____를 좋아해요.

  3. (요리하다) 집에서 ____가 어려워요?

  4. (먹다) ____ 전에 기도해요.

  5. (가다) 그의 ____을 기다리고 있어요. (Use formal form)

  6. Translate: "I like listening to music."

  7. (보다) 이 영화는 ____ 쉬워요.

  8. (쓰다) 한자를 ____가 힘들어요.

  9. Translate: "Knowledge is important." (Use 알다 → formal nominalized form)

  10. (일어나다) 일찍 ____를 싫어해요.

Show Answers 1. 공부하기 - 한국어를 **공부하기**가 재미있어요. - Studying Korean is fun (subject with -기) 2. 운동하기 - 매일 **운동하기**를 좋아해요. - I like exercising every day (object with -기) 3. 요리하기 - 집에서 **요리하기**가 어려워요? - Is cooking at home difficult? (subject with -기) 4. 먹기 - **먹기** 전에 기도해요. - I pray before eating (fixed expression -기 전에) 5. 감 - 그의 **감**을 기다리고 있어요. - I'm waiting for his coming (formal -ㅁ form with object particle) - 가다 → 감 (vowel stem + -ㅁ) 6. 저는 음악 듣기를 좋아해요. / 음악을 듣기를 좋아해요. - Either construction works; 듣다 → 듣기 7. 보기 - 이 영화는 **보기** 쉬워요. - This movie is easy to watch (-기 + adjective pattern) 8. 쓰기 - 한자를 **쓰기**가 힘들어요. - Writing hanja is difficult (subject with -기) 9. 앎이 중요해요. / 앎은 중요해요. - 알다 → 알 + -ㅁ = 앎 (knowledge) - Formal nominalized form as abstract noun 10. 일어나기 - 일찍 **일어나기**를 싫어해요. - I dislike waking up early (object with -기)

docs.title: Noun Modification
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Tense Verb Adjective 있다/없다 Example Present -는 - 있는/없는 가는 사람 (person who goes) Past -(으)ㄴ -(으)ㄴ 있었던/없었던 간 사람 (person who went) Future -(으)ㄹ -(으)ㄹ 있을/없을 갈 사람 (person who will go)

Adjectives use -(으)ㄴ for present tense: 큰 집 (big house)

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Noun modification (also called relative clauses) allows you to describe nouns with entire verb or adjective phrases. In English, we use "who," "which," or "that." In Korean, you modify the verb/adjective ending and place it directly before the noun.

docs.title: Key Differences from English
docs.text:
• No relative pronouns: No equivalent of "who," "which," "that"
  • Pre-modifier position: The modifying clause comes before the noun
  • Tense is shown in the modifier: The ending changes based on tense

docs.title: Formation Rules
docs.text:
Verbs:

  • Present (-는): Add -는 to the verb stem (all verbs)
  • 가다 → 가는 (going)

  • 먹다 → 먹는 (eating)

  • Past (-(으)ㄴ): Add -ㄴ after vowel, -은 after consonant

  • 가다 → 간 (went)

  • 먹다 → 먹은 (ate)

  • Future (-(으)ㄹ): Add -ㄹ after vowel or ㄹ, -을 after consonant

  • 가다 → 갈 (will go)
  • 먹다 → 먹을 (will eat)

Adjectives:

  • Present (-(으)ㄴ): Use past tense form for present meaning
  • 크다 → 큰 (big)

  • 작다 → 작은 (small)

  • Past (-(으)ㄴ + 었던/았던): Add past marker

  • 크다 → 컸던 (was big)

  • 작다 → 작았던 (was small)

  • Future (-(으)ㄹ): Same as verbs

  • 크다 → 클 (will be big)
  • 작다 → 작을 (will be small)

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
1. Identify the tense you need (present/past/future)
  2. Determine if you have a verb or adjective
  3. Take the stem (remove -다)
  4. Add the appropriate ending
  5. Place before the noun

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Present Tense Verbs:

  • 한국어를 공부하는 학생 (a student who studies Korean)
  • 회사에 다니는 사람들 (people who go to work)
  • 커피를 마시는 친구 (a friend who is drinking coffee)

Past Tense Verbs:

  • 어제 본 영화 (the movie I saw yesterday)
  • 제가 먹은 음식 (the food that I ate)
  • 서울에 갔던 사람 (the person who went to Seoul)

Future Tense Verbs:

  • 내일 만날 친구 (the friend I will meet tomorrow)
  • 우리가 갈 식당 (the restaurant we will go to)
  • 살 물건 (things to buy / things I will buy)

Present Adjectives:

  • 예쁜 꽃 (pretty flower)
  • 맛있는 음식 (delicious food)
  • 재미없는 영화 (boring movie)

Past Adjectives:

  • 작았던 집 (the house that was small)
  • 비쌌던 가방 (the bag that was expensive)
  • 추웠던 겨울 (the winter that was cold)

Future Adjectives:

  • 행복할 미래 (a future that will be happy)
  • 바쁠 내일 (a tomorrow that will be busy)
  • 어려울 시험 (an exam that will be difficult)

Complex Examples:

  • 제가 어제 도서관에서 만난 친구 (the friend I met at the library yesterday)
  • 엄마가 만드신 맛있는 김치 (delicious kimchi that mom made)
  • 우리가 다음 주에 갈 제주도 (Jeju Island that we'll go to next week)
  • 한국에서 유명한 가수 (a singer who is famous in Korea)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. (가다, present) 학교에 ____ 학생들이 많아요.

  2. (먹다, past) 어제 ____ 음식이 맛있었어요.

  3. (읽다, future) 내일 ____ 책을 샀어요.

  4. (아름답다, present) ____ 풍경을 봤어요.

  5. (비싸다, past) 그 ____ 가방을 팔았어요.

  6. Translate: "The person who is sitting over there is my teacher."

  7. Translate: "The movie I watched last week was boring."

  8. (쓰다, present) 한국어로 ____ 사람이 누구예요?

  9. (살다, past) 제가 ____ 아파트는 서울에 있었어요.

  10. (만들다, future) 내가 ____ 음식은 불고기예요.

Show Answers 1. 가는 - 학교에 **가는** 학생들이 많아요. - Present tense verb: students who go/are going to school 2. 먹은 - 어제 **먹은** 음식이 맛있었어요. - Past tense verb: the food that I ate yesterday 3. 읽을 - 내일 **읽을** 책을 샀어요. - Future tense verb: the book I will read tomorrow 4. 아름다운 - **아름다운** 풍경을 봤어요. - Present adjective (using -(으)ㄴ form): I saw beautiful scenery 5. 비쌌던 - 그 **비쌌던** 가방을 팔았어요. - Past adjective: I sold that bag that was expensive 6. 저기 앉아 있는 사람은 제 선생님이에요. - "앉아 있는" = sitting (present continuous state) 7. 지난주에 본 영화는 재미없었어요. - "본" = past tense of 보다 (to see/watch) 8. 쓰는 - 한국어로 **쓰는** 사람이 누구예요? - Present tense: Who is the person writing in Korean? 9. 살았던 - 제가 **살았던** 아파트는 서울에 있었어요. - Past tense: The apartment I lived in was in Seoul 10. 만들 - 내가 **만들** 음식은 불고기예요. - Future tense: The food I will make is bulgogi

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern Meaning Formation Formality Example -(으)려고 In order to, intending to Vowel/ㄹ: -려고 Casual 먹으려고 (in order to eat) Consonant: -으려고 사려고 왔어요 -기 위해(서) For the purpose of Stem + 기 위해(서) Formal 먹기 위해서 공부하기 위해 -(으)러 Go/come to do Vowel/ㄹ: -러 Casual 먹으러 가요 (only with 가다/오다/다니다) Consonant: -으러 보러 왔어요

Key Difference: -(으)려고 = intention/plan; -기 위해 = formal purpose; -(으)러 = motion verbs only

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: These patterns all express purpose, but they differ in formality, usage context, and which verbs they can combine with.

docs.title: -(으)려고 (In Order To, Planning To)
docs.text:
Formation: - After vowel or ㄹ: -려고 (가다 → 가려고) - After consonant: -으려고 (먹다 → 먹으려고)

Key Features:

  • Personal intention: Emphasizes the subject's plan or goal
  • Casual to neutral: Common in spoken Korean
  • Flexible: Works with many sentence endings
  • Can stand alone: 먹으려고요 (I'm planning to eat)

Special Conjugations:

  • 하다 → 하려고
  • 공부하다 → 공부하려고
  • 살다 → 살려고

docs.title: -기 위해(서) (For the Purpose Of)
docs.text:
Formation: Verb stem + 기 위해 or 기 위해서

  • 먹다 → 먹기 위해(서)
  • 가다 → 가기 위해(서)
  • 공부하다 → 공부하기 위해(서)

Key Features:

  • Formal purpose: More objective, less personal
  • Written Korean: Common in formal writing, news, essays
  • Stronger purpose: Emphasizes the goal more than the action
  • 위해서 vs 위해: 위해서 slightly more emphatic

Related Pattern:

  • 을/를 위해(서): "for the sake of" (noun + 을/를)
  • 가족을 위해서 (for the sake of family)
  • 건강을 위해 (for health)

docs.title: -(으)러 가다/오다/다니다 (Go/Come/Attend to Do)
docs.text:
Formation: - After vowel or ㄹ: -러 (가다 → 가러) - After consonant: -으러 (먹다 → 먹으러)

Must be followed by: - 가다 (to go) - 오다 (to come) - 다니다 (to attend/commute)

Key Features:

  • Motion verbs only: Cannot be used with other verbs
  • Physical movement: Implies going/coming somewhere
  • Casual and common: Very natural in spoken Korean

Special Conjugations:

  • 하다 → 하러 (만나러 가다, 놀러 오다)
  • 보다 → 보러 (영화 보러 가요)

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
For -(으)려고:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Check if it ends in vowel/ㄹ or consonant
  3. Add -려고 or -으려고
  4. Add main clause

For -기 위해(서):

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Add -기
  3. Add 위해 or 위해서
  4. Add main clause

For -(으)러:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Check if it ends in vowel/ㄹ or consonant
  3. Add -러 or -으러
  4. Must follow with 가다/오다/다니다

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
-(으)려고 (Intention/Plan):

  • 한국어를 배우려고 한국에 왔어요 (I came to Korea to learn Korean)
  • 친구를 만나려고 카페에 갔어요 (I went to the cafe to meet a friend)
  • 돈을 모으려고 아르바이트를 해요 (I work part-time to save money)
  • 건강해지려고 운동해요 (I exercise to become healthy)
  • 일찍 자려고 했어요 (I tried to sleep early)

-기 위해(서) (Formal Purpose):

  • 시험을 준비하기 위해서 도서관에 가요 (I go to the library to prepare for the exam)
  • 꿈을 이루기 위해 열심히 공부해요 (I study hard to achieve my dream)
  • 건강을 지키기 위해 운동이 필요해요 (Exercise is necessary to maintain health)
  • 성공하기 위해서는 노력이 필요해요 (Effort is necessary in order to succeed)
  • 환경을 보호하기 위해 노력해요 (We make efforts to protect the environment)

-(으)러 가다/오다 (Go/Come to Do):

  • 영화 보러 갈래요? (Do you want to go watch a movie?)
  • 친구를 만나러 서울에 왔어요 (I came to Seoul to meet a friend)
  • 쇼핑하러 갔어요 (I went shopping)
  • 밥 먹으러 가요 (Let's go eat)
  • 수영하러 수영장에 다녀요 (I go to the pool to swim)
  • 놀러 오세요! (Come visit/hang out!)

Comparing All Three:

Same meaning, different nuances:

  • 책을 사려고 서점에 갔어요 (I went to the bookstore to buy a book - personal plan)
  • 책을 사기 위해 서점에 갔어요 (I went to the bookstore for the purpose of buying a book - formal)
  • 책을 사러 서점에 갔어요 (I went to the bookstore to buy a book - natural, casual)

Complex Examples:

  • 의사가 되기 위해서 열심히 공부하려고 해요 (I'm trying to study hard to become a doctor)
  • 친구를 도와주려고 일찍 왔어요 (I came early to help my friend)
  • 한국 문화를 경험하러 한국에 왔어요 (I came to Korea to experience Korean culture)
  • 돈을 벌기 위해 일하러 갑니다 (I go to work to earn money)

docs.title: Common Patterns
docs.text:
With negative intentions:

  • 늦지 않으려고 일찍 출발했어요 (I left early in order not to be late)
  • 실수하지 않기 위해 조심해요 (I'm careful in order not to make mistakes)

With past tense:

  • 만나려고 했는데 못 만났어요 (I tried to meet but couldn't)
  • 가려고 했어요 (I was going to go)

Standalone responses:

  • 왜 왔어요? 친구 만나러요 (Why did you come? To meet a friend)
  • 뭐 하려고요? (What are you planning to do?)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. (먹다) 불고기를 _____ 한국 식당에 갔어요. (Use motion verb pattern)

  2. (공부하다) 한국어를 _____ 학교에 다녀요. (Use casual intention)

  3. (보다) 친구를 _____ 공항에 갔어요. (Use motion verb pattern)

  4. Translate: "I exercise to be healthy." (Use formal purpose)

  5. (사다) 선물을 _____ 백화점에 가요. (Use casual intention)

  6. (배우다) 기술을 _____ 학원에 등록했어요. (Use formal purpose)

  7. Translate: "I came to Korea to travel." (Use motion verb pattern)

  8. (되다) 선생님이 _____ 대학교에 가요. (Use casual intention)

  9. (만나다) 친구들을 _____ 카페에 왔어요. (Use motion verb pattern)

  10. (지키다) 약속을 _____ 노력해요. (Use formal purpose)

Show Answers 1. 먹으러 - 불고기를 **먹으러** 한국 식당에 갔어요. - I went to a Korean restaurant to eat bulgogi (motion verb pattern) 2. 공부하려고 - 한국어를 **공부하려고** 학교에 다녀요. - I attend school to study Korean (intention) 3. 보러 - 친구를 **보러** 공항에 갔어요. - I went to the airport to see my friend (motion verb pattern) 4. 건강하기 위해(서) 운동해요. / 건강해지기 위해 운동해요. - Formal purpose pattern for health 5. 사려고 - 선물을 **사려고** 백화점에 가요. - I go to the department store to buy a gift (intention) 6. 배우기 위해(서) - 기술을 **배우기 위해(서)** 학원에 등록했어요. - I registered at an academy to learn skills (formal purpose) 7. 여행하러 한국에 왔어요. - Motion verb pattern with 오다 8. 되려고 - 선생님이 **되려고** 대학교에 가요. - I go to university to become a teacher (intention) 9. 만나러 - 친구들을 **만나러** 카페에 왔어요. - I came to the cafe to meet friends (motion verb pattern) 10. 지키기 위해(서) - 약속을 **지키기 위해(서)** 노력해요. - I make an effort to keep promises (formal purpose)

docs.title: Result
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern Meaning Formation Example -게 되다 Come to, end up Stem + 게 되다 알게 되다 (come to know) Gradual change/result 한국어를 잘하게 됐어요 (often unintentional) -아/어지다 Become (change) 아/어 + 지다 좋아지다 (become better) State/quality change 날씨가 추워졌어요 (natural change)

Key Difference: -게 되다 = gradual result/process; -아/어지다 = direct change in state

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Both patterns express changes and results, but they focus on different aspects of the change process.

docs.title: -게 되다 (Come To, End Up)
docs.text:
Formation: Verb/Adjective stem + 게 되다

  • 알다 → 알게 되다 (come to know)
  • 먹다 → 먹게 되다 (come to eat)
  • 좋다 → 좋게 되다 (become good)

Key Features:

  • Process emphasized: Shows how something came about
  • Gradual change: Change happened over time
  • External factors: Often implies circumstances led to the result
  • Less direct control: Not entirely by choice
  • Can be intentional or unintentional

Common Uses:

  1. Learning/acquiring abilities
  2. Circumstantial changes
  3. Life transitions
  4. Realizations and understanding

Tense Conjugations:

  • Present: -게 돼요 (will come to)
  • Past: -게 됐어요 (came to)
  • Future: -게 될 거예요 (will come to)

docs.title: -아/어지다 (Become, Get)
docs.text:
Formation: Attach 아/어 (based on vowel harmony) + 지다

  • 좋다 → 좋아지다 (become good/better)
  • 나쁘다 → 나빠지다 (become bad/worse)
  • 크다 → 커지다 (become big/bigger)
  • 작다 → 작아지다 (become small/smaller)

Key Features:

  • State change focus: Emphasizes the new state
  • Natural progression: Change happens naturally
  • Observable change: Can see or feel the difference
  • Mostly adjectives: Primarily used with adjectives
  • Some verbs allowed: 잊다 → 잊어지다 (be forgotten)

Common Pattern:

More/less + adjective-아/어지다

  • 더 좋아지다 (get better)
  • 덜 추워지다 (get less cold)

Tense Conjugations:

  • Present: -아/어져요 (becomes)
  • Past: -아/어졌어요 (became)
  • Future: -아/어질 거예요 (will become)

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
For -게 되다:

  1. Take the verb/adjective stem
  2. Add -게
  3. Add conjugated form of 되다
  4. Conjugate 되다 for tense

For -아/어지다:

  1. Take the adjective stem (or specific verbs)
  2. Apply vowel harmony: 아 or 어
  3. Add -지다
  4. Conjugate -지다 for tense

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
-게 되다 (Gradual Result/Process):

  • 한국어를 잘하게 됐어요 (I came to speak Korean well)
  • 그 사람을 알게 됐어요 (I came to know that person)
  • 한국 음식을 좋아하게 됐어요 (I came to like Korean food)
  • 매일 운동하게 됐어요 (I ended up exercising every day)
  • 진실을 알게 될 거예요 (You'll come to know the truth)
  • 그 영화를 보게 됐어요 (I ended up watching that movie)
  • 이해하게 됐어요 (I came to understand)
  • 일찍 일어나게 됐어요 (I came to wake up early)

-아/어지다 (Change in State):

  • 날씨가 추워졌어요 (The weather became cold)
  • 한국어가 쉬워졌어요 (Korean became easier)
  • 길이 복잡해졌어요 (The road became complicated)
  • 유명해졌어요 (became famous)
  • 건강해졌어요 (became healthy)
  • 조용해졌어요 (became quiet)
  • 예뻐졌어요 (became pretty)
  • 많아졌어요 (became more/many)

Comparing Both:

Similar situations, different nuances:

  • 한국어를 잘하게 됐어요 (I came to be good at Korean - through experience/time)
  • 한국어가 잘해졌어요 (My Korean got better - observable improvement)

With Time Expressions:

  • 시간이 지나면서 익숙해졌어요 (It became familiar as time passed)
  • 3년 동안 한국어를 잘하게 됐어요 (Over 3 years, I came to speak Korean well)
  • 요즘 날씨가 따뜻해졌어요 (The weather has gotten warm lately)

Complex Examples:

  • 한국에 살게 되면서 김치를 좋아하게 됐어요 (While living in Korea, I came to like kimchi)
  • 공부하다 보니 쉬워지게 됐어요 (As I studied, it came to be easier)
  • 연습을 많이 해서 실력이 좋아졌어요 (Because I practiced a lot, my skills got better)
  • 나이가 들면서 건강의 중요성을 알게 됐어요 (As I got older, I came to know the importance of health)

docs.title: Special Cases
docs.text:
Passive-like with -아/어지다:

  • 문이 열어졌어요 (The door opened/became opened)
  • 문제가 해결됐어요 (The problem was solved)
  • 이름이 잊어졌어요 (The name was forgotten)

Can't always interchange:

❌ 키가 크게 됐어요 (Wrong) ✅ 키가 커졌어요 (I grew taller)

❌ 알아지다 (Doesn't exist) ✅ 알게 되다 (come to know)

docs.title: Common Expressions
docs.text:
With -게 되다:

  • 만나게 되다 (come to meet)
  • 생각하게 되다 (come to think)
  • 느끼게 되다 (come to feel)
  • 깨닫게 되다 (come to realize)

With -아/어지다:

  • 좋아지다 (get better)
  • 나빠지다 (get worse)
  • 많아지다 (increase)
  • 적어지다 (decrease)
  • 길어지다 (get longer)
  • 짧아지다 (get shorter)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. (알다) 한국 문화를 _____ 됐어요.

  2. (춥다) 날씨가 _____어요.

  3. (좋아하다) 김치를 _____ 됐어요.

  4. (쉽다) 한국어가 _____어요.

  5. Translate: "I came to understand Korean grammar."

  6. (많다) 학생들이 _____어요.

  7. (생각하다) 건강이 중요하다고 _____ 됐어요.

  8. (조용하다) 방이 _____어요.

  9. Translate: "The problem became difficult."

  10. (만나다) 좋은 친구들을 _____ 됐어요.

Show Answers 1. 알게 - 한국 문화를 **알게** 됐어요. - I came to know Korean culture (gradual learning process) 2. 추워졌 - 날씨가 **추워졌**어요. - The weather became cold (observable state change) 3. 좋아하게 - 김치를 **좋아하게** 됐어요. - I came to like kimchi (gradual change in preference) 4. 쉬워졌 - 한국어가 **쉬워졌**어요. - Korean became easier (state change) 5. 한국어 문법을 이해하게 됐어요. - 이해하다 → 이해하게 되다 (gradual understanding) 6. 많아졌 - 학생들이 **많아졌**어요. - The students became many/increased (quantity change) 7. 생각하게 - 건강이 중요하다고 **생각하게** 됐어요. - I came to think that health is important (realization over time) 8. 조용해졌 - 방이 **조용해졌**어요. - The room became quiet (state change) 9. 문제가 어려워졌어요. - 어렵다 → 어려워지다 (direct state change) 10. 만나게 - 좋은 친구들을 **만나게** 됐어요. - I came to meet good friends (circumstantial result)

docs.title: While/During
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern Meaning Formation Example -면서 While (simultaneous) Stem + 면서 걸으면서 (while walking) Same subject only 음악을 들으면서 공부해요 -는 동안 During, while Stem + 는 동안 자는 동안 (while sleeping) Different subjects OK 제가 자는 동안 눈이 왔어요 -다가 While then (switch) Stem + 다가 먹다가 (while eating, then) Interruption/change 공부하다가 잤어요

Key Difference: -면서 = doing both together; -는 동안 = time frame; -다가 = switch actions

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: These patterns express temporal relationships between actions, but each has distinct uses and nuances.

docs.title: -면서 (While, Simultaneous Actions)
docs.text:
Formation: Verb stem + 면서

  • 가다 → 가면서
  • 먹다 → 먹으면서
  • 공부하다 → 공부하면서

Key Features:

  • Same subject: The same person does both actions
  • Simultaneous: Both actions happen at the same time
  • Both actions are deliberate: Not accidental overlap

Usage:

Cannot be used with: - Adjectives (only action verbs) - Different subjects doing different actions - Sequential actions (use -고 instead)

docs.title: -는 동안 (During, While)
docs.text:
Formation: - Action verbs: Stem + 는 동안 - Adjectives: Stem + (으)ㄴ 동안 - Past: Stem + (으)ㄴ/았던/었던 동안

Examples: - 가다 → 가는 동안 - 크다 → 큰 동안 - 먹었다 → 먹은 동안

Key Features:

  • Different subjects allowed: Each clause can have its own subject
  • Time frame focus: Emphasizes the duration
  • Works with adjectives: Unlike -면서
  • More formal than -면서

docs.title: -다가 (While Then, Switching Actions)
docs.text:
Formation: Verb stem + 다가

  • 가다 → 가다가
  • 먹다 → 먹다가
  • 공부하다 → 공부하다가

Key Features:

  • Interruption: First action interrupted or stopped
  • Sequential change: Switch from one action to another
  • Unexpected events: Often used with surprises or accidents
  • Same subject typically

Common Uses:

  1. Interrupted actions
  2. Changed plans
  3. Unexpected discoveries
  4. Accidents during an action

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
For -면서:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Add -면서
  3. Add second clause (same subject)

For -는 동안:

  1. Identify if verb or adjective
  2. Add -는 동안 (verbs) or -(으)ㄴ 동안 (adjectives)
  3. Add second clause (any subject)

For -다가:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Add -다가
  3. Add second clause showing change/interruption

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
-면서 (Simultaneous Actions):

  • 음악을 들으면서 공부해요 (I study while listening to music)
  • 걸으면서 이야기해요 (We talk while walking)
  • 커피를 마시면서 책을 읽었어요 (I read a book while drinking coffee)
  • 웃으면서 말했어요 (He spoke while smiling)
  • 운전하면서 전화하지 마세요 (Don't use the phone while driving)

-는 동안 (During a Period):

  • 제가 자는 동안 눈이 왔어요 (It snowed while I was sleeping)
  • 방학인 동안 여행할 거예요 (I'll travel during vacation)
  • 엄마가 요리하는 동안 청소했어요 (I cleaned while mom was cooking)
  • 어렸을 동안 서울에 살았어요 (I lived in Seoul while I was young)
  • 회의하는 동안 조용히 하세요 (Be quiet during the meeting)

-다가 (Switching/Interruption):

  • 공부하다가 잤어요 (I fell asleep while studying)
  • 걷다가 친구를 만났어요 (I met a friend while walking)
  • 영화를 보다가 울었어요 (I cried while watching the movie)
  • 밥을 먹다가 전화를 받았어요 (I answered the phone while eating)
  • 한국에 살다가 미국으로 이사했어요 (I moved to America while living in Korea)

Comparing All Three:

Same situation, different nuances:

  • 음악을 들으면서 공부해요 (I study while listening to music - both intentional)
  • 음악을 듣는 동안 공부했어요 (I studied during the time I listened to music - time frame)
  • 음악을 듣다가 공부했어요 (I was listening to music, then switched to studying)

Complex Examples:

  • 한국에 사는 동안 한국어를 배웠어요 (I learned Korean during my time living in Korea)
  • 걸으면서 생각했어요 (I thought while walking)
  • 책을 읽다가 좋은 구절을 발견했어요 (I discovered a good passage while reading)
  • 일하는 동안 음악을 들으면서 해요 (During work, I do it while listening to music)

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
❌ 공부하면서 잤어요 (Can't be simultaneous - sleeping interrupts studying) ✅ 공부하다가 잤어요

❌ 엄마가 요리하면서 저는 청소했어요 (Different subjects) ✅ 엄마가 요리하는 동안 저는 청소했어요

❌ 예쁜면서 똑똑해요 (Can't use -면서 with adjectives for "and") ✅ 예쁘고 똑똑해요

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. (듣다, simultaneous) 음악을 _____ 달리기를 해요.

  2. (자다, during) 제가 _____ 친구가 왔어요.

  3. (걷다, then) 길을 _____ 넘어졌어요.

  4. Translate: "I watch TV while eating." (simultaneous)

  5. (공부하다, during) _____ 조용히 해 주세요.

  6. (읽다, then) 책을 _____ 잠이 들었어요.

  7. Translate: "I met my teacher while shopping."

  8. (일하다, simultaneous) 노래를 부르_____ 일해요.

  9. (비가 오다, during) _____ 집에 있었어요.

  10. (보다, then) 영화를 _____ 웃었어요.

Show Answers 1. 들으면서 - 음악을 **들으면서** 달리기를 해요. - I run while listening to music (simultaneous, same subject) 2. 자는 동안 - 제가 **자는 동안** 친구가 왔어요. - My friend came while I was sleeping (different subjects, time frame) 3. 걷다가 - 길을 **걷다가** 넘어졌어요. - I fell while walking (interruption/accident during action) 4. 먹으면서 텔레비전을 봐요. / 텔레비전을 보면서 먹어요. - Both actions done simultaneously by same person 5. 공부하는 동안 - **공부하는 동안** 조용히 해 주세요. - Please be quiet while (I'm) studying (time frame) 6. 읽다가 - 책을 **읽다가** 잠이 들었어요. - I fell asleep while reading (unintentional interruption) 7. 쇼핑하다가 선생님을 만났어요. / 쇼핑하는 동안 선생님을 만났어요. - -다가 emphasizes the unexpected meeting; -는 동안 is also acceptable 8. 부르면서 - 노래를 **부르면서** 일해요. - I work while singing (both actions simultaneous and intentional) 9. 비가 오는 동안 - **비가 오는 동안** 집에 있었어요. - I stayed home during the time it was raining 10. 보다가 - 영화를 **보다가** 웃었어요. - I laughed while watching the movie (spontaneous reaction during movie)

docs.title: Reported Speech
docs.text: Reported speech (indirect speech) allows you to convey what someone else has said, asked, or commanded without quoting them directly. This is essential for natural Korean conversation.

docs.title: What is Reported Speech?
docs.text:
Direct Speech: "I'm hungry," he said. Reported Speech: He said that he was hungry.

In Korean, reported speech uses specific endings attached to verbs and adjectives, then followed by 하다 (to say/do).

docs.title: 1. Statements (-다고/라고 하다)
docs.text:
Report what someone said as a fact or statement.

Patterns: - Verbs: -ㄴ다고/는다고 하다 - Adjectives/이다: -(이)라고 하다 - Past: -았/었다고 하다

Shortened Forms: - -다고 → -대(요) - -라고 → -래(요)

Example: - Direct: "저는 학생이에요" - Reported: 학생이라고 했어요 / 학생이래요

docs.title: 2. Questions (-냐고/-(으)냐고 하다)
docs.text:
Report questions that others asked.

Patterns: - Verbs: -냐고/느냐고 하다 - Adjectives: -(으)냐고 하다 - Past: -았/었냐고 하다

Shortened Form: -냐고 → -래(요)

Example: - Direct: "한국어를 공부해요?" - Reported: 한국어를 공부하냐고 물었어요

docs.title: 3. Commands (-(으)라고 하다)
docs.text:
Report commands, requests, or suggestions.

Patterns: - Action verbs: -(으)라고 하다 - Negative: -지 말라고 하다

Shortened Form: -(으)라고 → -래(요)

Example: - Direct: "공부하세요" - Reported: 공부하라고 했어요 / 공부하래요

docs.title: Key Differences from English
docs.text:
1. No quotation marks: Korean smoothly integrates reported speech
  2. Tense in the quote: Usually matches original tense (unlike English)
  3. Particles adjust: 저/나, 제/내 change based on perspective
  4. Shortened forms: Very common in casual speech

docs.title: Common Reporting Verbs
docs.text:
While 하다 (to say) is most common, other verbs work too:

  • 말하다 (to say, tell)
  • 물어보다/묻다 (to ask)
  • 대답하다 (to answer)
  • 설명하다 (to explain)
  • 듣다 (to hear)

docs.title: Learning Strategy
docs.text:
1. Master statements first: Most common type
  2. Learn shortened forms: Essential for natural speech
  3. Practice tense conversion: Keep track of time references
  4. Listen actively: Notice how natives use reported speech

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
Reported speech is crucial for:

  • Gossip and sharing information
  • Relaying messages
  • Talking about what you heard
  • Natural conversation flow
  • Understanding Korean media and conversations

Start with Statements to build your foundation in reported speech!

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Type Pattern Shortened Example Positive Command -(으)라고 하다 -래(요) 가라고 했어요 → 가래요 Negative Command -지 말라고 하다 -지 말래(요) 먹지 말라고 했어요 Polite Request -(으)시라고 하다 -(으)시래요 오시라고 했어요 Suggestion -자고 하다 -재(요) 가자고 했어요 → 가재요

Key Point: -(으)라고 for commands; -지 말라고 for negative; -자고 for suggestions

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Reported commands convey orders, requests, or suggestions that someone gave. The pattern differs from statements and questions.

docs.title: Positive Commands -(으)라고 하다
docs.text:
Formation:

  • After vowel or ㄹ: -라고 하다
  • 가다 → 가라고 하다 → 가래요

  • 살다 → 살라고 하다 → 살래요

  • After consonant: -으라고 하다

  • 먹다 → 먹으라고 하다 → 먹으래요

  • 읽다 → 읽으라고 하다 → 읽으래요

  • 하다 verbs: -하라고 하다

  • 공부하다 → 공부하라고 하다 → 공부하래요

Key Features:

  • Direct commands or orders
  • Can sound quite strong or blunt
  • Often from someone in authority
  • Use 시 for polite commands to superiors

docs.title: Negative Commands -지 말라고 하다
docs.text:
Formation: Verb stem + -지 말라고 하다

  • 가다 → 가지 말라고 하다 → 가지 말래요
  • 먹다 → 먹지 말라고 하다 → 먹지 말래요
  • 하다 → 하지 말라고 하다 → 하지 말래요

Key Features:

  • Tell someone NOT to do something
  • Same pattern for all verbs (no vowel/consonant distinction)
  • Can be softened with 달라고 instead of 말라고

docs.title: Polite Commands -(으)시라고 하다
docs.text:
Formation: Add -시- for honorific requests:

  • 가다 → 가시라고 하다
  • 먹다 → 드시라고 하다 (special honorific)
  • 오다 → 오시라고 하다

docs.title: Suggestions -자고 하다
docs.text:
Formation: Verb stem + -자고 하다

  • 가다 → 가자고 하다 → 가재요
  • 먹다 → 먹자고 하다 → 먹재요
  • 공부하다 → 공부하자고 하다 → 공부하재요

Key Features:

  • "Let's..." suggestions
  • Inclusive (includes speaker)
  • Softer than commands
  • Common in casual speech

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
For positive commands:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Check if ends in vowel/ㄹ or consonant
  3. Add -라고 or -으라고
  4. Add 하다 (conjugate as needed)
  5. Optional: Use -래요 shortening

For negative commands:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Add -지 말라고
  3. Add 하다 (conjugate as needed)
  4. Optional: Use -지 말래요

For suggestions:

  1. Take the verb stem
  2. Add -자고
  3. Add 하다 (conjugate as needed)
  4. Optional: Use -재요

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Positive Commands:

Direct → Reported (Formal) → Shortened

  • "앉으세요" → 앉으라고 했어요 → 앉으래요
  • "가세요" → 가라고 했어요 → 가래요
  • "먹어요" → 먹으라고 했어요 → 먹으래요
  • "공부하세요" → 공부하라고 했어요 → 공부하래요
  • "기다리세요" → 기다리라고 했어요 → 기다리래요
  • "읽으세요" → 읽으라고 했어요 → 읽으래요

Negative Commands:

  • "가지 마세요" → 가지 말라고 했어요 → 가지 말래요
  • "먹지 마세요" → 먹지 말라고 했어요 → 먹지 말래요
  • "걱정하지 마세요" → 걱정하지 말라고 했어요 → 걱정하지 말래요
  • "늦지 마세요" → 늦지 말라고 했어요 → 늦지 말래요
  • "잊지 마세요" → 잊지 말라고 했어요 → 잊지 말래요

Polite Requests (with 시):

  • "앉으세요" (to elder) → 앉으시라고 했어요
  • "오세요" → 오시라고 했어요
  • "드세요" → 드시라고 했어요
  • "쉬세요" → 쉬시라고 했어요

Suggestions:

  • "같이 가요" → 같이 가자고 했어요 → 같이 가재요
  • "영화 봐요" → 영화 보자고 했어요 → 영화 보재요
  • "밥 먹어요" → 밥 먹자고 했어요 → 밥 먹재요
  • "내일 만나요" → 내일 만나자고 했어요 → 내일 만나재요
  • "공부해요" → 공부하자고 했어요 → 공부하재요

Complex Sentences:

  • 선생님이 숙제를 하라고 하셨어요 (The teacher told me to do homework)
  • 엄마가 야채를 먹으라고 했어요 (Mom told me to eat vegetables)
  • 친구가 늦지 말라고 했어요 (My friend told me not to be late)
  • 오빠가 같이 가자고 했어요 (My brother suggested we go together)
  • 의사가 담배를 피우지 말라고 했어요 (The doctor told me not to smoke)

docs.title: Different Reporting Verbs
docs.text:
시키다 (to order, make someone do):

  • 청소하라고 시켰어요 (ordered me to clean)
  • 일찍 오라고 시켰어요 (ordered me to come early)

부탁하다 (to request, ask a favor):

  • 도와달라고 부탁했어요 (asked me to help)
  • 전화하라고 부탁했어요 (requested me to call)

말하다 (to tell, say):

  • 조용히 하라고 말했어요 (told me to be quiet)

제안하다 (to suggest):

  • 같이 가자고 제안했어요 (suggested going together)

docs.title: Softened Commands with -달라고
docs.text:
For softer requests, use -달라고 instead of -라고:

  • 도와달라고 했어요 (asked me to help - softer)
  • 와달라고 했어요 (asked me to come - softer)
  • 전화하달라고 했어요 (asked me to call - softer)

This is more like "asked me to" rather than "told me to."

docs.title: Shortened Forms in Casual Speech
docs.text:
The shortened forms are very common:

  • 빨리 가래 (telling me to go quickly)
  • 먹지 말래 (telling me not to eat)
  • 같이 가재 (suggesting to go together)
  • 조용히 하래 (telling me to be quiet)

Note: Context is crucial with -래 since it can mean: 1. Statement: 간래 (says he's going) 2. Question: 가래 (asking if I'm going) 3. Command: 가래 (telling me to go)

docs.title: Commands with Objects and Complements
docs.text:
• 책을 읽으라고 했어요 (told me to read a book)
  • 한국어로 말하라고 했어요 (told me to speak in Korean)
  • 집에 빨리 오라고 했어요 (told me to come home quickly)
  • 숙제를 내일까지 하라고 했어요 (told me to do homework by tomorrow)

docs.title: Multiple Commands
docs.text:
• 앉으라고 하고 기다리라고 했어요 (told me to sit and wait)
  • 먹지 말라고 하고 운동하라고 했어요 (told me not to eat and to exercise)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Direct command: "공부하세요" → Reported (formal):

  2. Direct command: "가지 마세요" → Reported (shortened):

  3. Direct suggestion: "같이 가요" → Reported (formal):

  4. Translate: "My mom told me to eat vegetables."

  5. Direct command: "조용히 하세요" → Reported (shortened):

  6. Direct command: "여기 앉으세요" → Reported (formal):

  7. Direct command: "걱정하지 마세요" → Reported (shortened):

  8. Direct suggestion: "내일 만나요" → Reported (shortened):

  9. Translate: "The teacher told me not to be late."

  10. Direct command: "빨리 오세요" → Reported (both formal and shortened):

Show Answers 1. 공부하라고 했어요 - 공부하다 → 공부하라고 (command form) 2. 가지 말래요 - 가다 → 가지 말다 → 가지 말래요 (negative command shortened) 3. 같이 가자고 했어요 - 가다 → 가자고 (suggestion form) 4. 엄마가 야채를 먹으라고 했어요 / 엄마가 야채 먹으래요 - 먹다 → 먹으라고 (command with object) 5. 조용히 하래요 - 하다 → 하라고 → 하래요 (command shortened) 6. 여기 앉으라고 했어요 - 앉다 → 앉으라고 (command with location) 7. 걱정하지 말래요 - 걱정하다 → 걱정하지 말다 → 걱정하지 말래요 (negative command) 8. 내일 만나재요 - 만나다 → 만나자고 → 만나재요 (suggestion shortened) 9. 선생님이 늦지 말라고 했어요 / 선생님이 늦지 말래요 - 늦다 → 늦지 말다 (negative command) 10. Formal: 빨리 오라고 했어요 / Shortened: 빨리 오래요 - 오다 → 오라고 (command with adverb)

docs.title: Questions
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Type Pattern Shortened Example Verb (Present) -냐고/느냐고 묻다 -냐고/느냐고 가냐고 물었어요 Verb (Past) -았/었냐고 묻다 -았/었냐고 갔냐고 물었어요 Adjective -(으)냐고 묻다 -(으)냐고 좋으냐고 물었어요 Noun (이다) -(이)냐고 묻다 -(이)냐고 학생이냐고 물었어요 All types -래 (casual) 가냐고 → 가래

Key Point: Use 묻다/물어보다 (to ask) instead of 하다; -래 can mean question or command!

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Reported questions convey questions that someone asked. Unlike statements, questions typically use 묻다 (to ask) as the reporting verb, though 하다 can also be used.

docs.title: Verb Questions
docs.text:
Present Tense:

Formation differs by verb ending:

  • Verbs ending in consonant: -느냐고 묻다
  • 먹다 → 먹느냐고 물었어요

  • 읽다 → 읽느냐고 물었어요

  • Verbs ending in vowel/ㄹ: -냐고 묻다

  • 가다 → 가냐고 물었어요

  • 살다 → 사냐고 물었어요

  • 하다 verbs: -하냐고 묻다

  • 공부하다 → 공부하냐고 물었어요

Past Tense:

All verbs: -았/었냐고 묻다

  • 먹다 → 먹었냐고 물었어요
  • 가다 → 갔냐고 물었어요
  • 공부하다 → 공부했냐고 물었어요

Future Tense:

-(으)ㄹ 거냐고 묻다

  • 먹다 → 먹을 거냐고 물었어요
  • 가다 → 갈 거냐고 물었어요

docs.title: Adjective Questions
docs.text:
Present Tense:

Add -(으)냐고 to the stem:

  • After vowel or ㄹ: -냐고
  • 크다 → 크냐고 물었어요

  • 어떻다 → 어떠냐고 물었어요

  • After consonant: -으냐고

  • 좋다 → 좋으냐고 물었어요
  • 맛있다 → 맛있냐고 물었어요

Past Tense:

-았/었냐고 묻다

  • 좋다 → 좋았냐고 물었어요
  • 예쁘다 → 예뻤냐고 물었어요

docs.title: Noun Questions (이다)
docs.text:
After consonant: -이냐고 묻다

  • 학생이다 → 학생이냐고 물었어요
  • 의사이다 → 의사냐고 물었어요

After vowel: -냐고 묻다

  • 선생님이다 → 선생님이냐고 물었어요
  • 가수이다 → 가수냐고 물었어요

Past: -이었냐고/였냐고 묻다

  • 학생이었다 → 학생이었냐고 물었어요

docs.title: Wh-Questions
docs.text:
For questions with question words (뭐, 어디, 누구, 언제, etc.), use the same patterns:

  • 뭐 먹느냐고 물었어요 (asked what I'm eating)
  • 어디 가냐고 물었어요 (asked where I'm going)
  • 누구냐고 물었어요 (asked who it is)
  • 언제 오냐고 물었어요 (asked when I'm coming)
  • 왜 안 먹느냐고 물었어요 (asked why I'm not eating)

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
1. Take the direct question
  2. Remove question ending (요?/니?/냐?)
  3. Identify verb/adjective/noun type
  4. Add appropriate -냐고/느냐고 ending
  5. Add 묻다/물어보다 (conjugate as needed)
  6. Optional: Use shortened form

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Present Tense Verbs:

Direct → Reported

  • "한국어를 공부해요?" → 한국어를 공부하냐고 물었어요
  • "어디 가요?" → 어디 가냐고 물었어요
  • "밥을 먹어요?" → 밥을 먹느냐고 물었어요
  • "책을 읽어요?" → 책을 읽느냐고 물었어요
  • "운동해요?" → 운동하냐고 물었어요

Past Tense Verbs:

  • "영화를 봤어요?" → 영화를 봤냐고 물었어요
  • "어디 갔어요?" → 어디 갔냐고 물었어요
  • "점심 먹었어요?" → 점심 먹었냐고 물었어요
