  • "숙제를 했어요?" → 숙제를 했냐고 물었어요

Future Tense:

  • "내일 올 거예요?" → 내일 올 거냐고 물었어요
  • "같이 갈 거예요?" → 같이 갈 거냐고 물었어요

Adjectives:

  • "한국어가 어려워요?" → 한국어가 어렵냐고 물었어요
  • "날씨가 좋아요?" → 날씨가 좋으냐고 물었어요
  • "음식이 맛있어요?" → 음식이 맛있냐고 물었어요
  • "방이 깨끗해요?" → 방이 깨끗하냐고 물었어요
  • "커요?" → 크냐고 물었어요

Nouns (이다):

  • "학생이에요?" → 학생이냐고 물었어요
  • "의사예요?" → 의사냐고 물었어요
  • "한국 사람이에요?" → 한국 사람이냐고 물었어요
  • "선생님이에요?" → 선생님이냐고 물었어요

Wh-Questions:

  • "뭐 해요?" → 뭐 하냐고 물었어요
  • "누구예요?" → 누구냐고 물었어요
  • "어디 살아요?" → 어디 사냐고 물었어요
  • "왜 안 왔어요?" → 왜 안 왔냐고 물었어요
  • "언제 만날까요?" → 언제 만나냐고 물었어요

Complex Sentences:

  • 친구가 제가 어디 사냐고 물어봤어요 (My friend asked where I live)
  • 엄마가 밥을 먹었냐고 물으셨어요 (Mom asked if I ate)
  • 선생님이 숙제를 했냐고 물으셨어요 (The teacher asked if I did homework)
  • 오빠가 뭐 하고 있냐고 물어봤어요 (My brother asked what I'm doing)

docs.title: Alternative Reporting Verbs
docs.text:
물어보다 (to ask - casual):

  • 가냐고 물어봤어요 (asked if going)

질문하다 (to question - formal):

  • 학생이냐고 질문했어요 (questioned if student)

하다 (to say - also acceptable):

  • 좋으냐고 했어요 (said/asked if it's good)

docs.title: Shortened Form -래
docs.text:
In very casual speech, -냐고 can become -래:

  • 어디 가냐고 → 어디 가래 (where are you going, they ask)
  • 뭐 하냐고 → 뭐 하래 (what are you doing, they ask)

Warning: -래 is ambiguous and can mean: 1. Reported question: 뭐 하래? (What are they asking you to do?) 2. Reported command: 하래 (They told me to do it)

Context determines meaning!

docs.title: Tense in Reporting Verb
docs.text:
묻다/물어보다 is usually in past tense (물었어요/물어봤어요) because you're reporting a question that was already asked:

  • 가냐고 물어요 (asks if I'm going - habitual)
  • 가냐고 물었어요 (asked if I'm going - one time)
  • 가냐고 물어볼 거예요 (will ask if I'm going - future)

docs.title: Yes/No vs Wh-Questions
docs.text:
Both use the same pattern in Korean:

  • Yes/No: 좋아하냐고 물었어요 (asked if I like it)
  • Wh-Question: 뭐 좋아하냐고 물었어요 (asked what I like)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Direct: "한국어를 공부해요?" → Reported:

  2. Direct: "어디 갔어요?" → Reported:

  3. Direct: "날씨가 좋아요?" → Reported:

  4. Direct: "학생이에요?" → Reported:

  5. Translate: "She asked if I ate breakfast."

  6. Direct: "뭐 해요?" → Reported:

  7. Direct: "영화가 재미있었어요?" → Reported:

  8. Direct: "내일 올 거예요?" → Reported:

  9. Direct: "누구예요?" → Reported:

  10. Direct: "왜 안 먹어요?" → Reported:

Show Answers 1. 한국어를 공부하냐고 물었어요 - 공부하다 → 공부하냐고 (present verb) 2. 어디 갔냐고 물었어요 - 가다 → 갔다 → 갔냐고 (past tense) 3. 날씨가 좋으냐고 물었어요 - 좋다 → 좋으냐고 (adjective with consonant ending) 4. 학생이냐고 물었어요 - 학생이다 → 학생이냐고 (noun after consonant) 5. 아침을 먹었냐고 물었어요 / 아침 먹었냐고 물어봤어요 - 먹다 → 먹었다 → 먹었냐고 6. 뭐 하냐고 물었어요 - 하다 → 하냐고 (wh-question with present verb) 7. 영화가 재미있었냐고 물었어요 - 재미있다 → 재미있었다 → 재미있었냐고 (past adjective) 8. 내일 올 거냐고 물었어요 - 오다 → 올 거다 → 올 거냐고 (future) 9. 누구냐고 물었어요 - 누구 + 이다 → 누구냐고 (wh-question with 이다) 10. 왜 안 먹느냐고 물었어요 - 먹다 → 안 먹다 → 안 먹느냐고 (negative present verb)

docs.title: Statements
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Type Pattern Shortened Example Verb (Present) -ㄴ다고/는다고 하다 -ㄴ대/는대 간다고 해요 → 간대요 Verb (Past) -았/었다고 하다 -았/었대 갔다고 해요 → 갔대요 Adjective -다고 하다 -대 좋다고 해요 → 좋대요 Noun (이다) -(이)라고 하다 -(이)래 학생이라고 해요 → 학생이래요 Verb (Future) -(으)ㄹ 거라고 하다 -(으)ㄹ 거래 갈 거라고 해요 → 갈 거래요

Key Point: -다고/-라고 attaches to the statement, then 하다 is conjugated

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: Reported statements convey what someone said as a fact or declaration. The ending changes based on whether it's a verb, adjective, or noun.

docs.title: Verb Statements
docs.text:
Present Tense:

Formation differs by verb type:

  • Action verbs ending in consonant: -는다고 하다
  • 먹다 → 먹는다고 하다 → 먹는대요

  • 읽다 → 읽는다고 하다 → 읽는대요

  • Action verbs ending in vowel/ㄹ: -ㄴ다고 하다

  • 가다 → 간다고 하다 → 간대요

  • 살다 → 산다고 하다 → 산대요

  • Descriptive verbs (하다 verbs): -ㄴ다고/는다고

  • 공부하다 → 공부한다고 하다 → 공부한대요

Past Tense:

All verbs: -았/었다고 하다

  • 먹다 → 먹었다고 하다 → 먹었대요
  • 가다 → 갔다고 하다 → 갔대요
  • 공부하다 → 공부했다고 하다 → 공부했대요

Future Tense:

All verbs: -(으)ㄹ 거라고 하다

  • 먹다 → 먹을 거라고 하다 → 먹을 거래요
  • 가다 → 갈 거라고 하다 → 갈 거래요

docs.title: Adjective Statements
docs.text:
Present Tense:

Simply add -다고 하다 to the stem:

  • 좋다 → 좋다고 하다 → 좋대요
  • 예쁘다 → 예쁘다고 하다 → 예쁘대요
  • 크다 → 크다고 하다 → 크대요

Past Tense:

Same as verbs: -았/었다고 하다

  • 좋다 → 좋았다고 하다 → 좋았대요
  • 예쁘다 → 예뻤다고 하다 → 예뻤대요

Future Tense:

-(으)ㄹ 거라고 하다

  • 좋다 → 좋을 거라고 하다 → 좋을 거래요

docs.title: Noun Statements (이다)
docs.text:
After consonant: -이라고 하다 → -이래(요)

  • 학생이다 → 학생이라고 하다 → 학생이래요
  • 의사이다 → 의사라고 하다 → 의사래요

After vowel: -라고 하다 → -래(요)

  • 선생님이다 → 선생님이라고 하다 → 선생님이래요
  • 가수이다 → 가수라고 하다 → 가수래요

Past: -이었다고/였다고 하다

  • 학생이었다 → 학생이었다고 하다 → 학생이었대요

docs.title: Formation Steps
docs.text:
1. Take the direct statement
  2. Remove polite ending (요/습니다)
  3. Identify if it's verb/adjective/noun
  4. Add appropriate -다고/라고 ending
  5. Add 하다 (conjugate as needed)
  6. Optional: Use shortened form

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Present Tense Verbs:

Direct → Formal → Shortened

  • "저는 매일 운동해요" → 매일 운동한다고 했어요 → 매일 운동한대요
  • "친구가 학교에 가요" → 친구가 학교에 간다고 했어요 → 학교에 간대요
  • "언니가 책을 읽어요" → 언니가 책을 읽는다고 했어요 → 책을 읽는대요
  • "오빠가 밥을 먹어요" → 오빠가 밥을 먹는다고 했어요 → 밥을 먹는대요

Past Tense Verbs:

  • "어제 영화를 봤어요" → 어제 영화를 봤다고 했어요 → 어제 영화를 봤대요
  • "한국에 갔어요" → 한국에 갔다고 했어요 → 한국에 갔대요
  • "김치를 먹었어요" → 김치를 먹었다고 했어요 → 김치를 먹었대요

Future Tense:

  • "내일 올 거예요" → 내일 올 거라고 했어요 → 내일 올 거래요
  • "공부할 거예요" → 공부할 거라고 했어요 → 공부할 거래요

Adjectives:

  • "날씨가 좋아요" → 날씨가 좋다고 했어요 → 날씨가 좋대요
  • "한국어가 어려워요" → 한국어가 어렵다고 했어요 → 한국어가 어렵대요
  • "방이 깨끗해요" → 방이 깨끗하다고 했어요 → 방이 깨끗하대요
  • "음식이 맛있었어요" → 음식이 맛있었다고 했어요 → 음식이 맛있었대요

Nouns (이다):

  • "저는 학생이에요" → 학생이라고 했어요 → 학생이래요
  • "제 친구는 의사예요" → 친구가 의사라고 했어요 → 의사래요
  • "선생님이에요" → 선생님이라고 했어요 → 선생님이래요
  • "한국 사람이었어요" → 한국 사람이었다고 했어요 → 한국 사람이었대요

Complex Sentences:

  • "저는 한국어를 열심히 공부한다고 했어요" (I said I study Korean diligently)
  • "친구가 내일 만나자고 했어요" (My friend said let's meet tomorrow)
  • "엄마가 저녁을 준비했다고 했어요" (Mom said she prepared dinner)
  • "날씨가 추울 거래요" (They say the weather will be cold)

docs.title: Reporting Verbs Beyond 하다
docs.text:
말하다 (to say, tell):

  • 좋다고 말했어요 (said it's good)
  • 학생이라고 말했어요 (said he's a student)

듣다 (to hear):

  • 비가 온다고 들었어요 (I heard it's raining)
  • 맛있다고 들었어요 (I heard it's delicious)

생각하다 (to think):

  • 어렵다고 생각해요 (I think it's difficult)
  • 좋다고 생각했어요 (I thought it was good)

docs.title: Shortened Forms in Context
docs.text:
Shortened forms (-대/-래) are very common in casual speech:

  • 친구가 바쁘대요 (My friend says they're busy)
  • 오빠가 집에 간대요 (My brother says he's going home)
  • 언니가 학생이래요 (My sister says she's a student)
  • 내일 비 온대요 (They say it'll rain tomorrow)
  • 그 식당 맛있대요 (They say that restaurant is delicious)

docs.title: Person Changes
docs.text:
When reporting, pronouns may shift:

Direct: "저는 학생이에요" - Reporting about yourself: 제가 학생이라고 했어요 - Reporting about someone else: 그 사람이 학생이라고 했어요

docs.title: Tense in Reporting Verb
docs.text:
The tense of 하다/말하다 shows when the reporting happened:

  • 좋다고 해요 (says it's good - habitual/general)
  • 좋다고 했어요 (said it's good - past reporting)
  • 좋다고 할 거예요 (will say it's good - future reporting)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
1. Direct: "저는 한국어를 공부해요" → Reported (formal):

  2. Direct: "날씨가 좋아요" → Reported (shortened):

  3. Direct: "어제 영화를 봤어요" → Reported (formal):

  4. Direct: "제 동생은 의사예요" → Reported (shortened):

  5. Direct: "내일 갈 거예요" → Reported (formal):

  6. Translate to reported speech: "He said he eats kimchi every day."

  7. Direct: "한국 음식이 맛있었어요" → Reported (shortened):

  8. Direct: "저는 학생이에요" → Reported (formal):

  9. Direct: "친구가 책을 읽어요" → Reported (shortened):

  10. Direct: "피곤해요" → Reported (both formal and shortened):

Show Answers 1. 한국어를 공부한다고 했어요 / 제가 한국어를 공부한다고 했어요 - 공부하다 → 공부한다고 (present verb) 2. 날씨가 좋대요 - 좋다 → 좋다고 → 좋대요 (adjective shortened) 3. 어제 영화를 봤다고 했어요 - 보다 → 봤다 → 봤다고 했어요 (past tense) 4. 동생이 의사래요 / 제 동생은 의사래요 - 의사이다 → 의사라고 → 의사래요 (noun after vowel) 5. 내일 갈 거라고 했어요 - 가다 → 갈 거다 → 갈 거라고 했어요 (future) 6. 매일 김치를 먹는다고 했어요 / 김치를 먹는대요 - 먹다 → 먹는다고 (present verb with consonant ending) 7. 한국 음식이 맛있었대요 - 맛있다 → 맛있었다 → 맛있었대요 (past adjective shortened) 8. 학생이라고 했어요 / 제가 학생이라고 했어요 - 학생이다 → 학생이라고 (noun after consonant) 9. 친구가 책을 읽는대요 - 읽다 → 읽는다고 → 읽는대요 (present verb shortened) 10. Formal: 피곤하다고 했어요 / Shortened: 피곤하대요 - 피곤하다 → 피곤하다고 (adjective)

docs.title: Reported Suggestions: -자고 하다
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern: Verb stem + -자고 하다/제안하다/말하다

  • 가다 → 가자고 하다 (suggest to go)
  • 먹다 → 먹자고 하다 (suggest to eat)
  • Shortened forms: -재(요), -잰(요)
  • Past tense: -자고 했다
  • Negation: -지 말자고 하다

docs.title: Formation
docs.text:
The pattern -자고 하다 is used to report someone's suggestion or proposal. It derives from the propositive ending -자 ("let's") combined with the quotation marker 고.

Basic Structure:

Base Form Pattern Meaning 가다 가자고 하다 suggest/propose to go 만나다 만나자고 하다 suggest to meet 시작하다 시작하자고 하다 suggest to start 쉬다 쉬자고 하다 suggest to rest

Alternative Verbs:

  • -자고 제안하다 (more formal - to propose)
  • -자고 말하다 (to say/suggest)
  • -자고 권하다 (to recommend)

docs.title: Shortened Forms
docs.text:
In spoken Korean, -자고 하다 commonly shortens:

-재(요) (casual suggestion reporting): - 가자고 해 → 가재 - 먹자고 해요 → 먹재요 - 같이 하자고 해 → 같이 하재

-잰(요) (past tense shortened): - 가자고 했어 → 갔잖아 (different meaning) - Use: -자고 했는데 → -잰데

docs.title: Negation
docs.text:
To report negative suggestions ("let's not..."):

Pattern: Verb stem + -지 말자고 하다

  • 가지 말자고 하다 (suggest not to go)
  • 먹지 말자고 했어요 (suggested not to eat)
  • 이야기하지 말자고 제안했다 (proposed not to talk about it)

docs.title: Usage Context
docs.text:
When to use:

  1. Reporting someone's proposal or suggestion
  2. Conveying invitations indirectly
  3. Discussing plans made by others
  4. Recounting group decision-making

Register: - Neutral formality - Common in both spoken and written Korean - Can be used in professional contexts

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Direct vs. Reported:

  1. Direct: 친구가 "영화 보러 가자!" Reported: 친구가 영화 보러 가자고 했어요. (My friend suggested we go see a movie.)

  2. Direct: 선생님이 "내일 일찍 만나자." Reported: 선생님이 내일 일찍 만나자고 하셨어요. (The teacher suggested we meet early tomorrow.)

Practical Examples:

  1. 동생이 저녁에 치킨을 먹자고 했어요. (My younger sibling suggested eating chicken for dinner.)

  2. 남편이 주말에 제주도에 가자고 제안했어요. (My husband proposed going to Jeju Island this weekend.)

  3. 친구들이 다음 달에 등산하자고 해요. (My friends are suggesting we go hiking next month.)

  4. 부장님이 회의를 내일로 미루자고 하셨어요. (The department head suggested postponing the meeting to tomorrow.)

  5. 엄마가 오늘은 외식하자고 하셨어요. (Mom suggested eating out today.)

  6. 아이들이 공원에서 놀자고 했어요. (The kids suggested playing at the park.)

Negative Suggestions:

  1. 친구가 그 사람한테 이야기하지 말자고 했어요. (My friend suggested not telling that person.)

  2. 의사가 당분간 운동하지 말자고 했어요. (The doctor suggested not exercising for the time being.)

Shortened Forms:

  1. 나중에 보재. (= 보자고 해) (They're saying let's see each other later.)

  2. 같이 공부하재요. (= 하자고 해요) (They're suggesting we study together.)

Past Context:

  1. 어제 오빠가 영화 보러 가자고 했는데 못 갔어요. (Yesterday my older brother suggested going to see a movie, but we couldn't go.)

  2. 작년에 이사하자고 했을 때 반대했어요. (When they suggested moving last year, I was against it.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Translate the following into Korean using -자고 하다 or its variations:

  1. My colleague suggested having lunch together tomorrow.

  2. The kids suggested going to the amusement park this weekend.

  3. My friend proposed studying Korean together every day.

  4. Mom suggested not buying expensive clothes.

  5. The teacher suggested starting class 10 minutes early.

  6. My roommate suggested cleaning the house today. (Use shortened form -재)

  7. They suggested meeting at the subway station at 3 o'clock.

  8. My older sister suggested not watching that movie.

  9. The boss proposed finishing the project by next week.

  10. My boyfriend suggested taking a trip during the holidays.

Show Answers 1. 동료가 내일 같이 점심 먹자고 했어요. 2. 아이들이 이번 주말에 놀이공원에 가자고 했어요. 3. 친구가 매일 같이 한국어 공부하자고 제안했어요. 4. 엄마가 비싼 옷을 사지 말자고 하셨어요. 5. 선생님이 수업을 10분 일찍 시작하자고 하셨어요. 6. 룸메이트가 오늘 집 청소하재요. 7. 3시에 지하철역에서 만나자고 했어요. 8. 언니가 그 영화를 보지 말자고 했어요. 9. 부장님이 다음 주까지 프로젝트를 끝내자고 하셨어요. 10. 남자 친구가 휴일에 여행 가자고 했어요.

docs.title: Passive and Causative Voice
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Passive Voice (피동): Subject receives the action

  • Suffixes: -이-, -히-, -리-, -기-
  • 보다 → 보이다 (to be seen)
  • 듣다 → 들리다 (to be heard)

Causative Voice (사동): Subject causes someone else to do something

  • Suffixes: -이-, -히-, -리-, -기-, -우-, -추-
  • 먹다 → 먹이다 (to feed)
  • 입다 → 입히다 (to dress someone)

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Korean has two voice transformations that change how actions relate to subjects:

docs.title: Passive Voice (피동)
docs.text:
The passive voice shifts focus from the doer to the receiver of an action.

English comparison: - Active: "I opened the door" - Passive: "The door was opened (by me)"

Korean: - Active: 제가 문을 열었어요 - Passive: 문이 열렸어요

Formation methods:

  1. Suffix addition (most common): -이/히/리/기-
  2. Auxiliary verbs: -아/어지다, -게 되다

docs.title: Causative Voice (사동)
docs.text:
The causative voice indicates that the subject makes or allows someone else to perform an action.

English comparison: - Direct: "The baby ate" - Causative: "I fed the baby" (I made the baby eat)

Korean: - Direct: 아기가 먹었어요 - Causative: 아기에게 먹였어요

Formation methods:

  1. Suffix addition: -이/히/리/기/우/추-
  2. Auxiliary verbs: -게 하다

docs.title: Passive vs. Causative
docs.text:
Type Focus Example Meaning Active Doer performs action 보다 to see Passive Receiver of action 보이다 to be seen Causative Causing action 보이다 to show (make see)

Important: Some verbs look identical but meaning depends on context:

  • 보이다 (passive): 별이 보여요 (Stars are visible)
  • 보이다 (causative): 사진을 보여요 (I show a photo)

docs.title: Identifying Passive vs. Causative
docs.text:
Passive indicators: - Subject is affected by the action - Often translated with "to be + past participle" - No agent making someone do something

Causative indicators: - Subject causes someone/something to act - Often has an indirect object (에게, 한테) - Translated with "make/let/have someone do"

docs.title: Overlapping Forms
docs.text:
Some verbs have the same form for both passive and causative:

Base Passive/Causative Passive Meaning Causative Meaning 먹다 먹히다 to be eaten to be fed 읽다 읽히다 to be read to make read 신다 신기다 (rare) to put shoes on someone

Context determines meaning:

  1. 이 책이 잘 읽혀요. (Passive - This book reads well)
  2. 아이에게 책을 읽혀요. (Causative - I make the child read a book)

docs.title: Suffix Selection
docs.text:
No strict rule exists for which suffix to use - it's lexically determined:

-이-: 보다 → 보이다, 먹다 → 먹이다, 쌓다 → 쌓이다 -히-: 잡다 → 잡히다, 읽다 → 읽히다, 닫다 → 닫히다 -리-: 들다 → 들리다, 울다 → 울리다, 열다 → 열리다 -기-: 안다 → 안기다, 신다 → 신기다, 벗다 → 벗기다 -우-: 자다 → 재우다, 서다 → 세우다 (causative only) -추-: 낮다 → 낮추다, 높다 → 높추다 (causative only)

docs.title: Passive Voice
docs.text:
When Koreans use passive:

  1. Focus on the result rather than the doer
  2. Formal or written contexts
  3. When the agent is unknown or unimportant
  4. Natural phenomena or states

Less common than English: - Korean often prefers active constructions - Where English uses passive, Korean might use active with different subject

docs.title: Causative Voice
docs.text:
Common uses:

  1. Parents with children (feeding, dressing, etc.)
  2. Teaching contexts (making students learn)
  3. Service contexts (having someone do something)
  4. Instructions and commands

docs.title: Passive Constructions
docs.text:
With suffixes: 

Subject + 이/가 + Passive Verb
문이 열렸어요. (The door opened/was opened.)

With -아/어지다: 

Subject + 이/가 + Adjective/Verb stem + 아/어지다
날씨가 추워졌어요. (The weather became cold.)

docs.title: Causative Constructions
docs.text:
With suffixes: 

Subject + 이/가 + Object + 에게/한테 + Causative Verb
엄마가 아기에게 밥을 먹였어요. (Mom fed the baby.)

With -게 하다: 

Subject + 이/가 + Object + 에게/한테 + Verb stem + 게 하다
선생님이 학생들에게 숙제를 하게 했어요. (The teacher made the students do homework.)

docs.title: Learning Path
docs.text:
1. Start with: Common passive/causative pairs (보이다, 들리다, 먹이다)
  2. Practice: Distinguishing passive from causative in context
  3. Expand: Learn verb-specific suffix patterns
  4. Master: Alternative constructions (-아/어지다, -게 하다)

Proceed to the detailed sections: - Passive Verbs - Comprehensive verb lists and formations - Causative Verbs - Causative suffix patterns and usage - Passive Expressions - Alternative passive constructions

docs.title: Causative Verbs (사동사)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Causative suffixes: -이-, -히-, -리-, -기-, -우-, -추-

Meaning: Make/let/have someone do something

  • 먹다 → 먹이다 (to feed)
  • 입다 → 입히다 (to dress someone)
  • 자다 → 재우다 (to put to sleep)
  • 앉다 → 앉히다 (to seat someone)

docs.title: What is Causative Voice?
docs.text:
Causative voice indicates that the subject causes or allows someone else to perform an action. Instead of doing something directly, you make or let someone else do it.

Structure: 

Subject + Object + 에게/한테 + Causative Verb
엄마가 아기에게 밥을 먹여요.
(Mom feeds the baby / makes the baby eat.)

docs.title: Key Characteristics
docs.text:
1. Indirect action: The subject doesn't perform the main action directly
  2. Object marker: Usually uses 에게, 한테 for the person being caused to act
  3. Dual interpretation: Can mean "make" (force) or "let" (allow)

docs.title: -이- Causative Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Causative Verb Meaning 먹다 먹이다 to feed (make eat) 보다 보이다 to show (make see) 쌓다 쌓이다 to pile up (make stack) 쓰다 (write) 쓰이다 to make write 씻다 씻기다 to wash (someone) 신다 신기다 to put shoes on (someone) 벗다 벗기다 to take off (someone's clothes)

Examples:

  1. 엄마가 아기에게 밥을 먹여요. (Mom feeds the baby.)

  2. 선생님이 학생들에게 사진을 보여 주세요. (Teacher, please show the students the photo.)

  3. 아이에게 옷을 입혀야 해요. (I need to dress the child.)

  4. 할머니가 손자에게 신발을 신겨 주셨어요. (Grandma put shoes on her grandchild.)

  5. 아기를 씻겨야 돼요. (I have to wash the baby.)

docs.title: -히- Causative Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Causative Verb Meaning 입다 입히다 to dress (someone) 읽다 읽히다 to make read 앉다 앉히다 to seat (someone) 맡다 맡기다 to entrust 맞다 맞히다 to make correct/guess 놓다 놓이다 to place, let go 숨다 숨기다 to hide (something)

Examples:

  1. 아이에게 따뜻한 옷을 입혔어요. (I dressed the child in warm clothes.)

  2. 선생님이 학생들에게 책을 읽혔어요. (The teacher had the students read the book.)

  3. 손님을 의자에 앉혔어요. (I seated the guest in a chair.)

  4. 아이를 할머니한테 맡겼어요. (I entrusted the child to grandma.)

  5. 정답을 맞혔어요. (I got the answer right / I guessed correctly.)

  6. 진실을 숨기면 안 돼요. (You shouldn't hide the truth.)

docs.title: -리- Causative Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Causative Verb Meaning 울다 울리다 to make cry, to ring 알다 알리다 to inform, notify 날다 날리다 to fly (something) 살다 살리다 to save (a life) 돌다 돌리다 to turn (something) 물다 물리다 to make bite 밀다 밀리다 to push 걸다 걸리다 to hang (something)

Examples:

  1. 아기를 울렸어요. (I made the baby cry.)

  2. 종을 울렸어요. (I rang the bell.)

  3. 친구들에게 소식을 알렸어요. (I informed my friends of the news.)

  4. 연을 날렸어요. (I flew a kite.)

  5. 의사가 환자를 살렸어요. (The doctor saved the patient.)

  6. 손잡이를 돌렸어요. (I turned the handle.)

docs.title: -기- Causative Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Causative Verb Meaning 안다 안기다 to hold (someone) 웃다 웃기다 to make laugh 옮다 옮기다 to move (something) 맡다 맡기다 to entrust 감다 감기다 to wrap 담다 담기다 to put in, fill

Examples:

  1. 아기를 안겼어요. (I held the baby / let someone hold the baby.)

  2. 친구가 저를 웃겼어요. (My friend made me laugh.)

  3. 책상을 옮겼어요. (I moved the desk.)

  4. 짐을 택배로 맡겼어요. (I entrusted the luggage to delivery service.)

docs.title: -우- Causative Verbs
docs.text:
This suffix is used primarily with certain verbs where other suffixes don't apply.

Active Verb Causative Verb Meaning 자다 재우다 to put to sleep 서다 세우다 to stand (something) up, to stop 타다 (burn) 태우다 to burn (something) 타다 (ride) 태우다 to give a ride 깨다 깨우다 to wake (someone) up 맞다 맞추다 to adjust, match 춥다 춥히다 to make cold 맵다 맵히다 to make spicy

Examples:

  1. 아기를 재웠어요. (I put the baby to sleep.)

  2. 차를 세웠어요. (I stopped the car.)

  3. 쓰레기를 태웠어요. (I burned the trash.)

  4. 친구를 차에 태웠어요. (I gave my friend a ride in my car.)

  5. 동생을 깨웠어요. (I woke up my younger sibling.)

  6. 시계를 맞췄어요. (I set/adjusted the clock.)

docs.title: -추- Causative Verbs
docs.text:
Less common suffix, mainly with adjectives.

Active Verb Causative Verb Meaning 낮다 낮추다 to lower 높다 높이다 to raise, heighten 넓다 넓히다 to widen 줄다 줄이다 to reduce 늘다 늘이다 to increase

Examples:

  1. 목소리를 낮췄어요. (I lowered my voice.)

  2. 가격을 높였어요. (They raised the price.)

  3. 도로를 넓혔어요. (They widened the road.)

  4. 지출을 줄였어요. (I reduced spending.)

  5. 근무 시간을 늘렸어요. (They increased working hours.)

docs.title: Make vs. Let
docs.text:
Context determines whether causative means "make" (force) or "let" (allow):

Make (force): - 엄마가 저를 공부하게 했어요. (Mom made me study.) - 아이를 재웠어요. (I put the child to sleep - gently forced)

Let (allow): - 아이를 놀게 했어요. (I let the child play.) - 친구에게 책을 보여 줬어요. (I showed my friend the book - allowed to see)

docs.title: Common Contexts
docs.text:
1. Childcare: - 먹이다 (feed), 씻기다 (wash), 입히다 (dress), 재우다 (put to sleep)

2. Service/Business: - 맡기다 (entrust), 태우다 (give a ride), 알리다 (notify)

3. Teaching: - 읽히다 (make read), 쓰게 하다 (make write), 배우게 하다 (make learn)

4. Adjustments: - 낮추다 (lower), 높이다 (raise), 줄이다 (reduce), 늘이다 (increase)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Translate the following using appropriate causative verbs:

  1. I need to feed the dog.

  2. Mom dressed my younger brother in new clothes.

  3. The teacher had the students read the textbook.

  4. I put the baby to sleep at 8 PM.

  5. Please show me your ID.

  6. I gave my friend a ride to the airport.

  7. The joke made everyone laugh.

  8. I woke up my roommate this morning.

  9. The company lowered prices.

  10. I entrusted my luggage to the hotel.

Show Answers 1. 개에게 밥을 먹여야 해요. 2. 엄마가 남동생에게 새 옷을 입혔어요. 3. 선생님이 학생들에게 교과서를 읽혔어요. 4. 8시에 아기를 재웠어요. 5. 신분증을 보여 주세요. 6. 친구를 공항에 태워 줬어요. 7. 그 농담이 모두를 웃겼어요. 8. 오늘 아침에 룸메이트를 깨웠어요. 9. 회사가 가격을 낮췄어요. 10. 호텔에 짐을 맡겼어요.

docs.title: Passive Expressions: -아/어지다 and -게 되다
docs.text:
Quick Reference

-아/어지다: Become, get (change of state)

  • 좋다 → 좋아지다 (to get better)
  • 나쁘다 → 나빠지다 (to get worse)
  • 시작하다 → 시작되다 (to be started)

-게 되다: Come to, end up (process/circumstance)

  • 알다 → 알게 되다 (come to know)
  • 만나다 → 만나게 되다 (come to meet)

docs.title: Detailed Explanation
docs.text: While Korean has passive suffixes (-이/히/리/기-), two auxiliary verb constructions provide alternative ways to express passive or intransitive meanings. These are often more flexible and productive than suffix passives.

docs.title: -아/어지다 Pattern
docs.text:
Formation: Verb/Adjective stem + -아/어지다

Core meaning: - Transformation or change of state - "Become" or "get" - Often translates as passive in English

Key characteristic: Emphasizes the result of a change rather than who caused it.

docs.title: -게 되다 Pattern
docs.text:
Formation: Verb stem + -게 되다

Core meaning: - Process leading to a result - "Come to," "end up," "turn out" - Implies gradual change or circumstance

Key characteristic: Emphasizes the process or circumstances leading to a state.

docs.title: With Adjectives (Change of State)
docs.text:
When attached to adjectives, -아/어지다 means "to become [adjective]":

Adjective With -아/어지다 Meaning 좋다 좋아지다 to get better, improve 나쁘다 나빠지다 to get worse, deteriorate 크다 커지다 to get bigger, grow 작다 작아지다 to get smaller 춥다 추워지다 to get cold 덥다 더워지다 to get hot 많다 많아지다 to increase, become more 적다 적어지다 to decrease, become less 가깝다 가까워지다 to get closer 멀다 멀어지다 to get farther

Examples:

  1. 날씨가 점점 추워져요. (The weather is getting gradually colder.)

  2. 건강이 많이 좋아졌어요. (My health has improved a lot.)

  3. 방이 너무 더워졌어요. (The room has gotten too hot.)

  4. 두 사람의 사이가 가까워졌어요. (The two people have become closer.)

  5. 교통이 나빠졌어요. (The traffic has gotten worse.)

docs.title: With Verbs (Passive-like Meaning)
docs.text:
With verbs, -아/어지다 often creates passive or intransitive meanings:

Verb With -아/어지다 Meaning 팔다 팔려지다 (팔리다) to be sold 쓰다 써지다 to be written 만들다 만들어지다 to be made 시작하다 시작되다 to be started, begin 끝나다 끝나지다 to be finished, end 정하다 정해지다 to be decided 열다 열려지다 to be opened 닫다 닫혀지다 to be closed 바꾸다 바뀌어지다 (바뀌다) to be changed 준비하다 준비되다 to be prepared

Examples:

  1. 회의가 3시에 시작돼요. (The meeting starts at 3.)

  2. 모든 계획이 정해졌어요. (All plans have been decided.)

  3. 새 제품이 곧 만들어질 거예요. (A new product will be made soon.)

  4. 일이 다 끝났어요. (The work is all finished.)

  5. 문이 자동으로 열려요. (The door opens automatically.)

docs.title: Special Forms
docs.text:
Some verbs use shortened forms:

Full Form Shortened Form Meaning 되어지다 되다 to become 이루어지다 이뤄지다 to be achieved 바뀌어지다 바뀌다 to change

docs.title: Expressing Gradual Change or Process
docs.text:
-게 되다 emphasizes the process or circumstances leading to a result.

Examples:

  1. 한국어를 잘하게 됐어요. (I've come to speak Korean well / I can now speak Korean well.)

  2. 그 사람을 좋아하게 됐어요. (I came to like that person / I've developed feelings for them.)

  3. 매일 운동하게 됐어요. (I've come to exercise every day / I now exercise daily.)

  4. 진실을 알게 됐어요. (I came to know the truth.)

  5. 새로운 친구를 사귀게 됐어요. (I came to make new friends / I ended up making new friends.)

docs.title: Circumstantial Outcomes
docs.text:
Often used to describe outcomes resulting from circumstances beyond one's control:

  1. 이사하게 됐어요. (I ended up moving / It turned out that I'm moving.)

  2. 회사를 그만두게 됐어요. (I ended up quitting my job.)

  3. 한국에서 살게 됐어요. (I came to live in Korea / It turned out I'm living in Korea.)

  4. 결혼하게 됐어요. (I ended up getting married / We're getting married.)

  5. 일찍 출발하게 됐어요. (It turned out we're leaving early.)

docs.title: With Passive Implications
docs.text:
-게 되다 can sometimes convey passive meaning:

  1. 그 소식을 듣게 됐어요. (I came to hear that news / I happened to hear that news.)

  2. 비밀을 알게 됐어요. (I came to know the secret.)

  3. 그 책을 읽게 됐어요. (I came to read that book / I ended up reading that book.)

docs.title: Key Differences
docs.text: Aspect -아/어지다 -게 되다 Focus Result/state Process/circumstance Change type Natural transformation Gradual development Control Often unintentional Often circumstantial With adjectives Yes (very common) No Formality Neutral Slightly more formal

docs.title: Comparison Examples
docs.text:
With state changes:

  • 날씨가 따뜻해졌어요. (The weather became warm - focus on result)
  • 날씨가 따뜻하게 됐어요. (Less natural - not commonly used)

With abilities/habits:

  • 한국어를 말하게 됐어요. (I came to speak Korean - emphasis on process)
  • 한국어를 말해져요. (Incorrect - not used this way)

With events:

  • 회의가 시작됐어요. (The meeting started - natural transformation)
  • 회의를 시작하게 됐어요. (We came to start the meeting - circumstantial)

docs.title: When to Use -아/어지다
docs.text:
1. Describing weather or environmental changes: - 하늘이 맑아졌어요. (The sky has cleared up.)

2. Physical or visible transformations: - 아이가 많이 컸어요. (The child has grown a lot.)

3. Quality improvements or deteriorations: - 실력이 좋아졌어요. (Skills have improved.)

4. Events beginning or ending: - 파티가 시작됐어요. (The party has started.)

docs.title: When to Use -게 되다
docs.text:
1. Life circumstances: - 한국에서 일하게 됐어요. (I ended up working in Korea.)

2. Gradual realizations: - 중요성을 깨닫게 됐어요. (I came to realize the importance.)

3. Acquired habits or abilities: - 매일 뉴스를 보게 됐어요. (I came to watch the news daily.)

4. Polite announcements: - 결혼하게 됐습니다. (We are getting married - formal announcement.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Choose the correct form (-아/어지다 or -게 되다):

  1. 공부를 열심히 해서 성적이 _. (improve - 좋다)

  2. 새 직장에서 일_. (come to work)

  3. 날씨가 점점 _. (get warmer - 따뜻하다)

  4. 한국 음식을 먹_. (came to eat)

  5. 방이 _. (got clean - 깨끗하다)

Translate the following sentences:

  1. The problem was solved.

  2. I came to understand Korean culture.

  3. The store opens at 9 AM.

  4. My Korean has gotten much better.

  5. I ended up moving to Seoul.

Show Answers 1. 좋아졌어요 2. 일하게 됐어요 3. 따뜻해져요 4. 먹게 됐어요 5. 깨끗해졌어요 6. 문제가 해결됐어요. / 문제가 풀렸어요. 7. 한국 문화를 이해하게 됐어요. 8. 가게가 9시에 열려요. / 가게가 9시에 열리게 돼요. 9. 한국어가 많이 좋아졌어요. 10. 서울로 이사하게 됐어요.

docs.title: Passive Verbs (피동사)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Passive suffixes: -이-, -히-, -리-, -기-

Formation: Active verb stem + suffix

  • 잡다 → 잡히다 (to be caught)
  • 듣다 → 들리다 (to be heard)
  • 보다 → 보이다 (to be seen)
  • 안다 → 안기다 (to be held/hugged)

docs.title: What is Passive Voice?
docs.text:
Passive voice shifts the focus from who performs an action to what receives the action. In Korean, passive verbs are formed by adding specific suffixes to active verb stems.

Key difference from English: - Korean passive is less common than English passive - Korean often uses active voice where English uses passive - Many Korean "passive" verbs function more like intransitive verbs

docs.title: Formation Patterns
docs.text: There is no predictable rule for which suffix to use with which verb. You must memorize each passive verb individually.

docs.title: -이- Passive Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Passive Verb Meaning 보다 보이다 to be seen, to be visible 쌓다 쌓이다 to be piled up 먹다 먹히다 to be eaten 쓰다 (use) 쓰이다 to be used 씹다 씹히다 to be chewed 밟다 밟히다 to be stepped on 뽑다 뽑히다 to be selected, pulled out 섞다 섞이다 to be mixed 꽂다 꽂히다 to be inserted, stuck in 묻다 (bury) 묻히다 to be buried

Examples:

  1. 저 건물이 여기서 잘 보여요. (That building is clearly visible from here.)

  2. 책상 위에 책들이 쌓여 있어요. (Books are piled up on the desk.)

  3. 이 단어는 자주 쓰여요. (This word is used frequently.)

  4. 눈에 무언가 섞였어요. (Something got mixed in my eye.)

  5. 꽃병에 꽃이 꽂혀 있어요. (Flowers are stuck in the vase.)

docs.title: -히- Passive Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Passive Verb Meaning 잡다 잡히다 to be caught 읽다 읽히다 to be read 닫다 닫히다 to be closed 맡다 맡히다 to be entrusted 쫓다 쫓히다 to be chased 좁다 좁히다 to be narrowed 넓다 넓히다 to be widened 낮다 낮히다 to be lowered 막다 막히다 to be blocked 잠그다 잠기다 to be locked

Examples:

  1. 도둑이 경찰한테 잡혔어요. (The thief was caught by the police.)

  2. 이 소설은 전 세계에서 읽혀요. (This novel is read all over the world.)

  3. 문이 닫혔어요. (The door is closed.)

  4. 길이 막혀서 늦었어요. (I was late because the road was blocked.)

  5. 창문이 잠겨 있어요. (The window is locked.)

docs.title: -리- Passive Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Passive Verb Meaning 듣다 들리다 to be heard 열다 열리다 to be opened 울다 울리다 to ring, to sound 알다 알리다 to be known, announced 팔다 팔리다 to be sold 걸다 걸리다 to be hung, to be caught 풀다 풀리다 to be untied, solved 물다 (bite) 물리다 to be bitten 밀다 밀리다 to be pushed 늘다 늘리다 to be increased

Examples:

  1. 멀리서 음악 소리가 들려요. (Music can be heard from far away.)

  2. 가게가 9시에 열려요. (The store opens at 9.)

  3. 전화벨이 울렸어요. (The phone rang.)

  4. 그 소식이 전국에 알려졌어요. (That news was announced nationwide.)

  5. 이 제품이 잘 팔려요. (This product sells well.)

  6. 문제가 풀렸어요. (The problem was solved.)

  7. 개한테 물렸어요. (I was bitten by a dog.)

docs.title: -기- Passive Verbs
docs.text:
Active Verb Passive Verb Meaning 안다 (hold) 안기다 to be held, hugged 신다 신기다 to have shoes put on 벗다 벗기다 to have removed 쫓다 쫓기다 to be chased 감다 감기다 to be wrapped 담다 담기다 to be contained 품다 품기다 to be embraced

Examples:

  1. 아기가 엄마 품에 안겨 있어요. (The baby is being held in mom's arms.)

  2. 어린이가 신발을 신기고 있어요. (The child is having shoes put on.)

  3. 상자에 선물이 담겨 있어요. (The gift is contained in the box.)

  4. 목에 스카프가 감겨 있어요. (A scarf is wrapped around the neck.)

docs.title: When to Use Passive Voice
docs.text:
1. Focus on the result or state:

  • 창문이 열려 있어요. (The window is open.)
  • 문이 잠겨 있어요. (The door is locked.)

2. Agent is unknown or unimportant:

  • 지갑을 도둑맞았어요. (My wallet was stolen.)
  • 그 건물은 1950년에 지어졌어요. (That building was built in 1950.)

3. Natural phenomena or spontaneous events:

  • 눈이 쌓였어요. (Snow has accumulated.)
  • 꽃이 피어 있어요. (Flowers are blooming.)

4. Formal or written language:

  • 회의는 내일 열립니다. (The meeting will be held tomorrow.)
  • 결과가 발표됩니다. (Results will be announced.)

docs.title: Passive vs. Intransitive
docs.text:
Many Korean passive verbs function like English intransitive verbs:

Passive Form English Translation 문이 열렸어요 The door opened (not "was opened") 길이 막혔어요 The road is blocked 문제가 풀렸어요 The problem solved itself

docs.title: State vs. Action
docs.text:
Passive verbs with -아/어 있다 emphasize the resulting state:

  • 문이 열려 있어요. (The door is in an open state.)
  • 문이 열렸어요. (The door opened / has opened.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Change the following active sentences to passive voice:

  1. 경찰이 범인을 잡았어요. (The police caught the criminal.)

  2. 사람들이 이 책을 많이 읽어요. (People read this book a lot.)

  3. 누군가 문을 닫았어요. (Someone closed the door.)

  4. 멀리서 누가 제 이름을 불렀어요. (Someone called my name from far away.)

  5. 어제 가게에서 이 신발을 다 팔았어요. (The store sold all these shoes yesterday.)

Fill in the blanks with the correct passive form:

  1. 길이 차로 __. (막다 - The road is blocked by cars.)

  2. 창문이 ____. (열다 - The window is open.)

  3. 그 소문이 빨리 ____. (알다 - That rumor spread quickly.)

  4. 옷장에 옷이 ____ 있어요. (걸다 - Clothes are hung in the closet.)

  5. 상자 안에 무엇이 ____? (담다 - What is contained in the box?)

Show Answers 1. 범인이 경찰한테 잡혔어요. 2. 이 책이 많이 읽혀요. 3. 문이 닫혔어요. 4. 멀리서 제 이름이 불렸어요. 5. 어제 이 신발이 가게에서 다 팔렸어요. 6. 막혔어요 7. 열려 있어요 8. 알려졌어요 9. 걸려 10. 담겨 있어요

docs.title: Korean Honorific System (존댓말)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Three main components:

  1. Subject Honorifics (주체 높임): -(으)시- to honor the subject
  2. Humble Forms (겸양어): Special verbs to lower yourself
  3. Honorific Vocabulary (높임말 어휘): Special nouns for respected persons

Core principle: Raise others, lower yourself

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Korean honorific system is a complex grammatical and lexical framework for showing respect based on social hierarchy, age, and formality. Understanding and using honorifics correctly is essential for social interaction in Korean culture.

docs.title: Why Honorifics Matter
docs.text:
In Korean society, showing proper respect through language is not optional - it's a fundamental aspect of communication. Using incorrect honorifics can be:

  • Socially awkward (too casual with superiors)
  • Offensive (not showing due respect)
  • Overly deferential (too formal with peers)

docs.title: Three Dimensions of Respect
docs.text:
Korean honorifics operate on three levels:

Type Function Example Subject Honorific Raise the subject 할머니가 주무세요 (Grandma sleeps) Object Honorific Raise the object 선생님께 드려요 (I give to teacher) Addressee Honorific Formal ending -요, -ㅂ니다

docs.title: Subject Honorifics: -(으)시-
docs.text:
The most common honorific marker, inserted between verb stem and ending.

Formation: - Verb stem + -시- + ending - 가다 → 가시다 → 가세요 (go - honorific)

When to use: - Subject is someone you respect - Talking about elders, superiors, customers, strangers - NOT used when subject is yourself (except royal "we")

Examples:

  1. 할아버지가 주무세요. (Grandfather is sleeping.)

  2. 선생님이 오셨어요. (The teacher came/has come.)

  3. 사장님이 말씀하셨어요. (The CEO spoke.)

docs.title: Humble Forms (Object Honorifics)
docs.text:
Special verbs used when you (the subject) perform an action for a respected person (the object).

Key humble verbs:

Plain Verb Humble Form Meaning 주다 드리다 to give (to respected person) 만나다 뵙다 to meet (respected person) 묻다 여쭙다 to ask (respected person) 데리다 모시다 to accompany (respected person) 있다 계시다 to exist (respected person) 먹다 드시다 to eat (respected person)

Examples:

  1. 선생님께 선물을 드렸어요. (I gave a gift to my teacher.)

  2. 교수님을 내일 뵙겠습니다. (I will meet the professor tomorrow.)

  3. 부모님께 여쭤봤어요. (I asked my parents.)

docs.title: Honorific Vocabulary
docs.text:
Special nouns used for respected persons:

Plain Honorific Meaning 밥 진지 meal (for respected person) 나이 연세 age 집 댁 house/home 이름 성함 name 말 말씀 words/speech 생일 생신 birthday

Examples:

  1. 진지 드셨어요? (Have you eaten? - to elder)

  2. 연세가 어떻게 되세요? (How old are you? - respectful)

  3. 성함이 어떻게 되세요? (What is your name? - respectful)

docs.title: When to Use Honorifics
docs.text:
MUST use honorifics: 1. Parents, grandparents, elders 2. Teachers, professors 3. Bosses, superiors at work 4. Customers (in service industry) 5. Strangers (adults) 6. In-laws (especially older)

Generally use honorifics: 7. Anyone significantly older (5+ years) 8. Professional contexts 9. First meetings with adults 10. Public speaking

Don't use honorifics: 1. Close friends (same age) 2. Younger siblings/people 3. Children 4. Yourself (except humble forms)

docs.title: Age and Hierarchy
docs.text:
Korean society is highly age-conscious:

  • Same age (동갑): Usually casual speech, but context matters
  • 1-2 years older: Often casual if close, honorifics if not
  • 3+ years older: Generally honorifics until invited to be casual
  • 10+ years older: Almost always honorifics

Workplace hierarchy overrides age: - Junior employee → Senior employee: Always honorific - Even if junior is older by age

docs.title: Regional and Generational Differences
docs.text:
Generational: - Older generation: Stricter honorific usage - Younger generation: More flexible, especially among friends

Regional: - Seoul: More relaxed in casual settings - Traditional areas: Stricter adherence - Jeolla: Known for particularly polite speech

docs.title: Mistake 1: Using -(으)시- for yourself
docs.text: Wrong: 제가 가셨어요. ❌ Right: 제가 갔어요. ✓

docs.title: Mistake 2: Not using honorifics with 계시다
docs.text: Wrong: 할머니가 집에 있어요. ❌ Right: 할머니께서 집에 계세요. ✓

docs.title: Mistake 3: Mixing plain and honorific vocabulary
docs.text: Wrong: 할아버지가 밥을 드셨어요. ❌ Right: 할아버지가 진지를 드셨어요. ✓

docs.title: Mistake 4: Using humble forms for the subject
docs.text: Wrong: 선생님이 저한테 드렸어요. ❌ Right: 선생님이 저한테 주셨어요. ✓

docs.title: Mistake 5: Overusing honorifics
docs.text:
Using excessive honorifics can sound awkward or sarcastic:

Awkward: 우리 아빠께서 주무시고 계십니다. (Too formal for casual context) Better: 우리 아빠가 주무세요. / 아버지께서 주무세요.

docs.title: Particles with Honorifics
docs.text:
Special particles used with respected persons:

Plain Honorific Function 이/가 께서 subject marker 에게 께 to/for 한테 께 to/for (casual)

Examples:

  1. 선생님께서 오셨어요. (The teacher came.)

  2. 할아버지께 말씀드렸어요. (I spoke to grandfather.)

docs.title: Levels of Formality
docs.text:
Korean has multiple formality levels:

Level Ending Context Formal polite -ㅂ니다/습니다 Business, presentations, news Informal polite -아/어요 Most common polite speech Formal casual -네, -ㄴ/는다 Written, formal casual Informal casual -아/어 Friends, younger people

Honorifics can combine with any level:

  • 할머니가 가십니다. (Formal polite + honorific)
  • 할머니가 가세요. (Informal polite + honorific)
  • 할머니가 가셔. (Informal casual + honorific - rare but possible)

docs.title: Learning Path
docs.text:
To master Korean honorifics:

  1. Start with: Basic -(으)시- insertion
  2. Learn: Common humble verbs (드리다, 뵙다)
  3. Practice: Honorific vocabulary pairs
  4. Master: Context-appropriate usage
  5. Refine: Workplace and formal situations

Proceed to detailed sections:

  • Subject Honorific Forms - -(으)시- conjugation and usage
  • Humble Forms - Object honorific verbs
  • Honorific Vocabulary - Special nouns and words
  • Workplace Korean - Business honorifics and email phrases

docs.title: Honorific Vocabulary (높임말 어휘)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Special nouns for respected persons:

  • 밥 → 진지 (meal)
  • 나이 → 연세 (age)
  • 집 → 댁 (house)
  • 이름 → 성함 (name)
  • 말 → 말씀 (words)
  • 생일 → 생신 (birthday)

docs.title: What is Honorific Vocabulary?
docs.text:
Korean has special vocabulary items used exclusively when referring to respected persons or their possessions. Using these words is essential for proper respectful speech.

Key principle: Regular nouns for yourself/peers, special nouns for respected persons.

docs.title: Why Special Vocabulary Matters
docs.text:
Using plain vocabulary for respected persons can sound: - Disrespectful - Childish - Socially inappropriate

Example: - Wrong: 할아버지 이름이 뭐예요? ❌ (What's grandfather's name?) - Right: 할아버지 성함이 어떻게 되세요? ✓ (What is grandfather's name?)

docs.title: Basic Needs and Daily Life
docs.text: Plain Honorific Category Usage 밥 진지 meal food for respected person 말 말씀 words/speech what respected person says 나이 연세 age age of respected person 집 댁 house home of respected person 이름 성함 name name of respected person 생일 생신 birthday birthday of respected person

docs.title: Body and Health
docs.text:
Plain Honorific Category Usage 이 치아 teeth More formal/respectful 병 병환 illness illness of respected person 몸 - body Use regular + honorific grammar

Note: Not all body parts have honorific equivalents. Use regular nouns with honorific grammar instead.

docs.title: Family Relations
docs.text:
Plain Honorific Category 아들 아드님 son 딸 따님 daughter 아내 부인 wife 남편 남편분 husband

Note: When referring to YOUR OWN family to outsiders, use plain forms to be humble.

docs.title: 진지 (Meal)
docs.text:
Plain: 밥 (rice, meal) Honorific: 진지

When to use: - Referring to a respected person's meal - Asking if elder has eaten - Offering food to respected person

Examples:

  1. 진지 드셨어요? (Have you eaten? - to elder)

  2. 할머니, 진지 드세요. (Grandmother, please eat.)

  3. 진지 잡수셨어요? (Have you eaten? - very respectful, old-fashioned)

  4. 진지 맛있게 드세요. (Please enjoy your meal. - to elder)

Don't use for yourself: - Wrong: 저는 진지 먹었어요. ❌ - Right: 저는 밥 먹었어요. ✓

docs.title: 말씀 (Words/Speech)
docs.text:
Plain: 말 Honorific: 말씀

When to use: - What a respected person says - Asking respected person to speak - Referring to respected person's words

Examples:

  1. 선생님 말씀을 잘 들으세요. (Listen carefully to what the teacher says.)

  2. 할아버지께서 말씀하셨어요. (Grandfather said/spoke.)

  3. 한 말씀만 여쭤봐도 될까요? (May I ask you one thing?)

  4. 사장님의 말씀대로 하겠습니다. (I will do as the CEO says.)

Combined with humble forms: - 말씀드리다 (to speak - humble) - 말씀하시다 (to speak - honorific)

docs.title: 연세 (Age)
docs.text:
Plain: 나이 Honorific: 연세

When to use: - Asking elder's age - Referring to respected person's age - Formal contexts

Examples:

  1. 연세가 어떻게 되세요? (How old are you? - very respectful)

  2. 할아버지 연세가 많으세요. (Grandfather is very old/advanced in age.)

  3. 연세에 비해 건강하세요. (You're healthy for your age.)

Cultural note: Koreans are generally open about age, but asking an elder's age requires proper honorific language.

docs.title: 댁 (House/Home)
docs.text:
Plain: 집 Honorific: 댁

When to use: - Respected person's house - Formal address - Polite reference

Examples:

  1. 댁이 어디세요? (Where is your house? - respectful)

  2. 할머니 댁에 갔어요. (I went to grandmother's house.)

  3. 사장님 댁으로 보내 드릴까요? (Shall I send it to your home?)

  4. 선생님 댁에서 파티가 있어요. (There's a party at the teacher's house.)

Also used as polite second-person: - 댁에서는 어떻게 생각하세요? (What do you think? - very formal/old-fashioned)

docs.title: 성함 (Name)
docs.text:
Plain: 이름 Honorific: 성함

When to use: - Asking respected person's name - Referring to respected person's name - Formal situations (registration, reception)

Examples:

  1. 성함이 어떻게 되세요? (What is your name? - very respectful)

  2. 성함을 여쭤봐도 될까요? (May I ask your name?)

  3. 고객님 성함을 말씀해 주세요. (Please tell me your name, customer.)

  4. 할아버지 성함은 김철수입니다. (Grandfather's name is Kim Chul-su.)

docs.title: 생신 (Birthday)
docs.text:
Plain: 생일 Honorific: 생신

When to use: - Respected person's birthday - Especially parents, grandparents - Formal celebrations

Examples:

  1. 할머니 생신이 언제세요? (When is grandmother's birthday?)

  2. 어머니 생신 선물을 샀어요. (I bought a birthday gift for mother.)

  3. 생신 축하드립니다. (Happy birthday - to respected person.)

  4. 내일이 아버지 생신이에요. (Tomorrow is father's birthday.)

docs.title: Actions and States
docs.text: Plain Honorific Meaning 죽다 돌아가시다 to die (pass away) 자다 주무시다 to sleep 먹다/마시다 드시다 to eat/drink 있다 계시다 to exist/be 아프다 편찮으시다 to be sick

docs.title: Objects and Possessions
docs.text:
Plain Honorific Meaning 선물 - gift (no special form, use honorific grammar) 물건 - thing (no special form) 의견 - opinion (no special form)

Note: Most objects don't have special honorific forms. Use regular nouns with honorific particles and grammar.

docs.title: Respectful Titles
docs.text: Context Title Usage Teacher 선생님 teacher, sir/ma'am Professor 교수님 professor Doctor 의사 선생님 doctor CEO 사장님 company president Manager 부장님, 과장님 department/section head Customer 고객님, 손님 customer, guest

docs.title: Second Person (You)
docs.text:
Avoid direct "you" pronouns with respected persons. Use:

  1. Name/Title + 님

  2. 선생님, 이거 보셨어요? (Teacher, did you see this?)

  3. Titles alone

  4. 사장님, 회의 시작할까요? (Shall we start the meeting?)

  5. 께서 (subject particle)

  6. When asking: 고객님께서 찾으시는 게 뭐예요?

docs.title: When to Use Honorific Vocabulary
docs.text:
Always use: 1. Parents, grandparents 2. Teachers, professors 3. Customers (service industry) 4. Elderly strangers 5. In-laws (older) 6. Boss, superiors

Context-dependent: 1. Aunts/uncles (family culture) 2. Older siblings (formality level) 3. Senior colleagues (workplace culture)

docs.title: When NOT to Use
docs.text: Don't use for: 1. Yourself (be humble) 2. Your family when talking to outsiders (be humble) 3. Friends and peers 4. Children 5. Younger siblings

docs.title: Humbling Your Own Family
docs.text:
When talking to outsiders about your own family, use plain terms:

To outsider about your father: - Wrong: 저희 아버지 성함은... ❌ - Right: 저희 아버지 이름은... ✓

To outsider about your mother: - Wrong: 어머니 생신이... ❌ - Right: 어머니 생일이... ✓

But when speaking TO your parents: - Right: 아버지 생신 축하드려요! ✓

docs.title: Asking Age Respectfully
docs.text:
1. 연세가 어떻게 되세요? (How old are you? - formal)

  2. 올해 연세가 어떻게 되십니까? (How old are you this year? - very formal)

docs.title: Asking Name Respectfully
docs.text:
1. 성함이 어떻게 되세요? (What is your name? - formal)

  2. 성함을 여쭤봐도 될까요? (May I ask your name?)

docs.title: Meal-Related
docs.text:
1. 진지 드셨어요? (Have you eaten?)

  2. 진지 많이 드세요. (Please eat a lot.)

docs.title: Birthday Celebrations
docs.text:
1. 생신 축하드립니다. (Happy birthday - to elder)

  2. 생신 선물이에요. (This is a birthday gift.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Choose the appropriate word (plain or honorific):

  1. 할머니 _이 언제세요? (생일/생신)

  2. 선생님의 _을 잘 들으세요. (말/말씀)

  3. 사장님 _이 어디세요? (집/댁)

  4. 교수님 _이 어떻게 되세요? (이름/성함)

  5. 할아버지, _ 드셨어요? (밥/진지)

Translate using appropriate honorific vocabulary:

  1. What is your age? (to elderly person)

  2. Grandfather, please eat. (meal)

  3. I listened to what the teacher said. (words)

  4. When is mother's birthday? (speaking to family)

  5. May I ask your name? (to respected stranger)

Show Answers 1. 생신 2. 말씀 3. 댁 4. 성함 5. 진지 6. 연세가 어떻게 되세요? 7. 할아버지, 진지 드세요. 8. 선생님 말씀을 들었어요. / 선생님의 말씀을 잘 들었습니다. 9. 어머니 생신이 언제세요? (to family) / 어머니 생일이 언제예요? (to outsiders about your mother) 10. 성함이 어떻게 되세요? / 성함을 여쭤봐도 될까요?

docs.title: Humble Forms (겸양어)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Humble verbs: Used when YOU act toward a respected person

  • 주다 → 드리다 (to give)
  • 만나다 → 뵙다 (to meet)
  • 묻다 → 여쭙다 (to ask)
  • 데리다 → 모시다 (to accompany)
  • 말하다 → 말씀드리다 (to speak)

docs.title: What Are Humble Forms?
docs.text:
Humble forms (겸양어) are special verbs used to show respect by lowering yourself rather than raising the subject. You use them when:

  1. You are the subject (doing the action)
  2. The object (receiver) is someone you respect
  3. You want to show respect by being humble

Key principle: Raise the object by lowering yourself.

docs.title: Humble vs. Honorific
docs.text:
Type Who to honor Subject Example Honorific (높임말) Subject Respected person 선생님이 주세요 (Teacher gives) Humble (겸양어) Object You (the speaker) 제가 드려요 (I give to teacher)

Wrong: 선생님이 드려요. ❌ (Teacher gives - humble form inappropriate) Right: 선생님이 주세요. ✓ (Teacher gives - honorific form) Right: 제가 선생님께 드려요. ✓ (I give to teacher - humble form)

docs.title: 드리다 (to give)
docs.text:
Plain: 주다 Humble: 드리다

Used when giving something to a respected person.

Conjugations: - Present: 드려요, 드립니다 - Past: 드렸어요, 드렸습니다 - Future: 드릴 거예요, 드리겠습니다

Examples:

  1. 선생님께 선물을 드렸어요. (I gave a gift to my teacher.)

  2. 부모님께 용돈을 드려요. (I give allowance money to my parents.)

  3. 할머니께 꽃을 드렸어요. (I gave flowers to my grandmother.)

  4. 사장님께 보고서를 드리겠습니다. (I will give the report to the CEO.)

docs.title: 뵙다 (to meet, see)
docs.text:
Plain: 만나다, 보다 Humble: 뵙다

Used when meeting a respected person.

Conjugations: - Present: 뵈요, 뵙니다 - Past: 뵈었어요 → 뵀어요, 뵈었습니다 → 뵀습니다 - Future: 뵐 거예요, 뵙겠습니다

Note: 뵈다 is the stem, but conjugates irregularly.

Examples:

  1. 내일 교수님을 뵙겠습니다. (I will meet the professor tomorrow.)

  2. 사장님을 뵀어요. (I met the CEO.)

  3. 언제 뵐 수 있을까요? (When can I see you? - respectful)

  4. 다음 주에 뵙겠습니다. (I'll see you next week. - polite farewell)

docs.title: 여쭙다 (to ask)
docs.text:
Plain: 묻다, 질문하다 Humble: 여쭙다

Used when asking a question to a respected person.

Conjugations: - Present: 여쭤요, 여쭙니다 - Past: 여쭤봤어요, 여쭤봤습니다 - Future: 여쭐 거예요, 여쭙겠습니다

Examples:

  1. 교수님께 여쭤봤어요. (I asked the professor.)

  2. 하나 여쭤봐도 될까요? (May I ask you something? - very polite)

  3. 부모님께 여쭤보고 결정하겠습니다. (I'll ask my parents and then decide.)

  4. 선생님께 질문을 여쭙고 싶어요. (I want to ask the teacher a question.)

docs.title: 모시다 (to accompany, escort)
docs.text:
Plain: 데리다, 함께 가다 Humble: 모시다

Used when accompanying or serving a respected person.

Conjugations: - Present: 모셔요, 모십니다 - Past: 모셨어요, 모셨습니다 - Future: 모실 거예요, 모시겠습니다

Examples:

  1. 부모님을 모시고 여행 갔어요. (I went on a trip with my parents.)

  2. 할머니를 병원에 모셨어요. (I took grandmother to the hospital.)

  3. 사장님을 공항에 모시겠습니다. (I will escort the CEO to the airport.)

  4. 손님을 회의실로 모셔 주세요. (Please escort the guest to the conference room.)

docs.title: 말씀드리다 (to speak, tell)
docs.text:
Plain: 말하다 Humble: 말씀드리다

Combination of 말씀 (honorific word for "words") + 드리다 (to give).

Conjugations: - Present: 말씀드려요, 말씀드립니다 - Past: 말씀드렸어요, 말씀드렸습니다 - Future: 말씀드릴 거예요, 말씀드리겠습니다

Examples:

  1. 한 가지 말씀드리고 싶어요. (I would like to say one thing.)

  2. 부장님께 말씀드렸어요. (I told the manager.)

  3. 그 사실을 말씀드려야 해요. (I need to tell you that fact.)

  4. 나중에 다시 말씀드리겠습니다. (I will tell you again later.)

docs.title: 도와드리다 (to help)
docs.text:
Plain: 돕다 Humble: 도와드리다

Combination of 돕다 + 드리다.

Examples:

  1. 제가 도와드릴까요? (Shall I help you?)

  2. 무엇을 도와드릴까요? (How may I help you? - service context)

  3. 언제든지 도와드리겠습니다. (I will help you anytime.)

docs.title: 안내해 드리다 (to guide, show)
docs.text:
Plain: 안내하다 Humble: 안내해 드리다

Examples:

  1. 제가 안내해 드리겠습니다. (I will guide you.)

  2. 길을 안내해 드릴까요? (Shall I show you the way?)

docs.title: 전해 드리다 (to convey, pass on)
docs.text:
Plain: 전하다 Humble: 전해 드리다

Examples:

  1. 메시지를 전해 드렸어요. (I conveyed the message.)

  2. 사장님께 전해 드리겠습니다. (I will pass it on to the CEO.)

docs.title: 알려 드리다 (to inform, let know)
docs.text:
Plain: 알리다 Humble: 알려 드리다

Examples:

  1. 결과를 알려 드리겠습니다. (I will inform you of the results.)

  2. 나중에 알려 드릴게요. (I'll let you know later.)

docs.title: Combined Forms with 드리다
docs.text:
Many verbs can combine with 드리다 to create humble forms:

Verb + 드리다 Meaning 보여 주다 보여 드리다 to show 설명하다 설명해 드리다 to explain 준비하다 준비해 드리다 to prepare 찾다 찾아 드리다 to find (for someone) 가져오다 가져다 드리다 to bring 만들다 만들어 드리다 to make (for someone)

Examples:

  1. 자료를 준비해 드렸어요. (I prepared the materials for you.)

  2. 커피를 가져다 드릴까요? (Shall I bring you coffee?)

  3. 설명해 드리겠습니다. (I will explain to you.)

docs.title: When to Use Humble Forms
docs.text:
Professional contexts:

  1. Employee → Boss

  2. 보고서를 드리겠습니다. (I will submit the report.)

  3. Service worker → Customer

  4. 도와드릴까요? (May I help you?)

  5. Junior → Senior colleague

  6. 내일 다시 말씀드리겠습니다. (I'll tell you again tomorrow.)

Personal contexts:

  1. Child → Parent

  2. 용돈을 드렸어요. (I gave allowance.)

  3. Student → Teacher

  4. 숙제를 드렸습니다. (I submitted homework.)

  5. Anyone → Elder

  6. 할머니를 모시고 갔어요. (I went with grandmother.)

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
Mistake 1: Using humble forms for respected subject

Wrong: 선생님이 저한테 드렸어요. ❌ Right: 선생님이 저한테 주셨어요. ✓ Right: 제가 선생님께 드렸어요. ✓

Mistake 2: Using plain verbs when humble is needed

Less polite: 사장님한테 줬어요. Better: 사장님께 드렸어요. ✓

Mistake 3: Overusing with peers

Awkward: 친구한테 드렸어. (Too formal for friend) Natural: 친구한테 줬어. ✓

docs.title: Particles with Humble Forms
docs.text:
Use honorific particles with the object:

께 (not 에게/한테): - 선생님께 드렸어요. ✓ - 선생님한테 드렸어요. △ (less formal) - 선생님에게 드렸어요. △ (less formal)

docs.title: Formal Announcements
docs.text:
Humble forms are common in formal announcements and business:

  1. 안내 말씀드립니다. (I would like to inform you. - announcement)

  2. 감사 말씀드립니다. (I would like to express gratitude. - speech)

  3. 보고 드리겠습니다. (I will report. - business)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Choose the correct humble form:

  1. 선생님께 선물을 _. (주다 - past)

  2. 내일 교수님을 _. (만나다 - future)

  3. 부모님께 _고 결정하겠습니다. (묻다 - ask and decide)

  4. 할아버지를 병원에 _. (데리다 - past)

  5. 사장님께 한 가지 _고 싶습니다. (말하다 - want to say)

Translate using appropriate humble forms:

  1. May I help you? (to customer)

  2. I will explain it to you. (to teacher)

  3. I met the CEO yesterday.

  4. I will inform you of the results. (to superior)

  5. I asked my parents. (humble form)

Show Answers 1. 드렸어요 2. 뵙겠습니다 / 뵐 거예요 3. 여쭤보 4. 모셨어요 5. 말씀드리 6. 도와드릴까요? 7. 설명해 드리겠습니다. 8. 어제 사장님을 뵀습니다. 9. 결과를 알려 드리겠습니다. 10. 부모님께 여쭤봤어요.

docs.title: Subject Honorific: -(으)시-
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern: Verb/Adjective stem + -(으)시- + ending

  • After vowel: 가다 → 가시다
  • After consonant: 먹다 → 드시다 (irregular)
  • Meaning: Honors the subject of the sentence
  • Usage: When subject is someone you respect

docs.title: What is -(으)시-?
docs.text:
The suffix -(으)시- is the primary grammatical marker for showing respect to the subject of a sentence. It's inserted between the verb stem and the ending.

Core principle: Use -(으)시- when the person performing the action deserves respect.

docs.title: Formation Rules
docs.text:
Basic pattern:

Stem Type Rule Example Vowel stem Stem + -시- 가다 → 가시다 Consonant stem Stem + -으시- 먹다 → 먹으시다 ㄹ stem Drop ㄹ + -시- 살다 → 사시다

docs.title: Conjugation with -(으)시-
docs.text:
The honorific marker comes before the final ending:

Structure: Stem + -시- + Tense + Ending

Present tense: - 가다 → 가시다 → 가세요 (informal polite) - 가다 → 가시다 → 가십니다 (formal polite)

Past tense: - 가다 → 가시다 → 가셨다 → 가셨어요 - 가다 → 가시다 → 가셨다 → 가셨습니다

Future tense: - 가다 → 가시다 → 가실 거예요 - 가다 → 가시다 → 가시겠어요

docs.title: Regular Verbs
docs.text: Dictionary +-(으)시- Present Past Future 가다 (go) 가시다 가세요 가셨어요 가실 거예요 오다 (come) 오시다 오세요 오셨어요 오실 거예요 보다 (see) 보시다 보세요 보셨어요 보실 거예요 듣다 (listen) 들으시다 들으세요 들으셨어요 들으실 거예요 읽다 (read) 읽으시다 읽으세요 읽으셨어요 읽으실 거예요 앉다 (sit) 앉으시다 앉으세요 앉으셨어요 앉으실 거예요 서다 (stand) 서시다 서세요 서셨어요 서실 거예요

docs.title: Special Honorific Verbs
docs.text:
Some common verbs have completely different honorific forms:

Plain Form Honorific Form Meaning 먹다 드시다 to eat 마시다 드시다 to drink 자다 주무시다 to sleep 있다 계시다 to exist/be 없다 안 계시다 to not be 죽다 돌아가시다 to die (pass away) 아프다 편찮으시다 to be sick

Examples:

  1. 먹다 → 드시다
  2. Plain: 밥을 먹어요.

  3. Honorific: 진지를 드세요.

  4. 자다 → 주무시다

  5. Plain: 잘 잤어요.

  6. Honorific: 잘 주무셨어요?

  7. 있다 → 계시다

  8. Plain: 집에 있어요.
  9. Honorific: 댁에 계세요.

docs.title: With -아/어요 Ending
docs.text:
Pattern: Stem + -시- + -어요 → contracted forms

Verb With -(으)시- Full Form Contracted Meaning 가다 가시다 가시어요 가세요 please go 오다 오시다 오시어요 오세요 please come 하다 하시다 하시어요 하세요 please do

Contraction rule: -시어 → -세

docs.title: With Past Tense
docs.text:
Pattern: Stem + -시- + -었/았- + ending

Present Past Polite Past 가세요 가셨다 가셨어요 오세요 오셨다 오셨어요 보세요 보셨다 보셨어요 드세요 드셨다 드셨어요 주무세요 주무셨다 주무셨어요

docs.title: With Modifiers
docs.text:
Pattern: Stem + -(으)시- + modifier ending

-는 (present modifier): - 가시다 → 가시는 - 선생님이 가시는 곳 (the place where the teacher goes)

-ㄴ/은 (past modifier): - 가시다 → 가신 - 할아버지가 가신 후에 (after grandfather left)

-ㄹ/을 (future modifier): - 가시다 → 가실 - 오실 분들 (people who will come)

docs.title: Who Gets -(으)시-?
docs.text:
Always use with:

  1. Parents and grandparents
  2. 아버지가 오셨어요. (Father came.)

  3. 할머니께서 주무세요. (Grandmother is sleeping.)

  4. Teachers and professors

  5. 선생님이 설명하셨어요. (The teacher explained.)

  6. 교수님께서 말씀하세요. (The professor is speaking.)

  7. Bosses and superiors

  8. 사장님이 회의하세요. (The CEO is in a meeting.)

  9. 부장님이 부르셨어요. (The manager called.)

  10. Customers (in service contexts)

  11. 손님이 오셨습니다. (A customer has arrived.)

  12. 무엇을 드시겠어요? (What would you like to eat?)

  13. Strangers (adults)

  14. 저분이 기다리세요. (That person is waiting.)

docs.title: Don't Use with:
docs.text:
1. Yourself (except in extremely formal third-person contexts)
  2. Wrong: 제가 가셨어요. ❌

  3. Right: 제가 갔어요. ✓

  4. Friends (same age or younger)

  5. 친구가 왔어. (Friend came.) - No -(으)시-

  6. Children or younger people

  7. 동생이 학교에 가. (Younger sibling goes to school.)

  8. When being humble about your family to outsiders

  9. 우리 아버지가 오셨어요. (My father came.) - To family
  10. 저희 아버지가 왔어요. (My father came.) - To outsiders (humble)

docs.title: With 께서 (Honorific Subject Marker)
docs.text:
Honorific subjects often take 께서 instead of 이/가:

  1. 선생님께서 말씀하세요. (The teacher is speaking.)

  2. 할아버지께서 오셨어요. (Grandfather came.)

  3. 사장님께서 회의 중이세요. (The CEO is in a meeting.)

docs.title: Double Honorific (Avoid)
docs.text:
Don't use -(으)시- with humble verbs:

Wrong: 선생님이 드리셨어요. ❌ Right: 선생님이 주셨어요. ✓ Right: 제가 선생님께 드렸어요. ✓

docs.title: Passive and Causative with -(으)시-
docs.text:
-(으)시- can combine with passive/causative:

  1. Passive: 열리다 → 열리시다

  2. 문이 열리셨어요. (Awkward - rarely used)

  3. Causative: 먹이다 → 먹이시다

  4. 할머니께서 강아지에게 먹이세요. (Grandmother feeds the dog.)

docs.title: Family Context
docs.text:
1. 아버지께서 신문을 보세요. (Father is reading the newspaper.)

  2. 어머니가 요리하셨어요. (Mother cooked.)

  3. 할아버지께서 산책하세요. (Grandfather is taking a walk.)

  4. 진지 드셨어요? (Have you eaten? - to elder)

docs.title: Workplace Context
docs.text:
1. 부장님이 출장 가셨어요. (The manager went on a business trip.)

  2. 사장님께서 내일 오십니다. (The CEO will come tomorrow.)

  3. 팀장님이 회의실에 계세요. (The team leader is in the conference room.)

docs.title: Service Context
docs.text:
1. 손님, 무엇을 찾으세요? (Customer, what are you looking for?)

  2. 이쪽으로 오세요. (Please come this way.)

  3. 잠시만 기다리세요. (Please wait a moment.)

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Add the appropriate honorific form:

  1. 선생님이 학교에 ______. (가다 - present)

  2. 할머니께서 진지를 ______? (먹다 - past question)

  3. 아버지가 집에 ______. (있다 - present)

  4. 교수님이 책을 ______. (읽다 - present)

  5. 사장님께서 내일 ______. (오다 - future)

Translate to Korean using honorifics:

  1. Grandfather is sleeping.

  2. The teacher came to school yesterday.

  3. Is the customer looking for something?

  4. Mom is cooking now. (to family member)

  5. The professor will explain tomorrow.

Show Answers 1. 가세요 2. 드셨어요 3. 계세요 4. 읽으세요 5. 오실 거예요 / 오시겠어요 6. 할아버지께서 주무세요. 7. 선생님이 어제 학교에 오셨어요. 8. 손님께서 무엇을 찾으세요? 9. 엄마가 지금 요리하세요. 10. 교수님께서 내일 설명하실 거예요.

docs.title: Workplace Korean (비즈니스 한국어)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Essential workplace honorifics:

  • Titles: -님 (사장님, 부장님, 과장님)
  • Email opening: 안녕하십니까
  • Reporting: 보고드립니다
  • Requesting: -아/어 주시면 감사하겠습니다
  • Meeting: 회의, 미팅

docs.title: Korean Workplace Culture
docs.text:
Korean workplace culture is hierarchical and formal. Proper use of honorifics and business language is crucial for:

  1. Showing respect to superiors and seniors
  2. Maintaining professionalism with colleagues
  3. Building relationships (인맥)
  4. Career advancement

Key principle: When in doubt, err on the side of formality.

docs.title: Common Job Titles
docs.text:
Korean Position Level 사장님 President/CEO Highest 부사장님 Vice President 전무님 Managing Director 상무님 Executive Director 이사님 Director 부장님 Department Head Senior 차장님 Deputy Department Head 과장님 Section Chief Middle 대리님 Assistant Manager 주임님 Junior Staff 사원 Staff/Employee Entry

Note: Always add -님 to titles when addressing someone directly or referring to them.

docs.title: Using Titles
docs.text:
Direct address: - 부장님, 보고서 확인하셨습니까? (Manager, did you check the report?)

Indirect reference: - 김 부장님이 회의실에 계십니다. (Manager Kim is in the conference room.)

Email/Written: - 박철수 부장님께 (To Department Head Park Chul-su)

docs.title: Colleagues and Peers
docs.text:
Same level, same year: - Use -씨 or first name (if close) - 민수 씨, 점심 먹었어요?

Same level, senior (older or hired earlier): - Use title or -님 - 김 대리님, 도와주실 수 있으세요?

docs.title: Email Structure
docs.text:
Standard format:

수신: [Recipient]
발신: [Sender]
제목: [Subject]

[Greeting]
[Body]
[Closing]

[Name]
[Title/Department]

docs.title: Opening Phrases
docs.text:
Formal:

  1. 안녕하십니까. (Hello/Greetings - very formal)

  2. 늘 건강하시기 바랍니다. (I hope you are always in good health.)

  3. 그간 안녕하셨습니까? (Have you been well?)

Standard business:

  1. 안녕하세요. (Hello - standard)

  2. 수고 많으십니다. (Thank you for your hard work.)

docs.title: Body - Making Requests
docs.text:
Polite requests:

  1. -아/어 주시면 감사하겠습니다 (I would be grateful if you would...)

  2. 확인해 주시면 감사하겠습니다. (I would appreciate if you could check.)

  3. -아/어 주시기 바랍니다 (I request that you...)

  4. 검토해 주시기 바랍니다. (I request that you review this.)

  5. -아/어 주실 수 있으십니까? (Would you be able to...?)

  6. 도와주실 수 있으십니까? (Would you be able to help?)

  7. -아/어 주시겠습니까? (Would you...?)

  8. 회신해 주시겠습니까? (Would you reply?)

docs.title: Body - Reporting
docs.text:
Reporting phrases:

  1. 보고드립니다. (I report to you. / This is my report.)

  2. 말씀드립니다. (I would like to inform you.)

  3. 알려 드립니다. (I am informing you.)

  4. 첨부 파일을 참고해 주시기 바랍니다. (Please refer to the attached file.)

  5. 다음과 같이 안내드립니다. (I inform you as follows.)

docs.title: Closing Phrases
docs.text:
Standard closings:

  1. 감사합니다. (Thank you.)

  2. 수고하십시오. (Good work / Take care.)

  3. 좋은 하루 되십시오. (Have a good day.)

  4. 건강하십시오. (Stay healthy.)

Formal closings:

  1. 항상 건강하시기 바랍니다. (I hope you stay healthy always.)

  2. 늘 행복하시기 바랍니다. (I wish you happiness always.)

docs.title: Sample Email
docs.text:
Subject: 회의 일정 조율 요청

김철수 부장님께

안녕하십니까.
마케팅팀 이영희 대리입니다.

다음 주 프로젝트 회의 일정을 조율하고자 연락드립니다.

가능하신 날짜와 시간을 알려 주시면 감사하겠습니다.
현재 다음과 같은 일정이 제안되었습니다:

- 11월 20일(월) 오후 2시
- 11월 21일(화) 오전 10시
- 11월 22일(수) 오후 3시

확인 후 회신해 주시기 바랍니다.

감사합니다.

이영희 대리
마케팅팀

Translation: To Department Head Kim Chul-su

Hello, This is Assistant Manager Lee Young-hee from the Marketing Team.

I am contacting you to coordinate the schedule for next week's project meeting.

I would be grateful if you could let me know your available dates and times. The following schedule has been proposed:

  • November 20 (Mon) 2 PM
  • November 21 (Tue) 10 AM
  • November 22 (Wed) 3 PM

Please review and reply.

Thank you.

Lee Young-hee, Assistant Manager Marketing Team

docs.title: Starting a Meeting
docs.text:
1. 회의를 시작하겠습니다. (Let's start the meeting.)

  2. 모두 참석하셨습니까? (Is everyone present?)

  3. 오늘 안건은 다음과 같습니다. (Today's agenda is as follows.)

  4. 먼저 지난 회의 내용을 검토하겠습니다. (First, let's review the previous meeting.)

docs.title: During Meeting
docs.text:
Asking for opinions:

  1. 어떻게 생각하십니까? (What do you think?)

  2. 의견을 말씀해 주시겠습니까? (Would you share your opinion?)

  3. 부장님 생각은 어떠십니까? (What are your thoughts, Manager?)

Giving opinions:

  1. 제 생각에는... (In my opinion...)

  2. 한 말씀 드려도 되겠습니까? (May I say something?)

  3. 말씀드리고 싶은 것이 있습니다. (There's something I'd like to say.)

Agreeing:

  1. 좋은 의견입니다. (That's a good opinion.)

  2. 동의합니다. (I agree.)

  3. 그렇게 하는 것이 좋겠습니다. (It would be good to do it that way.)

Disagreeing (politely):

  1. 죄송하지만, 다른 의견이 있습니다. (I'm sorry, but I have a different opinion.)

  2. 조금 다르게 생각합니다. (I think a bit differently.)

  3. 한 가지 우려되는 점이 있습니다. (There's one thing I'm concerned about.)

docs.title: Ending Meeting
docs.text:
1. 오늘 회의는 여기까지 하겠습니다. (Let's end today's meeting here.)

  2. 다음 회의는 [날짜]에 있겠습니다. (The next meeting will be on [date].)

  3. 수고하셨습니다. (Good work, everyone.)

docs.title: Answering Phone
docs.text:
Company phone:

  1. 여보세요, [회사명]입니다. (Hello, this is [Company name].)

  2. [부서명] [이름]입니다. ([Department] [Name] speaking.)

Connecting caller:

  1. 잠시만 기다려 주십시오. (Please wait a moment.)

  2. 연결해 드리겠습니다. (I'll connect you.)

  3. 지금 자리에 안 계십니다. (They're not at their desk right now.)

docs.title: Making Calls
docs.text:
Introduction:

  1. 안녕하십니까. [회사명] [이름]입니다. (Hello, this is [Name] from [Company].)

  2. [부장님]과 통화할 수 있을까요? (May I speak with [Manager]?)

Leaving message:

  1. 메시지를 남겨 주시겠습니까? (Would you leave a message?)

  2. 전화 주시라고 전해 주시겠습니까? (Could you tell them to call me back?)

docs.title: Daily Greetings
docs.text:
1. 안녕하십니까. (Formal morning greeting)
  2. 안녕하세요. (Standard greeting)
  3. 수고하세요. (Keep up the good work)
  4. 먼저 가겠습니다. (I'm leaving first)
  5. 수고하셨습니다. (Good work - end of day)

docs.title: Requesting Help
docs.text:
1. 도와주실 수 있으십니까? (Could you help me?)

  2. 부탁드립니다. (I ask you for a favor.)

  3. 여쭤봐도 되겠습니까? (May I ask you something?)

docs.title: Apologizing
docs.text:
1. 죄송합니다. (I'm sorry - formal)

  2. 실례했습니다. (Excuse me / I apologize)

  3. 늦어서 죄송합니다. (I'm sorry for being late.)

docs.title: Thanking
docs.text:
1. 감사합니다. (Thank you - formal)

  2. 고맙습니다. (Thank you - slightly less formal)

  3. 수고해 주셔서 감사합니다. (Thank you for your hard work.)

docs.title: Common Terms
docs.text: Korean English Usage 회의 meeting 회의가 있습니다 미팅 meeting (loanword) 미팅 시간 보고서 report 보고서를 작성하다 발표 presentation 발표하다 출장 business trip 출장 가다 근무 work/duty 근무 시간 야근 overtime work 야근하다 휴가 vacation 휴가를 내다 결재 approval 결재를 받다 검토 review 검토하다

docs.title: Action Verbs (Business Context)
docs.text: Verb Humble Form Meaning 보고하다 보고드리다 to report 설명하다 설명해 드리다 to explain 확인하다 확인해 드리다 to confirm 준비하다 준비해 드리다 to prepare 전달하다 전해 드리다 to convey

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Write appropriate workplace responses:

  1. How to ask your manager to review a document? (email style)

  2. How to answer the company phone?

  3. How to politely disagree in a meeting?

  4. How to close a formal email to a superior?

  5. How to ask a senior colleague for help?

Translate to Korean (workplace context):

  1. Manager, the meeting is at 2 PM.

  2. I will report the results tomorrow.

  3. Could you please check the attached file?

  4. Thank you for your hard work. (end of day)

  5. I would appreciate it if you could reply by tomorrow.

Show Answers 1. 부장님, 문서를 검토해 주시면 감사하겠습니다. / 검토해 주시기 바랍니다. 2. 여보세요, [회사명]입니다. / [부서명] [이름]입니다. 3. 죄송하지만, 조금 다르게 생각합니다. / 다른 의견이 있습니다. 4. 감사합니다. 좋은 하루 되십시오. / 항상 건강하시기 바랍니다. 5. [이름] 선배님, 도와주실 수 있으세요? / 여쭤봐도 되겠습니까? 6. 부장님, 회의가 오후 2시에 있습니다. 7. 내일 결과를 보고드리겠습니다. 8. 첨부 파일을 확인해 주시겠습니까? / 확인해 주시면 감사하겠습니다. 9. 수고하셨습니다. 10. 내일까지 회신해 주시면 감사하겠습니다.

docs.title: Advanced Conjunctions (고급 연결어미)
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Advanced conjunction types:

  1. Contrast: -는 반면(에), -더니
  2. Condition: -아/어야, -거든, -는 한
  3. Concession: -아/어도, -ㄹ지라도, -더라도, -ㄴ들

These create more sophisticated and nuanced Korean sentences.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Advanced conjunctions allow you to express complex relationships between clauses with greater precision and sophistication. They're essential for:

  • Academic writing
  • Formal speech
  • Nuanced expression
  • Native-like fluency

docs.title: Why Advanced Conjunctions Matter
docs.text:
While basic conjunctions like -고, -지만, and -(으)면 work for simple connections, advanced conjunctions provide:

  1. Specificity: Exact relationships between ideas
  2. Formality: More sophisticated register
  3. Nuance: Subtle differences in meaning
  4. Emphasis: Highlighting particular aspects

docs.title: 1. Contrast Conjunctions
docs.text:
Express differences, opposition, or simultaneous contrasting states.

Pattern Meaning Usage -는 반면(에) while, whereas, on the other hand Formal contrast -더니 and then, but then Personal observation of change

Example contrast:

  • 여름은 덥다. 겨울은 춥다. (Two separate sentences)
  • 여름은 더운 반면에 겨울은 춥다. (One sentence with contrast)

docs.title: 2. Conditional Conjunctions
docs.text:
Express conditions, requirements, or hypotheticals with various nuances.

Pattern Meaning Usage -아/어야 only if, must Strong necessity -거든 if/when, since Casual condition or reason -는 한 as long as, insofar as Limited condition

Example conditions:

  • Basic: 공부하면 합격해요. (If you study, you'll pass.)
  • Strong: 열심히 공부해야 합격해요. (Only if you study hard will you pass.)
  • Limited: 열심히 하는 한 합격할 거예요. (As long as you work hard, you'll pass.)

docs.title: 3. Concessive Conjunctions
docs.text:
Express concession: something happens despite an opposing condition.

Pattern Meaning Usage -아/어도 even if, although Basic concession -ㄹ지라도 even if, even though Formal concession -더라도 even if (past experience) Concession with past context -ㄴ들 even if Rhetorical concession

Example concessions:

  • 비가 와도 갈 거예요. (Even if it rains, I'll go.)
  • 비가 올지라도 갈 것입니다. (Even if it should rain, I will go. - formal)

docs.title: Basic vs. Advanced Contrast
docs.text:
Basic (-지만): - 형은 크지만 동생은 작아요. (Older brother is big, but younger brother is small.)

Advanced (-는 반면에): - 형은 큰 반면에 동생은 작아요. (Older brother is big, whereas younger brother is small.)

Difference: -는 반면에 is more formal and emphasizes the contrast.

docs.title: Basic vs. Advanced Condition
docs.text:
Basic (-(으)면): - 열심히 하면 성공해요. (If you work hard, you'll succeed.)

Advanced (-아/어야): - 열심히 해야 성공해요. (You must work hard to succeed / Only if you work hard will you succeed.)

Difference: -아/어야 expresses necessity or requirement.

docs.title: Basic vs. Advanced Concession
docs.text:
Basic (-지만): - 어렵지만 할 거예요. (It's difficult, but I'll do it.)

Advanced (-아/어도): - 어려워도 할 거예요. (Even if it's difficult, I'll do it.)

Difference: -아/어도 emphasizes doing something despite obstacles.

docs.title: Formality Levels
docs.text:
Korean conjunctions vary in formality:

Casual Neutral Formal -거든 -는 반면 -ㄹ지라도 -더니 -아/어도 -더라도 - -는 한 -

Usage context:

  • Casual: Conversation with friends
  • Neutral: General writing and speech
  • Formal: Academic papers, formal speeches, official documents

docs.title: Combining Conjunctions
docs.text:
Advanced Korean often combines multiple conjunctions:

  1. 아무리 어려워도 포기하지 않는 한 성공할 수 있다. (No matter how difficult it is, as long as you don't give up, you can succeed.)

  2. 날씨가 좋은 반면에 공기는 나쁘더니 저녁에는 비까지 왔다. (While the weather was nice, the air quality was bad, and then it even rained in the evening.)

docs.title: In Academic Writing
docs.text:
Advanced conjunctions are essential for academic Korean:

  1. 이 연구는 성공적인 반면에 한계점도 있다. (This research is successful; however, it also has limitations.)

  2. 모든 참가자가 동의해야 프로젝트를 시작할 수 있다. (Only if all participants agree can the project begin.)

docs.title: In News and Media
docs.text:
Formal conjunctions appear frequently in news:

  1. 경제가 성장하는 반면 양극화는 심화되고 있다. (While the economy is growing, polarization is deepening.)

  2. 날씨가 좋지 않더라도 행사는 진행됩니다. (Even if the weather is not good, the event will proceed.)

docs.title: In Daily Conversation
docs.text:
Some advanced conjunctions appear in daily speech:

  1. 비싸도 살 거야. (Even if it's expensive, I'll buy it.)
  2. 열심히 해야 돼. (You must work hard / You need to work hard.)
  3. 먹더니 잤어. (They ate and then slept.)

docs.title: Progression Path
docs.text:
1. Master basic conjunctions first (-고, -지만, -(으)면, -아/어서)
  2. Learn one advanced category at a time (contrast, then condition, then concession)
  3. Practice in context with reading and writing
  4. Note formality levels and when to use each

docs.title: Recognition vs. Production
docs.text:
• Recognition: Learn to understand all forms in reading
  • Production: Focus on most common and useful forms for speaking/writing

Priority for production: 1. -아/어도 (concession - very common) 2. -는 반면 (contrast - useful in writing) 3. -아/어야 (necessity - common in speech)

docs.title: Section Guide
docs.text:
Proceed to detailed sections:

  • Contrast Conjunctions - -는 반면(에), -더니
  • Conditional Conjunctions - -아/어야, -거든, -는 한
  • Concessive Conjunctions - -아/어도, -ㄹ지라도, -더라도, -ㄴ들

Each section provides: - Detailed formation rules - Usage contexts and nuances - Multiple examples - Practice exercises

docs.title: Addition Conjunctions
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Pattern Meaning Formality -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 not only... but also Formal -(으)ㄹ 뿐더러 not only... but also Formal/Written -는 데다가 in addition to, on top of Neutral -(으)며 and (simultaneous/listing) Formal -고도 and yet, despite doing Neutral

These patterns add information, emphasizing that multiple things are true or happening.

docs.title: -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라
docs.text: "Not only... but also" — The most common addition pattern.

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: Verb Type Formation Example Action verb Stem + -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 먹을 뿐만 아니라 Descriptive verb Stem + -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 예쁠 뿐만 아니라 Noun + 이다 Noun + 일 뿐만 아니라 학생일 뿐만 아니라 Past -았/었을 뿐만 아니라 갔을 뿐만 아니라

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Korean English 그는 똑똒할 뿐만 아니라 성실하다 He is not only smart but also diligent 이 식당은 맛있을 뿐만 아니라 싸다 This restaurant is not only delicious but also cheap 한국어를 배울 뿐만 아니라 일본어도 배운다 I learn not only Korean but also Japanese 그녀는 가수일 뿐만 아니라 배우이기도 하다 She is not only a singer but also an actress

docs.title: Shortened Form: -ㄹ 뿐 아니라
docs.text: In speech, 만 is often dropped: - 예쁠 뿐 아니라 착하다 (not only pretty but also kind)

docs.title: -(으)ㄹ 뿐더러
docs.text: Same meaning as -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라, but more formal/literary.

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: Type Example Vowel stem 가 + ㄹ 뿐더러 → 갈 뿐더러 Consonant stem 먹 + 을 뿐더러 → 먹을 뿐더러 ㄹ stem 살 + 뿐더러 → 살 뿐더러

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Korean English 비가 올 뿐더러 바람도 분다 Not only is it raining, but it's also windy 그 사람은 부자일 뿐더러 인기도 많다 That person is not only rich but also popular 피곤할 뿐더러 배도 고프다 I'm not only tired but also hungry

docs.title: -는 데다가
docs.text: "In addition to, on top of" — Adds cumulative information, often building toward a conclusion.

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: Type Formation Example Action (present) -는 데다가 먹는 데다가 Action (past) -(으)ㄴ 데다가 먹은 데다가 Descriptive -(으)ㄴ 데다가 예쁜 데다가 Noun 인 데다가 학생인 데다가

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Korean English 비가 오는 데다가 춥기까지 하다 On top of it raining, it's even cold 늦은 데다가 준비도 안 했다 On top of being late, I wasn't prepared either 맛있는 데다가 양도 많다 It's delicious and on top of that, the portions are big 월요일인 데다가 아침이라 사람이 많다 Since it's Monday and on top of that morning, there are many people

docs.title: Nuance
docs.text: -는 데다가 often implies the combined factors lead to a result or conclusion.

docs.title: -(으)며
docs.text: "And" — Formal connector for listing or simultaneous actions.

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: Stem ending Formation Example Vowel -며 가며 Consonant -으며 먹으며

docs.title: Two Uses
docs.text:
1. Listing (and) | Korean | English | |--------|---------| | 그는 의사이며 교수이다 | He is a doctor and (also) a professor | | 서울은 크며 복잡하다 | Seoul is large and complex |

2. Simultaneous actions | Korean | English | |--------|---------| | 음악을 들으며 공부한다 | I study while listening to music | | 웃으며 말했다 | (He) said while smiling |

docs.title: Comparison: -며 vs -고
docs.text: -며 -고 More formal More casual Written/news Spoken Emphasizes simultaneity Sequential or simple listing

docs.title: -고도
docs.text: "And yet, despite doing" — Adds information with a nuance of contrast or unexpectedness.

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: Verb stem + -고도

docs.title: Examples
docs.text: Korean English 알고도 모른 척했다 Despite knowing, (he) pretended not to know 먹고도 배가 고프다 Even after eating, I'm still hungry 듣고도 못 들은 척했다 Despite hearing, (she) pretended not to hear 보고도 믿을 수 없다 Even seeing it, I can't believe it

docs.title: Nuance
docs.text: -고도 implies "even though X happened, Y is still the case" — often unexpected.

docs.title: Comparison Chart
docs.text: Pattern Nuance Example -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 A and also B (neutral addition) 예쁠 뿐만 아니라 착하다 -는 데다가 A, and on top of that B (cumulative) 비가 오는 데다가 춥다 -(으)며 A and B (formal listing) 크며 아름답다 -고도 Despite A, still B (unexpected) 알고도 모른 척했다

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Complete the sentences with the appropriate pattern:

  1. 한국어는 재미있___ 유용하다. (not only... but also)
  2. 시험이 어려운 ___ 시간도 부족했다. (on top of)
  3. 그녀는 노래를 잘하___ 춤도 잘 춘다. (formal: and)
  4. 약속을 하___ 안 지켰다. (despite doing)
  5. 그 영화는 재미없___ 너무 길다. (not only... but also)

Transform these sentences using the pattern in parentheses:

  1. 피곤하다 + 배고프다 → (not only... but also)
  2. 눈이 온다 + 바람이 분다 → (on top of)
  3. 경고를 받았다 + 또 실수했다 → (despite doing)
  4. 서울은 크다 + 서울은 현대적이다 → (formal and)
  5. 운동을 잘한다 + 공부도 잘한다 → (not only... but also)
Show Answers 1. 한국어는 재미있**을 뿐만 아니라** 유용하다. 2. 시험이 어려운 **데다가** 시간도 부족했다. 3. 그녀는 노래를 잘하**며** 춤도 잘 춘다. 4. 약속을 하**고도** 안 지켰다. 5. 그 영화는 재미없**을 뿐만 아니라** 너무 길다. 6. 피곤할 뿐만 아니라 배고프다. 7. 눈이 오는 데다가 바람도 분다. 8. 경고를 받고도 또 실수했다. 9. 서울은 크며 현대적이다. 10. 운동을 잘할 뿐만 아니라 공부도 잘한다.

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: When to use Pattern "Not only A but also B" -ㄹ 뿐만 아니라 "A, and on top of that B" -는 데다가 Formal listing/simultaneous -(으)며 "Despite A, still B" -고도

docs.title: Concessive Conjunctions
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Concessive meaning: "Even if," "although," "despite"

  • -아/어도: Basic concession (even if, although)
  • -ㄹ지라도: Formal concession (even if/though)
  • -더라도: Concession with past experience (even if)
  • -ㄴ들: Rhetorical concession (even if)

docs.title: What is Concession?
docs.text:
Concessive conjunctions express that something happens or will happen despite an opposing condition. The second clause occurs regardless of the first clause.

Structure: Even though A, B (B happens despite A)

English examples: - Even if it rains, I'll go. - Although it's expensive, I'll buy it. - Despite being tired, she continued working.

docs.title: Formation
docs.text:
Pattern: Verb/Adjective stem + -아/어도

Contraction rules (same as -아/어요):

Stem Vowel Suffix Example ㅏ, ㅗ -아도 가다 → 가도 Other vowels -어도 먹다 → 먹어도 하다 -해도 하다 → 해도

Special contractions: - 오다 → 와도 - 되다 → 돼도 - 이다 → 이어도/여도 - 아니다 → 아니어도/아니라도

docs.title: Meaning and Usage
docs.text:
Core meaning: "Even if," "even though," "although"

Key characteristics:

  • Most common concessive form
  • Natural in speech: Used in daily conversation
  • Versatile: Works with any verb or adjective
  • Neutral formality: Suitable for most contexts

When to use:

  • Expressing determination despite obstacles
  • Acknowledging difficulties but proceeding
  • Making concessions in arguments
  • Daily conversation

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Basic concession (even if):

  1. 비가 와도 갈 거예요. (Even if it rains, I'll go.)

  2. 어려워도 할 거예요. (Even if it's difficult, I'll do it.)

  3. 피곤해도 공부해야 해요. (Even if I'm tired, I have to study.)

  4. 바빠도 전화해 줘. (Even if you're busy, call me.)

  5. 비싸도 살 거예요. (Even if it's expensive, I'll buy it.)

Acknowledging contrary conditions:

  1. 돈이 없어도 행복할 수 있어요. (Even if you don't have money, you can be happy.)

  2. 날씨가 나빠도 출발할 거예요. (Even if the weather is bad, we'll depart.)

  3. 실패해도 다시 시도할 거예요. (Even if I fail, I'll try again.)

  4. 아무리 늦어도 기다릴게요. (No matter how late it is, I'll wait.)

  5. 아무리 힘들어도 포기하지 마세요. (No matter how hard it is, don't give up.)

With question words (no matter how/what/who):

  1. 누가 뭐라고 해도 할 거예요. (No matter what anyone says, I'll do it.)

  2. 어디에 가도 같아요. (No matter where you go, it's the same.)

  3. 얼마나 먹어도 배가 안 불러요. (No matter how much I eat, I don't feel full.)

docs.title: Formation
docs.text:
Pattern: Verb/Adjective stem + -ㄹ지라도 / -을지라도

Final Sound Suffix Example Vowel or ㄹ -ㄹ지라도 가다 → 갈지라도 Consonant -을지라도 먹다 → 먹을지라도

Irregular verbs: - ㄹ-drop: 살다 → 살지라도 (drop ㄹ) - ㅂ-irregular: 춥다 → 추울지라도 - 듣다 → 들을지라도

docs.title: Meaning and Usage
docs.text:
Core meaning: "Even if," "even though" (formal/literary)

Key characteristics:

  • Formal register: More formal than -아/어도
  • Written language: Common in formal writing
  • Emphatic: Stronger emphasis than -아/어도
  • Literary tone: Used in speeches, essays

When to use:

  • Formal speeches
  • Academic writing
  • Literary works
  • Official statements

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Formal concession:

  1. 비가 올지라도 갈 것입니다. (Even if it should rain, I will go.)

  2. 어렵더라도 포기하지 않을지라도 성공할 수 있다. (Even if you don't give up despite difficulties, you can succeed.)

  3. 실패할지라도 시도할 가치가 있다. (Even if one fails, it's worth trying.)

  4. 아무리 힘들지라도 계속해야 한다. (No matter how difficult it may be, one must continue.)

Strong determination:

  1. 모두가 반대할지라도 제 의견을 지키겠습니다. (Even if everyone opposes, I will maintain my opinion.)

  2. 시간이 오래 걸릴지라도 완성하겠습니다. (Even if it takes a long time, I will complete it.)

  3. 위험할지라도 도전할 것이다. (Even if it's dangerous, I will take on the challenge.)

Literary/formal contexts:

  1. 비록 가난할지라도 행복할 수 있다. (Even though one may be poor, one can be happy.)
