Plain form (-다, -았다): - Hard news, serious topics - Statements of fact - Headlines

Polite form (-습니다, -했습니다): - Softer stories - Feature articles - Direct address to readers

Modern trend: Mix both in same article:

정부가 새 정책을 발표했다. (plain)
이 정책은 내년부터 시행됩니다. (polite)
전문가들은 효과를 기대했다. (plain)

docs.title: Common news verbs:
docs.text:
발표하다 - to announce
밝히다 - to reveal, state
전망하다 - to forecast
추진하다 - to push forward
강조하다 - to emphasize
지적하다 - to point out
촉구하다 - to urge
요구하다 - to demand
반박하다 - to refute
제안하다 - to propose

docs.title: Direct quotes:
docs.text:
Pattern: "[Quote]"(이)라고 말했다/밝혔다

대통령은 "개혁이 필요하다"고 말했다.
The president said, "Reform is needed."

전문가는 "상황이 심각하다"고 지적했다.
The expert pointed out, "The situation is serious."

관계자는 "조사 중"이라고 밝혔다.
An official stated, "Under investigation."

docs.title: Indirect quotes:
docs.text:
Pattern: -(ㄴ/는)다고 말했다

대통령은 개혁이 필요하다고 말했다.
The president said reform is needed.

전문가는 상황이 심각하다고 지적했다.
The expert pointed out the situation is serious.

docs.title: Attribution verbs:
docs.text:
말했다 - said
밝혔다 - stated, revealed
강조했다 - emphasized
전했다 - reported, conveyed
설명했다 - explained
덧붙였다 - added
주장했다 - claimed, argued

docs.title: Politics:
docs.text:
정부 - government
대통령 - president
국회 - National Assembly
여당 - ruling party
야당 - opposition party
정책 - policy
개혁 - reform
선거 - election
법안 - bill, legislation

docs.title: Economy:
docs.text:
경제 - economy
성장률 - growth rate
실업률 - unemployment rate
수출 - exports
수입 - imports
투자 - investment
주식 - stocks
환율 - exchange rate
물가 - prices

docs.title: Society:
docs.text:
확진자 - confirmed cases
방역 - epidemic prevention
재난 - disaster
사고 - accident
범죄 - crime
교육 - education
환경 - environment

docs.title: Reporting future plans:
docs.text:
-ㄴ/는다고 밝혔다
...할 것이라고 전망했다
...할 계획이다
...할 예정이다

Examples: 

정부는 내년에 새 정책을 시행할 계획이다.
The government plans to implement a new policy next year.

전문가들은 경제가 회복될 것이라고 전망했다.
Experts forecast the economy will recover.

docs.title: Showing statistics:
docs.text:
[Number/Percentage] + 를 기록했다
[Number]명/개/건
[Percentage]% 증가/감소

확진자가 1000명을 넘었다.
Confirmed cases exceeded 1,000.

실업률이 3%를 기록했다.
Unemployment recorded 3%.

수출이 10% 증가했다.
Exports increased 10%.

docs.title: Expressing urgency:
docs.text:
...에 따라 (according to)
...로 인해 (due to)
긴급히 (urgently)
즉시 (immediately)
조속히 (promptly)

docs.title: Sample News Article
docs.text:
[제목] 정부, 청년 일자리 대책 발표

[리드] 정부가 15일 청년 실업 문제 해결을 위한 종합 대책을 발표했다.

[본문] 이번 대책에는 청년 일자리 10만 개 창출과 직업훈련 강화가 포함됐다.
정부는 향후 3년간 5조 원을 투입할 계획이다.

[인용] 고용노동부 관계자는 "청년 일자리 문제가 시급하다"며
"실효성 있는 정책을 추진하겠다"고 밝혔다.

[배경] 현재 청년 실업률은 10%를 넘어서며 역대 최고 수준을 기록하고 있다.

[전망] 전문가들은 이번 대책의 효과를 주목하고 있다.
한 경제학자는 "장기적 관점에서 접근해야 한다"고 조언했다.

docs.title: Exercise 1: Write Headlines
docs.text:
Create headlines for:

  1. Samsung announces new smartphone (tomorrow)
  2. Seoul weather: heavy snow warning
  3. President emphasizes education reform
  4. COVID cases reach 500
  5. Stock market falls 2%

docs.title: Exercise 2: Write a Lead
docs.text: Write a lead paragraph (2-3 sentences) with 5W1H: - Government announces new traffic policy - Starting next month - To reduce congestion in Seoul - Through bus lane expansion

docs.title: Exercise 3: Convert to News Style
docs.text:
Convert this casual text to news style:

어제 서울에서 큰 행사가 있었어요.
많은 사람들이 참여했고 정말 재미있었어요.
시장님도 오셔서 축사를 하셨어요.

docs.title: Exercise 4: Add Quotes
docs.text:
Add appropriate attribution verbs:

  1. 전문가는 "상황이 좋아지고 있다" .
  2. 대통령은 개혁이 필요하다 .
  3. 회사 관계자는 "신제품을 출시할 것"_ _.
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1. 삼성, 내일 신형 스마트폰 공개 2. 서울, 폭설 주의보 발령 3. 대통령, "교육 개혁" 강조 4. 코로나 확진자 500명 돌파 5. 주식시장 2% 하락

Exercise 2: Sample Answer 

정부가 다음 달부터 서울 교통 혼잡 완화를 위한
새로운 교통 정책을 시행한다.
이번 정책은 버스 전용차로 확대를 통해
대중교통 이용을 늘리는 데 중점을 둔다.

Exercise 3: 

14일 서울에서 대규모 행사가 열렸다.
수천 명의 시민이 참여한 가운데
시장이 참석해 축사를 했다.

Exercise 4: 1. 고 말했다 / 라고 밝혔다 2. 고 말했다 / 고 강조했다 3. 이라고 밝혔다 / 라고 전했다

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Too casual in headlines: 

❌ 정부가 정책을 발표했어요
✓ 정부, 새 정책 발표

2. Missing attribution: 

❌ "상황이 심각하다."
✓ "상황이 심각하다"고 전문가는 말했다.

3. Buried lead: 

❌ 어제 회의가 있었다. 정부가 새 정책을 발표했다.
✓ 정부가 어제 새 정책을 발표했다.

4. Inconsistent style: 

❌ 정부는 발표했어요. 이 정책은 중요하다.
✓ 정부는 발표했다. 이 정책은 중요하다.

docs.title: Do:
docs.text:
• Put most important info first
  • Use active voice when possible
  • Be concise and direct
  • Attribute quotes properly
  • Use specific numbers/data
  • Maintain objective tone

docs.title: Don't:
docs.text:
• Bury the lead
  • Use opinion words (great, terrible)
  • Use first person
  • Include irrelevant details
  • Use vague language
  • Mix formality levels inconsistently

docs.title: Korean News Characteristics
docs.text:
Korean news tends to:

  1. Be more formal than English news
  2. Use honorifics for respected figures
  3. Quote extensively rather than paraphrase
  4. Focus on hierarchy (titles matter)
  5. Be less sensationalist than some Western tabloids

docs.title: Titles matter:
docs.text:
이재용 삼성전자 부회장 (Lee Jae-yong, Samsung Vice Chairman)
윤석열 대통령 (President Yoon Seok-yeol)
김 교수 (Professor Kim)

Always use proper titles in Korean news.

docs.title: Passive voice for sensitive topics:
docs.text:
✓ 사고가 발생했다. (An accident occurred)
Rather than: 운전자가 사고를 냈다. (The driver caused an accident)

This maintains neutrality until fault is determined.

docs.title: Advanced: Editorial Writing
docs.text:
Editorials (사설) use more opinion:

...해야 한다 (must/should)
...이 바람직하다 (is desirable)
...을 우려한다 (be concerned that)
...을 기대한다 (hope/expect)

Example: 

정부는 보다 적극적인 대책을 마련해야 한다.
이러한 문제는 장기적 관점에서 접근하는 것이 바람직하다.

But regular news stays objective!

Master news style to read Korean news effectively and write professional news-style Korean.

docs.title: Colloquial Korean
docs.text: Colloquial Korean is the casual, everyday language spoken by native speakers in informal settings. It differs significantly from textbook Korean through contractions, slang, shortcuts, and natural speech patterns.

docs.title: Why Learn Colloquial Korean?
docs.text:
Understanding native speakers: - K-dramas and variety shows - Casual conversations with friends - Social media and text messages - YouTube videos and podcasts

Sounding natural: - Less textbook, more authentic - Building rapport with native speakers - Understanding cultural references - Fitting in socially

docs.title: Contractions
docs.text: Shortening words and phrases for speed and naturalness: - 뭐 해? (what doing?) instead of 무엇을 해? - 왔어 (came) instead of 왔어요

docs.title: Slang
docs.text: Generation-specific and trendy language: - 대박 (awesome, jackpot) - 헐 (OMG, what?!) - 쩐다 (amazing, intense)

docs.title: Texting Language
docs.text: Digital communication shortcuts: - ㅋㅋ (laughter) - ㅇㅇ (yes, yeah) - ㄴㄴ (no, nope)

docs.title: Filler Words
docs.text: Natural hesitations and speech markers: - 음... (um...) - 그... (uh...) - 뭐랄까... (how should I say...)

docs.title: Formality Spectrum
docs.text:
Most Formal: 합니다체 → 해요체 → 반말 (casual) → 슬랭 (slang) Least Formal

Colloquial Korean lives in the 반말 and 슬랭 zones.

docs.title: Appropriate:
docs.text:
• Close friends (same age or younger)
  • Family members (depending on relationship)
  • Online gaming and social media
  • Text messages to friends
  • Casual social situations

docs.title: Not appropriate:
docs.text:
• Workplace (unless very casual company)
  • Strangers
  • Anyone older than you (unless they explicitly say it's okay)
  • Formal situations
  • Academic or business writing

docs.title: Warning: Age and Hierarchy Matter
docs.text:
Korean is highly sensitive to social relationships. Using colloquial language with the wrong person can be: - Disrespectful - Offensive - Socially damaging

Safe rule: Wait for the other person to use casual language first, or ask permission: 

반말해도 돼요?
Is it okay to use casual language?

docs.title: Contractions
docs.text: Common shortenings in everyday speech: - 뭐 → 머 - 것 → 거 - 그것 → 그거 - And many more

docs.title: Slang Basics
docs.text: Contemporary informal expressions: - Common slang terms - When and how to use them - Generational differences

docs.title: Texting Language
docs.text: Digital communication: - Korean keyboard shortcuts - Emoticons and symbols - Abbreviations - Internet slang

docs.title: Filler Words
docs.text: Natural speech patterns: - Hesitation markers - Discourse particles - Conversation fillers - How to sound natural

docs.title: Learning Approach
docs.text:
1. Listen extensively: - Watch Korean content with Korean subtitles - Note differences from formal Korean - Pay attention to patterns

2. Start recognizing: - Learn to understand before using - Passive knowledge first - Active use with caution

3. Practice appropriately: - Only with people where it's suitable - Start with safe contractions - Build up to slang gradually

4. Stay current: - Slang changes quickly - What's popular now may be outdated soon - Follow Korean social media

docs.title: Common Challenges
docs.text:
For learners: - Knowing when it's appropriate - Understanding fast, casual speech - Keeping up with new slang - Balancing casual and polite speech

Solutions: - Consume lots of native content - Ask Korean friends for guidance - Focus on understanding first - Be conservative with usage

docs.title: Korean Social Dynamics
docs.text: Colloquial Korean reflects: - Age hierarchy: Younger speaks casually to younger - Intimacy: Close relationships allow casual speech - Context: Situation determines appropriateness - Group culture: In-group vs. out-group language

docs.title: The "우리" (we) Culture
docs.text:
Koreans often use casual speech to show: - We're on the same team - We're close friends - We're comfortable together - We trust each other

But misusing it shows: - Lack of respect - Cultural ignorance - Poor social awareness

docs.title: Moving Forward
docs.text:
Each section will help you: - Understand natural Korean speech - Sound less textbook-like - Navigate different social situations - Communicate more naturally

Remember: Understanding colloquial Korean is essential, but using it requires cultural awareness and judgment.

Let's explore the casual side of Korean!

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Full Form Contraction Meaning 무엇 뭐 what 것 거 thing 이것 이거 this 그것 그거 that 저것 저거 that (over there) ~지 않다 안~, ~지 말다 → ~지 마 not

docs.title: Question Words
docs.text:
무엇 → 뭐 

Full: 무엇을 해요?
Casual: 뭐 해? / 뭐 해요?
What are you doing?

무엇 → 뭘 (before verb, with 을/를) 

뭘 먹을까?
What should we eat?

뭘 샀어?
What did you buy?

무슨 → 무슨 (stays same, but pronunciation shortens) 

무슨 일이야?
What's the matter?

docs.title: Demonstratives
docs.text:
이것 / 그것 / 저것 → 이거 / 그거 / 저거 

이거 뭐야?
What's this?

그거 내 거야.
That's mine.

저거 봐!
Look at that!

이것을 / 그것을 → 이걸 / 그걸 / 저걸 

이걸 어떻게 해?
How do I do this?

그걸 왜 샀어?
Why did you buy that?

이것이 / 그것이 → 이게 / 그게 / 저게 

이게 뭐야?
What is this?

그게 문제야.
That's the problem.

이렇게 / 그렇게 / 저렇게 → 이렇게 / 그렇게 / 저렇게 Often shortened in pronunciation: 

이렇게 → 이케 (very casual)
그렇게 → 그케 (very casual)

docs.title: People References
docs.text:
얘 / 쟤 / 걔 

이 아이 → 얘 (this kid, this person)
저 아이 → 쟤 (that kid, that person over there)
그 아이 → 걔 (that kid, that person)

얘 누구야?
Who's this?

걔 왔어?
Did that person come?

docs.title: 것 (thing) Contractions
docs.text:
-는 것 → -는 거 

가는 것 → 가는 거
먹는 것 → 먹는 거

뭐 하는 거야?
What are you doing?

-ㄴ/은 것 → -ㄴ/은 거 

만든 것 → 만든 거
먹은 것 → 먹은 거

이거 네가 만든 거야?
Did you make this?

-ㄹ 것 → -ㄹ 거 

갈 것이다 → 갈 거야
먹을 것이다 → 먹을 거야

내일 뭐 할 거야?
What will you do tomorrow?

docs.title: -아/어 Contractions
docs.text:
해 + 어 combinations: 

하여 → 해
하여서 → 해서

어떻게 해?
What should I do?

너무 바빠서 못 갔어.
I was too busy so I couldn't go.

-지 않다 → 안 

가지 않다 → 안 가다
먹지 않다 → 안 먹다

안 가.
I'm not going.

-지 말다 → -지 마 

하지 마!
Don't do it!

가지 마.
Don't go.

먹지 마.
Don't eat.

docs.title: -아/어요 → -아/어
docs.text:
Dropping 요 in casual speech: 

가요 → 가
했어요 → 했어
먹어요 → 먹어

뭐 해?
What are you doing?

어디 가?
Where are you going?

docs.title: -고 있다 → -고 있어
docs.text:
먹고 있다 → 먹고 있어
공부하고 있다 → 공부하고 있어

지금 뭐 하고 있어?
What are you doing right now?

docs.title: Past Tense Shortcuts
docs.text:
-았/었어요 → -았/었어 

갔어요 → 갔어
먹었어요 → 먹었어

어제 뭐 했어?
What did you do yesterday?

Double 이 reduction: 

이었어요 → 였어요 → 였어
학생이었어요 → 학생이었어 → 학생였어

나도 학생였어.
I was a student too.

docs.title: Question Endings
docs.text:
-는가 → -나, -냐 

가는가? → 가냐? / 가나?
먹는가? → 먹냐?

어디 가냐?
Where are you going?

뭐 하냐?
What are you doing?

-ㄹ 것인가 → -ㄹ까 

갈 것인가? → 갈까?
먹을 것인가? → 먹을까?

같이 갈까?
Shall we go together?

docs.title: Statement Endings
docs.text:
-는다 / -ㄴ다 (casual statements) 

간다.
I'm going. / (I) go.

먹는다.
I'm eating. / (I) eat.

좋다.
It's good.

docs.title: Everyday Expressions
docs.text:
뭐 하고 있어? → 뭐 해? 

Full: 지금 무엇을 하고 있어?
Casual: 지금 뭐 해?
What are you doing now?

-지 않을래 → 안 할래 

가지 않을래? → 안 갈래?
Won't you go?

-하지 않았어 → 안 했어 

먹지 않았어 → 안 먹었어
Didn't eat.

docs.title: Propositions
docs.text:
-ㄹ까요? → -ㄹ까? 

갈까요? → 갈까?
Shall we go?

뭐 먹을까?
What shall we eat?

-합시다 → -자 

가자!
Let's go!

먹자!
Let's eat!

docs.title: Particle Dropping
docs.text:
In casual speech, particles are often dropped:

을/를 dropping: 

밥을 먹어 → 밥 먹어
뭐를 해? → 뭐 해?

밥 먹었어?
Did you eat?

은/는 dropping: 

나는 학생이야 → 나 학생이야
이것은 뭐야? → 이거 뭐야?

나 배고파.
I'm hungry.

이/가 often stays (for clarity): 

누가 왔어?
Who came?

에 sometimes drops: 

집에 가 → 집 가 (very casual)
학교에 가? → 학교 가?

docs.title: Multiple Contractions Combined
docs.text:
In real speech, multiple contractions stack:

Example 1: 

Level 5: 그것을 하지 않을 것입니다
Level 4: 그것을 하지 않을 거예요
Level 3: 그거 하지 않을 거예요
Level 2: 그거 안 할 거예요
Level 1: 그거 안 할 거야
Casual: 그거 안 해

I won't do that.

Example 2: 

Level 5: 무엇을 하고 있습니까?
Level 4: 뭐 하고 있어요?
Level 3: 뭐 하고 있어?
Level 2: 뭐 해?
What are you doing?

docs.title: Exercise 1: Contract These Sentences
docs.text:
1. 이것이 무엇이에요?
  2. 그것을 어떻게 해요?
  3. 지금 무엇을 하고 있어요?
  4. 내일 어디에 갈 것이에요?
  5. 하지 마세요.

docs.title: Exercise 2: Expand to Full Form
docs.text:
1. 그거 뭐야?
  2. 어디 가?
  3. 안 먹어.
  4. 뭘 샀어?
  5. 얘 누구야?

docs.title: Exercise 3: Choose Most Natural Casual Form
docs.text:
Which sounds most natural for casual speech with friends?

  1. a) 무엇을 먹을까요? b) 뭐 먹을까? c) 뭘 먹을까?
  2. a) 하지 마세요 b) 하지 마 c) 하지 않아요
  3. a) 이것 좀 봐요 b) 이거 좀 봐 c) 이것 좀 보세요
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1. 이게 뭐야? / 이거 뭐야? 2. 그걸 어떻게 해? / 그거 어떻게 해? 3. 지금 뭐 해? / 지금 뭐 하고 있어? 4. 내일 어디 갈 거야? 5. 하지 마. / 하지 마!

Exercise 2: 1. 그것이 무엇이에요? 2. 어디에 가요? / 어디 가요? 3. 먹지 않아요 / 안 먹어요 4. 무엇을 샀어요? 5. 이 아이가 누구예요?

Exercise 3: 1. b) or c) both very natural 2. b) most casual with friends 3. b) most natural casual

docs.title: Regional Variations
docs.text:
Some contractions vary by region:

Seoul/Standard: 

뭐 해?
What are you doing?

Busan dialect: 

뭐 하노?
What are you doing?

Jeolla dialect: 

뭐 하시냐?
What are you doing?

Focus on standard Seoul contractions as a learner.

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Over-formalizing casual situations: 

❌ (to close friend) 무엇을 하고 계세요?
✓ 뭐 해?

2. Being too casual in wrong situations: 

❌ (to stranger) 뭐 해?
✓ 뭐 하세요?

3. Unclear contractions: 

Some contractions can be ambiguous:
그게 - could be 그것이 or 그것을
Context makes it clear.

docs.title: Pronunciation Tips
docs.text:
Some contractions also change pronunciation:

이거 [이거] or [이꺼] The ㄱ can sound harder.

뭐 [뭐] becomes very short Almost like "mwo" in one quick syllable.

했어 [해써] The ㅆ is pronounced clearly.

docs.title: Natural Usage Tips
docs.text:
1. Use with same-age or younger friends only
  2. Start with safe contractions: 뭐, 거, 이거/그거
  3. Watch for context: Even with friends, some situations need politeness
  4. Listen more than speak: Build intuition for when contractions fit
  5. Don't overdo it: Mix with some full forms for clarity

docs.title: Contractions Show Closeness
docs.text: Using contractions signals: - Intimacy: We're close enough for casual speech - Same level: We're equals (or I'm senior) - Comfortable: This is a relaxed situation - In-group: We're part of the same social circle

docs.title: When Koreans Meet
docs.text:
New acquaintances typically: 1. Start with 존댓말 (polite speech) 2. Gradually relax if similar age 3. Eventually ask "반말 할까?" (Shall we use casual speech?) 4. Then switch to contractions and casual forms

This progression is important for building relationships properly.

docs.title: In K-Dramas
docs.text:
Notice how characters: - Switch between formal and casual - Use contractions with friends - Maintain politeness with superiors - Change speech based on situation

This code-switching is a crucial Korean communication skill!

Master contractions to sound natural, but always prioritize appropriate usage over casual coolness.

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Filler Function Example 음... Hesitation (um...) 음... 잘 모르겠어 어... Thinking (uh...) 어... 그게... 그... Hesitant start 그... 저기... 뭐랄까 How to say... 뭐랄까, 좀 이상해 좀 Softener 좀 도와줄래?

docs.title: 음... / 어... (Um... / Uh...)
docs.text:
Basic thinking sounds: 

음... 잘 모르겠는데.
Um... I'm not sure.

어... 뭐였더라?
Uh... what was it?

음... 생각해 볼게.
Um... let me think about it.

Usage: - Shows you're thinking - Buys time to formulate response - Natural in all casual conversations - Can be extended: 음음음...

Difference: - 음 - deeper, more thoughtful - 어 - lighter hesitation

docs.title: 그... / 저기... (Uh... / Um...)
docs.text:
Soft conversation starters: 

그... 실례지만...
Uh... excuse me but...

저기... 물어볼 게 있는데...
Um... I have something to ask...

그게... 사실은...
Well... actually...

Usage: - Polite way to start - Softens what you're about to say - Shows hesitation or uncertainty - Often paired: 그... 저기...

저기 specifically: - Getting attention politely - Interrupting gently - Starting a request

docs.title: 그러니까... (So... / I mean...)
docs.text:
Explaining or clarifying: 

그러니까, 내 말은...
So, what I mean is...

그러니까 그게 아니라...
I mean, it's not that...

Usage: - Restating your point - Clarifying misunderstanding - Buying time while explaining - Can show slight frustration

docs.title: 뭐... (Well... / What...)
docs.text:
Downplaying or hedging: 

뭐, 괜찮아.
Well, it's fine.

뭐, 그럭저럭.
Well, so-so.

뭐 어때?
Well, so what?

Usage: - Casual acceptance - Indifference - Dismissive tone (context dependent) - Downplaying importance

docs.title: 뭐랄까 (How should I say... / Kind of...)
docs.text:
Searching for words: 

뭐랄까, 좀 이상한 느낌이야.
How should I say... it's kind of a strange feeling.

그 사람은 뭐랄까... 독특해.
That person is, how should I say... unique.

Variations: - 뭐라고 해야 하지? (What should I call it?) - 뭐라 표현하지? (How to express it?)

docs.title: 그냥 (Just... / I don't know...)
docs.text:
Minimizing or being vague: 

왜 샀어? - 그냥.
Why did you buy it? - Just because.

그냥 그래.
Just... because.

그냥 궁금해서.
Just curious.

Usage: - Avoiding detailed explanation - Being casual - "No particular reason" - Can seem dismissive

docs.title: 근데 / 그런데 (But... / By the way...)
docs.text:
Topic shift or contrast: 

근데 너 어제 뭐 했어?
But what did you do yesterday?

그런데 말이야...
But you know...

Usage: - Changing subject - Adding new thought - Contrasting with previous statement - Very common in conversation flow

docs.title: 막 (Like... / Just...)
docs.text:
Describing vaguely or intensely: 

막 달려왔어.
I just ran here.

막 이렇게 했어.
(I) like, did it like this.

막 화났어.
(I was) like, so angry.

Usage: - Intensifier - Vague description - "All of a sudden" - Very casual, common among young people

docs.title: 약간 (Kind of... / Sort of...)
docs.text:
Hedging statements: 

약간 이상해.
It's kind of weird.

약간 그런 느낌?
Kind of that feeling, you know?

Usage: - Softening statements - Not fully committing - "Somewhat" - More precise than 좀

docs.title: 좀 (A bit... / Please...)
docs.text:
Multiple functions:

Softening requests: 

좀 도와줘.
Help me a bit. / Please help me.

물 좀 줄래?
Can you give me some water? (softer)

Meaning "a little": 

좀 추워.
It's a bit cold.

좀 기다려.
Wait a bit.

Usage: - Makes requests more polite - Essential in casual Korean - Can mean "please" in context - Never omit in requests to sound polite

docs.title: 좀 vs. 조금
docs.text:
좀 - casual, common in speech
조금 - more formal, written or polite speech

좀 주세요. (casual polite)
조금 주세요. (more formal)

docs.title: 진짜 / 정말 (Really)
docs.text:
As emphasis: 

진짜?
Really?

진짜 좋아.
(I) really like it.

정말 고마워.
Really, thank you.

Difference: - 진짜 - more casual - 정말 - slightly more formal - Both very common

docs.title: 한 (About... / Like...)
docs.text:
Approximation: 

한 10분?
About 10 minutes?

한 5개쯤.
Like about 5 of them.

Usage: - Estimating quantities - "Approximately" - Very natural in casual speech

docs.title: 그래서 (So... / And then...)
docs.text:
Showing result: 

배고팠어. 그래서 먹었어.
I was hungry. So I ate.

그래서 어떻게 됐어?
So what happened?

docs.title: 그리고 (And... / And then...)
docs.text:
Adding information: 

밥 먹었어. 그리고 영화 봤어.
I ate. And then watched a movie.

docs.title: 아니 (No... / Like...)
docs.text:
Multiple functions:

Denial: 

아니, 나 안 그랬어.
No, I didn't do that.

Emphasis/surprise: 

아니, 그게 아니라...
No, like, that's not it...

아니, 진짜?
What, really? / No way, really?

Usage: - Very versatile - Tone matters a lot - Can express surprise, denial, emphasis - Common conversation starter

docs.title: 참 (Oh right... / By the way...)
docs.text:
Remembering something: 

아, 참!
Oh right!

참, 너 어제...
Oh by the way, yesterday you...

docs.title: 맞아 / 그래 (Right / Yeah)
docs.text:
Agreeing: 

맞아, 맞아.
Right, right.

그래, 그렇지.
Yeah, that's right.

docs.title: 진짜? / 정말? (Really?)
docs.text:
Showing interest: 

A: 나 합격했어.
B: 진짜? 축하해!

A: I passed.
B: Really? Congrats!

docs.title: 그렇구나 / 그렇네 (I see / Oh, I get it)
docs.text:
Understanding: 

아, 그렇구나.
Ah, I see.

그렇네요.
Oh, that's how it is. (polite)

docs.title: -지 (Right? / You know...)
docs.text:
Seeking agreement: 

맛있지?
It's good, right?

알았지?
You got it, right?

docs.title: -잖아 (You know... / As you know...)
docs.text:
Stating obvious: 

그거 비싸잖아.
You know that's expensive.

내가 말했잖아.
I told you, you know.

docs.title: -거든 (Because... / You know...)
docs.text:
Explaining reason: 

바빠거든.
(It's) because I'm busy.

못 갔거든요.
I couldn't go, you see. (polite)

docs.title: -는데 / -은데 (But... / And...)
docs.text:
Setting context: 

좋긴 한데... 비싸.
It's good, but... it's expensive.

배고픈데 뭐 먹을까?
I'm hungry, so what should we eat?

docs.title: Trailing off with -는데...
docs.text:
Leaving thoughts incomplete: 

가고 싶긴 한데...
I do want to go, but...

맛있긴 한데...
It is delicious, but...

Implies: "but there's a problem" or "but..."

docs.title: Repeating for emphasis
docs.text:
진짜 진짜 좋아!
Really really like it!

빨리 빨리!
Hurry hurry!

조금 조금.
Little by little.

docs.title: Starting with response words
docs.text:
글쎄... (Well... / I'm not sure...)
글쎄, 잘 모르겠는데.
Well, I'm not really sure.

뭐... (Well...)
뭐, 그럭저럭.
Well, so-so.

docs.title: Exercise 1: Fill in Natural Fillers
docs.text:
1. _____ 잘 모르겠는데.
  2. _____ 물어볼 게 있어요.
  3. 왜? - _____ 궁금해서.
  4. 어제 _____ 달려갔어.
  5. _____ 이상한 느낌이야.

docs.title: Exercise 2: Make Requests Softer
docs.text:
Make these requests more polite/natural with fillers:

  1. 도와줘.
  2. 물 줘.
  3. 기다려.
  4. 이것 좀 봐.
  5. 조용히 해.

docs.title: Exercise 3: Add Natural Connectors
docs.text:
Connect these sentences naturally:

  1. 배고팠어. 밥 먹었어.
  2. 영화 봤어. 재미있었어.
  3. 피곤해. 자고 싶어.
Answer Key

Exercise 1: (multiple answers possible) 1. 음... / 어... 2. 저기... / 그... 3. 그냥 4. 막 5. 뭐랄까 / 약간

Exercise 2: 1. 좀 도와줘 / 도와줄래? 2. 물 좀 줘 / 물 좀 줄래? 3. 좀 기다려 / 기다려줄래? 4. 이것 좀 봐 / 이것 좀 봐줄래? 5. 좀 조용히 해줄래?

Exercise 3: 1. 배고팠어. 그래서 밥 먹었어. 2. 영화 봤어. 그리고 재미있었어. / 근데 재미있었어. 3. 피곤해. 그래서 자고 싶어.

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Overusing fillers: 

❌ 음... 그... 저기... 뭐랄까... 좀... (too many)
✓ 음... 좀 어려운데. (balanced)

2. Using wrong tone with 아니: 

Context matters: 아니 can sound rude if tone is wrong

3. Forgetting 좀 in requests: 

❌ 도와줘. (can sound demanding)
✓ 좀 도와줘. (natural, softer)

4. Using too formal fillers in casual speech: 

❌ (to friend) 글쎄요... 잘 모르겠습니다.
✓ (to friend) 글쎄... 잘 모르겠는데.

docs.title: Why Fillers Matter
docs.text: Korean conversation values: - Indirectness: Not being too abrupt - Softness: Gentle requests and statements - Flow: Natural pauses and connections - Uncertainty: Showing humility by hedging

docs.title: Native-like Speech
docs.text: Using fillers appropriately makes you sound: - More natural and fluent - Less textbook/robotic - More Korean in speech rhythm - Better integrated socially

docs.title: Regional Variations
docs.text:
Different regions have different fillers:

Seoul: - 좀, 진짜, 약간

Busan: - Different intonation patterns - Regional particles

Stick to standard Seoul Korean as a learner.

docs.title: Listening Practice
docs.text:
Where to notice fillers: - Korean variety shows - Casual conversations in K-dramas - Korean YouTube vloggers - Podcast conversations

Listen for: - How often natives use fillers - Which fillers in which situations - Rhythm and flow of conversation - Natural pauses and hesitations

docs.title: Combining Fillers Naturally
docs.text:
Common combinations: 

그... 저기... 좀...
Um... excuse me... a bit...

음... 뭐랄까... 약간...
Um... how should I say... kind of...

근데 말이야...
But you know...

그러니까... 그게...
So... well the thing is...

docs.title: Tips for Using Fillers
docs.text:
1. Start simple: Just use 음, 어, 좀
  2. Listen actively: Notice patterns in native speech
  3. Don't overdo: Too many sounds unnatural
  4. Match context: Formal situations need fewer fillers
  5. Practice rhythm: It's not just words, but timing

Fillers are the "secret sauce" that makes your Korean sound fluent and natural. Practice incorporating them gradually for more native-like speech!

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Slang Meaning Usage 대박 Awesome, jackpot 대박! 진짜? 헐 OMG, what?! 헐, 진짜야? 쩐다 Amazing, intense 진짜 쩐다 별로 Not really, meh 별로야 짱 Best, awesome 너 짱이야!

docs.title: Warning: Slang Changes Quickly
docs.text: Korean slang evolves rapidly. What's popular now may be outdated in 1-2 years. This guide covers widely-used terms, but stay current through Korean media and friends.

docs.title: Positive Reactions
docs.text:
대박 [dae-bak] - Awesome, jackpot, amazing 

대박! 진짜?
Wow! Really?

대박이다!
That's awesome!

Usage: Very common, suitable for most situations

쩐다 [jjeon-da] - Intense, amazing, awesome 

진짜 쩐다!
That's really amazing!

이거 쩌는데?
This is awesome, isn't it?

Usage: Slightly more intense than 대박

짱 [jjang] - Best, number one, awesome 

너 짱이야!
You're the best!

짱이다!
It's the best!

Usage: Common among younger speakers
Note: Can be used as prefix: 짱 좋다 (super good)

꿀잼 [kkul-jaem] - Super fun, very entertaining 

이 영화 꿀잼!
This movie is super fun!

꿀잼이었어.
It was really entertaining.

From: 꿀 (honey) + 재미 (fun) → super fun

개 [gae] - Intensifier (very, super) 

개 웃겨!
Super funny!

개 맛있어!
Super delicious!

Warning: Originally vulgar (means "dog"), now common among young people
Not appropriate with elders or formal situations

docs.title: Negative Reactions
docs.text:
헐 [heol] - OMG, what?!, no way 

헐, 진짜야?
OMG, really?

헐... 어떡해?
Oh no... what should I do?

Usage: Surprise, shock, disbelief

별로 [byeol-lo] - Not really, not particularly good, meh 

별로야.
It's not that great. / Meh.

별로 안 좋아해.
I don't particularly like it.

Usage: Polite way to express dislike

노잼 [no-jaem] - Not fun, boring 

이 영화 노잼.
This movie is boring.

노잼이다.
It's not fun.

From: No + 재미 (fun)
Opposite: 꿀잼

최악 [choe-ak] - The worst 

오늘 최악이야.
Today is the worst.

최악이다.
It's the worst.

docs.title: Positive
docs.text:
잘생기다 [jal-saeng-gi-da] - Handsome (slang shortened forms) 

완전 잘생겼어!
So handsome!

Short: 잘생

예쁘다 [ye-ppeu-da] - Pretty (standard, but common in casual speech) 

진짜 예쁘다.
Really pretty.

귀엽다 [gwi-yeop-da] - Cute 

너무 귀여워!
So cute!

Short casual: 귀욤

멋있다 [meot-it-da] - Cool, stylish 

멋있어!
Cool!

멋지다 also common

docs.title: Personality/Behavior
docs.text:
착하다 [chak-ha-da] - Kind, nice 

진짜 착해.
Really kind.

~충 [-chung] - Person who... (often negative) 

관종 - attention seeker (관심+충)
맘충 - annoying mom with kids (엄마+충)

Usage: Usually negative, be careful

꼰대 [kkondae] - Old-fashioned person, out-of-touch elder 

완전 꼰대네.
What an old-fashioned person.

Warning: Disrespectful, don't use directly to someone

docs.title: Common Expressions
docs.text:
ㅇㅈ [인정, in-jeong] - Agreed, I acknowledge that 

ㅇㅈ? (인정?)
You agree?

ㅇㅈ (I agree)

Often: 인정? with question mark

실화? [sil-hwa] - Is this real? For real? 

실화야?
Is this for real?

실화냐?
Are you serious?

레알 [re-al] - Real (from English) 

레알?
Really?

레알 대박
Really awesome

Note: 리얼 also used

인싸 / 아싸 [in-ssa / a-ssa] 

인싸 - insider, popular person (인사이더)
아싸 - outsider, loner (아웃사이더)

나 완전 아싸야.
I'm a total outsider.

TMI - Too much information (from English) 

Used in Korean context as "unnecessary info I'm sharing"

TMI인데, 나 오늘...
This is TMI, but today I...

docs.title: Shortened Internet Speak
docs.text:
ㅅㄱ [수고] - Good work 

ㅅㄱ했어!
Good work!

ㅊㅋ [축하] - Congratulations 

ㅊㅋㅊㅋ!
Congrats!

ㄱㅅ [감사] - Thanks 

ㄱㅅ
Thanks

docs.title: Dating & Relationship Slang
docs.text:
썸 [sseom] - "Something" - ambiguous relationship stage 

우리 썸 타는 것 같아.
I think we have something going on.

썸남/썸녀 - guy/girl you have a "thing" with

밀당 [mil-dang] - Push and pull (in dating) 

밀고 당기기 shortened
Playing hard to get

밀당하지 마.
Don't play games.

솔로 [sol-lo] - Single (from English "solo") 

나 평생 솔로야.
I'm forever single.

커플 [keo-peul] - Couple (from English) 

우리 커플이야.
We're a couple.

docs.title: Food Slang
docs.text:
꿀맛 [kkul-mat] - Honey taste → delicious 

이거 꿀맛이다!
This is delicious!

존맛 [jon-mat] - Super delicious 

존맛탱! (even more emphatic)
Super delicious!

From: 존나 (very vulgar intensifier) + 맛
Note: 존나 is vulgar, but 존맛 is widely used

JMT - 존맛탱 (abbreviated) 

이 식당 JMT!
This restaurant is amazing!

docs.title: Emotional States
docs.text:
빡치다 [ppak-chi-da] - To be pissed off, annoyed 

진짜 빡쳐.
I'm really pissed off.

빡친다!
That's so annoying!

멘붕 [men-bung] - Mental breakdown 

멘탈 붕괴 shortened

멘붕 왔어.
I'm having a mental breakdown.

심쿵 [sim-kkung] - Heart flutter 

심장이 쿵 shortened

심쿵했어.
My heart fluttered.

Usage: When excited or touched by something cute/romantic

docs.title: Exercise 1: Match the Meaning
docs.text:
1. 대박
  2. 헐
  3. 별로
  4. 짱
  5. 꿀잼

a) Not really, meh b) Best, awesome c) Super fun d) OMG, what?! e) Awesome, jackpot

docs.title: Exercise 2: Choose Appropriate Slang
docs.text:
1. Your friend shows you their amazing test score:
  2. You just saw something surprising:
  3. Someone asks if you liked a boring movie:
  4. Your friend looks really good today:
  5. You're describing a really fun party:

docs.title: Exercise 3: Context Check
docs.text:
Which situations is it okay to use slang?

  1. Text message to close friend
  2. Email to professor
  3. Casual conversation with same-age friend
  4. Job interview
  5. K-drama reaction with friends
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1-e, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b, 5-c

Exercise 2: Sample Answers 1. 대박! / 짱이다! 2. 헐! / 대박! 3. 별로였어 / 노잼이었어 4. 오늘 멋있어! / 완전 예쁘다! 5. 꿀잼이었어 / 대박이었어

Exercise 3: 1. ✓ Appropriate 2. ✗ Too casual 3. ✓ Appropriate 4. ✗ Too casual 5. ✓ Appropriate

docs.title: Older Slang (Still Used)
docs.text: 짱 - Still common but slightly dated 완전 - Totally (still very common) 대박 - Very stable, all generations

docs.title: Current Popular (2020s)
docs.text: 꿀잼/노잼 - Popular 인싸/아싸 - Current TMI - Trendy

docs.title: Outdated (Avoid)
docs.text:
쩐다 - Becoming dated 엄지척 - Dated (thumbs up)

Stay current by watching recent K-content!

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Using slang in formal situations: 

❌ (to professor) 이 수업 짱이에요!
✓ (to professor) 이 수업 정말 좋아요

2. Overusing intensifiers: 

❌ 개 개 개 좋아 (too much)
✓ 진짜 좋아 / 개 좋아 (pick one)

3. Mixing very different age group slang: 

Don't use slang from 2000s mixed with 2020s - sounds awkward

docs.title: When to Use Slang
docs.text:
Safe contexts: - Close friends same age - Casual group chat - Reacting to media/content - Informal social situations

Risky contexts: - Anyone older (even by 1-2 years) - Workplace - School with teachers - First meetings

docs.title: Age Sensitivity
docs.text: Korean age hierarchy is strict: - Even 1 year difference can matter - Slang with 오빠/언니 might be okay if very close - Never with 선배 unless invited - Absolutely never with elders or superiors

docs.title: Regional Variations
docs.text: Seoul vs. Busan vs. other regions have different slang. As a learner, stick to standard Seoul slang you hear in mainstream media.

docs.title: Learning Resources
docs.text:
To stay current: - Korean variety shows - K-drama (recent ones) - Korean YouTubers - Korean social media (Instagram, Twitter/X) - Webtoon comments sections - Ask Korean friends!

Warning signs slang is outdated: - Parents using it - Not hearing it in recent media - Koreans laugh when you use it - Feels forced in conversation

Use slang sparingly until you're confident in contexts and timing. It's better to sound slightly formal than to misuse slang inappropriately!

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Symbol Meaning Example ㅋㅋ Laughter (haha) ㅋㅋㅋ 웃겨 ㅎㅎ Softer laugh (hehe) ㅎㅎ 그렇구나 ㅇㅇ Yes, yeah ㅇㅇ 알았어 ㄴㄴ No, nope ㄴㄴ 아니야 ㅜㅜ Crying ㅜㅜ 슬퍼

docs.title: ㅋㅋㅋ (Kekeke)
docs.text:
The standard laugh: 

ㅋ - small chuckle
ㅋㅋ - haha
ㅋㅋㅋ - hahaha
ㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋ - HAHAHA

Usage: 

A: 오늘 넘어졌어 ㅠㅠ
B: ㅋㅋㅋㅋ괜찮아?

A: I fell today ㅠㅠ
B: Hahaha are you okay?

Length indicates intensity: - More ㅋ = funnier/more laughter - Too many ㅋ (20+) = overly enthusiastic or sarcastic

docs.title: ㅎㅎ (Hehe)
docs.text:
Softer, gentler laugh: 

ㅎㅎ 그렇구나
Hehe I see

ㅎㅎ 고마워
Hehe thanks

Compared to ㅋㅋ: - ㅋㅋ = haha (louder) - ㅎㅎ = hehe (softer, politer) - ㅎㅎ feels more mature/gentle

docs.title: Other Laugh Variations
docs.text: ㅋㄷㅋㄷ [크득크득] - Giggling sound ㅍㅎㅎ [pfft] - Snickering ㅋㅋ루ㅋㅋ - Silly/cute laugh variation ㄱㄱㄷ - 기 크들 shortened (obscure, not common)

docs.title: Agreeing/Confirming
docs.text:
ㅇㅇ [응응] - Yes, yeah 

A: 내일 올 거지?
B: ㅇㅇ

A: You're coming tomorrow, right?
B: Yeah

ㅇㅋ [오케이] - OK 

ㅇㅋ 알았어
OK got it

ㄱㄱ [고고] - Go go, let's go 

A: 갈까?
B: ㄱㄱ

A: Shall we go?
B: Let's go

ㅇㅈ [인정] - Agreed, I acknowledge 

A: 이거 진짜 맛있다
B: ㅇㅈ

A: This is really delicious
B: Agreed

docs.title: Disagreeing/Denying
docs.text:
ㄴㄴ [노노] - No, nope 

A: 너 갈 거야?
B: ㄴㄴ 안 가

A: Are you going?
B: Nope, not going

ㄴㄴㄴ - NO NO NO (emphasis)

docs.title: Crying/Sadness
docs.text:
ㅠㅠ or ㅜㅜ - Crying face 

ㅠㅠ 슬퍼
ㅠㅠ sad

시험 망했어 ㅜㅜ
I failed the exam ㅜㅜ

Can be combined: 

ㅠㅠㅠㅠㅠ - very sad
ㅠ_ㅠ - crying face with nose
ㅜ.ㅜ - crying face variation

docs.title: Shock/Surprise
docs.text:
ㅎㄷㄷ [후덜덜] - Shivering from shock/fear 

ㅎㄷㄷ 무서워
ㅎㄷㄷ scary

가격 ㅎㄷㄷ
The price ㅎㄷㄷ (shocking!)

ㄷㄷㄷ [덜덜덜] - Trembling 

Similar to ㅎㄷㄷ but just trembling

docs.title: Single-Character Initials
docs.text:
ㅈㅅ [죄송] - Sorry 

ㅈㅅ 늦었어
Sorry I'm late

ㄱㅅ [감사] - Thanks 

ㄱㅅ!
Thanks!

Also: ㄱㅅㄱㅅ (thank you thank you)

ㅊㅋ [축하] - Congrats 

ㅊㅋㅊㅋ!
Congrats!

ㅅㄱ [수고] - Good work 

ㅅㄱ했어!
Good work!

ㅂㅂ [바이바이] - Bye bye 

ㅂㅂ 내일 봐
Bye see you tomorrow

ㅎㅇ [하이] - Hi 

ㅎㅇ!
Hi!

docs.title: Two-Character Combinations
docs.text:
ㄱㅊ [괜찮] - It's okay, fine 

A: 미안해
B: ㄱㅊ아

A: Sorry
B: It's okay

ㅇㅋ [오케이] - OK ㄴㄴ [노노] - No no ㅇㅈ [인정] - Agreed ㄱㄱ [고고] - Go go

docs.title: Consonant Extraction
docs.text:
Taking first consonants from each syllable:

ㅁㅊ [미친] - Crazy 

ㅁㅊ 대박!
Crazy awesome!

ㄱㅇㅇ [귀여워] - Cute 

ㄱㅇㅇ
So cute

ㅅㅂ [시발] - F*** (vulgar!) 

Warning: Don't use unless you understand it's very vulgar

ㅈㄱㄴ [전국노래자랑] - National singing contest 

Longer phrases also abbreviated in context

ㅁㄹ [모르] - Don't know 

ㅁㄹ (I don't know)

docs.title: Common Phrase Abbreviations
docs.text:
ㅇㄱㄹㅇ [이거레알] - This is real (for real) 

ㅇㄱㄹㅇ?
Is this for real?

ㄹㅇ [레알/리얼] - Real 

ㄹㅇ?
Really?

ㄹㅇㅋㅋ
For real haha

ㅈㄴ [존나] - Very (vulgar!) 

Warning: Vulgar intensifier, avoid

docs.title: Using numbers for sounds
docs.text:
1 [일] - Can sound like "i" 2 [이] - Sounds like "i" 4 [사] - Sounds like "sa" 8 [팔] - Sounds like "pal" 10 [십] - Can mean "shit" in context

Examples: 

8282 [빨리빨리] - Hurry hurry
Rarely used now, mostly outdated

1004 [천사] - Angel
ㅊㅅ also used

docs.title: Face Emoticons
docs.text:
^^ or ^_^ - Happy, smiling 

고마워 ^^
Thanks ^^

ㅠㅠ or ㅜㅜ - Crying 

슬퍼 ㅠㅠ
Sad ㅠㅠ

ㅡㅡ - Unamused, deadpan 

진짜? ㅡㅡ
Really? ㅡㅡ (skeptical)

ㅎㅎ - Gentle smile ㅋㅋ - Laughing

docs.title: Combined Emoticons
docs.text:
^^7 - Salute
^ㅁ^ - Big smile
ㅇㅅㅇ - Surprised face
ㅇ<-< - Fish (random fun)

docs.title: Common Words
docs.text: ㅇㅋ - 오케이 (OK) ㄴㄴ - 노노 (no) ㄱㅊ - 괜찮 (fine, okay) ㅅㄱ - 수고 (good work) ㅈㅅ - 죄송/죄송합니다 (sorry) ㄱㅅ - 감사 (thanks) ㅊㅋ - 축하 (congrats)

docs.title: Longer Phrases
docs.text: ㄱㄴㄱㄴ - 기능 기능 (function/ability - gaming) ㄷㅂㄷㅂ - 댓글 부탁해 (please comment) ㄹㅇㅋㅋ - 리얼 크크크 (really haha)

docs.title: Internet Slang Combinations
docs.text:
ㅋㅋㄹㅃㅃ [크크르 ㅂㅂ] - Haha okay bye bye 

Combining laugh + bye
Informal, playful

ㅇㅈ? ㄹㅇㅋㅋ [인정? 리얼ㅋㅋ] 

Agreed? For real haha
Stacking abbreviations

docs.title: Gaming Shortcuts
docs.text: ㄱㄱ [고고] - Go go (start) ㅅㄱ [수고] - Good game, good work ㄱㅈ [거짓말] - Lie, joking ㅅㅅ [ㅅㅂ soft version] - Sorry (in gaming)

docs.title: Exercise 1: Decode These Messages
docs.text:
1. ㅋㅋㅋ진짜?
  2. ㅇㅇ ㄱㅊ아
  3. ㅎㄷㄷ무서워
  4. ㅊㅋㅊㅋ!
  5. ㅈㅅ늦었어 ㅠㅠ

docs.title: Exercise 2: Write in Texting Style
docs.text:
1. 하하하 정말 웃겨!
  2. 응 괜찮아
  3. 고마워!
  4. 미안해
  5. 바이바이 내일 봐

docs.title: Exercise 3: Appropriate Usage
docs.text:
Which are appropriate for texting a close friend?

  1. ㅋㅋㅋ
  2. ^^
  3. ㅠㅠ
  4. ㅅㅂ (very vulgar)
  5. ㅎㅎ
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1. Hahaha really? 2. Yeah it's okay 3. ㅎㄷㄷ scary / shocking 4. Congrats congrats! 5. Sorry I'm late ㅠㅠ

Exercise 2: 1. ㅋㅋㅋ 진짜 웃겨! 2. ㅇㅇ ㄱㅊ아 / ㅇㅇ ㄱㅊ 3. ㄱㅅ! / ㄱㅅㄱㅅ! 4. ㅈㅅ 5. ㅂㅂ 내일 봐

Exercise 3: 1. ✓ Very common 2. ✓ Common 3. ✓ Common 4. ✗ Too vulgar 5. ✓ Common

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Using abbreviations in formal contexts: 

❌ (to professor) ㄱㅅ합니다!
✓ (to professor) 감사합니다!

2. Overusing ㅋ: 

ㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋㅋ (30+ ㅋ)
Can seem insincere or sarcastic

3. Mixing Korean and English abbreviations oddly: 

❌ LOLㅋㅋ (mixing cultures awkwardly)
✓ ㅋㅋㅋ (stick to Korean in Korean texts)
✓ LOL (in English contexts)

docs.title: KakaoTalk
docs.text:
• Most common: ㅋㅋ, ㅎㅎ, ^^
  • Stickers very popular
  • Voice messages common

docs.title: Instagram/Twitter
docs.text:
• More ㅋㅋㅋ
  • Hashtags common
  • Mix of abbreviations

docs.title: Online Games
docs.text:
• ㄱㄱ, ㅅㄱ very common
  • Quick communication needed
  • More abbreviations

docs.title: Generational Differences
docs.text:
Older generation (40+): - Prefer full words - Use ^^ more - Less comfortable with heavy abbreviation

20s-30s: - Moderate abbreviation - ㅋㅋ, ㅎㅎ, ^^ - Mix of styles

Teens: - Heavy abbreviation - Newest trends - Constantly evolving

docs.title: Formality in Digital Communication
docs.text:
Even in texting, hierarchy matters:

To friends: 

ㅇㅇㄱㅊ ㅋㅋ
Yeah fine haha

To seniors/professors: 

네 괜찮습니다 ^^
Yes, I'm fine ^^

Notice: full words + polite endings even in text

docs.title: Reading Comprehension vs. Production
docs.text:
As a learner: 1. Understand most abbreviations (for reading) 2. Use only safe, common ones (ㅋㅋ, ㅎㅎ, ^^, ㅇㅇ) 3. Avoid vulgar or very casual ones until confident 4. Match the style of the person you're texting

The safest approach: slightly more formal than too casual.

Master texting language to understand Korean digital communication, but use conservatively until you're sure of appropriateness!

docs.title: Idiomatic Expressions
docs.text: Korean idiomatic expressions (관용어) are phrases whose meanings can't be understood from the literal meanings of individual words. Like English "it's raining cats and dogs," Korean has its own colorful, culturally rich idioms.

docs.title: What Are Idioms?
docs.text:
Idioms are: - Fixed phrases with figurative meanings - Culturally specific expressions - Often metaphorical - Not translatable word-for-word

Examples: 

눈이 높다 (eyes are high)
→ Literal: eyes are high
→ Actual: have high standards, be picky

발이 넓다 (feet are wide)
→ Literal: feet are wide
→ Actual: have many connections, be well-connected

docs.title: Why Learn Korean Idioms?
docs.text:
Understanding: - K-dramas and movies use idioms constantly - Newspapers and articles include idioms - Native speakers use them in everyday conversation - Understanding culture through language

Sounding natural: - Sound more fluent and native-like - Express complex ideas concisely - Show cultural understanding - Connect better with native speakers

Cultural insight: - Idioms reflect Korean values - Historical and cultural references - Understanding Korean thinking patterns - Deeper appreciation of the language

docs.title: Body Part Idioms
docs.text: Using body parts metaphorically: - 눈 (eyes), 귀 (ears), 손 (hands) - 발 (feet), 머리 (head), 입 (mouth) - Each body part has multiple idiomatic uses

docs.title: Color Idioms
docs.text: Colors with symbolic meanings: - 빨강 (red), 파랑 (blue), 하양 (white) - 노랑 (yellow), 검정 (black) - Cultural color associations

docs.title: Animal Idioms
docs.text: Using animal characteristics: - 개 (dog), 고양이 (cat), 호랑이 (tiger) - Cultural views of different animals

docs.title: Proverbs (속담)
docs.text: Traditional wisdom in short phrases: - Passed down through generations - Moral lessons - Common situations

docs.title: Common Patterns
docs.text:
Korean idioms often follow these structures:

[Body part] + [Verb/Adjective]: 

눈이 높다 - high standards
귀가 얇다 - easily influenced

[Action] + 것 같다: 

하늘의 별 따기 - extremely difficult (like picking stars)

[Comparison] structures: 

누워서 떡 먹기 - piece of cake (eating rice cake lying down)

docs.title: How to Learn Idioms
docs.text:
1. Learn in context: - Not just translations - Understand when and why used - See in real sentences

2. Group by theme: - Body parts together - Colors together - Easier to remember

3. Practice usage: - Try using in your own sentences - Note when you hear them - Build mental associations

4. Cultural understanding: - Know why the idiom makes sense - Understand cultural background - Connect to Korean values

docs.title: Usage Levels
docs.text:
Idioms vary in formality:

Casual idioms: - Used among friends - In everyday conversation - May be slangy

Universal idioms: - Appropriate in most situations - Commonly understood - Safe to use

Formal/literary idioms: - News, writing, formal speech - Educated speech - Traditional proverbs

docs.title: Body Idioms
docs.text: Common expressions using body parts: - Eyes, ears, hands, feet - Head, mouth, nose - Cultural meanings and usage

docs.title: Color Idioms
docs.text: Symbolic meanings of colors: - Red, blue, white, black - Traditional associations - Modern usage

docs.title: Common Proverbs
docs.text: Essential 속담 (sayings): - 10-15 most useful proverbs - When to use them - Cultural background

docs.title: Study Approach
docs.text:
Start with common ones: 1. Learn 5-10 most frequent idioms 2. Focus on body part idioms first 3. Gradually expand

Notice in media: - K-dramas - News articles - Conversations - Song lyrics

Practice actively: - Use in conversation when appropriate - Write example sentences - Quiz yourself

docs.title: Warning: Use Appropriately
docs.text:
Be careful: - Some idioms are quite casual - Some may sound odd from non-natives - Overusing idioms sounds forced - Context matters greatly

Safe approach: - Understand more than you use - Start with common, neutral idioms - Use in appropriate situations - Don't force them into every sentence

docs.title: Cultural Values in Idioms
docs.text:
Korean idioms reflect:

Collectivism: 

백지장도 맞들면 낫다
Even a sheet of paper is lighter when lifted together
(Teamwork makes things easier)

Respect for elders: 

윗물이 맑아야 아랫물이 맑다
When the upper stream is clear, the lower stream is clear
(Leaders set the example)

Hard work: 

로마는 하루아침에 이루어지지 않았다
Rome wasn't built in a day

Relationships: 

가는 말이 고와야 오는 말이 곱다
If your words are kind, the response will be kind
(Treat others as you want to be treated)

docs.title: Moving Forward
docs.text:
Each section provides: - Common idioms by category - Literal and figurative meanings - Usage examples - Cultural context - Practice exercises

Master these idioms to: - Understand Korean media better - Sound more natural - Appreciate Korean culture - Connect deeper with the language

Let's explore Korean idioms!

docs.title: Eyes (눈)
docs.text:
눈이 높다 - Have high standards (eyes are high) 

저 사람은 눈이 높아서 결혼을 못 해요.
That person can't get married because they're too picky.

눈이 낮다 - Have low standards 눈이 없다 - Have no eye/taste for something

눈에 띄다 - Stand out, catch one's eye 

그 학생이 눈에 띄어요.
That student stands out.

눈 밖에 나다 - Fall out of favor (be out of sight) 

선생님 눈 밖에 났어요.
I fell out of favor with the teacher.

눈을 붙이다 - Take a nap (attach eyes = close eyes) 

잠깐 눈 좀 붙일게요.
I'll take a quick nap.

눈(을) 감아주다 - Let something slide, overlook 

이번에는 눈 감아줄게.
I'll let it slide this time.

docs.title: Ears (귀)
docs.text:
귀가 얇다 - Easily influenced (ears are thin) 

귀가 얇아서 남의 말을 잘 믿어요.
Being easily influenced, (they) believe others easily.

귀가 밝다 - Have good hearing / be well-informed 귀가 어둡다 - Hard of hearing

귀에 못이 박히다 - Hear something repeatedly (nail in ear) 

귀에 못이 박히도록 들었어요.
I've heard it so many times my ears have calluses.

귀를 기울이다 - Listen carefully (tilt ears) 

학생들의 의견에 귀를 기울여야 해요.
We should listen carefully to students' opinions.

docs.title: Hands (손)
docs.text:
손이 크다 - Cook generous portions (hands are big) 

우리 엄마는 손이 커서 음식이 항상 많아요.
My mom cooks generous portions, so there's always lots of food.

손이 작다 - Cook small portions

손(을) 떼다 - Stop doing something, wash hands of 

그 일에서 손 떼세요.
Stop doing that. / Stay out of it.

손(을) 쓰다 - Take action, use means 

다른 방법으로 손을 써 봤어요.
I tried taking action another way.

손에 익다 - Become skilled at, familiar with 

이 일이 손에 익었어요.
I've become skilled at this work.

손(이) 가다 - Require effort/work 

이 요리는 손이 많이 가요.
This dish requires a lot of work.

docs.title: Feet (발)
docs.text:
발이 넓다 - Well-connected (feet are wide) 

그 사람은 발이 넓어서 모르는 사람이 없어요.
That person is so well-connected, there's no one they don't know.

발이 좁다 - Have few connections

발(을) 끊다 - Stop visiting/going 

술집에 발을 끊었어요.
I stopped going to bars.

발(이) 묶이다 - Be tied down, unable to leave 

비 때문에 발이 묶였어요.
I'm stuck here because of the rain.

발(을) 빼다 - Back out, withdraw 

그 계획에서 발을 뺐어요.
I backed out of that plan.

docs.title: Head/Mind (머리)
docs.text:
머리가 좋다 - Smart, intelligent 머리가 나쁘다 - Not smart

머리를 쓰다 - Use one's brain, think 

좀 더 머리를 써 봐요.
Think harder. / Use your brain.

머리를 짜다 - Rack one's brain 

해결책을 찾으려고 머리를 짰어요.
I racked my brain trying to find a solution.

머리가 크다 - Be grown up (head is big) 

머리 큰 사람이 그런 행동을 하면 안 돼요.
A grown person shouldn't behave like that.

머리(가) 아프다 - Be bothersome, troublesome 

생각만 해도 머리 아파요.
Just thinking about it is troublesome.

docs.title: Mouth (입)
docs.text:
입이 무겁다 - Keep secrets well (mouth is heavy) 

걱정 마세요. 저는 입이 무거워요.
Don't worry. I can keep a secret.

입이 가볍다 - Can't keep secrets (mouth is light)

입(이) 떨어지다 - Be amazed, mouth-dropping 

그 경치에 입이 떨어졌어요.
I was amazed by that scenery.

입에 맞다 - Suit one's taste 

이 음식이 입에 안 맞아요.
This food doesn't suit my taste.

입이 싸다 - Talk too much, gossip 

그 사람은 입이 싸서 비밀을 못 지켜요.
That person talks too much and can't keep secrets.

docs.title: Face (얼굴)
docs.text:
얼굴이 두껍다 - Shameless (face is thick) 

얼굴이 두꺼워서 뭐든지 할 수 있어요.
Being shameless, (they) can do anything.

얼굴이 넓다 - Know many people

얼굴에 쓰여 있다 - Written on one's face (obvious) 

거짓말하지 마. 얼굴에 다 쓰여 있어.
Don't lie. It's written all over your face.

docs.title: Heart (마음)
docs.text:
마음(이) 넓다 - Generous, open-minded 마음(이) 좁다 - Narrow-minded

마음을 먹다 - Make up one's mind 

마음만 먹으면 할 수 있어요.
If you make up your mind, you can do it.

마음에 들다 - Like, be pleased with 

이 옷이 마음에 들어요.
I like these clothes.

마음을 놓다 - Feel relieved 

이제 마음을 놓았어요.
Now I feel relieved.

docs.title: Exercise 1: Match the Idiom
docs.text:
1. 눈이 높다
  2. 귀가 얇다
  3. 손이 크다
  4. 발이 넓다
  5. 입이 무겁다

a) Well-connected b) Keep secrets well c) Cook generous portions d) Easily influenced e) Have high standards

docs.title: Exercise 2: Complete with Body Part
docs.text:
1. ___ 에 띄다 (stand out)
  2. ___ 를 쓰다 (use one's brain)
  3. ___ 을 기울이다 (listen carefully)
  4. ___ 에 맞다 (suit one's taste)
  5. ___ 을 먹다 (make up one's mind)

docs.title: Exercise 3: Use in Sentences
docs.text:
Create sentences using: 1. 눈에 띄다 2. 손이 많이 가다 3. 발을 끊다

Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1-e, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a, 5-b

Exercise 2: 1. 눈 2. 머리 3. 귀 4. 입 5. 마음

Exercise 3: Sample Answers 1. 빨간 옷을 입어서 눈에 띄었어요. 2. 한국 음식은 손이 많이 가요. 3. 담배를 끊으려고 그 가게에 발을 끊었어요.

docs.title: Cultural Notes
docs.text:
Body part idioms reflect Korean cultural values: - Physical characteristics = personality traits - Body metaphors for abstract concepts - Practical wisdom in everyday language

Use these naturally to sound more Korean!

docs.title: Red (빨강/빨강색/적색)
docs.text:
빨간 맛 - Exciting taste/experience (popularized by Red Velvet song) 

빨간 맛이 궁금해!
Curious about that red taste! (that exciting feeling)

빨간 날 - Red-letter day, holiday 

달력에 빨간 날이 많으면 좋아요.
It's nice when there are many holidays on the calendar.

빨간 불 - Red light (danger, warning) 

우리 회사에 빨간 불이 켜졌어요.
Our company is in danger. (red light is on)

빨간 줄 - Red line (connection, relationship) 

그들 사이에 빨간 줄이 있대요.
They say there's a red string between them. (destined relationship)

docs.title: Blue (파랑/파랑색/청색)
docs.text:
파란만장 - Full of ups and downs, eventful 

그의 인생은 파란만장했어요.
His life was full of ups and downs.
From: 파란 (blue/green waves) + 만장 (full)

청춘 - Youth (blue spring) 

청춘을 즐겨라!
Enjoy your youth!

청출어람 - Student surpassing teacher (blue from indigo) 

그 학생은 청출어람이에요.
That student has surpassed the teacher.
From Chinese idiom

docs.title: White (하얀/하양/백색)
docs.text:
새하얗다 - Pure white, completely white 

눈이 와서 산이 새하얘요.
It snowed so the mountain is pure white.

백지 - Blank slate (white paper) 

다시 백지에서 시작해요.
Let's start from a blank slate again.

백발 - White hair (elderly) 

백발이 되도록 사랑하세요.
Love each other until you have white hair (forever).

백기를 들다 - Surrender, give up (raise white flag) 

너무 어려워서 백기를 들었어요.
It was too hard so I gave up.

백지장도 맞들면 낫다 - Proverb: teamwork helps 

Even a sheet of paper is lighter when lifted together.

docs.title: Black (검정/검정색/흑색)
docs.text:
흑백 - Black and white, clear distinction 

흑백을 가려야 해요.
We need to distinguish right from wrong.

흑자 - Surplus, profit (black) 적자 - Deficit, loss (red) 

올해는 흑자를 냈어요.
This year we made a profit.

Note: Opposite of English red/black accounting

검은 머리 파뿌리 되도록 - Until death (black hair becomes white roots) 

검은 머리 파뿌리 되도록 함께해요.
Let's be together until death.

docs.title: Yellow/Gold (노랑/금색)
docs.text:
황금 - Gold (valuable) 

황금 같은 시간
Golden/precious time

황금알을 낳는 거위
The goose that lays golden eggs

노랗다 - Yellow (also means scared) 

겁이 나서 얼굴이 노래졌어요.
Their face turned yellow from fear.

docs.title: Color Combinations
docs.text:
알록달록 - Colorful, variegated 

꽃이 알록달록해요.
The flowers are colorful.

형형색색 - Various colors 

형형색색의 옷을 입었어요.
Wore clothes of various colors.

오색찬란 - Five colors brilliant (very colorful) 

무지개가 오색찬란해요.
The rainbow is brilliantly colorful.

docs.title: Gray/Uncertain
docs.text:
회색 지대 - Gray area 

법의 회색 지대
Gray area of law

회색빛 - Grayish, uncertain 

전망이 회색빛이에요.
The outlook is uncertain.

docs.title: Red
docs.text:
• Celebration, good fortune
  • Passion, excitement
  • Danger, warning

docs.title: Blue
docs.text:
• Youth, vitality
  • Sadness (like English "feeling blue")
  • Calm, serenity

docs.title: White
docs.text:
• Purity, cleanliness
  • Death, mourning (traditional)
  • New beginning

docs.title: Black
docs.text:
• Darkness, evil
  • Elegance, formality
  • Depth, seriousness

docs.title: Yellow/Gold
docs.text:
• Wealth, prosperity
  • Autumn, harvest
  • Cowardice (in some contexts)

docs.title: Exercise 1: Color Meanings
docs.text: What color is associated with: 1. Holidays on calendar 2. Youth 3. Giving up/surrender 4. Profit in business 5. Eventful life

docs.title: Exercise 2: Complete Idioms
docs.text:
1. ___ 기를 들다 (give up)
  2. ___ 만장 (eventful)
  3. ___ 불이 켜지다 (in danger)

docs.title: Exercise 3: Use in Context
docs.text:
When would you use these expressions? 1. 흑자를 내다 2. 백지에서 시작하다 3. 빨간 날

Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1. Red (빨간 날) 2. Blue (청춘) 3. White (백기를 들다) 4. Black (흑자) 5. Blue (파란만장)

Exercise 2: 1. 백 2. 파란 3. 빨간

Exercise 3: 1. When business makes profit 2. When starting over fresh 3. Referring to holidays/days off

docs.title: Modern Usage
docs.text:
Some color idioms are evolving: - 빨간 맛 became trendy after K-pop - Yellow associations changing with Western influence - Some traditional meanings fading

Stay current by noticing how colors are used in contemporary Korean media!

docs.title: 1. 가는 말이 고와야 오는 말이 곱다
docs.text:
Literal: If outgoing words are beautiful, incoming words are beautiful Meaning: Treat others as you want to be treated Usage: Encouraging good treatment of others

친구한테 그렇게 말하면 안 돼요.
가는 말이 고와야 오는 말이 곱다고 했잖아요.

Don't speak to your friend like that.
They say if you speak nicely, you'll be treated nicely.

docs.title: 2. 티끌 모아 태산
docs.text:
Literal: Gathering specks of dust makes a mountain Meaning: Little by little adds up; every penny counts Usage: Saving money, gradual progress

조금씩 저금하세요. 티끌 모아 태산이에요.
Save little by little. Small amounts add up.

docs.title: 3. 백지장도 맞들면 낫다
docs.text:
Literal: Even a sheet of paper is lighter when lifted together Meaning: Teamwork makes things easier; many hands make light work Usage: Encouraging cooperation

같이 하면 빨리 끝나요. 백지장도 맞들면 낫다잖아요.
If we do it together, it'll finish quickly. Teamwork helps!

docs.title: 4. 소 잃고 외양간 고친다
docs.text:
Literal: Fix the barn after losing the cow Meaning: Too little, too late; closing the barn door after the horse has bolted Usage: Warning against acting too late

지금 후회해도 소용없어요. 소 잃고 외양간 고치는 격이에요.
Regretting now is useless. It's too late.

docs.title: 5. 말은 해야 맛이고 고기는 씹어야 맛이다
docs.text:
Literal: Words taste good when spoken, meat tastes good when chewed Meaning: Speak up; communication is important Usage: Encouraging someone to express themselves

말을 해야 알지. 말은 해야 맛이라잖아요.
We need to know what you think. You have to speak up!

docs.title: 6. 낮말은 새가 듣고 밤말은 쥐가 듣는다
docs.text:
Literal: Birds hear daytime words, mice hear nighttime words Meaning: Walls have ears; be careful what you say Usage: Warning about gossip or secrets

조심해서 말해요. 낮말은 새가 듣고 밤말은 쥐가 듣는다니까요.
Be careful what you say. You never know who's listening.

docs.title: 7. 윗물이 맑아야 아랫물이 맑다
docs.text:
Literal: When the upper stream is clear, the lower stream is clear Meaning: Leaders set the example; actions start from the top Usage: About leadership and setting examples

부모가 먼저 모범을 보여야 해요.
윗물이 맑아야 아랫물이 맑으니까요.

Parents should set an example first.
The leader's behavior influences followers.

docs.title: 8. 금강산도 식후경
docs.text:
Literal: Even Mt. Geumgang (most beautiful mountain) is after eating Meaning: Food first, business later; can't work on empty stomach Usage: Prioritizing practical needs

얘기는 나중에 하고 먼저 밥 먹어요.
금강산도 식후경이라고요.

Let's eat first and talk later.
We need energy before anything else.

docs.title: 9. 시작이 반이다
docs.text:
Literal: Starting is half Meaning: Well begun is half done; the first step is the hardest Usage: Encouraging someone to start

일단 시작해 봐요. 시작이 반이에요.
Just start. Beginning is half the battle.

docs.title: 10. 원숭이도 나무에서 떨어진다
docs.text:
Literal: Even monkeys fall from trees Meaning: Everyone makes mistakes; even experts fail sometimes Usage: Consoling someone who made a mistake

실수할 수 있어요. 원숭이도 나무에서 떨어진다니까요.
You can make mistakes. Even experts mess up sometimes.

docs.title: 11. 아니 땐 굴뚝에 연기 날까
docs.text:
Literal: Would smoke come from a chimney without fire? Meaning: There's no smoke without fire; rumors usually have some basis Usage: Suggesting rumors have some truth

그 소문이 완전히 거짓은 아닐 거예요.
아니 땐 굴뚝에 연기 날까요?

That rumor probably isn't completely false.
There's no smoke without fire.

docs.title: 12. 돌다리도 두들겨 보고 건너라
docs.text:
Literal: Even a stone bridge, knock on it before crossing Meaning: Be cautious; better safe than sorry; look before you leap Usage: Advising caution

조심하는 게 좋아요. 돌다리도 두들겨 보고 건너라잖아요.
It's better to be careful. Better safe than sorry.

docs.title: 13. 누워서 떡 먹기
docs.text:
Literal: Eating rice cake while lying down Meaning: Piece of cake; very easy Usage: Describing something simple

그 시험? 누워서 떡 먹기예요.
That test? It's a piece of cake.

docs.title: 14. 하늘의 별 따기
docs.text:
Literal: Picking stars from the sky Meaning: Extremely difficult; impossible Usage: Describing something very hard

그 대학 들어가기는 하늘의 별 따기예요.
Getting into that university is extremely difficult.

docs.title: 15. 작은 고추가 더 맵다
docs.text:
Literal: Small peppers are spicier Meaning: Good things come in small packages; small but mighty Usage: About someone small but capable

키는 작아도 실력은 최고예요. 작은 고추가 더 맵다니까요.
Small in height but top in skill. Don't judge by size!

docs.title: Exercise 1: Match Proverbs to Situations
docs.text:
1. A student starts studying for exams
  2. Saving money little by little
  3. Being careful before investing
  4. Someone small but talented
  5. Everyone makes mistakes

a) 원숭이도 나무에서 떨어진다 b) 시작이 반이다 c) 작은 고추가 더 맵다 d) 티끌 모아 태산 e) 돌다리도 두들겨 보고 건너라

docs.title: Exercise 2: Complete the Proverb
docs.text:
1. 가는 말이 고와야 _____
  2. 윗물이 맑아야 _____
  3. 낮말은 새가 듣고 _____
  4. 금강산도 _____
  5. 소 잃고 _____

docs.title: Exercise 3: When to Use?
docs.text:
Which proverb would you use:

  1. To tell someone it's too late to regret
  2. To encourage teamwork
  3. To say something is very easy
  4. To emphasize being nice to others
  5. To say food should come first
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1-b, 2-d, 3-e, 4-c, 5-a

Exercise 2: 1. 오는 말이 곱다 2. 아랫물이 맑다 3. 밤말은 쥐가 듣는다 4. 식후경 5. 외양간 고친다

Exercise 3: 1. 소 잃고 외양간 고친다 2. 백지장도 맞들면 낫다 3. 누워서 떡 먹기 4. 가는 말이 고와야 오는 말이 곱다 5. 금강산도 식후경

docs.title: Usage Tips
docs.text:
Using proverbs naturally:

  1. Don't overuse - One per conversation is plenty
  2. Match the situation - Use appropriately
  3. Add softeners: ~(이)라고 했잖아요, ~(이)라니까요
  4. Know your audience - Some are old-fashioned
  5. Context matters - Make sure it fits

Common patterns: 

~(이)라고 - They say...
~잖아요 - You know...
~(이)라니까요 - I'm telling you...
~(이)라고 했어요 - As they say...

docs.title: Modern Usage
docs.text:
Still very common: - 시작이 반이다 - 누워서 떡 먹기 - 하늘의 별 따기 - 금강산도 식후경

Less common (but understood): - 낮말은 새가 듣고 밤말은 쥐가 듣는다 - 돌다리도 두들겨 보고 건너라

Know but may sound old: - 작은 고추가 더 맵다 (still used but less frequent)

docs.title: Cultural Note
docs.text:
Korean proverbs reflect: - Agricultural society: Many farm/nature references - Confucian values: Hierarchy, respect, hard work - Practical wisdom: Common sense advice - Collective culture: Teamwork, relationships

Using proverbs shows: - Cultural understanding - Wisdom - Fluency - Integration into Korean thinking

But be careful not to sound like you're lecturing—use naturally and sparingly!

docs.title: Advanced Korean
docs.text: Welcome to advanced Korean. At this level, you'll explore sophisticated grammar, learn hanja (Chinese characters) essential for deeper understanding, and master specialized vocabulary for professional and academic contexts.

docs.title: What Makes This "Advanced"?
docs.text: Advanced Korean involves: - Literary and archaic forms rarely used in daily speech - Hanja (한자) understanding for academic/formal Korean - Specialized vocabulary for professional fields - Cultural and historical depth in language use - Native-level nuance and sophistication

docs.title: Advanced Grammar
docs.text: Complex patterns found in: - Literature and formal writing - Legal and academic texts - Classical Korean - Formal speeches - Archaic forms still appearing in modern Korean

docs.title: Hanja (Chinese Characters)
docs.text: Understanding 한자 helps with: - Academic vocabulary (70% of Korean words have Chinese roots) - Newspaper reading - Formal documents - Professional terminology - Etymology and word relationships

docs.title: Specialized Korean
docs.text: Professional language for: - Business and commerce - Academic research - Media and journalism - Technical fields

docs.title: Study Approach
docs.text: At this level: 1. Focus on your specific needs (business, academic, etc.) 2. Read extensively in your field 3. Build specialized vocabulary systematically 4. Understand hanja for word relationships 5. Practice formal/sophisticated expression

docs.title: Moving Forward
docs.text:
Choose sections based on your goals: - Academic path: Focus on academic style + hanja - Business path: Business Korean + formal grammar - General advancement: Broad exposure to all sections

Let's reach native-level proficiency!

docs.title: Advanced Grammar
docs.text: Advanced grammar patterns appear in formal writing, literature, legal documents, and classical Korean. While not used in everyday conversation, understanding these patterns is essential for reading sophisticated Korean texts.

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text: Literary Forms - Patterns from literature and classical texts Archaic Endings - Historical forms still appearing in modern Korean Formal Particles - Specialized particles for formal contexts Complex Patterns - Sophisticated grammatical constructions

docs.title: Study Focus
docs.text:
These patterns are primarily for: - Recognition (reading comprehension) - Formal writing (academic, legal, literary) - Cultural understanding (classical texts, historical documents)

Most are not for everyday conversation.

docs.title: Sections
docs.text:
• Literary forms and expressions
  • Archaic sentence endings
  • Formal particles (께서, (으)로서, (으)로써)
  • Complex grammatical patterns

docs.title: Archaic Verb Endings
docs.text:
Quick Reference

Ending Modern Equivalent Usage -도다 -구나, -네 Exclamatory -노라 -ㄴ다 Declarative (literary) -거늘 -는데 Concessive background -건대 -ㄴ다면 Conditional -로다 -구나 Exclamatory (copula) -더라 -더라 Still used (retrospective) -리라 -ㄹ 것이다 Future/determination -리오 -겠는가 Rhetorical question

These endings appear in classical literature, historical dramas, poetry, traditional songs, and formal/ceremonial contexts.

docs.title: -도다
docs.text:
Expresses strong emotion or realization. Modern equivalent: -구나, -네

Archaic Modern Meaning 아름답도다 아름답구나 How beautiful! 슬프도다 슬프구나 How sad! 장하도다 장하구나 How magnificent!

Example from literature:

산이 높도다 - The mountain is high! (poetic admiration)

docs.title: -로다
docs.text:
Exclamatory with copula 이다. Modern: -이구나

Archaic Modern Meaning 봄이로다 봄이구나 It is spring! 그대로다 그대구나 It is you!

docs.title: -노라
docs.text:
Literary declarative, often in first person. Modern: -(느)ㄴ다

Archaic Modern Meaning 가노라 간다 I go / I am going 사랑하노라 사랑한다 I love 맹세하노라 맹세한다 I swear/vow

Famous usage:

님은 갔지마는 나는 님을 보내지 아니하였노라 "My love has left, but I did not send my love away" — 한용운, 님의 침묵

docs.title: -리라
docs.text:
Future or strong determination. Modern: -ㄹ 것이다, -겠다

Archaic Modern Meaning 가리라 갈 것이다 I shall go 이기리라 이길 것이다 I shall win 돌아오리라 돌아올 것이다 I shall return

docs.title: -거늘
docs.text:
Concessive or background information. Modern: -는데

Archaic Modern Meaning 봄이 왔거늘 봄이 왔는데 Spring has come, and yet... 알거늘 아는데 Though (one) knows...

Example:

때가 되었거늘 어찌 오지 않는가? The time has come, so why do you not come?

docs.title: -건대
docs.text:
Conditional "if one considers." Modern: -(느)ㄴ다면, -자면

Archaic Modern Meaning 생각건대 생각하자면 If one thinks about it 말하건대 말하자면 If one speaks of it

docs.title: -리오, -랴
docs.text:
Rhetorical questions. Modern: -겠는가, -ㄹ까

Archaic Modern Meaning 알리오 알겠는가 Would (one) know? 누가 알리오 누가 알겠는가 Who would know? 어찌 잊으랴 어찌 잊겠는가 How could (I) forget?

docs.title: -ㄴ가, -는가
docs.text:
Still used in formal/written Korean, but sounds archaic in speech.

Example Meaning 무엇인가? What is it? 어디로 가는가? Where are you going?

docs.title: Where You'll Encounter These
docs.text: Context Common Endings Historical dramas (사극) -도다, -노라, -거늘 Classical poetry (시조) -노라, -리라, -로다 Traditional songs (가사) -도다, -리라 Buddhist texts -노라, -리라, -거늘 Formal ceremonies -노라, -리라 Literary writing -건대, -거늘

docs.title: Modern Remnants
docs.text:
Some archaic forms survive in fixed expressions:

Expression Meaning Context 만세 (萬歲) Long live! Celebrations 할지어다 May it be done Religious/formal 삼가 고하노라 I humbly announce Ceremonies 명심하라 Keep in mind Formal commands

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
Read these archaic sentences and identify the endings:

  1. 아, 조국이여! 그대 이름 아름답도다.
  2. 내 이 몸이 죽어 가도 님을 잊지 못하리라.
  3. 봄이 왔거늘 꽃이 피지 않는구나.
  4. 그대 어찌 나를 모르랴?
  5. 오늘 이 자리에서 맹세하노라.
Show Answers 1. **-도다** (exclamatory) - "Oh motherland! Your name is beautiful!" 2. **-리라** (future/determination) - "Even if this body dies, I shall not forget my love." 3. **-거늘** (concessive) - "Spring has come, yet the flowers do not bloom." 4. **-랴** (rhetorical question) - "How could you not know me?" 5. **-노라** (declarative) - "I hereby vow at this place today."

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Understanding archaic endings is essential for: - Appreciating classical Korean literature - Understanding historical dramas - Recognizing ceremonial language - Reading traditional poetry and songs

You don't need to use these actively, but recognition helps you engage with Korea's rich literary heritage.

docs.title: -는 셈이다 (Can be considered as, amounts to)
docs.text: Meaning: Regarding something as, considering, amounts to

docs.title: Formation
docs.text:
• Action verbs: -는 셈이다
  • Descriptive/Past: -(으)ㄴ 셈이다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
매일 운동하니까 돈을 절약하는 셈이에요.
Since I exercise daily, it's like saving money.

반값이니까 공짜나 마찬가지인 셈이다.
At half price, it's basically like it's free.

실패했지만 경험을 쌓은 셈이다.
Although I failed, it amounts to gaining experience.

10년을 기다렸으니 평생을 기다린 셈이다.
Having waited 10 years, it's like waiting a lifetime.

Common patterns: - ~나 마찬가지인 셈이다 (it's as if...) - ~(으)ㄴ 셈 치다 (consider it as...)

docs.title: -기 마련이다 (Bound to, naturally, it's natural that)
docs.text: Meaning: It's natural/inevitable, bound to happen

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: • All verbs: -기 마련이다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
사람은 실수하기 마련이다.
People are bound to make mistakes.

세월이 지나면 변하기 마련이에요.
As time passes, things are bound to change.

노력하면 성공하기 마련이다.
If you try hard, you're bound to succeed.

처음에는 어렵기 마련이에요.
It's naturally difficult at first.

Expresses: - Natural law/principle - Inevitable outcome - Common sense - Universal truth

docs.title: -는 법이다 (It's the way/rule that, it's how)
docs.text: Meaning: That's how it is, that's the way, it's the rule

docs.title: Formation
docs.text:
• Action verbs: -는 법이다
  • Descriptive: -(으)ㄴ 법이다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
노력하는 사람이 성공하는 법이다.
Those who try hard succeed - that's how it works.

시간이 지나면 잊는 법이에요.
As time passes, you forget - that's how it is.

부모는 자식을 사랑하는 법이다.
Parents love their children - that's the way it is.

급할수록 돌아가는 법이다.
The more urgent, the more you should take time - that's the rule.

Similar to -기 마련이다 but emphasizes "the way things work"

docs.title: -고 말다 (End up doing, finally do)
docs.text: Meaning: Eventually, in the end, finally (often negative outcome)

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: • All verbs: -고 말다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
결국 포기하고 말았어요.
In the end, I gave up.

비밀이 들키고 말았다.
The secret ended up being discovered.

결국 화를 내고 말았어요.
I ended up getting angry.

늦고 말았다.
I ended up being late.

Often implies: - Regret - Negative outcome - Inevitability - Finality

Contrast: 

결국 성공했다. (neutral: finally succeeded)
결국 성공하고 말았다. (implies: against odds, or with mixed feelings)

docs.title: -아/어 내다 (Successfully complete, manage to)
docs.text: Meaning: Complete action, succeed in doing, manage to do

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: • All verbs: -아/어 내다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
어려운 시험을 통과해 냈어요.
I managed to pass the difficult exam.

끝까지 참아 냈다.
I endured to the end.

드디어 해냈어!
I finally did it!

힘들었지만 버텨 냈어요.
It was hard but I held out.

Emphasizes: - Completion despite difficulty - Achievement - Persistence - Success

docs.title: -기는 하다 (Do ~ but...)
docs.text: Meaning: It's true that..., I do..., (admitting) but...

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: • All verbs: -기는 하다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
비싸기는 한데 품질이 좋아요.
It is expensive, but the quality is good.

먹기는 먹었는데 별로였어요.
I did eat it, but it wasn't great.

알기는 아는데 설명하기는 어려워요.
I do know it, but it's hard to explain.

좋기는 좋은데 너무 비싸요.
It is good, but it's too expensive.

Often followed by: -ㄴ/는데, -지만 (contrastive)

docs.title: -ㄹ/을 뿐이다 (Only, merely, just)
docs.text: Meaning: Only, merely, nothing but

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: • All verbs: -ㄹ/을 뿐이다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
도와주고 싶을 뿐이에요.
I merely want to help.

최선을 다할 뿐이다.
I'll just do my best (nothing more).

모를 뿐이다.
I simply don't know.

기다릴 뿐이에요.
All I can do is wait.

More formal than: -만

Often with negatives: 

알지 못할 뿐이다.
I simply don't know.

docs.title: -기만 하다 (Only do, do nothing but)
docs.text: Meaning: Do nothing but, only keep doing

docs.title: Formation
docs.text: • All verbs: -기만 하다

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
놀기만 하고 공부를 안 해요.
(They) only play and don't study.

말만 하고 행동하지 않아요.
(They) only talk and don't act.

울기만 해요.
(They) do nothing but cry.

Usually negative connotation - doing too much of one thing

docs.title: Exercise 1: Choose Pattern
docs.text:
1. 사람은 실수___ (bound to make mistakes)
  2. 열심히 공부했으니 합격___ (amounts to passing)
  3. 결국 포기___ (ended up giving up)
  4. 비싸___ 좋아요 (it is expensive but...)

a) -하기 마련이다 b) -한 셈이다 c) -하고 말았다 d) -기는 한데

docs.title: Exercise 2: Complete Sentences
docs.text:
1. 노력하는 사람이 성공 . (it's the way)
  2. 드디어 해___ ! (managed to do)
  3. 기다릴 ___ 이에요. (can only wait)
  4. 말___ ___ 행동은 안 해요. (only talks)
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1. a (하기 마련이다) 2. b (한 셈이다) 3. c (하고 말았다) 4. d (기는 한데)

Exercise 2: 1. 하는 법이다 2. 냈어 3. 뿐 4. 만 하고 / 기만 하고

docs.title: Common Patterns Combined
docs.text:
These patterns often combine with others:

-기 마련이니까 (since it's bound to...)
-는 셈 치고 (considering it as...)
-고 말 거야 (will end up doing)
-아/어 내고 말았다 (ended up succeeding)

docs.title: Usage Tips
docs.text:
1. -기 마련이다 / -는 법이다: Use for general truths
  2. -는 셈이다: Use for reframing/rationalizing
  3. -고 말다: Use for finality (often negative)
  4. -아/어 내다: Use for achievement despite difficulty
  5. -을 뿐이다: Use for emphasis on limitation

These patterns appear frequently in: - Formal writing - News articles - Academic texts - Speeches - Literary works

Master them for sophisticated Korean expression!

docs.title: 께서 (Honorific subject marker)
docs.text:
Instead of: 이/가 (subject particle) Usage: Extremely respectful subject marking

할아버지께서 오셨습니다.
Grandfather came.

선생님께서 말씀하셨습니다.
The teacher spoke.

사장님께서 결정하실 것입니다.
The president will decide.

When to use: - Highly respected persons - Formal speeches - Business presentations - Formal writing

Don't use for: Yourself, peers, younger people

docs.title: (으)로서 vs (으)로써
docs.text: These look similar but have completely different meanings!

docs.title: (으)로서 - As (in the capacity of, in one's position as)
docs.text:
Meaning: In one's role/capacity as

한국인으로서 자랑스럽습니다.
As a Korean, I'm proud.

학생으로서 할 일을 다했다.
I did my duty as a student.

교사로서 책임감을 느낀다.
As a teacher, I feel responsibility.

부모로서 걱정이 된다.
As a parent, I'm worried.

Pattern: [Noun] + (으)로서 - After consonant: 으로서 - After vowel: 로서

docs.title: (으)로써 - By means of, with
docs.text:
Meaning: Using, by means of, with (instrument/method)

이 문제를 대화로써 해결하자.
Let's solve this problem through dialogue.

노력으로써 성공했다.
Succeeded through effort.

법으로써 처벌하다.
Punish by law.

힘으로써 이기려 하지 마라.
Don't try to win by force.

Pattern: [Noun] + (으)로써 - After consonant: 으로써 - After vowel: 로써

docs.title: Key Difference
docs.text:
로서 = as (role/position) 로써 = by means of (method/tool)

교사로서 학생을 가르친다.
As a teacher, (I) teach students.
(position/role)

책으로써 학생을 가르친다.
(I) teach students by means of books.
(method/tool)

docs.title: Practice Contrast
docs.text:
1. 한국인___ 투표할 권리가 있다.
  2. 이 문제를 평화___ 해결해야 한다.
  3. 리더___ 모범을 보여야 한다.
  4. 기술___ 세계를 바꿀 수 있다.

Answers: 1. 으로서 2. 로써 3. 로서 4. 로써

docs.title: 에게서 vs 한테서 vs 로부터
docs.text: All mean "from" but with different formality levels:

docs.title: 에게서 (Neutral to formal)
docs.text:
친구에게서 편지를 받았다.
Received a letter from a friend.

선생님에게서 배웠습니다.
Learned from the teacher.

docs.title: 한테서 (Casual)
docs.text:
친구한테서 들었어.
Heard it from a friend.

누구한테서 받았어?
Who did you get it from?

docs.title: 로부터 (Formal, from source/origin)
docs.text:
정부로부터 지원을 받았다.
Received support from the government.

경험으로부터 배운다.
Learn from experience.

Usage: - 에게서: Standard, neutral - 한테서: Casual conversation - 로부터: Formal writing, abstract sources

docs.title: 께 (Honorific to/for)
docs.text:
Instead of: 에게, 한테

할머니께 드렸습니다.
I gave (it) to grandmother.

선생님께 여쭤보세요.
Please ask the teacher.

부모님께 감사드립니다.
I'm grateful to my parents.

Always use with: - Respected elders - Teachers, bosses - Formal situations

docs.title: 의 (Possessive - formal usage)
docs.text:
Standard possessive marker

나의 책 = 내 책 (my book)
한국의 역사 (Korea's history)
대통령의 연설 (the president's speech)

In formal writing: - Often keep full 의 - In speech, often shortened or dropped

Formal: 한국의 문화 Casual: 한국 문화

docs.title: Exercise 1: Choose (으)로서 or (으)로써
docs.text:
1. 학생___ 공부하는 것은 당연하다.
  2. 이 도구___ 작업할 수 있다.
  3. 국민___ 의무를 다해야 한다.
  4. 사랑___ 세상을 바꿀 수 있다.

docs.title: Exercise 2: Add Correct Particle
docs.text:
1. 할아버지___ 오셨습니다. (subject)
  2. 선생님___ 질문했습니다. (to)
  3. 친구___ 선물을 받았다. (from - formal)
  4. 교사___ 학생을 가르친다. (as)
Answer Key

Exercise 1: 1. 으로서 (as a student) 2. 로써 (by means of this tool) 3. 으로서 (as citizens) 4. 으로써 (through/by means of love)

Exercise 2: 1. 께서 2. 께 3. 에게서 / 로부터 4. 로서

docs.title: Common Mistakes
docs.text:
1. Confusing 로서 and 로써: 

❌ 학생으로써 공부한다 (wrong - not a tool!)
✓ 학생으로서 공부한다 (as a student)

2. Using 께서 for yourself: 

❌ 저께서 하겠습니다 (can't honorific yourself!)
✓ 제가 하겠습니다

3. Wrong formality level: 

❌ (to friend) 너께 줄게 (unnecessarily formal)
✓ (to friend) 너한테 줄게
✓ (to elder) 할머니께 드릴게요

docs.title: Cultural Note
docs.text:
Proper particle usage shows: - Respect: Using께서, 께 appropriately - Education: Knowing 로서 vs 로써 - Formality awareness: Choosing right level - Social competence: Understanding hierarchy

Mastering these particles is essential for professional and formal Korean!

docs.title: -도다 (Literary declarative)
docs.text:
Usage: Literary texts, poems, formal declarations

아름답도다!
How beautiful (it is)!

그 산이 높도다.
That mountain is high.

Modern equivalent: -구나, -네

docs.title: -도다 / -로다 (Exclamatory)
docs.text:
Similar to above but more exclamatory:

슬프도다!
How sad!

기쁘도다!
How joyful!

docs.title: -나니 / -으나니 (Archaic causal)
docs.text:
Meaning: Since, because (archaic)

봄이 왔으나니 꽃이 피리라.
Since spring has come, flowers shall bloom.

Modern: -으니까, -아/어서

docs.title: -리라 / -으리라 (Future/will)
docs.text:
Usage: Poems, declarations of intention

내일은 해가 뜨리라.
Tomorrow the sun will rise.

나는 가리라.
I shall go.

Modern: -(으)ㄹ 것이다, -(으)ㄹ게요

docs.title: -도록 (To the extent that)
docs.text:
Still used in modern Korean:

아플 도록 아름답다.
Beautiful to the point of pain.

죽도록 사랑한다.
Love to death.

docs.title: -시나이다 (Archaic honorific)
docs.text:
Usage: Historical dramas, traditional ceremonies

왕이 오시나이다.
The king is coming.

Modern: -십니다

docs.title: -이다 Literary Copula
docs.text:
Older form of to be:

이것이 진리이다.
This is truth.

Modern casual: 이거야

docs.title: -거늘 (But, although - archaic)
docs.text:
노력하였거늘 실패하였다.
Although (I) tried hard, (I) failed.

Modern: -았/었지만, -는데

docs.title: -건대 (When it comes to)
docs.text:
내 생각건대...
When it comes to my thinking... / In my opinion...

Modern: 제 생각에는, -라고 생각하는데

docs.title: -다시피 (As you know/see)
docs.text:
보다시피 괜찮아요.
As you can see, it's fine.

아시다시피 오늘은...
As you know, today...

Common in modern speech!

docs.title: -기 마련이다 (Bound to, naturally)
docs.text:
실수하기 마련이다.
(People) are bound to make mistakes.

변하기 마련이에요.
It's bound to change.

Still used in modern Korean.

docs.title: -ㄴ/는 법이다 (It's the way/rule that)
docs.text:
노력하는 사람이 성공하는 법이다.
It's the way that those who try hard succeed.

세월이 가는 법이에요.
That's how time passes.

Common expression.

docs.title: Practice
docs.text:
These forms appear in: - Historical K-dramas - Classical poetry (한시) - Formal declarations - Traditional ceremonies - Religious texts

For learners: Focus on recognition rather than production. You'll encounter these in reading but rarely need to use them actively.

docs.title: What is Hanja?
docs.text: Hanja (한자) are Chinese characters used in Korean. Although modern Korean primarily uses Hangul, approximately 60-70% of Korean vocabulary has Chinese origins.

docs.title: Why Learn Hanja?
docs.text:
1. Vocabulary understanding: - Distinguish homophones: 수도 (首都 capital / 水道 waterworks) - Understand word formation - Expand vocabulary efficiently - Etymology and word relationships

2. Reading comprehension: - Newspapers sometimes use hanja - Academic texts - Formal documents - Historical texts

3. Cultural literacy: - Classical literature - Historical understanding - Cultural depth - East Asian cultural connections

docs.title: How Hanja Works in Korean
docs.text:
Three types of Korean words:

  1. Pure Korean (순우리말): 하늘, 사랑, 나라
  2. Sino-Korean (한자어): 학교 (學校), 사회 (社會)
  3. Loanwords (외래어): 컴퓨터, 버스

70% of Korean words are Sino-Korean!

docs.title: What You'll Learn
docs.text:
• Why learn hanja (benefits and usage)
  • Common 100 hanja characters
  • Word formation principles
  • Hanja in daily life
  • How to study effectively

docs.title: Study Approach
docs.text:
For learners: - Focus on recognition, not writing - Learn common characters first - Understand word formation patterns - Use for vocabulary building

You don't need to write hanja, but recognizing common ones helps tremendously with vocabulary!

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 百 백 hundred 백화점 (department store), 백발 (white hair) 千 천 thousand 천원 (1000 won), 천사 (angel) 萬 만 ten thousand 만원 (10,000 won), 만세 (long live)

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 人 인 person 한국인 (Korean person), 인간 (human) 男 남 man 남자 (man), 남편 (husband) 女 여 woman 여자 (woman), 여성 (female) 子 자 child 남자 (man), 여자 (woman), 왕자 (prince) 母 모 mother 모국 (mother country), 모교 (alma mater) 父 부 father 부모 (parents), 부친 (father-formal) 友 우 friend 친구 (friend), 우정 (friendship) 生 생 life, birth 학생 (student), 생일 (birthday)

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 學 학 study, learning 학교 (school), 대학 (university) 校 교 school 학교 (school), 교실 (classroom) 先 선 first, ahead 선생 (teacher), 선배 (senior) 生 생 student, life 학생 (student), 생활 (life) 文 문 writing, literature 문학 (literature), 문화 (culture) 書 서 book, writing 도서관 (library), 독서 (reading)

docs.title: Time
docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 日 일 day, sun 일요일 (Sunday), 생일 (birthday) 月 월 month, moon 일월 (January), 월요일 (Monday) 年 년/연 year 올해/올연 (this year), 내년 (next year) 時 시 time, hour 한 시 (1 o'clock), 시간 (time) 今 금 now 지금 (now), 금년 (this year) 古 고 old, ancient 고대 (ancient times), 고향 (hometown) 新 신 new 신문 (newspaper), 신년 (new year)

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 來 래/내 come 미래 (future), 왕래 (coming and going) 去 거 go 과거 (past), 거리 (distance) 出 출 exit, go out 출구 (exit), 출발 (departure) 入 입 enter 입구 (entrance), 입학 (admission) 見 견 see 의견 (opinion), 견학 (field trip) 聞 문 hear 신문 (newspaper), 문의 (inquiry) 言 언 speak, word 언어 (language), 발언 (statement) 食 식 eat, food 음식 (food), 식당 (restaurant)

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 國 국 country 한국 (Korea), 외국 (foreign country) 家 가 house, family 국가 (nation), 가족 (family) 山 산 mountain 산 (mountain), 등산 (hiking) 水 수 water 수영 (swimming), 수도 (capital/water) 火 화 fire 화재 (fire disaster), 화요일 (Tuesday) 木 목 tree, wood 나무 (tree), 목요일 (Thursday) 金 금 gold, metal 금 (gold), 금요일 (Friday) 土 토 earth, soil 토요일 (Saturday), 토지 (land) 東 동 east 동쪽 (east), 동양 (Orient) 西 서 west 서쪽 (west), 서양 (Western) 南 남 south 남쪽 (south), 남부 (southern part) 北 북 north 북쪽 (north), 북부 (northern part) 中 중 middle, center 중앙 (center), 중국 (China) 大 대 big, great 대학 (university), 대통령 (president) 小 소 small 소학교 (elementary school), 소설 (novel)

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 好 호 good, like 호감 (favorable impression) 悪 악 bad, evil 악마 (devil), 최악 (worst) 長 장 long, chief 사장 (company president), 성장 (growth) 短 단 short 단점 (weak point), 단기 (short-term) 高 고 high 고속 (high speed), 고등학교 (high school) 低 저 low 저가 (low price), 저녁 (evening) 多 다 many 다수 (majority), 다양 (diverse) 少 소 few, little 소수 (minority), 소량 (small amount)
