docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 心 심 heart, mind 마음 (heart), 관심 (interest) 力 력/역 power, strength 능력 (ability), 노력 (effort) 氣 기 energy, spirit 공기 (air), 기분 (mood) 事 사 affair, matter 일 (work), 사건 (incident) 物 물 thing, object 동물 (animal), 식물 (plant) 道 도 way, path 철도 (railroad), 도로 (road) 會 회 meeting, society 회의 (meeting), 사회 (society) 業 업 business, work 사업 (business), 작업 (work)

docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 白 백 white 백색 (white color), 백인 (white person) 黑 흑 black 흑색 (black color), 흑인 (black person) 靑 청 blue/green 청소년 (youth), 청바지 (blue jeans) 赤 적 red 적색 (red color), 적십자 (Red Cross) 黃 황 yellow 황색 (yellow color), 황금 (gold)

docs.title: Essential Verbs in Hanja
docs.text: Hanja Korean Meaning Examples 使 사 use 사용 (use), 대사 (ambassador) 作 작 make, create 작품 (work/artwork), 동작 (movement) 動 동 move 운동 (exercise), 자동 (automatic) 止 지 stop 중지 (stop), 정지 (halt) 住 주 live, dwell 주소 (address), 거주 (residence) 知 지 know 통지 (notice), 인지 (recognition) 思 사 think 사고 (accident/thought), 생각 (thought) 愛 애 love 사랑 (love), 애정 (affection)

docs.title: Recognizing Compound Words
docs.text:
Can you guess the meaning?

  1. 학교 (學校) = study + school = ?
  2. 생일 (生日) = birth + day = ?
  3. 동물 (動物) = move + thing = ?
  4. 한국인 (韓國人) = Korea + country + person = ?
  5. 출입구 (出入口) = exit + enter + mouth = ?

Answers: 1. school, 2. birthday, 3. animal, 4. Korean person, 5. entrance/exit

docs.title: Study Tips
docs.text:
1. Learn radicals first: Many hanja share components
  2. Group by theme: Numbers, time, people, etc.
  3. Focus on recognition: Don't worry about writing
  4. See patterns: Same hanja appears in many words
  5. Use flashcards: Spaced repetition works well

Knowing these 100 characters unlocks thousands of Korean words!

docs.title: 1. Signs & Public Spaces
docs.text:
Exit/Entrance signs: - 出口 (출구) - Exit - 入口 (입구) - Entrance - 非常口 (비상구) - Emergency Exit

Buildings: - 圖書館 (도서관) - Library - 美術館 (미술관) - Art Museum - 博物館 (박물관) - Museum - 百貨店 (백화점) - Department Store

docs.title: 2. Newspapers
docs.text:
Headlines sometimes show hanja in parentheses: 

대통령(大統領) 방문
수출(輸出) 증가(增加)
교육(敎育) 개혁(改革)

Why? Clarifies meaning for important/ambiguous terms.

docs.title: 3. Names
docs.text:
Personal names (이름): Almost all Korean names use hanja: - 김민준 (金民俊) - 이서연 (李瑞妍) - 박지호 (朴智浩)

Place names: - 서울 (漢城/首爾) - 부산 (釜山) - 대구 (大邱)

docs.title: 4. Formal Documents
docs.text:
Legal documents: - 契約書 (계약서) - Contract - 證明書 (증명서) - Certificate - 申請書 (신청서) - Application

Business cards (명함): Often show hanja for names and titles: - 社長 (사장) - Company President - 部長 (부장) - Department Head

docs.title: 5. Academic Contexts
docs.text:
Textbooks: - 數學 (수학) - Mathematics - 科學 (과학) - Science - 歷史 (역사) - History

Degrees: - 學士 (학사) - Bachelor's - 碩士 (석사) - Master's - 博士 (박사) - Doctorate

docs.title: Time & Calendar
docs.text:
Days of week (all use hanja!): - 月曜日 (월요일) - Monday (Moon day) - 火曜日 (화요일) - Tuesday (Fire day) - 水曜日 (수요일) - Wednesday (Water day) - 木曜日 (목요일) - Thursday (Wood day) - 金曜日 (금요일) - Friday (Metal day) - 土曜日 (토요일) - Saturday (Earth day) - 日曜日 (일요일) - Sunday (Sun day)

Months: - 一月 (일월) - January - 二月 (이월) - February - Through 十二月 (십이월) - December

docs.title: Four-Character Idioms (四字成語)
docs.text:
일석이조 (一石二鳥) - One stone, two birds - Kill two birds with one stone

자화자찬 (自畫自讚) - Self drawing, self praise - Blowing your own horn

동문서답 (東問西答) - East question, west answer - Irrelevant answer

docs.title: Traditional Concepts
docs.text: 오륜 (五倫) - Five Moral Principles 삼강 (三綱) - Three Fundamental Principles 효도 (孝道) - Filial piety

docs.title: Modern Digital Age
docs.text:
Even with smartphones, hanja appears:

Apps & Technology: - 檢索 (검색) - Search - 畫面 (화면) - Screen - 設定 (설정) - Settings - 登錄 (등록) - Register

Social Media: Many profile names use hanja Captions sometimes include hanja for emphasis

docs.title: Recognition vs. Production
docs.text:
You need to: - ✓ Recognize common hanja - ✓ Understand hanja-based words - ✓ Read signs with hanja

You don't need to: - ✗ Write hanja by hand - ✗ Memorize every character - ✗ Use hanja in daily writing (Hangul is standard)

docs.title: Practical Tips
docs.text:
When you see unfamiliar Sino-Korean word:

  1. Look for familiar hanja components
  2. Break down into parts
  3. Deduce approximate meaning
  4. Verify with dictionary if needed

Example: 도서관 - 圖 (picture/plan) - might not know - 書 (book) - you know this! - 館 (building) - you know this! - → Probably related to books and buildings → Library!

docs.title: Bottom Line
docs.text:
Hanja is everywhere in Korean life, even if not always visible. Understanding common characters: - Makes vocabulary learning easier - Helps read formal texts - Clarifies confusing words - Deepens cultural understanding

Focus on the most common 100-300 characters for practical daily use!

docs.title: Distinguishing Homophones
docs.text:
Many Korean words sound identical but have different hanja:

수도 [su-do]: - 首都 - capital city - 水道 - waterworks, water supply - 修道 - religious training - 手刀 - hand blade (karate chop)

사회 [sa-hoe] vs 사회 [sa-hoe]: - 社會 - society - 司會 - host, MC

독서 [dok-seo]: - 讀書 - reading books - 毒書 - poisonous book (rare)

Knowing hanja = instant clarity!

docs.title: Building Blocks
docs.text:
Learning one hanja unlocks multiple words:

學 (학) = learning, study - 학교 (學校) - school - 학생 (學生) - student - 대학 (大學) - university - 과학 (科學) - science - 철학 (哲學) - philosophy - 문학 (文學) - literature

One character = dozens of words!

docs.title: Logical Combinations
docs.text:
生 (생) = life, birth 日 (일) = day

  • 생일 (生日) - birthday (birth + day)
  • 일생 (一生) - lifetime (one + life)

Once you know the parts, you can understand new words instantly!

docs.title: Newspapers
docs.text: Korean newspapers use hanja in: - Headlines (occasionally) - Proper names - Clarifying meaning - Formal announcements

docs.title: Academic Writing
docs.text: Academic Korean heavily uses Sino-Korean vocabulary: - 연구 (硏究) - research - 분석 (分析) - analysis - 이론 (理論) - theory - 방법 (方法) - method

docs.title: Legal Documents
docs.text: Legal Korean is full of Sino-Korean terms: - 계약 (契約) - contract - 법률 (法律) - law - 권리 (權利) - rights

docs.title: Classical Literature
docs.text: Korean classical texts mix hangul and hanja: - 훈민정음 (訓民正音) - Historical documents - Traditional poetry

docs.title: Names
docs.text:
Korean names are based on hanja: - 김영수 (金英秀) - 이민준 (李民俊) - 박서연 (朴瑞妍)

Understanding hanja helps understand name meanings!

docs.title: Proverbs
docs.text: Many 속담 come from Chinese: - 화룡점정 (畫龍點睛) - finishing touch - 일석이조 (一石二鳥) - kill two birds with one stone

docs.title: Pattern Recognition
docs.text:
Words with same hanja share meaning:

國 (국) = country: - 한국 (韓國) - Korea - 미국 (美國) - America - 중국 (中國) - China - 외국 (外國) - foreign country - 국가 (國家) - nation

Learn one character = understand all these instantly!

docs.title: Etymology
docs.text: Understanding where words come from: - 감사합니다 (感謝-) "I thank you" - 感 = feeling, 謝 = gratitude - 축하합니다 (祝賀-) "Congratulations" - 祝 = celebrate, 賀 = congratulate

docs.title: Reading Signs
docs.text: Public signs sometimes use hanja: - 入口 (entrance) - 出口 (exit) - 非常口 (emergency exit)

docs.title: Understanding Contexts
docs.text: Formal speeches, news, announcements use Sino-Korean vocabulary heavily. Hanja knowledge = better comprehension.

docs.title: Cross-Cultural Connections
docs.text: Hanja connects you to: - Chinese culture and language - Japanese kanji - East Asian cultural sphere - Historical texts across region

docs.title: How Much Hanja to Learn?
docs.text:
Practical levels:

  1. Basic (50-100 characters): Useful for daily vocabulary
  2. Intermediate (500 characters): Read most texts comfortably
  3. Advanced (1000+ characters): Academic proficiency
  4. Expert (1800+ characters): Traditional education level

For most learners: 100-300 common characters is very useful!

docs.title: Bottom Line
docs.text:
You don't need to write hanja, but recognizing common characters: - Clarifies confusing vocabulary - Accelerates vocabulary acquisition - Deepens cultural understanding - Improves reading comprehension - Connects related words

Time invested in learning hanja pays off exponentially in vocabulary growth!

docs.title: Basic Principles
docs.text: Korean Sino-Korean words are formed by combining hanja characters, each contributing meaning.

docs.title: Pattern: Character + Character = Word
docs.text: 學 (study) + 校 (school) = 학교 (school) 生 (birth) + 日 (day) = 생일 (birthday)

docs.title: 1. Same Character Repeated
docs.text: 人 + 人 = 인간 (人間) - human being 國 + 國 = 국가 (國家) - nation 時 + 時 = 시시 (時時) - constantly

docs.title: 2. Opposite Concepts
docs.text: 東 (east) + 西 (west) = 동서 (東西) - things, stuff 上 (up) + 下 (down) = 상하 (上下) - up and down, hierarchy 男 (man) + 女 (woman) = 남녀 (男女) - men and women 出 (exit) + 入 (enter) = 출입 (出入) - going in and out

docs.title: 3. Related Concepts
docs.text: 父 (father) + 母 (mother) = 부모 (父母) - parents 兄 (older brother) + 弟 (younger brother) = 형제 (兄弟) - brothers 姉 (older sister) + 妹 (younger sister) = 자매 (姉妹) - sisters

docs.title: 4. Modifier + Main
docs.text: 大 (big) + 學 (learning) = 대학 (大學) - university 小 (small) + 學 (learning) = 소학 (小學) - elementary learning 中 (middle) + 學 (learning) = 중학 (中學) - middle learning 高 (high) + 等 (class) = 고등 (高等) - high class

docs.title: 5. Action + Object
docs.text: 讀 (read) + 書 (book) = 독서 (讀書) - reading 食 (eat) + 事 (matter) = 식사 (食事) - meal 作 (make) + 品 (item) = 작품 (作品) - work of art

docs.title: Using 學 (study/learning)
docs.text:
• 학교 (學校) - school
  • 학생 (學生) - student
  • 대학 (大學) - university
  • 과학 (科學) - science
  • 철학 (哲學) - philosophy
  • 문학 (文學) - literature
  • 수학 (數學) - mathematics
  • 화학 (化學) - chemistry

One character → 8+ words!

docs.title: Using 國 (country)
docs.text:
• 한국 (韓國) - Korea
  • 중국 (中國) - China
  • 미국 (美國) - America
  • 외국 (外國) - foreign country
  • 국가 (國家) - nation
  • 국민 (國民) - citizen
  • 국제 (國際) - international
  • 국내 (國內) - domestic

docs.title: Using 生 (birth/life)
docs.text:
• 생일 (生日) - birthday
  • 학생 (學生) - student
  • 선생 (先生) - teacher
  • 인생 (人生) - life
  • 생활 (生活) - living, lifestyle
  • 생각 (生-, native root) - thought
  • 생명 (生命) - life
  • 탄생 (誕生) - birth

docs.title: Understanding New Words
docs.text:
Once you know components, you can deduce meaning:

未知的 word: 도서관 (圖書館) - 圖 (picture/plan) + 書 (book) + 館 (building) - = Building for books = Library!

未知的 word: 전화기 (電話機) - 電 (electricity) + 話 (speech) + 機 (machine) - = Machine for electric speech = Telephone!

docs.title: Three-Character Words
docs.text:
天氣圖 → 일기예보 (天氣豫報) - 天 (heaven) + 氣 (air) + 豫 (beforehand) + 報 (report) - = Weather forecast

自動車 → 자동차 - 自 (self) + 動 (move) + 車 (vehicle) - = Self-moving vehicle = Car

docs.title: By Category
docs.text:
Education: - 교육 (敎育) - education - 교실 (敎室) - classroom - 교사 (敎師) - teacher - 교과서 (敎科書) - textbook

Transportation: - 교통 (交通) - traffic/transportation - 차량 (車輛) - vehicle - 지하철 (地下鐵) - subway - 비행기 (飛行機) - airplane

docs.title: Hanja Helps Distinguish Homophones
docs.text:
사기: - 士氣 - morale - 詐欺 - fraud - 沙器 - earthenware - 事記 - historical record

Without hanja: Confusing! With hanja: Crystal clear!

docs.title: Modern Usage
docs.text: New words still formed with hanja: - 스마트폰 (smartphone) - 휴대폰 (携帶phone) - 컴퓨터 (computer) - 전자계산기 (電子計算機) - Hybrid: 인터넷 (internet) + 서점 (書店) = 인터넷 서점

docs.title: Decode These Words
docs.text:
1. 남북 (南北)
  2. 출발 (出發)
  3. 한국어 (韓國語)
  4. 외국인 (外國人)
  5. 동서남북 (東西南北)

Answers: 1. South + North = North-South 2. Exit + Depart = Departure 3. Korea + Country + Language = Korean language 4. Outside + Country + Person = Foreigner 5. East + West + South + North = All directions

docs.title: Study Strategy
docs.text:
1. Learn common characters first (100-300)
  2. Group words by shared character
  3. Notice patterns in formation
  4. Deduce new word meanings
  5. Verify with dictionary

Hanja knowledge = vocabulary multiplication!

docs.title: Specialized Korean
docs.text: Korean for professional and specialized contexts requires domain-specific vocabulary and conventions. This section covers the most common specialized areas.

docs.title: Business Korean
docs.text:
• Corporate communication
  • Meetings and presentations
  • Negotiations
  • Business correspondence
  • Office vocabulary

docs.title: Academic Korean
docs.text:
• Research and writing
  • Academic presentations
  • Thesis writing
  • Citation and references
  • Scholarly discussion

docs.title: Media Korean
docs.text:
• News language
  • Broadcasting
  • Journalism
  • Interview techniques
  • Media terminology

docs.title: Approach
docs.text: Each specialized area has: - Unique vocabulary specific to the field - Conventional expressions used in that context - Formality expectations appropriate to the setting - Cultural norms for professional interaction

docs.title: Study Focus
docs.text:
Choose based on your needs: - Business professionals → Business Korean - Students/researchers → Academic Korean - Media industry → Media Korean

Master the vocabulary and conventions relevant to your field for professional-level Korean competency.

docs.title: Research Terms
docs.text:
• 연구 (硏究) - research
  • 논문 (論文) - paper, thesis
  • 분석 (分析) - analysis
  • 조사 (調査) - investigation, survey
  • 실험 (實驗) - experiment
  • 이론 (理論) - theory
  • 가설 (假說) - hypothesis
  • 방법론 (方法論) - methodology
  • 자료 (資料) - data, materials
  • 결과 (結果) - results
  • 결론 (結論) - conclusion

docs.title: Academic Writing
docs.text:
• 서론 (序論) - introduction
  • 본론 (本論) - body
  • 문헌 검토 (文獻檢討) - literature review
  • 참고문헌 (參考文獻) - references
  • 인용 (引用) - citation, quotation
  • 각주 (脚註) - footnote
  • 목차 (目次) - table of contents

docs.title: Academic Expressions
docs.text:
Introducing research: 

본 연구의 목적은 ~을/를 분석하는 것이다.
The purpose of this research is to analyze ~.

이 논문에서는 ~을/를 다룬다.
This paper deals with ~.

Citing: 

김영수(2020)에 따르면...
According to Kim (2020)...

선행 연구에서는...
In previous research...

Presenting results: 

연구 결과는 다음과 같다.
The research results are as follows.

분석 결과 ~으로 나타났다.
Analysis showed that ~.

Concluding: 

결론적으로...
In conclusion...

본 연구의 시사점은...
The implications of this study are...

docs.title: Formal statements
docs.text:
~라고 할 수 있다 - can be said that
~로 볼 수 있다 - can be seen as
~을/를 알 수 있다 - it can be known that
~라고 생각한다 - (I) think that

docs.title: Causation
docs.text:
~기 때문이다 - because
~으로 인해 - due to
~에 따라 - according to, following
~의 결과 - as a result of

This vocabulary is essential for Korean academic success!

docs.title: Company Structure
docs.text:
• 회사 (會社) - company
  • 본사 (本社) - headquarters
  • 지사 (支社) - branch office
  • 부서 (部署) - department
  • 팀 (team) - team

docs.title: Positions & Titles
docs.text:
• 사장 (社長) - president/CEO
  • 부사장 - vice president
  • 전무 - executive director
  • 상무 - managing director
  • 이사 (理事) - director
  • 부장 (部長) - department head
  • 과장 (課長) - section chief
  • 대리 - assistant manager
  • 사원 (社員) - employee

docs.title: Business Activities
docs.text:
• 회의 (會議) - meeting
  • 출장 (出張) - business trip
  • 보고 (報告) - report
  • 계약 (契約) - contract
  • 협상 (協商) - negotiation
  • 제안 (提案) - proposal
  • 프로젝트 - project
  • 마감 - deadline

docs.title: Meetings
docs.text:
회의를 시작하겠습니다.
Let's begin the meeting.

안건을 말씀드리겠습니다.
I'll present the agenda.

의견을 말씀해 주십시오.
Please share your opinion.

검토해 보겠습니다.
We'll review it.

docs.title: Email Phrases
docs.text:
메일 확인하셨습니까?
Did you check the email?

첨부 파일을 참고해 주십시오.
Please refer to the attached file.

회신 부탁드립니다.
Please reply.

확인 후 연락드리겠습니다.
I'll contact you after checking.

docs.title: Phone Calls
docs.text:
○○ 회사 △△입니다.
This is △△ from ○○ Company.

담당자를 바꿔 드리겠습니다.
I'll transfer you to the person in charge.

메시지를 남기시겠습니까?
Would you like to leave a message?

다시 전화드리겠습니다.
I'll call back.

docs.title: Requests & Responses
docs.text:
부탁드립니다.
I ask for your help.

알겠습니다.
Understood.

검토하겠습니다.
I'll review it.

확인 후 답변드리겠습니다.
I'll respond after checking.

docs.title: Business Meeting Structure
docs.text:
Opening: 

바쁘신 중에 참석해 주셔서 감사합니다.
Thank you for attending despite your busy schedule.

Presenting: 

먼저 ~에 대해 말씀드리겠습니다.
First, I'll speak about ~.

다음 슬라이드를 보시겠습니다.
Please look at the next slide.

Q&A: 

질문 있으십니까?
Do you have any questions?

좋은 질문입니다.
That's a good question.

Closing: 

오늘 회의는 여기까지 하겠습니다.
That concludes today's meeting.

docs.title: Negotiation Language
docs.text:
조건을 검토해 보겠습니다.
We'll review the conditions.

할인이 가능하신가요?
Is a discount possible?

재고하겠습니다.
We'll reconsider.

합의점을 찾아봅시다.
Let's find common ground.

docs.title: Cultural Notes
docs.text:
Hierarchy matters: - Always use proper titles - Defer to seniors in meetings - Business cards (명함) exchanged formally

Communication style: - Indirect, not blunt - Use humble language - Show respect through formality

This is essential for professional Korean business environments!

docs.title: Media Terms
docs.text:
• 언론 (言論) - media, press
  • 기자 (記者) - reporter, journalist
  • 취재 (取材) - news gathering, coverage
  • 보도 (報道) - news report
  • 기사 (記事) - article
  • 특종 (特種) - scoop, exclusive
  • 속보 (速報) - breaking news
  • 헤드라인 - headline

docs.title: Broadcasting
docs.text:
• 방송 (放送) - broadcast
  • 뉴스 - news
  • 앵커 - anchor
  • 생방송 (生放送) - live broadcast
  • 녹화 (錄畫) - recording
  • 인터뷰 - interview

docs.title: News Expressions
docs.text:
Reporting: 

~(이)라고 밝혔다 - stated that
~(이)라고 전했다 - reported that
~로 알려졌다 - it was learned that
~로 나타났다 - it appeared that

Headlines: 

정부, 새 정책 발표
Government announces new policy

주가 급등
Stock prices surge

Breaking news: 

속보입니다.
This is breaking news.

지금 들어온 소식입니다.
This is news just coming in.

Essential for understanding Korean news media!

docs.title: Sentence Endings by Formality
docs.text: Formality Statement Question Proposal Command Formal (합니다체) -습니다/-ㅂ니다 -습니까/-ㅂ니까 -(으)ㅂ시다 -(으)십시오 Polite (해요체) -아/어요 -아/어요? -(으)ㄹ까요? -(으)세요 Casual (반말) -아/어 -아/어? -(으)ㄹ까? -아/어

docs.title: Past Tense
docs.text:
-았/었/했- - After ㅏ, ㅗ: -았- - After other vowels: -었- - 하다 → 했-

가다 → 갔다
먹다 → 먹었다
하다 → 했다

docs.title: Future Tense
docs.text: -(으)ㄹ 거예요 - will (casual prediction) -(으)ㄹ게요 - will (speaker's intention) -(으)ㄹ 것이다 - will (formal/written)

docs.title: Connectors
docs.text: Pattern Meaning Example -고 And (sequential) 밥을 먹고 갔어요 -아/어서 So, because 바빠서 못 갔어요 -(으)니까 Since, because 비가 오니까 우산을 가져가세요 -지만 But, although 비싸지만 샀어요 -(으)면 If, when 시간이 있으면 올게요 -(으)면서 While 음악을 들으면서 공부해요

docs.title: Modifiers
docs.text:
Action verbs (present): -는 

가는 사람 - person who goes
먹는 음식 - food (that I) eat

Descriptive verbs & past: -(으)ㄴ 

큰 집 - big house
간 사람 - person who went

Future: -(으)ㄹ 

갈 사람 - person who will go
먹을 음식 - food (I'll) eat

docs.title: Ability & Possibility
docs.text:
-(으)ㄹ 수 있다/없다 - can/cannot 

한국어를 할 수 있어요 - can speak Korean
갈 수 없어요 - cannot go

docs.title: Intention & Planning
docs.text: -(으)려고 하다 - intend to -고 싶다 - want to -(으)ㄹ까 하다 - thinking about doing -기로 하다 - decided to

docs.title: Experience
docs.text:
-아/어 본 적이 있다/없다 - have/haven't done 

한국에 가 본 적이 있어요 - I've been to Korea
먹어 본 적이 없어요 - I've never eaten it

docs.title: Obligation
docs.text: -아/어야 하다/되다 - must, have to -(으)면 안 되다 - must not

docs.title: Permission
docs.text: -아/어도 되다 - may, it's okay to -(으)면 안 되다 - must not

docs.title: Trying & Attempting
docs.text:
-아/어 보다 - try doing 

먹어 봐요 - Try eating it

docs.title: Giving & Receiving
docs.text: 주다 - give (to someone) 드리다 - give (humble) 받다 - receive -아/어 주다 - do for someone

docs.title: Honorifics
docs.text: Subject: -(으)시- Special verbs: - 먹다 → 드시다/잡수시다 - 자다 → 주무시다 - 있다 → 계시다 - 말하다 → 말씀하시다

docs.title: Quick Grammar Patterns
docs.text:
-고 있다 - be doing (progressive) -아/어 있다 - be in a state -게 되다 - come to be -아/어지다 - become -(으)ㄴ/는데 - but, and (background) -거든요 - you know, because -잖아요 - you know (as you know) -(이)라서 - because (it's)

This is a quick reference—see individual lessons for detailed explanations!

docs.title: ㄷ Irregular
docs.text: When ㄷ final consonant meets vowel, ㄷ becomes ㄹ

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 듣다 (to hear) → 들어요, 들었어요
  • 걷다 (to walk) → 걸어요, 걸었어요
  • 묻다 (to ask) → 물어요, 물었어요

Conjugation: 

듣다:
Present: 들어요 (not 듣어요)
Past: 들었어요
Modifier: 듣는 (ㄷ stays before -는)

Exception: 받다 (receive) is regular → 받아요

docs.title: ㅂ Irregular
docs.text: When ㅂ final meets vowel, ㅂ becomes 우

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 춥다 (cold) → 추워요
  • 덥다 (hot) → 더워요
  • 돕다 (help) → 도와요
  • 아름답다 (beautiful) → 아름다워요

Conjugation: 

춥다:
Present: 추워요 (not 춥어요)
Past: 추웠어요
Modifier: 추운

Exception: 좁다 (narrow) can be regular → 좁아요

docs.title: ㅅ Irregular
docs.text: When ㅅ final meets vowel, ㅅ disappears

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 짓다 (build) → 지어요
  • 낫다 (better) → 나아요
  • 잇다 (connect) → 이어요

Conjugation: 

짓다:
Present: 지어요 (not 짓어요)
Past: 지었어요
Modifier: 짓는 (ㅅ stays before consonants)

docs.title: ㅎ Irregular
docs.text: When ㅎ meets ㄴ or vowel, ㅎ disappears

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 빨갛다 (red) → 빨개요, 빨간
  • 노랗다 (yellow) → 노래요, 노란
  • 하얗다 (white) → 하얘요, 하얀

Conjugation: 

빨갛다:
Present: 빨개요 (not 빨갛어요)
Modifier: 빨간 (not 빨갛은)
Past: 빨갰어요

docs.title: ㄹ Irregular
docs.text: ㄹ drops before ㄴ, ㅂ, ㅅ

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 살다 (live) → 살아요, BUT: 삽니다, 사는
  • 만들다 (make) → 만들어요, BUT: 만듭니다, 만드는
  • 알다 (know) → 알아요, BUT: 압니다, 아는

Conjugation: 

살다:
Present polite: 살아요 (keep ㄹ)
Present formal: 삽니다 (ㄹ drops before ㅂ)
Modifier: 사는 (ㄹ drops before ㄴ)
Past: 살았어요

docs.title: 르 Irregular
docs.text: 르 + vowel → double ㄹ + 라/러

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 모르다 (not know) → 몰라요
  • 부르다 (call, sing) → 불러요
  • 빠르다 (fast) → 빨라요

Conjugation: 

모르다:
Present: 몰라요 (모르 + 아 → 몰 + 라)
Past: 몰랐어요
Modifier: 모르는

docs.title: 으 Irregular
docs.text: 으 drops before -아/어

docs.title: Examples:
docs.text:
• 쓰다 (write, use) → 써요
  • 끄다 (turn off) → 꺼요
  • 크다 (big) → 커요

Conjugation: 

쓰다:
Present: 써요 (쓰 + 어 → 써)
Past: 썼어요
Modifier: 쓰는 (으 stays before consonants)

Exception: 따르다 (follow) is regular → 따라요

docs.title: Summary Table
docs.text: Type Change Example Polite Past ㄷ ㄷ→ㄹ 듣다 들어요 들었어요 ㅂ ㅂ→우 춥다 추워요 추웠어요 ㅅ ㅅ drops 짓다 지어요 지었어요 ㅎ ㅎ drops 빨갛다 빨개요 빨갰어요 ㄹ ㄹ drops (before ㄴ/ㅂ/ㅅ) 살다 살아요 살았어요 르 르→double ㄹ 모르다 몰라요 몰랐어요 으 으 drops 쓰다 써요 썼어요

docs.title: Quick Test
docs.text:
Are these irregular?

  1. 받다 (receive) - No (regular)
  2. 굽다 (grill) - Yes (ㅂ irregular) → 구워요
  3. 걷다 (walk) - Yes (ㄷ irregular) → 걸어요
  4. 걷다 (roll up) - No (regular) → 걷어요
  5. 이르다 (early) - Yes (르 irregular) → 일러요

Note: Some verbs can be both regular and irregular with different meanings!

docs.title: Common Irregular Verbs to Memorize
docs.text:
ㄷ Irregular: 듣다, 걷다, 묻다, 싣다

ㅂ Irregular: 춥다, 덥다, 춥다, 돕다, 아름답다, 가볍다

ㅅ Irregular: 짓다, 낫다

ㅎ Irregular: 빨갛다, 노랗다, 하얗다, 파랗다, 까맣다

ㄹ Irregular: 살다, 만들다, 알다, 팔다

르 Irregular: 모르다, 부르다, 빠르다, 고르다

으 Irregular: 쓰다, 끄다, 크다, 바쁘다

Practice these until conjugation becomes automatic!

docs.title: Subject Particles
docs.text: Particle After Usage Example 이 Consonant Subject marker 책이 있어요 가 Vowel Subject marker 물가 있어요 께서 Any Honorific subject 할아버지께서 오셨어요

docs.title: Object Particles
docs.text: Particle After Usage Example 을 Consonant Object marker 책을 읽어요 를 Vowel Object marker 물을 마셔요

docs.title: Topic Particles
docs.text:
Particle After Usage Example 은 Consonant Topic marker 저는 학생이에요 는 Vowel Topic marker 나는 학생이야

Topic vs Subject: - 이/가: New information, emphasis - 은/는: Known topic, contrast

docs.title: Location Particles
docs.text: Particle Meaning Example 에 At, to, in (static location) 집에 있어요 에서 At, in (action location) 도서관에서 공부해요 에서 From (starting point) 서울에서 왔어요 로/으로 To, toward (direction) 학교로 가요 까지 Until, to (endpoint) 서울까지 가요 부터 From (starting point) 9시부터 시작해요

docs.title: Direction/Means Particles
docs.text:
Particle After Meaning Example 로 Vowel/ㄹ By means of, toward 버스로 가요 으로 Other consonants By means of, toward 지하철로 가요

Uses of (으)로: - Direction: 왼쪽으로 (to the left) - Means: 한국어로 (in Korean) - Material: 나무로 (made of wood)

docs.title: Possession/Relationship
docs.text:
Particle Usage Example 의 Possessive ('s, of) 나의 책 (my book)

Often shortened: 나의 → 내, 저의 → 제

docs.title: Indirect Object (to/for)
docs.text: Particle After Usage Example 에게 Any To (person) 친구에게 줬어요 한테 Any To (casual) 친구한테 줬어 께 Any To (honorific) 선생님께 드렸어요

docs.title: From (source)
docs.text: Particle Formality Example 에게서 Neutral 친구에게서 들었어요 한테서 Casual 친구한테서 들었어 로부터 Formal 정부로부터 지원받았습니다

docs.title: Comparison
docs.text: Particle Meaning Example 보다 More than 이것이 저것보다 좋아요 처럼/같이 Like, as 천사처럼 예뻐요 만큼 As much as 너만큼 좋아해

docs.title: Inclusive/Exclusive
docs.text: Particle Meaning Example 도 Also, too, even 나도 가요 만 Only, just 물만 마셔요 밖에 (+ negative) Only (nothing but) 천 원밖에 없어요

docs.title: Listing/Choice
docs.text: Particle Meaning Example 나/이나 Or (listing) 차나 커피 (이)나 As many as 열 명이나 왔어요 (이)든지 Any (choice) 뭐든지 좋아요

docs.title: Time Particles
docs.text: Usage Particle Example Specific time 에 3시에 만나요 Duration 동안 2시간 동안 Before/after 전/후 식사 전에 Time range 부터~까지 9시부터 5시까지

docs.title: Quotation
docs.text: Particle Usage Example 라고/고 Quoting 친구가 좋다고 했어요

docs.title: Emphasis/Addition
docs.text: Particle Meaning Example 도 Even, also 이것도 비싸요 까지 Even (extreme) 선생님까지 왔어요 조차 Even (formal) 물조차 없어요 마저 Even (last thing) 친구마저 떠났어요

docs.title: Particle Combinations
docs.text:
Common particle combinations:

Combination Meaning Example 에서도 Even at/in 학교에서도 공부해요 에게도 To ~ also 친구에게도 줬어요 만큼은 At least as for 이것만큼은 해요 부터 Starting from (topic) 나부터 할게요

docs.title: Particle Dropping
docs.text:
In casual speech, particles often drop:

Can drop: 을/를, 은/는 

밥 먹어? (instead of 밥을 먹어?)
나 학생이야 (instead of 나는 학생이야)

Usually keep: 이/가, 에, 에서 

누가 왔어? (need 가)
어디에 가? (usually keep 에)

docs.title: Special Formal Particles
docs.text: Particle Usage Example (으)로서 As (capacity) 학생으로서 (으)로써 By means of 노력으로써 께서 Subject (honorific) 선생님께서 께 To/for (honorific) 할머니께

docs.title: Quick Reference Tips
docs.text:
이/가 vs 은/는: - First mention → 이/가 - Already mentioned → 은/는 - Emphasis/contrast → 은/는

에 vs 에서: - Static existence → 에 - Action location → 에서

에게 vs 한테: - Formal/written → 에게 - Casual speech → 한테

Particles are the glue of Korean sentences—master them for fluency!

docs.title: Beginner
docs.text:
Integrated Korean (Klear Textbooks) - Comprehensive series - University-level curriculum - Workbook and audio included - Beginner through Advanced

Talk To Me In Korean (TTMIK) - Free online lessons - Natural, conversational approach - Podcast format - Workbooks available

docs.title: Intermediate-Advanced
docs.text:

Yonsei Korean - Academic approach - Strong grammar focus - Widely used

Korean Grammar in Use - Beginner, Intermediate, Advanced levels - Excellent grammar reference - Clear examples

docs.title: Study Tips
docs.text:
Daily Practice: 1. Anki review (20 min) 2. Grammar lesson (30 min) 3. Listening practice (20 min) 4. Reading (20 min) 5. Writing/speaking practice (20 min)

Immersion: - Change phone/computer to Korean - Watch K-dramas with Korean subs - Listen to Korean music daily - Follow Korean social media

Active Learning: - Use a language journal - Practice speaking (even alone!) - Write short texts daily - Find a language partner

docs.title: Recommended Learning Path
docs.text:
Beginner (0-6 months): - TTMIK Levels 1-3 OR Integrated Korean 1 - Anki for vocabulary - Simple K-drama with subs - Basic grammar focus

Intermediate (6-18 months): - TTMIK Levels 4-7 OR Integrated Korean 2-3 - Korean Grammar in Use (Intermediate) - K-dramas with Korean subs - Start reading webtoons - Language exchange practice

Advanced (18+ months): - Advanced textbooks - Korean Grammar in Use (Advanced) - News, novels, academic texts - TOPIK II preparation - Regular conversation practice

docs.title: Free vs Paid
docs.text:
Best Free Resources: - TTMIK (lessons 1-10) - How to Study Korean - Anki - YouTube channels - Library textbooks

Worth Paying For: - TTMIK workbooks - Professional tutor (italki) - Grammar in Use series - Quality textbooks - TOPIK practice materials

The key to success is consistency - daily practice, even 20 minutes, beats sporadic intensive study!

docs.title: Essential Nouns (100 core words)
docs.text: People: 사람, 남자, 여자, 아이, 학생, 선생님, 친구, 가족 Places: 집, 학교, 회사, 병원, 은행, 식당, 카페, 가게 Time: 오늘, 어제, 내일, 지금, 아침, 점심, 저녁, 시간 Things: 책, 펜, 가방, 컴퓨터, 전화, 옷, 음식, 물

docs.title: TOPIK I (Beginner)
docs.text:
• Focus on 500-1000 most common words
  • Daily life vocabulary
  • Basic verbs and adjectives
  • Numbers, time, days

docs.title: TOPIK II Level 3-4 (Intermediate)
docs.text:
• Expand to 2000-3000 words
  • Abstract concepts
  • Connecting words
  • Topic-specific vocabulary

docs.title: TOPIK II Level 5-6 (Advanced)
docs.text:
• Master 5000+ words
  • Specialized vocabulary
  • Sino-Korean words
  • Formal expressions
  • Idiomatic expressions

docs.title: Learning Tips
docs.text:
1. Use spaced repetition - Review regularly
  2. Learn in context - Not just translations
  3. Group by topic - Easier to remember
  4. Practice writing - Reinforce memory
  5. Read authentic materials - See words in use
  6. Make word families - 공부, 공부하다, 공부방

docs.title: For Writing
docs.text:
• 첫째/둘째/셋째 (first/second/third)
  • 예를 들어 (for example)
  • 따라서/그러므로 (therefore)
  • 결론적으로 (in conclusion)
  • ~에 따르면 (according to)

docs.title: For Reading Comprehension
docs.text:
• ~을/를 통해 (through)
  • ~에 대해 (about, regarding)
  • ~으로 인해 (due to)
  • ~에도 불구하고 (despite)
  • ~는 반면에 (whereas)

Building strong vocabulary is key to TOPIK success!

docs.title: 가다 (to go) - Regular Vowel Stem
docs.text: Form Conjugation Example Dictionary 가다 Stem 가- Present (formal) 갑니다 학교에 갑니다 Present (polite) 가요 학교에 가요 Present (casual) 가 학교에 가 Past (formal) 갔습니다 학교에 갔습니다 Past (polite) 갔어요 학교에 갔어요 Past (casual) 갔어 학교에 갔어 Future 갈 거예요 학교에 갈 거예요 Progressive 가고 있어요 학교에 가고 있어요 Want to 가고 싶어요 학교에 가고 싶어요 Can 갈 수 있어요 학교에 갈 수 있어요 Must 가야 해요 학교에 가야 해요 Modifier (present) 가는 가는 사람 Modifier (past) 간 간 사람 Modifier (future) 갈 갈 사람

docs.title: 먹다 (to eat) - Regular Consonant Stem
docs.text: Form Conjugation Example Dictionary 먹다 Stem 먹- Present (formal) 먹습니다 밥을 먹습니다 Present (polite) 먹어요 밥을 먹어요 Present (casual) 먹어 밥 먹어 Past (polite) 먹었어요 밥을 먹었어요 Future 먹을 거예요 밥을 먹을 거예요 Progressive 먹고 있어요 밥을 먹고 있어요 Modifier (present) 먹는 먹는 사람 Modifier (past) 먹은 먹은 음식 Modifier (future) 먹을 먹을 음식

docs.title: 크다 (to be big) - Descriptive Verb
docs.text:
Form Conjugation Example Dictionary 크다 Present (formal) 큽니다 집이 큽니다 Present (polite) 커요 집이 커요 Past (polite) 컸어요 집이 컸어요 Modifier (present) 큰 큰 집 Modifier (past) 컸던/큰 컸던 집

Note: Descriptive verbs don't use -고 있다 (progressive)

docs.title: 공부하다 (to study)
docs.text:
Form Conjugation Present (polite) 공부해요 Past (polite) 공부했어요 Future 공부할 거예요 Progressive 공부하고 있어요 Want 공부하고 싶어요

Pattern: All -하다 verbs conjugate the same way - 사랑하다 → 사랑해요 - 노래하다 → 노래해요

docs.title: Formal Endings (합니다체)
docs.text:
After vowel: -ㅂ니다 

가다 → 갑니다
오다 → 옵니다

After consonant: -습니다 

먹다 → 먹습니다
읽다 → 읽습니다

docs.title: Polite Endings (해요체)
docs.text:
ㅏ, ㅗ stems: -아요 

가다 → 가 + 아요 → 가요

Other vowels: -어요 

먹다 → 먹 + 어요 → 먹어요
서다 → 서 + 어요 → 서요

하다: 해요 

하다 → 하 + 여요 → 해요 (contracted)

docs.title: Past Tense (-았/었-)
docs.text:
ㅏ, ㅗ stems: -았- 

가다 → 갔어요
오다 → 왔어요

Other vowels: -었- 

먹다 → 먹었어요
서다 → 섰어요

하다: 했- 

하다 → 했어요
공부하다 → 공부했어요

docs.title: Future Tense (-(으)ㄹ)
docs.text:
After vowel/ㄹ: -ㄹ 

가다 → 갈 거예요
오다 → 올 거예요
만들다 → 만들 거예요

After consonant: -을 

먹다 → 먹을 거예요
읽다 → 읽을 거예요

docs.title: Modifiers (Relative Clauses)
docs.text:
Present action verbs: -는 

가는 사람 (person who goes)
먹는 음식 (food that I eat)

Descriptive verbs & past: -(으)ㄴ 

큰 집 (big house)
간 사람 (person who went)
작은 방 (small room)

Future: -(으)ㄹ 

갈 곳 (place to go)
먹을 것 (thing to eat)

docs.title: Negation
docs.text:
안 (short form): 

안 가요 (don't go)
안 먹어요 (don't eat)
안 커요 (not big)

-지 않다 (long form): 

가지 않아요 (don't go)
먹지 않아요 (don't eat)
크지 않아요 (not big)

docs.title: Honorifics (-(으)시-)
docs.text:
After vowel: -시- 

가다 → 가시다 → 가세요
오다 → 오시다 → 오세요

After consonant: -으시- 

먹다 → 먹으시다 → 드세요 (irregular)
읽다 → 읽으시다 → 읽으세요

docs.title: Stem Vowel Contractions
docs.text:
Some combinations contract:

아 + 아 = 아 

가 + 아요 → 가요 (not 가아요)

오 + 아 = 와 

오 + 아요 → 와요

우 + 어 = 워 

배우다: 배우 + 어요 → 배워요

이 + 어 = 여 

마시다: 마시 + 어요 → 마셔요

ㅗ + 아 = ㅘ 

보다: 보 + 아요 → 봐요

ㅜ + 어 = ㅝ 

주다: 주 + 어요 → 줘요

하 + 여 = 해 

하다: 하 + 여요 → 해요

docs.title: Quick Conjugation Steps
docs.text:
1. Identify stem (remove -다)
  2. Check stem ending (vowel or consonant)
  3. Check stem vowel (ㅏ/ㅗ or other)
  4. Apply pattern (합니다체, 해요체, etc.)
  5. Check for contractions/irregulars

See irregular verbs page for exceptions!
